HEADLINE: Colombia's Drug Money

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Colombia's decision to include income from illegal drug crops in its official economic figures is yet another step in the creation of the Americas' first narco-state (news article, June 27). Colombian officials claim they must report the value of drug crops so they can provide a clear economic picture to international lending institutions. 
 However, this new step not only legitimates the internal unrest caused by drug lords and narco-guerrillas, but it also ignores that the drug trade does not really "add" to the Colombian economy.
Drug money finances insurgent forces to the tune of almost $100 million a month, damaging the judiciary and the military. The new policy gives the illusion that Colombia is growing when in fact it is being undermined.
 
LORENZO R. CORTES
Alexandria, Va., June 28, 1999
 
The writer is a research assistant at the National Defense Council Foundation. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Reports on Economy Signal Solid Growth

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Manufacturing in the Midwest expanded at a faster pace than forecast in June, and the index of leading economic indicators rose in May, suggesting growth could accelerate in the months ahead.
The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago said yesterday that its monthly index of regional manufacturing rose to 60.0 in June from 57.9 in May. Analysts expected a reading of 57.3. A reading above 50 means manufacturing is expanding, and a reading below 50 signals a contraction. 
 While the Chicago purchasing managers report measures activity only in the Chicago area, investors watch it because it has often foreshadowed the National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index, which measures conditions nationwide. That report will be released today, and most analysts, who had expected the index to drop to 54.3 from 55.2 in May, revised their forecasts after the Chicago number was reported.
The index of leading economic indicators, which is intended to forecast economic growth the next half year, rose three-tenths of a percent in May after falling one-tenth of a percent in April, the Conference Board reported yesterday. The increase matched analysts' estimates.
May's increase in the index was led by an increase in the money supply, widening interest rate spreads and vendor delivery times, which slow when the economy speeds up. Of the 10 components of the index, 9 made a positive contribution. The only negative contribution, a fall in stock prices, "was insignificant," the report said.
The increase in the index was "consistent with the overall solid growth trend in the U.S. economy," said Ryan Brecht, a market analyst at MMS International. "It's not really going to add or subtract anything to the market's knowledge of the economy. It just repeats what we already know."
The current expansion, now in its ninth year, will become the longest ever six months from now in January.

HEADLINE: Coke Expects Sales to Decline 1% to 2%, Mainly in Europe

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Citing the recall of its soft drinks in Europe last month -- the biggest in company history -- the Coca-Cola Company estimated yesterday that its beverage sales fell 1 percent to 2 percent in the second quarter compared with sales in the period a year earlier.
Sales in the company's European division, which includes Belgium, France and other countries where Coke was ordered off store shelves after a contamination scare, are expected to fall 6 percent to 7 percent, the largest drop in any of Coke's six global divisions. 
 "It's a fairly damaging blow that occurred as a result of the recall," said Skip Carpenter, a beverage analyst for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, adding that before the recall began on June 14, "their Continental Europe business was seeing some good momentum in a lot of markets."
Other markets appeared unimpressive, too. In the United States, typically Coke's star performer, sales are expected to be flat.
"Volume trends for the quarter reflect the difficult global economic conditions that remain in many key markets," the company said in a statement. "In addition, during the month of June, the company has experienced a negative impact on sales in several countries within the Greater Europe Group as a result of the recent temporary product withdrawal in Belgium and France."
Coca-Cola did not say how much the sales drop would affect earnings in the second quarter. Profit was already expected to fall, to 41 cents a share from 47 cents a share in the quarter a year earlier, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings.
Coca-Cola has been mired in a bad year, with profit already down for two consecutive quarters. Starting last August, the company's sales declined in many of its biggest markets around the globe, including Germany, Japan and Brazil, largely because of economic downturns. That slowdown has also affected some of its large bottlers, which have posted gloomy results, too. In the United States, a price increase in many stores has caused sales to drop off.
Efforts by Coke to buy additional brands to expand its overseas business have been stymied by regulators in Europe, Mexico and Australia. In addition, fears that Coke's products were contaminated, which arose when hundreds of people in Belgium complained of nausea, dizziness and other symptoms after drinking Coke and Fanta, led to Government-ordered recalls of an estimated 15 million cases of drinks in Belgium, France and Luxembourg. Three factories in Europe were shut until the bans, which went into effect on June 14 and June 15, were lifted on June 23.
On Tuesday, mold was discovered inside bottles of Bonaqua, a mineral water sold by Coke, and that brand was recalled in Poland.
The volume declines were expected by Wall Street, which reacted positively to the news. Shares of Coca-Cola rose 81.25 cents, to $62, on a day when the rest of the market advanced smartly.
The company said it expected its volume in Latin America to be flat or down 1 percent, compared with 12 percent growth in the second quarter of last year. In Africa, which grew 18 percent in the second quarter of last year on a small base, volume is expected to fall 1 percent to 2 percent, the company said. The company's Asian and Middle Eastern business, which grew 7 percent in the second quarter last year, is expected to decline 1 percent to 2 percent.
M. Douglas Ivester, Coca-Cola's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement that "the worst is behind us" and predicted improvement in the second half of the year and next year.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A leading forecaster of ad spending predicts stronger-than-expected gains for this year.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A LEADING forecaster of advertising spending has raised his estimate for 1999 after cutting it earlier because of concerns about the worldwide economic turmoil last fall.
With those qualms virtually vanquished, and amid reports of robust first-quarter ad spending in myriad media, Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at the McCann-Erickson USA unit of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, is raising his predicted gain for 1999. 
 In December, the last time Mr. Coen offered predictions, "we saw signs the economy was questionable," he said yesterday in a presentation at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan, "and we were cautious."
"But 1999 is turning out to be so much stronger than anybody expected," he added. "We have a lot more stimulus than anyone thought possible six months ago."
For good measure, Mr. Coen also increased for a fourth consecutive time his figures for how much marketers spent to advertise in 1998. And taking his first look at 2000, Mr. Coen was bullish, forecasting that ad spending would be stimulated significantly by elections, the Summer Olympics, millennium hoopla and even advisories about Year 2000 computer problems.
Ad spending is carefully monitored because it is considered a reliable way to assess the condition of the overall economy, particularly the propensity of consumers to spend. Mr. Coen's optimism dovetails with other signs that the economy remains robust, such as the announcement yesterday by the Conference Board that its index of leading economic indicators rose three-tenths of a percent in May after a small decline in April.
"The marketplace looks very strong," said Mr. Coen, whose projections are closely watched because he has been tracking advertising and media trends for five decades for McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, now part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
Mr. Coen predicted that marketers would spend a record $213.9 billion this year compared with a revised figure of $201.6 billion for 1998, which represents a 7.5 percent increase from the $187.5 billion spent in 1997.
National ad spending in 1999 is now expected to rise 6.4 percent, to $126.6 billion, compared with Mr. Coen's December estimate of 6 percent. And local ad spending is now expected to grow 5.7 percent, to $87.3 billion, up from his previous forecast of 5 percent.
If Mr. Coen's 1999 forecast is correct, advertising as a percentage of gross domestic product would reach a record 2.39 percent, compared with 2.37 percent in 1998.
In June 1998, when Mr. Coen made his first estimate for 1999 ad spending, he projected an increase of 6 percent. That was trimmed to 5.5 percent in December because of the financial crises in the Asia-Pacific region and Latin America, coupled with global stock market swoons. In his presentation, he revised the figure to a gain of 6.1 percent.
While that gain would be the slowest growth since a 5.2 percent increase in 1993, it would still be notable for a "hammock" year between Olympics and elections.
"We're encouraged by the upside revisions," said Karen R. Ficker, managing director for advertising, publishing and new media at Furman Selz in New York, which becomes ING Barings today.
"Everyone's talking about stabilization in Asia-Pacific now, if not improvement," said Ms. Ficker, who attended the Coen presentation.
In revamping his 1999 figures, Mr. Coen cited first-quarter media spending in several important national ad categories, including airlines, computers, drugs and remedies, movies, resorts and tours, restaurants and telecommunications. He also pointed to sharp gains in categories like banks, brokers and mutual funds, cigarettes and liquor.
All that helped increase ad revenue in the first quarter for cable television networks by 28 percent, newspapers by 12.6 percent, magazines by 7.7 percent and yellow pages by 7.1 percent. In the local realm, there were good first-quarter results for media, including radio, up 15 percent; yellow pages, up 5 percent, and newspaper retail ads, up 4.5 percent.
Turning to ad spending overseas, Mr. Coen predicted an improvement, based on the brightening outlooks for countries like Malaysia, the Philippines and South Korea and continued growth in countries like Poland.
Spending outside the United States should total $212 billion, he said, up 4.1 percent from a revised figure of $203.7 billion for 1998. That spending last year was a decline of 3 percent from $210 billion in 1997 and was the second consecutive decline after three years of gains.
Mr. Coen's worldwide total estimate for 1999, then, is $425.9 billion, up 5.1 percent from his final figure for 1998 of $405.3 billion, which would be the largest growth since 1995. The spending last year represented a gain of 2 percent from $397.5 billion in 1997, the smallest annual increase since 1993.
Mr. Coen's initial worldwide forecast for 1999, made in June 1998, was $440.5 billion, which was lowered to $435.9 billion in December.
And peering forward for the first time at 2000, Mr. Coen offered a "guesstimate" for snappy growth at home of 7.5 percent, to $230 billion, and respectable growth abroad of 5.7 percent, to $224 billion. The total: $454 billion, up 6.6 percent from 1999.
"I see a lot of similarities between 2000 and 1976," Mr. Coen said, when ad spending in the United States was fueled by Bicentennial campaigns as well as Olympic and election ads.
Another analyst who attended Mr. Coen's presentation, Michael J. Russell Jr., said that he agreed with the 7.5 percent increase predicted domestically for next year.
In addition to Year 2000 factors, said Mr. Russell, advertising analyst in New York for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, Madison Avenue will benefit from such new "brand pipelines" as spending to promote prescription drugs to consumers and Internet advertising.
"Internet I.P.O.'s and business plans say 'Give me money to advertise,' " he added. "There was never a time before when that happened."

HEADLINE: Fed Statement on Rates

 BODY:
Following is the statement issued by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to raise short-term rates: 
 The Federal Open Market Committee today voted to raise its target for the Federal funds rate 25 basis points to 5 percent. Last fall the committee reduced interest rates to counter a significant seizing-up of financial markets in the United States. Since then, much of the financial strain has eased, foreign economies have firmed and economic activity in the United States has moved forward at a brisk pace. Accordingly, the full degree of adjustment is judged no longer necessary.
Labor markets have continued to tighten over recent quarters, but strengthening productivity growth has contained inflationary pressures.
Owing to the uncertain resolution of the balance of conflicting forces in the economy going forward, the F.O.M.C has chosen to adopt a directive that includes no predilection about near-term policy action. The committee, nonetheless, recognizes that in the current dynamic environment it must be especially alert to the emergence, or potential emergence, of inflationary forces that could undermine economic growth.

HEADLINE: After 2 Years, Hong Kong Looks More Like China

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Thursday, July 1

 BODY:
This former British colony passed its second year under Chinese rule today, and to a growing number of critics Hong Kong is taking on a disquieting resemblance to its motherland.
As Hong Kong commemorated the handover, raising the local and national flags and unveiling a Reunification Monument next to its futuristic Convention Center, concern is mounting that it is losing its image as an oasis in freewheeling China, one where the rule of law prevails. 
 Although Hong Kong was supposed to be a semiautonomous region within China for 50 years after the handover -- under the Chinese-British agreement known as "one country, two systems" -- recent events suggest that the one country is rapidly subsuming the two systems.
On June 26, Beijing overruled a Hong Kong court on a landmark immigration case, using a legislative mechanism that deeply troubled legal experts but was requested by the territory's leaders.
A few days earlier, the United States Senate had passed a bill that stipulated that Hong Kong be treated like the rest of China in exporting American technology with military applications. The move was in response to a Congressional report on military espionage and China in which Hong Kong was portrayed as a staging ground for smuggling technology.
"If Hong Kong doesn't constantly bang away at the differences between it and China, the rest of the world is going to start treating them the same," said Michael DeGolyer, director of an academic project that surveys attitudes about Hong Kong's return to China. "If that happens, Hong Kong is dead."
That Hong Kong's autonomy should be threatened is no surprise, said academic experts, lawyers and democracy advocates. Before the handover, many people had predicted that no treaty between Britain and China would be a match for the ineluctable march of Chinese sovereignty.
But in the first year after the change, worries that China would meddle were obscured by the Asian financial crisis, which plunged this prosperous enclave into its worst recession since World War II.
China largely stayed out of Hong Kong affairs, leaving the local government to battle rising unemployment, a swooning stock market and currency speculators. Now, though, as the economy begins to recover, worries about Hong Kong's rule of law and autonomy are resurgent.
The reversal by Beijing of the Court of Final Appeal here was its first overt interference in the Hong Kong legal system. The Chinese Government was acting at the behest of the local authorities, who feared that the ruling would open the door to more than one million immigrants from mainland China. But critics said the decision could a set a precedent for Beijing to overturn any unpopular ruling.
"The rule of law is the cornerstone of Hong Kong's success," a democracy advocate, Emily Lau, said. "If we don't have the rule of law, then we're just another Chinese city."
On Wednesday, lawyers protested the reversal in a silent march.
The chairman of the Hong Kong Bar Association, Ronny Tong, said, using a British phrase for a singular case: "I'm an optimist, and I would like to think this is a one-off situation. But the Government keeps giving out mixed signals."
The Hong Kong Justice Secretary, Elsie Leung, has refused to rule out asking Beijing to intervene in future court rulings.
But the No. 2 official, Anson Chan, said on Wednesday that Beijing's action "was an exceptional decision made in exceptional circumstances." Mrs. Chan, who had just returned from a trip to the United States and Canada, said officials there had expressed doubts about Hong Kong. Among the skeptics was Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California, who led the committee that investigated accusations that China had acquired military secrets from the United States.
In a meeting with Mrs. Chan, Mr. Cox said he was concerned that China could divert technology from Hong Kong by smuggling it across the border on trucks that belonged to the Chinese Army, which has maintained a garrison in Hong Kong since the change in government.
Mrs. Chan said Mr. Cox had accepted her invitation to visit Hong Kong to inspect its customs procedures. But she conceded that he was not alone in harboring doubts about the separation between Hong Kong and China.
Hong Kong has not been helped by a recent Chinese Government decision to bar United States military planes from landing here. That extends a ban imposed on American warships. Experts said China was sending a chilly message in the aftermath of the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade.
Although China is entitled to take such action, analysts said it simply reinforces the perception that Hong Kong -- two years later -- is in danger of becoming an afterthought rather than an exception.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
China in No Hurry to Reopen Talks on Joining Trade Group

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 30

 BODY:
In public statements and private signals, China has indicated that it will not resume talks with the United States any time soon over its proposed entry into the World Trade Organization.
"The talks are certainly moribund," said the departing American Ambassador, James Sasser, in an interview in Beijing today, his last day on the job. 
 "But I wouldn't say it's reached the stage of a total cadaver," said Mr. Sasser, who has met in recent days with the top Chinese leaders, and predicted that relations would improve this fall. At an Asia-Pacific economic meeting this week in New Zealand, the deputy United States trade representative, Richard Fisher, said the United States was ready to restart the talks and that "the ball's in China's court."
But a top Chinese trade official at the same meeting, Long Yongtu, responded today that China would not enter negotiations until it received a "convincing explanation" for the deadly bombing in May of its Embassy in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.
Earlier in June, a senior American diplomat came to Beijing to offer a detailed description of what went wrong in the air attack, which killed three Chinese. But China rejected the explanation as implausible.
So the condition laid out by Mr. Long seems to have put the trade negotiations on ice for now -- even though the Chinese have said for years that rapid entry into the world body, which sets rules for trade and market access, was a priority.
The two countries have not held talks on China's entry into the trade organization since April, when Prime Minister Zhu Rongji visited Washington and offered many of the market-opening measures demanded by the West. Fearing Congressional opposition, President Clinton did not conclude a deal at the time.
Talks had been expected to resume within weeks, and both sides had said they hoped to reach agreement this year. Then the embassy bombing chilled relations. But China said it wanted to continue normal economic ties, and the Americans have waited ever since for an invitation to resume discussions.
Mr. Zhu, an advocate of entry into the World Trade Organization, has been subjected to growing criticism by ministries and industries that feel they would be harmed by a rapid opening of markets.
For status as well as economics, China has for years said it wanted to enter the trade group, and charged that Western countries were imposing unduly strict conditions for entry.
Today, Mr. Long reiterated China's intention to join. But his political condition for talks, along with other recent signals here, suggests that the Chinese Government may be more divided than in the past over rapid entry -- perhaps even preferring to put off talks while blaming American intransigence.
"I think they've decided it's no big deal for them right now," Mr. Sasser said today.
Mr. Sasser, a former Democratic Senator from Tennessee, is moving to Washington, where, he said, he hopes he can help the Presidential bid of his old friend Al Gore. President Clinton has selected retired Admiral Joseph W. Prueher, former Commander of Pacific Forces, as the next Ambassador, but his nomination is subject to Senate confirmation.

HEADLINE: The Fed Makes a Minimal Move

 BODY:
William McChesney Martin Jr., the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board during the great economic expansion of the 1950's and 1960's, once said that the role of the Fed was "to take away the punch bowl just when the party gets going."
Alan Greenspan, the current Fed chairman, yesterday served notice that he does not want to spoil the fun. While the Fed did raise an important interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point, as had been widely expected, it also said its policy was now neutral, rather than biased in favor of a further increase. Wall Street celebrated by sending the Dow Jones industrial average up 200 points in the first 15 minutes after the Fed announcement. Mr. Greenspan and his colleagues seem to be betting that the economy will cool down without much action by the central bank. 
 The Fed has been expecting the American economy to slow for the past three years, but the willingness of consumers to spend rather than save has kept the economy roaring ahead. Now, with the manufacturing sector strengthening as overseas economies rebound, signs of inflation have appeared, as Mr. Greenspan noted in testimony before the Joint Economic Committee two weeks ago.
The bond market had expected the Fed to take stronger action yesterday -- or at least not signal that it would probably forgo another rate increase -- and the yield on long-term government bonds slipped below 6 percent after the announcement. But that rate is up from 4.8 percent late last year, a fact that has pushed mortgage interest rates up and slightly slowed the strong housing market.
Even with rates rising, however, consumer confidence has climbed to a 30-year high. That suggests that neither the economy nor consumer spending is likely to slow soon. If the American economy continues to grow at the recent rate of above 4 percent, there are substantial risks that inflation will accelerate and that, with the record trade deficit continuing to expand, the dollar will eventually come under heavy pressure.
Those risks will be intensified if the White House and Congress choose to ease fiscal policy now, either through large new spending programs or by a big tax decrease. Should that happen, Mr. Greenspan may have no choice but to push interest rates up again later this year.

HEADLINE: Banks Raise Prime Rates

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Bank of America Corporation, the biggest United States bank; the No. 2 Chase Manhattan Corporation; the Bank One Corporation, and Keycorp raised their prime rates to 8 percent from 7.75 percent yesterday after the Federal Reserve increased interest rates for the first time since March 1997.
Other banks are expected to do the same. The Fed raised the target overnight-bank lending rate by a quarter point, to 5 percent. to slow inflation by damping economic growth. 
 The prime rate, traditionally the rate at which banks lend money to their best customers, is a benchmark interest rate for bank loans to consumers. The rate increases announced by banks yesterday are effective today.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Late-Season Spurt Helps Shares in Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Statistically, the spring quarter was another banner period for stocks, as the main gauges all climbed between 5 and 12 percent, shattering records along the way.
But the gains, capped by yesterday's surge after the Federal Reserve chose the mildest of expected options on monetary policy, raising rates a quarter of a percentage point, masked unusual market turmoil. 
 The Nasdaq market, where high-technology issues dominate, tumbled below its March 31 level each of the three months in the second quarter before ending at a new peak.
Its gyrations included gut-wrenching declines in many of the most prominent Internet stocks and coincided with a steady rise in interest rates that pushed yields up one-half to three-quarters of a percentage point across the board.
But while many of these onetime highfliers remained far below their peaks -- Amazon.com, for example, skidded to $125.125 from $172.1875 -- the Nasdaq market as a whole finished the quarter ahead 9.1 percent, with more than half of this gain in the final three days.
"The main theme was the rebound in technology," said Robert J. Froehlich, vice chairman of Kemper Funds, noting that stocks trading at high multiples of annual earnings are particularly vulnerable to rising interest rates. "That should be bad news for tech, but these things rallied right in the face of it."
Earlier in the quarter, however, rising rates took a heavy toll on both established growth stocks and more speculative ones, as many investors shifted money into stocks of companies tied to the economic cycle. Their reasoning was that the economy was growing so fast that these laggards might finally get some leverage to raise product prices.
"There was this turbocharged rotation out of the high price-earnings growth stocks and into the lagging cyclicals," said Charles J. Pradilla, chief investment strategist at S. G. Cowen Securities.
Pfizer, for example, skidded from a high of $150.125 in mid-April, to $95.125 in mid-June, while Alcoa rallied from a low of $40.75 in early April, to as high as $67.9375 in mid-June. The differential between the drug company's percentage loss and the aluminum company's percentage gain was more than 100 percent, a stunning gap that Mr. Pradilla said was no doubt far greater than any plausible change in economic conditions. By the end of the quarter Pfizer was up to $109 and Alcoa down to $61.875.
Indeed, as the quarter ended many cyclicals were fading, perhaps having benefited more from a lack of other places to put money that had come out of growth stocks than from a conviction that pricing-power inflation might be on its way. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which is skewed toward big growth companies, finished the quarter with a 6.7 percent gain, surpassing its 4.6 percent first-quarter gain. This means that if the second half of the year is as good as the first half, this index, so widely used as a benchmark, will once again confound forecasters and advance more than 20 percent for a fifth straight year.
The Dow Jones industrial average posted the best performance of the three major gauges, rising 12.1 percent but failing by the narrowest of margins, one-tenth of 1 percent, to regain enough ground to end the quarter above its record, 11,107.19 set on May 13.
Significant amounts of the money that was switched into cyclicals in the quarter went into smaller-company shares, with some value-oriented portfolio managers declaring that this long-neglected sector might finally be getting its due. Indeed, the Russell 2000, the most widely cited index for this group, gained a hefty 15.1 percent in the quarter.
But there was a growing view as the quarter ended that the Federal Reserve would one way or another make sure that the economy's 4 percent growth rate was throttled back. A slowing economy is a poor climate for small companies.
Besides the Internet casualties in the quarter -- America Online, for example, ended 35 percent lower than its April 6 peak of $175.50 -- the drug group took a heavy hit.
McKesson-HBOC slumped 52.3 percent; Pfizer, 24.4 percent; Amgen, 20 percent; Eli Lilly, 19.9 percent, and Merck, 10.8 percent as talks heated on proposals that could involve Federal price controls on prescriptions.
The top winners in the S.& P. 500 had the following gains in the quarter: National Semiconductor, 168.5 percent; Nalco Chemical, 94.8 percent; Case, 92.1 percent; Millipore, 62.7 percent; Raychem, 60.7 percent, and Cummins Engine, 60.5 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
As Rates Rose, Underwriting Dipped in the Second Quarter

BYLINE: By SHOLNN FREEMAN 

 BODY:
Wall Street's core business -- the underwriting of stocks and bonds -- slowed slightly in the second quarter as market interest rates rose.
Securities firms and banks issued $553.1 billion of bonds and stocks, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data, a drop of nearly 11 percent from $620 billion in the second quarter of 1998. It was also down 9 percent from the first quarter of this year. The firms' performances were particulary weak in June, at $157 billion in new issues, the smallest monthly total so far this year. 
 Uncertainty about the outlook for interest rates knocked a chunk out of the debt business. Over all, the volume of corporate debt issued fell 11 percent, to $495.3 billion, in the quarter from a year earlier. The amount of new high-yield securities, the low-rated issues sometimes referred to as junk, fell 42 percent.
For the first half of the year, only Merrill Lynch & Company and Salomon Smith Barney had more than $100 billion in debt underwriting volume, while four firms did so last year. Morgan Stanley's debt underwriting fell 28 percent from a year ago, while that of Goldman, Sachs dropped by about 32 percent in the first half.
The much-anticipated decision yesterday by the Federal Reserve to raise a key short-term interest rate by one-quarter of a percentage point could have helped clear the air.
"Investors became cautious as interest rate fears took over the market, especially by the last month of the second quarter," said Ernesto Cruz, head of equity capital markets at Credit Suisse First Boston. "With the completion of the Fed's action we might see some stability in interest rates and recovery in new issues."
Merrill Lynch continued to lead securities firms in total underwriting volume. In the second quarter of the year the firm handled about 14 percent of the stock and bond volume. Salomon Smith Barney placed second, followed by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Goldman, Sachs. Credit Suisse First Boston knocked off Lehman Brothers to finish in the top five.
The quarterly rankings of securities firms, known as league tables, are closely watched within the industry as an indicator of which banks and brokerage houses are strongest. Goldman, Sachs led Merrill Lynch by one key measure, underwriting fees, in large part because of its lucrative business with hot Internet stocks. In the first half of the year, Goldman, Sachs saw a 22 percent gain in fees to $900 million. The other top firms reported sharp declines in fees. Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, which finished second and third respectively, saw fees drop by more than 25 percent in the first six months of the year.
In the coveted role of underwriting initial public offerings of stock, Goldman dominated in the most recent quarter. It underwrote $5.6 billion worth of new issues for 35 percent of the total market. Goldman brought public Etoys and TheStreet.com, among others. But its biggest issue was the $3.7 billion public offering of Goldman itself. Without its own issue, Goldman would have edged out Morgan Stanley, which handled $1.8 billion in initial stock offerings, by just $200 million in the latest quarter. Morgan Stanley had about a 12 percent market share.
Goldman came close to doubling its market share in the much bigger field of underwriting stock offerings by companies that are already public. In all, the industry underwrote $56 billion in the latest quarter, $3 billion less than a year earlier, in what are called secondary equity offerings. After Goldman came Morgan Stanley, which took second place away from Merrill Lynch. Salomon Smith Barney and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette completed the top five.
Merger and acquisition activity fell by 19 percent, to $552 billion in the second quarter, from $681 billion a year ago, based on the value of the announced deals. Goldman won the race, but lost market share, barely edging out Merrill Lynch. Goldman handled $193 billion in United States deals, for a 34.9 percent share, besting Merrill by a tenth of one percent.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE UNITED NATIONS;
Annan Urges Swift Action On Assistance To Kosovo

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 30

 BODY:
Warned today that urgent action was needed to reintegrate refugees flooding back into Kosovo, United Nations members were cajoled or shamed into pledging additional money and personnel to help secure and assist a democratic, multiethnic Kosovo.
By the end of the conference, organized by Secretary General Kofi Annan, 18 self-declared "Friends of Kosovo" had almost doubled their contributions to what will be an armed international police force in the Serbian province -- increasing the promised forces from 1,000 to 1,938. That, however, is still about 1,000 short of the 3,110 police officers that the United Nations estimates are needed to stop revenge killings and looting and to restore order. 
 At the same time, members of the United Nations failed to agree on the nature and scope of assistance for Yugoslavia as long as Slobodan Milosevic remains President.
Pledges of additional support came from the foreign ministers and other senior officials who attended the conference, the first review of international relief and rehabilitation efforts since June 10, when the Security Council approved a resolution authorizing the United Nations to run a civilian administration in Kosovo alongside the NATO-led military force. While that force is supposed to have 50,000 troops, less than half have been deployed.
Mr. Annan organized the conference largely to encourage donors to increase their contributions. "These are pledges, and we cannot deploy and distribute what we do not have," Mr. Annan told the conference.
Mr. Annan was unable today to name the United Nations chief representative to Kosovo. According to senior United Nations officials, he had planned to appoint Martti Ahtisaari, the Finnish President, but Mr. Ahtisaari was said to have withdrawn after France demanded that he resign as President in order to devote himself full time to the post.
France has its own candidate: Bernard Kouchner, its Health Minister, whom Mr. Annan named today as one of four candidates he is considering. The others are Paddy Ashdown, Britain's retiring Liberal Party leader; Emma Bonino, an Italian who heads the European Commission for Humanitarian Affairs, and Jan Pronk, the Dutch Housing and Environmental Minister.
Several foreign ministers and senior diplomats at the four-hour, closed-door conference praised the United Nations effort on the ground, especially the performance of Sergio Vieira de Mello, the United Nations Undersecretary General whom Mr. Annan assigned as temporary chief representative until the post is filled.
While some diplomats had urged Mr. Annan to give the post to Mr. de Mello, a Brazilian, the Europeans, who are financing most of the Balkans reconstruction, insist that a European get the job.
At a news conference after the meeting, Mr. Annan said the ministers had disagreed over what constituted "humanitarian" assistance and whether Serbia should receive it.
A senior Administration official said that Japan and Britain, the Netherlands and other Europeans wanted to insure that Belgrade got no reconstruction or other assistance as long as its leader is Mr. Milosevic, who has been indicted on war-crimes charges. But Russia and China pushed for a broad definition, insisting that because Kosovo is part of the former republic of Yugoslavia, Serbia should get aid.
"Some ministers sounded more like 'friends of Serbia' than "friends of Kosovo," a senior American official said.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright reiterated Washington's stance that Serbia should receive no help that would "bolster the position of the current regime in Belgrade."
But Mr. Annan said that unless Serbia received minimum assistance -- such as money to rebuild bridges over the Danube, and electrical and water plants that NATO jets destroyed -- neither Kosovo nor the Balkans would recover. "It is pointless to take in loads and loads of medicine if people are taking in dirty water and then get sick," he said.
Privately, the Americans have said they would not oppose aid to, say, dredge the Danube of debris, since such obstacles block navigation that is critical to the economic recovery of Belgrade's neighbors. But they oppose aid that might benefit Mr. Milosevic.
Ms. Albright said today that the United States would send 550 American police officers and trainers to Kosovo. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Stockand Bond Markets Both Like What They Hear From the Fed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock and bond markets both rallied yesterday after investors got a surprise they liked from the Federal Reserve Board. The central bank signaled that a quarter percentage point increase in its short-term interest rate target could be enough to keep inflation in check.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 210 points within 13 minutes after the Fed's announcement at 2:15 P.M. and finished the day at 10,970.80, up 155.45 points, or 1.44 percent. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 21.26 points, or 1.57 percent, to a new high of 1,372.71. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 44.01 points, or 1.67 percent, to a new high of 2,686.12. The S.&.P.'s previous high was in May and the Nasdaq's in late April, both just before the Fed indicated, after its May policy meeting, that a rate increase was in the offing.
In the bond market, the price of the 30-year bond jumped 1 9/32, to 90 6/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.96 percent, from 6.06 percent on Tuesday. The yield on the two-year note, which is more sensitive to Fed interest rate moves, dropped to 5.52 percent from 5.68 percent.
The Fed announcement had a calming effect on the more vulnerable emerging markets, especially in Latin America. The Bovespa index in Brazil jumped more than 300 points after the news, to close up 2.2 percent. More important, interest rates on emerging-market bonds dropped sharply in comparison with rates on United States Treasury securities.
Fed policy makers, meeting in Washington, announced that they had raised their target for the Federal funds rate, which is the interest on overnight loans between banks, to 5 percent from 4.75 percent. That move was expected and led several major banks to raise their prime lending rates a quarter-point, to 8 percent.
At the same time, the Fed surprised investors by shifting its interest rate outlook. Rather than leaning toward higher interest rates, as they were going into yesterday's meeting, policy makers are now neutral.
But some analysts argued that the Fed's shift did not mean there would not be another rate increase. That will depend on how fast the economy continues to grow and how tame inflation remains.
The Conference Board reported on Tuesday that its consumer confidence index in June rose to its highest level in more than 30 years, a fact that could keep consumers spending. The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago reported that its factory index had jumped again in June, showing a growing manufacturing revival in the Chicago region.
A recent rally in copper prices, which reached a 1999 high of 75.95 cents a pound yesterday, could reflect a worldwide economic rebound and put upward pressure on inflation. Also yesterday, the price of oil for August delivery broke out of an eight-week trading range, rising to a 1999 high of $19.29 a barrel.
More indications on economic growth will come today, with the release by National Association of Purchasing Management of its manufacturing index for the entire nation, and on Friday with the employment data for June.
In addition, the rally in market interest rates since last week could keep key rates -- like those for mortgages -- from rising much more, a fact that would make a significant slowdown in growth less likely. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note yesterday was 5.78 percent, a quarter-point below its recent high and less than a quarter-point above where it was when the Fed gave its May signal of an interest rate increase.
"I think a little bit of this celebration is unwarranted," said Thomas McManus, the equity strategist at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities.
Neil M. Soss, chief United States economist at Credit Suisse First Boston, thinks another rate increase is likely in August, although the odds have diminished. But he said that "from the market's point of view, this is pretty much an all-clear." That, he said, is because the news yesterday reassured investors that the Fed, at worst, would push interest rates only modestly higher.
The Dow, which was down as much as 83 points early in the day, was led higher by J. P. Morgan, I.B.M. and General Electric, all three of which rallied after the Fed announcement. The Nasdaq, which was down 21 points, was powered by Microsoft, Cisco Systems and Yahoo.
The Fed decision also appeared to help stocks of smaller companies, which were undervalued after years of lackluster performance but have rallied sharply since March as investors moved from growth stocks. The Russell index of 2,000 smaller company stocks rose 3.6 points, to a 1999 high of 457.68. Since March 23, the Russell index is up 19.4 percent, matching the Dow's performance for the entire year. But the index is still below its high of 491.41 in April 1998.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Clinton Says He's Not Slowing Down

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, June 30

 BODY:
Two days ago, a local politician introducing President Clinton at a fund-raising luncheon in Westport, Conn., said Mr. Clinton was entitled to a "victory lap" of public valedictories as he completed his final 18 months in office.
Mr. Clinton bristled at his host's well-meaning remarks. 
 "I don't feel I'm on a victory lap or a final lap," Mr. Clinton told the crowd of contributors, a smile disguising his impatience with those ready to write him off. "They're beginning to talk to me as if I'm -- there is a sort of ring of eulogy about all of this. As far as I can tell, I'm reasonably healthy. I still show up."
Say this about Bill Clinton: He will not go gentle into political oblivion.
In the past six days, he has given a major domestic policy speech laying out his priorities for the next year, conducted a 75-minute endurance test of a news conference and announced that his budget team had found an additional trillion dollars in Federal surpluses over the next 15 years.
He also unveiled the most sweeping set of proposals for remaking Medicare in the program's 34-year history, which he pitched to senior citizens here today.
Mr. Clinton has called on Republicans in Congress to set aside partisanship and embark with him on a "season of progress" on Medicare and Social Security, education, gun control, health care and campaign financing.
Mr. Clinton said the public was pleading for at least a temporary truce in the partisan bickering and rancor that have characterized his six and a half years in office.
Never mind that Mr. Clinton and the Democrats are at least as responsible as the Republicans for the capital's polarization. Mr. Clinton now wants progress on his agenda -- and his legacy -- and says he is willing to compromise on taxes in order to get it.
He swears that he is serious about wanting to get things done before Presidential politics and Congressional campaigns swallow Washington's energy. Responding to Republicans who doubt his sincerity -- and even some in his own party who would prefer to run their campaigns against a do-nothing Republican Congress -- Mr. Clinton said there was a narrow window for bipartisan agreement on critical national issues.
On Friday, Mr. Clinton told a group of students at Georgetown University: "Now, some other people here really believe that because the Presidential season has already started, the battle for Congress has already started, even though it's a year and however many months away, that the best politics is just to run out the clock and wait until the next election and hope that the country is doing so well and we enjoy the lazy days of summer so much, nobody will notice. I don't agree with that, either."
Mr. Clinton's speech at the White House on Tuesday detailing his Medicare proposal was similarly suffused with the spirit of sweet reason. He hailed the participation of several Republican leaders, saying: "Their presence here today indicates that we can all raise concerns about each other's ideas without raising our voices. It augurs well for this announcement today and for the welfare of our Republic."
But inside that velvet glove of accommodation was the President's mailed fist of partisan aggression. Mr. Clinton said the nation's leaders had not only an opportunity but also an "obligation" to remodel Medicare for the onslaught of the baby boom generation early in the next century.
The clear message is that if Mr. Clinton's health-care plan is rejected or weakened, it will be the fault of the parsimonious Republicans who prefer to give the nation's economic bounty to the wealthy, in the form of cuts in capitals gains and estate taxes, rather than to the deserving elderly.
Mr. Clinton's health and education plans follow a familiar pattern: he proposes generous new programs that poll well with the public and challenges Republicans to act on them.
So, too, with Medicare. Polls show that a subsidized prescription drug benefit is extremely popular with the public and the new budget surplus projections afford Mr. Clinton the luxury of proposing it.
Mr. Clinton was warmly received here today when he pitched his Medicare proposal to an audience of several hundred older people at the Chicago Cultural Center.
One member of the audience, Frances Krause, 79, of Chicago, expressed hope that the President could persuade Congress to pass his Medicare proposal, or at least the prescription drug part of it. But Mrs. Krause, a registered Republican who often splits her votes between the two parties, said Republicans might try to block the plan to prevent Mr. Clinton from getting credit for it.
"Whatever he's for, they're against," she said.

HEADLINE: Housing and Medicaid Laws Lapse as Budget Talks Hit Wall

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 30

 BODY:
State budget talks collapsed today, as New York reached the unfortunate milestone of going three months without a budget, and lawmakers failed to extend laws that protect loft tenants, lower New York City property taxes and trim Medicaid costs.
"The budget process in this state is continuing to fail," said Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader. Recalling that in 1997 New York's budget was passed on Aug. 4, 126 days late, a modern record for any state, he added, "What I see is probably us setting another record for a late budget." 
 Mr. Bruno and the Democratic Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, said they were very close to agreement this week on the outlines of a $73.8 billion budget that would have allowed the two houses to convene conference committees to work out the final details. But Gov. George E. Pataki stepped in today and, Mr. Silver said, "indicated very strongly that he would not approve where we were."
While the leaders said they would continue to meet, no sessions are scheduled. Members of both houses have been sent home until July 12, though they could be summoned sooner. The budget, which was supposed to be in place by the April 1 start of the fiscal year, will be 92 days overdue on Thursday, the third-latest in state history.
The main sticking point, the three leaders said, was Medicaid spending. Mr. Pataki, a Republican, insists on keeping the Medicaid cuts that were enacted in 1995 and 1996, and has called for new cuts worth about $800 million a year. Both houses of the Legislature have rejected the new cuts, and the Assembly Democrats want to reverse some of the old ones.
At midnight tonight, some of the 1995 and 1996 cuts will lapse, forcing state and local governments to shoulder higher hospital and nursing home costs for at least three months. That will cost the state $82 million, and New York City and counties around the state $50 million, for the quarter, and local officials have heavily lobbied state lawmakers not to let the measures lapse.
Also at midnight, the law governing about 4,000 loft units, nearly all of them in Manhattan, will expire, and those lofts will effectively become illegal dwellings, theoretically exposing their residents to eviction. At the same time, a $166 million-a-year tax break for co-op and condominium owners in New York City will also lapse.
However, lawmakers predict that both problems will be fixed retroactively without any damage done, though the standoff has unnerved thousands of city residents.
Tonight's deadlines were seen by officials in both parties as factors that could prod painfully slow budget talks, because Mr. Silver wanted to extend the loft law, the Governor wanted to preserve the existing Medicaid cuts, and both men favored keeping the city tax break. Instead, the looming expirations produced a stare-down between the Governor and the Speaker, whose caustic relationship has reached new lows this year. In the end, neither man blinked.
As it became clear today that the deadlines would pass without any action, the leaders called news conferences to take shots at each other. Mr. Pataki accused Mr. Silver of trying "to give all things to all people," trying to spend so much that it would create a fiscal crisis, and then talking "about creating jobs and improving the economy."
He added, "I think it's tragic that Speaker Silver and the leadership of the Democratic Assembly refuse to pass a continuation of the Medicaid cost containment."
The Speaker, in turn, said of the Governor, "The lack of leadership has set us back." He noted that at a time when the state has a $2 billion surplus, Mr. Pataki has proposed trimming Medicaid, reducing aid to poor college students and backing away from the state's 1997 commitment to pay for prekindergarten classes. "We will not balance the budget on the backs of those 4-year-olds," Mr. Silver said.
When asked who was to blame for the latest breakdown, Mr. Bruno sighed and said, "When the system is as dysfunctional as ours is, it's hard to point a finger as to who's at fault."
Still, in intensive talks over the last three weeks, the three leaders have made considerable progress toward a budget, with Mr. Silver greatly reducing his spending demands, and Mr. Pataki agreeing to spend significantly more than outlined in his January proposal. Lawmakers in both parties say they are near agreement on a proposal very much like the Senate Republicans', for a $73.8 billion budget, $1.1 billion above the Governor's.
Just as important, the Governor pledged that if the overall numbers were in that range, he would not veto broad portions of the budget, as he did last year. But he did not include Medicaid in that promise.
Most state officials believe that in the end, the 1995 and 1996 cuts will be restored, and the proposed new cuts will not take effect, but reaching that point has proved difficult. Local government officials are blaming Mr. Silver for raising their costs, because the Senate voted to renew the old cuts, while Mr. Pataki is under attack from the hospital workers' union for his proposed cuts.
Mr. Silver said today that the local governments will not really lose $50 million through the expiration of the Medicaid cuts. Some of the higher payments, he said, will go to city- and county-owned hospitals and nursing homes, and will trigger higher Federal matching payments.
Lawmakers in both parties predict that the loft law and the co-op and condominium tax break will be extended, and that in any case, it would take weeks or months for a landlord to evict someone.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: FED RAISES A RATE, BUT THEN SUGGESTS THAT MAY SUFFICE

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve nudged its benchmark interest rate up by a quarter of a percentage point today but said there was no clear case for another rate increase to keep inflation at bay.
The increase in the overnight lending rate between banks, known as the Federal funds target rate, had been expected by economists and investors for weeks. The rise, to 5 percent from 4.75 percent, came after a series of three quarter-point rate reductions made by the central bank last fall during the height of the global financial crisis. 
 But many analysts had expected the Federal Reserve to raise rates by another quarter-point at its next meeting in August, and they were caught off guard by the central bank's suggestion today that there was no consensus on the need for another increase to slow the economy's growth.
That suggestion, in the form of a shift to a neutral stance from a stance toward higher rates, was taken as a green light by investors on Wall Street, who rapidly bid up stock and bond prices in the belief that higher rates were less likely this summer.
The Dow Jones industrial average surged 210 points in the 13 minutes after the central bank's announcement and finished up 155.45 points, to 10,970.80. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell below 6 percent, closing at 5.96 percent. Page C1.
Economists warned that investors might have overreacted and said that the Fed had not ruled out the possibility of another rate increase as soon as August if the economy did not show clear signs of cooling. In fact, a continued rise in stock prices could offset the slowing effect of today's increase and could prompt the Fed to raise rates even more.
The central bank left unchanged, at 4.5 percent, its discount rate on loans to banks. Its quarter-point increase in the Federal funds rate could lead to an increase in loan rates for businesses and consumer credit like auto and home-equity loans. Many large banks raised their prime lending rates to 8 percent from 7.75 percent after the Fed completed its two-day policy meeting this afternoon.
But interest rates that are set directly or indirectly in the financial markets, like those on mortgages and corporate bonds, will depend on whether investors think the likelihood of further rate increases has been diminished and that inflation is no threat.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has warned over the last several months that although there is almost no inflation, there is an increasing risk that continued robust growth could push wages and then prices into an upward spiral.
Market interest rates had been moving higher over the last several months in anticipation of a rate increase by the Federal Reserve, helping to cool off rate-sensitive sectors of the economy like housing. But economic indicators have given mixed signals in recent weeks about the prospects for slowing, and analysts said the Fed's shift to a neutral stance today was intended to say that the central bank would wait for more data before deciding how to proceed rather than that it was finished tightening monetary policy for the year.
"They wanted to signal to the market that they haven't prejudged the next move," said William Dudley of Goldman, Sachs. "In the end the decision is going to be dependent on the economic environment."
But some analysts said they now expected the Fed to tighten policy only when it had tangible evidence of brewing inflationary pressures, not just an expectation of them.
In explaining its decision, the Federal Reserve's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee remained open to what has become known as the "new age" economic paradigm: that huge investments in computers and other technology have made businesses so much more efficient that the economy can run at much higher levels than in the past, and at lower rates of unemployment, without generating inflation.
"Labor markets have continued to tighten over recent quarters, but strengthening productivity growth has contained inflationary pressures," the committee said. "Owing to the uncertain resolution of the balance of conflicting forces in the economy going forward, the F.O.M.C. has chosen to adopt a directive that includes no predilection about near-term policy action."
The statement went on, however, to emphasize that the Fed's tolerance for strong growth and low unemployment has its limits.
"The committee nonetheless recognizes that in the current dynamic environment, it must be especially alert to the emergence, or potential emergence, of inflationary forces that might undermine growth," the statement said.
Since the Fed cut rates three times last fall, the economy has grown, and the financial crisis that started in Asia and spread around the world has abated. The central bank justified the rate increase today in those terms, saying "the full degree" of last fall's rate reductions is "no longer necessary" to keep financial markets well oiled and the economy in the United States on an even keel.
If history is any guide, the shift to a neutral policy stance, or bias, is no guarantee that the Federal Reserve will not raise rates when it next meets on Aug. 24. The central bank has traditionally moved back to a neutral bias after raising rates even when another rate increase seemed likely. It maintained a neutral stance in 1994, for example, even as it was doubling the Federal funds rate to 6 percent from 3 percent.
What is different this time around is that the Fed is disclosing its policy bias publicly after each meeting. In 1994, and until earlier this year, it kept the bias a secret until after the subsequent policy meeting, meaning that the central bank was not using it to signal its intentions to the markets.
Whatever the Fed's intentions, the market's response today was to send stock prices higher, making consumers feel that much wealthier and willing to spend, and to bring down bond yields, providing a kick to the economy that could well offset whatever slowing effect the increase in official short-term rates accomplishes.
"In the process of making this announcement, the Fed has greatly reduced the odds that the economy is going to slow down," said Paul L. Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "The fear of Greenspan has been removed from the financial markets. That means the restrictiveness on the economy that had been put in place based on the expectation of higher rates has been removed."
Investors could reassess their initial reaction in coming days, as they often do when it comes to the Fed's hints about policy. But they are most likely to take their cue from key indicators of growth and inflation in coming weeks, starting with job creation and the unemployment rate for June on Friday.
Still, an array of politicians and business executives who had been pressing Mr. Greenspan to show restraint in slowing the economy given the absence of inflation took heart from the Fed's signals today.
"Given the dearth of inflation and strong but steady growth, today's decision was, in my judgment, an error, but a minor one," said Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, which has long argued that the economy's potential for noninflationary growth is much higher than the Fed recognizes.
Robert B. Reich, the former Labor Secretary in the Clinton Administration, said the Fed had "exercised restraint" in its rate increase but said the central bank had yet to recognize that it should not sacrifice growth and jobs to fighting inflation that does not yet exist.
"The metaphor suggesting that a little inflation is like the genie out of the bottle is simply wrong," Mr. Reich said. "We know empirically that inflation can be stopped. More to the point, the lag between when the Fed acts and the response in the economy is actually very small, because financial markets are extraordinarily efficient and respond very quickly."

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Hard Hearts Were Softened By a Boy's Tale

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
NOW that all of us supposedly savvy New Yorkers have been conned by a 13-year-old Honduran who speaks no English, what is there to say to him? Only a simple, heartfelt message:
Bienvenido a Nueva York! Nuestra casa es tu casa! 
 No one belongs in this city more than Edwin Daniel Sabillon, the teen-ager who arrived telling of an epic journey from Honduras. Those details happen not to be true, but his is still a quintessential New York success story.
Edwin got off the bus Sunday afternoon with $24 and a bag of cookies. By Tuesday, without benefit of a single phone call from Howard Rubenstein, his trip was making front-page news: "Incredible Journey," one headline aptly put it. The Mayor and the Police Commissioner were attending to his needs; literary agents were wondering if the book and movie rights would command six or seven figures.
Without a single pitch meeting, Edwin devised an irresistible plot: village boy loses family in hurricane, journeys across continent, wanders big city looking for dad. "Wizard of Oz" meets "Huckleberry Finn" meets "Home Alone II."
Now the story needs a little adjustment, but it still has commercial potential. It's a variation of "The Music Man." This time, instead of the slicker going to the provinces to hustle the bumpkins, the bumpkin comes to the city, but the result is the same: the slickers are seduced by the bumpkins.
It is a reasonably happy ending, partly because Edwin now stands to get help for the genuine troubles in his life, partly because his tale is a useful reminder that New Yorkers can be the world's biggest saps. While putting on a tough front, we're prone to falling for a tale like Edwin's because it touches our hidden fears.
The story of a naif lost thousands of miles from home resonated with the many people here -- half the population -- who came from somewhere else. Far from the safety net of families, New Yorkers competing for scarce jobs and paying exorbitant rents could play out through Edwin their own worst-case scenarios: one or two calamities, they imagine, and they too could be wandering the mean streets, impoverished and homeless.
Journalists have always worked hard to satisfy the appetites of tender-hearted New Yorkers, but it is not easy to maintain the production of newsworthy pathos. The facts all too often get in the way, as I discovered when I was assigned to the homeless beat nearly a decade ago.
The beat had plenty of grim stories, but the victims were generally not the sort of victim that readers identify with: a sober, industrious person in desperate shape because of bad breaks and society's indifference. The homeless men I met seemed afflicted mainly by drugs, alcohol and mental illness. They didn't spend a lot of time cursing the indifference of society.
Finally, though, I found a promising candidate named Jimmy, an affable, articulate young guy living in a shantytown on Donald Trump's land along the Hudson River in the West 60's. His wooden shack had a closet neatly arranged with dress shirts, ties and a half-dozen suits.
JIMMY seemed to be over the cocaine problem that had landed him in the streets. He had a part-time job at a soup kitchen, where he ladled out food and talked about how much he enjoyed helping his homeless neighbors still struggling with their demons. He said that he wanted to find a full-time job and move into an apartment, but that he was being thwarted by prejudice against the homeless.
"I'm ready to work," he said, "but if you don't already have a home and an address, you can't get past the job interview."
Eager to document this injustice, I accompanied him on a job-hunting expedition. We started at the state unemployment office, which sent him to the Swingline factory in Long Island City. He was promptly hired.
It wasn't the sad story I'd anticipated, but I kept monitoring his progress. Three days later he quit the job. "I don't like the commute," he explained. A week later he disappeared from the shantytown along with his wardrobe and his neighbors' possessions.
The neighbors in the shantytown were furious at the theft, but they did not share my astonishment at his duplicity. Nor were they surprised that a member of the press had fallen for a line. They seemed to realize one of the secrets of media relations in New York: to make it here, sometimes all you have to do is make it up.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A Unified Europe Ends Most Duty-Free Shopping

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: ABOARD THE FERRYBOAT DOVER, in the English Channel, June 30

 BODY:
It was the last day of duty-free shopping bounty that Europeans have savored for five decades, and Stella Horton knew it.
With determination and vigor, Mrs. Horton, long a buyer of duty-free goods on the ferries that ply the Channel, set about snapping up what she assumed would be the final bargains in the closing hours before these sales within the 15-nation European Union end at midnight tonight. 
 Into her shopping basket went cigarettes at $2.50 a pack instead of $6.50 in Britain and Scotch at $20 instead of $30 a bottle. Total outlay: $160. Total savings over British retail prices: $180.
So slick was the duty-free shopping that she and her companion, Dennis Pointer, both retirees from Ramsgate, England, didn't even have to disembark when this car ferry -- a floating temple to discount sales of everything from single malts to CD's -- berthed briefly at Calais, France, then turned back for the 22-mile run to Dover, England.
But as Mrs. Horton and Mr. Pointer were shopping, duty-free operators like the P & O Stena Line, which runs this ship, and airport authorities across Europe were scrambling -- worried about what the end of duty-free shopping in and offshore European Union nations would mean for their own prosperity.
The European Union's decision to end such shopping was made eight years ago on the basis that duty-free sales skew Europe's vaunted single market. The International Duty-Free Confederation, a trade group made up mainly of airports and ferry companies, fought unsuccessfully to preserve the system, arguing that more than 140,000 jobs in the $6.5 billion annual business would be at risk.
Many have sought to devise alternate ways of selling such goods. Some are absorbing part of the costs themselves to keep discounted prices in their stores. German ferry operators are contemplating switching the destination of their "butter cruises" to neighboring Poland, outside European Union limits, just as Finnish ferry operators now say they will run duty-free shopping trips to Estonia, also outside the union.
Some British airport stores will continue to offer duty-free goods to travelers leaving the European Union for countries like the United States, Switzerland or Russia, while subsidizing discounted liquor and other goods, though not cigarettes, to travelers within the 15 countries -- all at the same airport stores.
French and German airport operators forecast higher prices for liquor and tobacco for European Union travelers, but according to Wolfgang Schwalm, a spokesman for Frankfurt Main International Airport, retailers will "reduce profit margins to maintain the current price level" on luxury goods like perfume.
Perhaps most curiously, ferries like this one will, as of Friday, offer goods at French hypermarket prices -- two-thirds that of many British shop prices because of lower excise taxes in France -- but only when the vessel is halfway across the Channel and out of British territorial waters.
For Europe's supposed single market, that means Britons will pay taxes to the French authorities for goods they consume back home in Britain, robbing their own tax collectors of revenue. The price of some purchases like Scotch whisky will stay the same, while cigarettes become more expensive, but still less costly than in Britain.
"I think it's a farce," said Jim Biggs, 48, from Deal in Kent, who was planning to shop in a low-priced French hypermarket today before returning to England. "I think a group of men in gray suits made a decision without understanding the economic consequences."
But the end of duty-free shopping also means the end of the limitations that European authorities placed on just how many duty-free cigarettes and bottles of liquor and perfume travelers could import -- generally 200 cigarettes, one liter of spirits and two liters of wine for each person.
"When they bring in the French taxes, we'll be able to bring in as much as we like," said Melvyn Lethaby, a crane driver from Dartford who was shopping with his daughter, Michelle May, and who had just bought 24 cans of Foster's lager for half the British price. (British customs officials say this is not quite true: travelers will be expected to honor an informal -- and nominal -- limit of 10 liters of spirits, 110 liters of beer and 800 cigarettes.)
BAA P.L.C., the British airport authority that runs Heathrow, London's principal airport, and six others, says it plans to spend around $70 million a year on subsidizing the prices paid for some goods, though not cigarettes or low-cost liquor, for sale to the 20 percent of passengers traveling within the European Union. The hope is that "where we are going to lose out by discounting, the volumes will increase," said Abigail Rowland, a BAA spokeswoman.
And Gail Isted, a spokeswoman for P & O Stena Line, which is a unit of the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company, said, "Duty-free was low volumes with high margins," acknowledging what many travelers had suspected for years: that duty-free purchases were not always the bargains they seemed.
At the same time, the spread of duty- and tax-free sales from liquor and tobacco to silk scarves and cameras had built a growing business on the balance sheets of ferry and airport operators and airlines. P & O Stena Line, for instance, says that the $200 million people spend each year on shopping, food and drinks contributes one-third of its income.
And BAA has increased landing fees by 5 percent to compensate for lost income from duty-free sales, deepening the fear that whatever is ultimately lost from ending the system will be passed along to fliers in the form of higher fares.
European duty-free shopping for travelers was introduced in Ireland in 1947. But with the concept of a European single market taking shape in the early 1990's, duty-free sales began to seem to some European officials like an anomaly that gave some businesses an unfair competitive advantage.
The argument went back and forth. In the end, Denmark persuaded wavering members of the European Union to stand firm against the urging of retailers and travelers that tonight's deadline be extended. The Danes did so at their peril.
"We aren't buying their Danish bacon no more," Mr. Pointer said. "That's for sure."

(Jonathan Player for The New York Times)
