HEADLINE: Ailing Foreigners Burden Emergency Rooms in U.S.

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
They look like any of the anxious patients who walk into the city's polyglot emergency rooms.
But there are telltale signs.Sometimes they arrive with luggage and with tourist visas in their pockets. Often they have crumpled notes from doctors back home in China or Africa. 
 One man from the Dominican Republic flew into La Guardia Airport weak with fever, asked for an ambulance and presented himself at New York Presbyterian Hospital, where he announced that he had leukemia and needed help. Along with his suitcase, he carried his own intravenous drip.
They are known as medical immigrants, poor or middle-class foreigners who scrape and save to fly to New York, but not to join family, flee oppression or find work. Instead, they come solely to seek treatment at city emergency rooms, where Federal and state law says they must be examined and treated if their problems require immediate care.
Doctors say that such patients have been gravitating to the city in modest numbers for years, mostly to the city's public hospitals. While New York appears to receive the brunt, hospitals in Chicago, Houston and Miami also report treating a steady stream of medical immigrants, mostly from poor countries.
No one is able to say exactly how many there are or how much their care costs hospitals. And in part, this is a policy decision. Many emergency departments, fearing the anti-immigrant sentiment that has restricted access to health care in California and other states, resist counting such patients or pressing them about where they came from if they do not volunteer that information.
"Should I wonder whether this is the guy from Third Avenue who doesn't have any money or the guy from the third world who doesn't have any?" asked Dr. Lewis Goldfrank, emergency services director at Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan. "That's not my job," he said. "I'm a doctor."
But especially in New York, those who keep an eye on city hospitals' precarious finances say that if something does not change, the hospitals will not be able to keep their emergency room doors open to the world.
Medical immigrants are a tiny but striking example of a larger and growing problem of uninsured or underinsured patients -- both citizens and immigrants, legal and illegal -- who rely on emergency rooms as clinics for everything from colds to cancer.
According to the New York State Health Department, city hospitals provided $1.2 billion in care to those who could not pay in 1997, the last year for which figures are available. The same year, the state collected only $635 million in a charity pool used for such care, most of which went to city hospitals. The pool is financed through taxes on hospitals and insurers.
In addition to the shortfall, New York's percentage of uninsured people, 19.1 percent, is not only higher than the country's, but is growing faster. Medical immigrants are only a sliver of this group, but Patricia Wang, a senior vice president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, called the phenomenon "a tremendous concern to hospitals as the number of uninsured grows."
"It's another thing that's putting a lot of stress on hospital budgets," she said.
The patients come from all over the world, many with long-neglected, serious illnesses. Just after 2 on Sunday morning, a newly arrived Honduran woman showed up at Elmhurst Hospital's emergency room, and doctors determined that she had an aggressive form of cancer.
Last year, Dr. Goldfrank treated a West African with kidney failure who had sold his house and possessions to travel to Guinea for dialysis. He could not get help there, but tacked to a bulletin board in the hospital was an announcement saying that if patients could get to Bellevue or Pitie-Salpetriere Hospital in Paris they would get free dialysis.
The man, whose name was not released, flew to New York last February and walked into the emergency room with almost fatal levels of potassium in his blood, Dr. Goldfrank said. He was stabilized and has remained in New York for weekly dialysis, paid for with emergency Medicaid money that require mountains of paperwork for the hospital.
When Bellevue officials asked the man whether he would be willing to be interviewed, provided that his name not be used, he became so frightened that nurses in the dialysis program worried that he would not show up for his treatments again.
"These are people who are on a mission to save their lives," Dr. Goldfrank said. "It's their last resort before they give up. And it can be a very courageous journey they're taking."
Not all cities are as welcoming. At Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami, officials have begun to make access much harder when patients cannot prove legal residency or an ability to pay. They might be stabilized in the emergency room but not admitted. Or if their condition is not immediately life-threatening, they may be told to go to the hospital's clinic, where they must pay a fee before being seen.
 
Taking the Drastic Step: Alerting the Authorities
Recently, Jackson has even begun taking the most drastic step: alerting immigration authorities if hospital administrators determine that a patient's condition can be treated in his home country. When this leads to deportation, the hospital will sometimes pick up the cost of the airline ticket, many thousands of dollars cheaper than the care they might otherwise have provided.
"We have to draw a line, and we're doing it more and more," said Maria Rosa Gonzalez, a spokeswoman. "The county has made it very clear that our first responsibility is to the people of Miami-Dade County. And we're not ashamed to admit that."
In California, the flow of medical immigrants has slowed considerably since the 1994 passage of Proposition 187, which sought to deny most medical help to illegal immigrants and require doctors to report them to the police. While the measure has been mostly dismantled in court, uncertainty among immigrants about whether they will be treated has deterred them from traveling to California for medical care.
But New York doctors who see such patients say they would never deny care because of economics or immigration status, even though in some cases the law might allow them to discharge the patients once they are stabilized.
"From my point of view, I'm just interested in getting them taken care of," said Dr. Stuart Kessler, the director of the emergency department at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens, another city emergency room frequently sought out by such patients because of its diverse neighborhood and proximity to airports. "Whether it's a strain on resources or not, that's an issue I can debate some other time."
 
Many Patients Lie About Visit's Purpose
Bellevue estimates that it may see a few dozen patients a year who doctors or social workers determine have traveled to the country just for medical care. But hospital officials believe there are probably dozens more patients who lie, thinking they are more likely to receive treatment if they claim they came to the city for a vacation or to find work and then fell ill. Elmhurst officials say they may see a few patients a month who they know to be medical immigrants.
"They are the patients all the doctors talk about," said Dr. Kessler, who said he is always struck by those who bring doctors' notes or medical charts. "This is not a letter from a doctor down the street. It's from another part of the world."
In New York City, the number of these patients appears to have risen only slightly over the years, probably because of obvious barriers, doctors say. First, the patients must be able to get a tourist or temporary visa in their countries and come up with the money for the airline ticket. They must also have a certain level of sophistication to know that they will indeed be treated once they show up. Sometimes this knowledge comes from friends or relatives who live in New York and take them to the hospital after they arrive.
In other cases, underequipped hospitals in third world countries actually urge seriously ill patients, like the West African with kidney failure, to go to New York as a last resort.
The man from the Dominican Republic who showed up at New York Presbyterian was lucky. He got a bone marrow transplant, said a former doctor at the hospital. But sometimes, Dr. Goldfrank says, the patients arrive too late. A few years ago, a man in Mexico City who knew he had serious heart problems began having chest pains and got on a plane. He landed, took a cab to Bellevue and walked into the emergency room in shock. He died several days later.
New York doctors say they have seen no patterns of immigrants from specific countries or regions, but for the last several years they have noticed several South Americans with AIDS, West Africans with kidney failure and Chinese with cancer.
Sometimes they arrive straight from the airport, with no contacts in New York other than the doctors and nurses who help them. More commonly, friends or relatives in the city familiar with a certain hospital take the patient to the emergency room within a few days of his arrival.
Some of the immigrant traffic may be an unintended side effect of occasional good-will missions by public and private hospitals, which bring in foreign patients from impoverished or war-torn countries in need of complicated surgeries or treatments. These patients get special medical visas, they usually have the support of a charity, and the cases generate a huge amount of publicity for the hospitals. It is publicity sometimes seen around the world as an invitation to free care at New York's emergency rooms.
"There's apparently good word of mouth about us in Mongolia, which is nice to know," said Pam McDonnell, the director of communications at Bellevue.
 
A Complaint of Patients Sent to Public Hospitals
 The city's public hospitals complain that when medical immigrants, especially those with serious illnesses, show up on the doorsteps of private hospitals, they may be stabilized and then shipped over to a public hospital for the costly surgery or long stay.
Francesco Santoni-Rugiu, an Italian cardiologist who is leaving Mount Sinai Medical Center to return to practice in Italy, said doctors at private hospitals would like to keep the patients because they often have medical conditions either no longer as common in the United States or virtually unheard of, like leprosy.
"But probably," he said, "the hospital isn't going to be in favor of admitting these people."
They often end up at Bellevue.
Last year, the social work staff there took a statistical snapshot of the admitted patient population on one day, Dec. 3. The report was mostly to determine the size of the homeless population, but it found something that surprised administrators. Of the 701 patients, 166 were not United States citizens and 70 were ineligible for government entitlements, meaning that they were probably illegal immigrants.
No one can say how many of the 70 had entered the United States specifically for medical help, but Patricia Blau, deputy director of the Social Work Department, estimated that it was probably over half.
"I think some of the medical staff were surprised with the numbers we found," she said. "But we weren't. The word is on the streets, so to speak, that if you come in these doors, you will not be turned away."

HEADLINE: U.S. Warns That Arms Race May Begin Between Koreas

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 30

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is increasingly worried that South Korea may be pushing ahead with several missile projects that could further fuel an arms race on the Korean Peninsula, just as North Korea appears to be preparing another launch of a long-range missile.
Administration officials say they will raise their concerns that a South Korean missile program could destabilize an already dangerous situation when South Korea's President, Kim Dae Jung, visits Washington on Friday. 
 Two weeks ago, the South sank a North Korean vessel in a firefight along their coastal border that resulted in more than 20 deaths.
While the two Presidents will publicly declare that they have agreed on a common strategy for dealing with the North, one senior Administration official said that the South Koreans feel "unduly constrained" by a two-decade-old agreement that sharply limits their ability to deploy a powerful fleet of missiles as a deterrent.
The political pressure in Seoul to deploy such missiles is bound to grow if the North fires another Taepo Dong missile over the Sea of Japan in the coming weeks. Today, Kurt M. Campbell, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Asian and Pacific Affairs, was the first Administration official to acknowledge publicly that American intelligence had detected "some preparations" for a launch in coming weeks or months.
"We'd view any potential launch of either a satellite or a missile as a very serious act with very real consequences for U.S. foreign policy toward North Korea," he said.
The North's first launch, on Aug. 31 last year, took American intelligence agencies by surprise and set off outrage in Japan. The test seemed intended to demonstrate that the North could strike Tokyo and any of the bases where 55,000 American troops are stationed in Japan. Japan threatened to pull out of an accord under which it is providing much of the financing to build electric-power stations in the North, the quid pro quo for Pyongyang, the North's capital, to agree to freeze its nuclear weapons program.
William Perry, a former Defense Secretary who now is President Clinton's special adviser on North Korea, warned North Korea during a visit to Pyongyang last month that a second missile test could endanger the Administration's effort to begin a slow normalization of relations with the Communist country, including a gradual lifting of economic sanctions. Mr. Perry will meet with Mr. Kim on Friday.
Mr. Campbell said today that despite the warnings, North Korea could have several motivations to defy the United States and allies and proceed with the test launch.
"There is a very real desire to put a satellite in space," he said, referring to the North's claim that last year's launch propelled a small satellite into a low orbit, where the North claims it has broadcast songs hailing achievements of North Korea's founder, the late Kim Il Sung. "There is also a desire to develop their missile program," he said.
But as they try to convince North Korea to end its missile tests, Washington is also scrambling to urge President Kim to resist growing political pressure in the South to develop longer-range missiles that can strike targets throughout the North.
In the late 1970's, after the United States discovered and terminated a South Korean effort to build a nuclear weapon of its own, Seoul agreed not to build missiles with a range greater than 180 kilometers, or about 108 miles. That limit puts Pyongyang just out of reach of South Korea's existing missile batteries.
On April 10, however, South Korea launched a surface-to-surface missile, the Hyonmu, from an island off its west coast. It traveled only a short distance, but reports at the time suggested that its fuel tank was only partially filled, so that the United States would not discover the true range of the weapon.
Some American intelligence officials are now casting doubt on the assessment that the South limited the test to avoid American suspicions. But Mr. Kim's Government has not shared much information with the Pentagon about its plans for its missile program.
A senior military official said he believed that South Korea had "a fairly determined national program to create capabilities that are competitive with the North Korean capability." They also do not want to be overly dependent on the United States to supply all of their weaponry, officials said. Some South Korean officials have complained that the United States is not being tough enough on the North about its missile program, while pressuring Seoul to contain its own development programs.
Two American officials said that the United States might be willing to extend the permissible range of South Korea's missiles to roughly 180 miles.
That might ease the domestic pressure on President Kim , while keeping South Korea within the limits of an international agreement to restrict missile proliferation. Neither North Korea nor South Korea has signed the agreement.

INTERNATIONAL A3-12
 
Barak Creates Coalition With Seven Israeli Parties
Prime Minister-elect Ehud Barak of Israel ended six weeks of forging a broad coalition Government by clinching a deal with the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party. The new Government is to take over next week. A1 

Senate Passes Aid Bill
The Senate, voting 97 to 2, passed a $12.7 billion foreign aid bill that designates Yugoslavia a terrorist state. The White House called it grossly inadequate and threatened a veto. A6
 
Holbrooke Clears Hurdle
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved the nomination of Richard C. Holbrooke to be the chief American diplomat at the United Nations. It is not known when the full Senate will take it up. A6
 
Disclosures on Chile
The C.I.A. and other agencies had detailed reports of widespread human rights abuses by the Chilean military almost immediately after the 1973 right-wing coup that the United States supported, according to once-secret Government documents. A11
 
Russian Planes Raise Alarm
Russian bombers flew close enough to Iceland and Norway last week to cause the United States and Norway to scramble fighter planes, a National Security Council official said. A3
 
Russia's Kosovo Role Unsettled
Russia and NATO are still arguing about just where Russian peacekeepers should go in Kosovo and whose orders they should follow. A10
 
Ex-Premier Heads Company
Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the former Prime Minister of Russia, was installed as the chairman of the biggest corporation in his country, the natural gas monopoly Gazprom. A3
 
Korean Missile Race Feared
The Administration is worried that South Korea may be pushing ahead with missile projects that may further fuel an arms race on the Korean Peninsula, just as North Korea appears to be preparing to launch another long-range missile. A3
 
Ulster Mediators Pass Deadline
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain; his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, and Northern Ireland political leaders talked past a deadline to try break an impasse threatening the peace settlement. A12
 
World Briefing A8
 
NATIONAL A14-17
 
Record Fund-Raising Gives Bush an Advantage
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas said his Presidential campaign had amassed $36.3 million in four months, a record. It means his campaign may forgo Federal matching subsidies, which would let it exceed the near $50 million ceiling for the primary season and not have to worry about specific spending caps in pivotal battleground states. A1
 
Senator John McCain called on the Republican rank and file to rise up against a system he branded "an elaborate influence-peddling scheme in which both parties conspire to stay in office by selling the country to the highest bidder." A17
 
Clinton Friend Enters Pleas
The independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr formally declared an end to the Arkansas phase of his wide-ranging investigation as Webster L. Hubbell, once the No. 3 official in the Justice Department, pleaded guilty to a felony and a misdemeanor. A16
 
House Abortion Vote
The House voted to make it a Federal crime for an adult to take a minor to another state for an abortion to bypass a parental-notification law in the girl's home state. A17
 
How Guns Get to the Street
A study for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms found a compelling pattern of evidence showing that guns used to commit crimes moved quickly from manufacturers to juvenile offenders and older criminals through a relative handful of corrupt dealers. A14
 
A Plan for the Everglades
The Clinton Administration will formally present a plan today to redirect billions of gallons of water a day into the Everglades in what supporters say is the largest effort at environmental restoration in history. A14
 
Heart Ailment Not So Common
Researchers report in The New England Journal of Medicine that only about 2 percent of the population -- significantly less than thought -- have the heart disorder mitral valve prolapse. A1
 
Anger at Coast Guard Actions
Miami's large Cuban-American population bristled with outrage a day after the Coast Guard used water pumps and pepper spray in an attempt to turn back six Cuban refugees who had come within 150 yards of the Miami Beach shore. A14
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8
 
Ailing Foreigners Add To City Hospitals' Woes
City hospitals are laboring under the strain of uninsured or underinsured patients who use emergency rooms as clinics, with many of those people immigrants who come to the country specifically for that purpose. A1
 
Albany Budget Talks Fail
Budget talks collapsed, leaving New York without a budget three months after it was due. Lawmakers failed to extend laws to protect loft tenants, lower New York City property taxes and trim Medicaid costs. B1
 
City Hall Considers an Ouster
Mayor Giuliani was said to be weighing whether to push the Board of Education to oust the current president, William C. Thompson Jr., an unfailing ally of Chancellor Rudy Crew, in favor of a mayoral ally. B1
 
A Millennium Trail for Queens
The White House listed the No. 7 subway line as one of 16 National Millennium Trails, which recognize special places in American history, in this case the role the line played in the lives of immigrants who settled along it. B1
 
Judge Strikes Down Zoning Rule
A Manhattan judge overturned a year-old New York City zoning rule that allows Broadway theaters to sell the development rights above their buildings to developers. B3

BUSINESS DAY C1-22
 
A Quarter-Point Increase
The Fed nudged its benchmark interest rate up by a quarter of a percentage point, but said there was no clear case for another rate increase to keep inflation at bay. The increase, to 5 percent from 4.75 percent, came after three separate quarter-point rate reductions last fall, during the global financial crisis. A1
 
The stock and bond markets both rallied after the Fed announcement. The Dow closed up 155.45 points, or 1.44 percent, at 10,970.80. Other market gauges were higher. C1
 
Financier Traced to Europe
Federal investigators looking for Martin R. Frankel, the money manager wanted in a huge insurance fraud, said they believed that they had traced him to Europe. Regulators in several states say he fled as a scheme to drain cash from a series of insurance companies he controlled was unraveling. C1

Microsoft said the commission was investigating accounting practices involving the stating of the company's financial reserves. C1

PUB-DATE: July 2, 1999

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 37; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4688 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.
* denotes a highly recommended show. 

Museums
 
"THE AMERICAN CENTURY: ART AND CULTURE, 1900-1950," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Aug. 22). This is the first half of a marathon end-of-an-era survey. (Part 2, covering 1950-2000, opens on Sept. 26.) It flows chronologically through four floors of the museum's galleries, resulting in a show of substantial if circumscribed pleasures. Most of the 600 paintings, drawings and sculptures are familiar icons from a canonical art history, one in need of shaking up. But if what is here is short on fresh insights, there are wonderful things to look at. And by the time you've worked your way from Gilded Age society portraits on the top floor to Jackson Pollock below, you've had a genuine time-travel experience: exhausting, diverting, sometimes moving, even pride-inspiring. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, 1 to 8 P.M. Admission: $12.50; $10.50, students and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
"COLLECTING IN DEPTH: DRAWINGS BY GROSZ, SCHWITTERS, ERNST AND KLEE," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9400 (through July 20). While a little on the dry side, this exhibition effectively encapsulates the careers of four major German modernists, layering their sensibilities like a sandwich and demonstrating the singular uses that each artist found for Cubism. For the outer layers, George Grosz and Paul Klee reformed the tensile lines and transparencies of Analytic Cubism for the purposes, respectively, of scathing social satire and psychologically charged fusions of fantasy and form. In between, Kurt Schwitters and Max Ernst took innovations of Synthetic Cubist collage into new territory. Schwitters used the detritus of everyday life to create a streetwise formalism that indexed different kinds of social interaction and human contact. Ernst extracted found images from their natural habitat in the public press to create a universe as fully imaged as Klee's, only scarier. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays, to 8:15 P.M. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
* "CROSSCURRENTS: MASTERPIECES OF EAST ASIAN ART FROM NEW YORK PRIVATE COLLECTIONS," Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through July 11). The strength of New York private collecting in Asian art is confirmed in this beautiful show. It begins with a heart-lifting 13th-century Japanese wood carving of the bodhisattva Jizo, protector of travelers and children, and ends with an installation of tea ceremony utensils from China, Korea and Japan. In between come paintings, porcelains and lacquer, all exemplary. A big, expansive accomplishment for the Japan Society. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $5 (Cotter).
 
"FROM CEZANNE TO VAN GOGH: THE COLLECTION OF DR. GACHET," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 15). A show of works from the collection of a homeopathic physician and amateur painter named Paul-Ferdinand Gachet (1828-1909). He was one of those curious figures of French bohemia, an intimate of Courbet, Champfleury and Baudelaire and later a friend to painters like Monet, van Gogh and Cezanne, whose works he collected when they were still unrecognized. Some of these works are great, others so bad that doubts have been raised about their authenticity. Any show that invites you to contemplate the difference between fake van Goghs and poor van Goghs is, as you might expect, not altogether visually thrilling. But it has an instructive value as an exercise in comparative viewing, and this is not negligible. It also includes relics like van Gogh's palette that have an extraordinary talismanic appeal, which often exceeds the attraction of the pictures. Hours: Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 8:45 P.M. Suggested admission: $10; $5, students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
"IMPRESSIONISTS IN WINTER: EFFETS DE NEIGE," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Aug. 29). Think of the Impressionists and chances are you think green: lawns, hedges and fertile fields of a deciduous nature caught at full leaf. But these artists were year-round workers, and winter landscapes, rendered in the frosty open air or through the glass of a studio window, figured in their repertory. Here are some 60 such paintings. And if ever a show were tailor-made for summer viewing, this one is. Its size is untaxing, and its deep-freeze images of snow-covered fields and ice-caked trees are the visual equivalent of air-conditioning. Of course, much of the work by Monet, Pissarro, Sisley and their colleagues is extremely beautiful in that immediate, you-have-to-be-there Impressionist way. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, to 8 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. (to 11 P.M. on the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $9.50; $7.50, students over 10 and the elderly (Cotter).
 
"A MEASURED QUIETUDE: CONTEMPORARY IRISH DRAWINGS," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166 (through July 31). Judging from these drawings by seven Irish artists, Minimalism and to a lesser extent Post-Minimalism are the lingua franca of international contemporary art. Thus the exceptions stand out, including Liadin Cooke's odd little drawings whose isolated shapes suggest bone shards, maps and landscapes and whose tiny texts evoke "The Iliad," but are actually from de Sade; Colin Darke's elegant little drawing-texts that feature writings of Lenin and Trotsky copied in minuscule script onto cigarette papers -- a well-known method among political prisoners in Northern Ireland for passing secret messages. Across the street in the Center's Drawing Room, the frescolike white-on-black wall drawings of John Kindness update the Attic vase style of Classical Greek and recasts Herakles as a fearless Belfast youth. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free (Smith).
 
* "THE MEDIEVAL HOUSEBOOK: A VIEW OF 15TH-CENTURY LIFE," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through July 25). Mystery still surrounds the vivacious 15th-century German manuscript known as the Medieval Housebook. For example, who were the artists? Part idyll, part real-life manual for the landed gentry, the housebook touches on such miscellaneous matters as astronomy, astrology, courtly love, chivalry, mining, metallurgy, jousting, warfare, recipes, medications, castle defense, animal husbandry and the trapping of men by female predators. In its exquisitely detailed drawings, a mischievous mix of the elegant and the bawdy, men and women conduct lofty amours and earthy functions, the raffish mingle with the raffine, and sybarites are far more evident than saints. A secular sanctuary in a religious era, the manuscript captures the spirit of a world that's bygone yet very much a prologue to our own. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 6 P.M. Admission: $7; $5, students and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
GUSTAVE MOREAU, "Between Epic and Dream," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Aug. 22). The first retrospective in this country in 35 years for Gustave Moreau, the French painter who ignored the art of his own time and, firing his imagination with story lines and stylistic tips lifted from various past cultures, created an art for the future. His highly finished paintings, with their opulent detail and hothouse emotionality, look as intensely strange and decadent as ever. His independence and ability to create a complete, self-sustaining esthetic universe is particularly pertinent today, when the dearth of clear-cut art movements makes many artists feel like loners. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
* "EL NUEVO MUNDO: THE LANDSCAPE OF LATINO LOS ANGELES," Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, Smithsonian Institution, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 (through Sept. 5). For more than two decades, the photographer Camilo Jose Vergara has documented the process of physical change in the poorest neighborhoods in American cities. The story is often one of disintegration, but in the color pictures here he turns his eye on the largely Mexican community in Los Angeles, where transplanted cultural roots are in photogenic flower. Life is hard, but houses, stores and city walls are painted with vivid images of religious icons, consumer goods and yearned-for south-of-the-border vistas. Mr. Vergara's career-long project is an important one; this show is a vivid installment in his expansive fieldwork. And it takes on an extra resonance at the Cooper-Hewitt, a former Andrew Carnegie mansion. Hours: Tuesdays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Admission: $5; children under 12 and the elderly, $3 (Cotter).
 
* "SURREALISM: TWO PRIVATE EYES," the Nesuhi Ertegun and Daniel Filipacchi Collections, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 12). The Surrealist collections formed by two friends fill the museum from lobby to ceiling. Although it has more than 700 objects, this powerful show is by no means a comprehensive survey but an intense, close-up experience of Surrealism that might be imparted by two obsessed acquisitors taking you on a personal tour of their treasures. Highlights include clusters of paintings by Dali, Victor Brauner, Magritte, Andre Masson and Yves Tanguy; a splendid group of boxes by Joseph Cornell; a brilliant selection of photographs rife with portraits by Man Ray; dozens of beautifully bound books, and remarkable drawings by Hans Bellmer and Masson. The show has notable omissions and a few surprising inclusions, but by and large the menu is gourmet. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 8 P.M. Admission: $12; $7, students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
* "TO CONSERVE A LEGACY: AMERICAN ART FROM HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES," Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500 (through July 11). The 200 works on view, drawn from the collections of six educational institutions and spanning more than a century, form a lively and eclectic gathering in which Georgia O'Keeffe and Romare Bearden, Edmonia Lewis and Arthur Dove, the ultra-urbane Charles Demuth and the ecstatic self-taught Minnie Evans keep kindred-spirit, all-American company. The exhibition serves as a lesson in the intricacies of art conservation, an introduction to the endlessly absorbing subject of American education and a richly deserved 30th-birthday celebration for the Studio Museum itself. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 6 P.M. Admission: $5; $3, students and the elderly. Admission is free the first Saturday of each month (Cotter).
 
"0044," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Aug. 29). The work of 20 Irish artists who live and work in London, whose work sometimes addresses Irish themes and sometimes doesn't. Although the level of professionalism is uniformly high, most of the artists are pursuing familiar strategies of painting, sculpture, installation or video art. Look for Frances Hegarty's video self-portrait, Liadin Cooke's aluminum casts of small rough balls of Irish clay, Kathy Prendergast's drawings of the world's rivers and lakes, Tina O'Connell's installation pieces (which riff on Post-Minimalists like Robert Smithson, Carl Andre and Lynda Benglis without losing their identity) and Daphne Wright's walk-in environment of tall craggy outcroppings of aluminum foil, each accompanied by its own tiny foil seagull. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $5 (Smith).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
"CHARLES HENRI FORD: PRINTED MATTER, 1929-1969," Ubu Gallery, 16 East 78th Street, (212) 794-4444 (through July 16). This revelatory exhibition covers four decades of the busy career of Charles Henri Ford, poet, novelist, editor and publisher. It includes copies of Blues: A Magazine of New Rhythms, which Mr. Ford founded in 1929, at the age of 19, and of View, notable for its artist-designed covers, which he created and oversaw in the 1940's. But it is dominated by the less well-known "Poem Posters" that Mr. Ford made in 1964-65. These, in turn, are dominated by acid colors, chains of verse spliced together like a kidnapper's ransom note and pop culture images, Jayne Mansfield among them. They may be high Pop Art, but they are also the culmination of Mr. Ford's long involvement with Surrealism, whose strategies find new expression here (Smith).
 
ARISTODIMOS KALDIS, Lori Bookstein Fine Art, 50 East 78th Street, (212) 439-9605 (through July 14) and Foundation for Hellenic Culture, 7 West 57th Street, (212) 308-6908 (through Aug. 31). The ebullient work of the Turkish-born, Greek-bred painter Kaldis (1899-1979) was always based on the Mediterranean landscape of his childhood. In his earlier canvases, sunny, lively colors, simple lines and sparsely detailed forms made up sweet scenes of seaside life. Later, his work became more complex. The forms grew more abstract; the canvases got bigger, and his compositions exploded spatially, allowing large areas of white to dominate, punctuated by dashes and bursts of color that stood for landscape elements. A catchy lyrical harmony informs these later paintings (at the Foundation), keeping them fresh (Glueck).
 
JAN MATULKA, Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through July 30). This exhibition of harbor scenes presents Matulka (1890-1972), one of the lesser known but more engaging of American Early Modernists, at his most appealing. The paintings offer views of seaside houses, sheds and wharves, rocky shores, cozy, blue bays and chunky, toylike boats robustly painted in a brightly colored, chunky style that looks like a marriage of folk art and Cubism (Ken Johnson).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
ELLIOTT GREEN, JANE HAMMOND, DAVID TRUE, TREVOR WINKFIELD, Tibor de Nagy, 724 Fifth Avenue, (212) 262-5050 (through July 26). Each of the painters in this well-selected show has developed his or her own idiosyncratic mix of Pop, Surrealism and figurative narrative. They harmonize well together, but Mr. True's big, zany cartoon version of the Biblical Expulsion, with its eerie population of rubbery, incandescently hued characters, steals the show (Johnson).
 
JASPER JOHNS, Susan Sheehan, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 489-3331 (through July 31). Familiar Johnsian motifs are here embodied in prints from the 60's, 70's and 80's: the numbers 0 through 9 stenciled one over another; three versions of brushes in a Savarin coffee can; five expansive, hatchwork abstractions; a blotchy, black-and-white double flag; and the autobiographical suite "Four Seasons." Johns's distinctively deft, matter-of-fact touch animates them all (Johnson).
 
ALICE TRUMBULL MASON, Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through July 23). Descended from a prominent Colonial New England family, Mason (1904-1971) studied with Arshile Gorky in the late 1920's. As this selection of works from four decades proves, she remained devoted to abstraction throughout her long, under-recognized career. Her modestly scaled paintings, always rigorously structured, sensuously painted and richly colored, were influenced by Miro early on and later by Mondrian, but they always have their own engaging personality (Johnson).
 
JOHN McLAUGHLIN, Ameringer Howard, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 935-1110 (through July 30). McLaughlin (1898-1976) dealt in Asian antiquities and served as a high-ranking translator during World War II before moving to California and, at age 50, beginning his distinguished career as a painter of austere, Zen-inspired abstractions. This show presents five dry, near-Minimalist rectilinear canvases and a series of lithographs from which Peter Halley might have gotten the barred windows of his cell paintings (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
BARTON LIDICE BENES, Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Spring Street, (212) 941-0012 (through July 30). Mr. Benes produces modern reliquaries: broad, shallow boxes divided into little cubbyholes, each containing a labeled, more or less sacred relic. Among the items displayed in "Celebrity" you'll find a police badge worn by Sean Penn in the movie "Colors" and a wad of Dustin Hoffman's chewing gum. These devotional works are for a Warholian world where the gods have devolved into celebrities (Johnson).
 
ROSS BLECKNER, Betsy Senior, 375 West Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 941-0960 (through Aug. 27). The 10 new etchings in this show correspond to the large cellular abstract paintings Mr. Bleckner exhibited last fall. Patterns of luminous, blurry lines and glowing dots are Bleckneresque but the prints don't have the magical illusionism of the paintings (Johnson).
 
"INVITATIONAL EXHIBITION," Curt Marcus, 578 Broadway, near Prince Street, (212) 226-3200 (through July 9). The five painters in this exhibition work in various styles but are united by a predilection for painterly richness and conscientious craft. Included are Matthew Abbot's dazzingly complicated Pop mandalas; Elizabeth Saveri's small, charmingly unassuming realist pictures; lovely, subtly patterned and layered abstractions by Dean Smith; luminous, crusty abstractions by Richard Tsao and lush grids by David Collins (Johnson).
 
TOBA KHEDOORI, David Zwirner, 43 Greene Street, (212) 966-9074 (through July 9). This Australia-born Californian continues to do what she's been celebrated for since she emerged about five years ago. On vast, dirty and waxy paper surfaces she floats delicate, subtly tinted schematic pictures of architecture or furniture: a corner of a room where two doors stand ajar; a child's-size desk and chair; a cityscape of simple, building-shaped blocks. The drawings are formulaic but poetic and sensuously material (Johnson).
 
ANTOINE PEVSNER, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through July 31). This remarkable exhibition presents 120 drawings done from 1912 to 1956 by one of the original Russian Constructivists. Made in graphite in an elasticized Cubist style, they realize Pevsner's fantasy of Machine Age dynamism more persuasively than do his sculptures, which today look clunky and dated. Artists who continue to explore the possibilities of abstraction might find this collection a rich source of ideas (Johnson).
 
"SAMPLING," Ronald Feldman Gallery, 31 Mercer Street, (212) 226-3232 (through July 9). For this big, end-of-season group exhibition, Feldman got in touch with art galleries in Europe, Australia, India, Japan and Egypt, asking them for works by artists they represent. Almost three dozen are on view here. The information-gathering idea is a terrific one, and if the results, drawing on a global pool of styles and media, are intriguing rather than earth-shaking, there are artists here one looks forward to hearing from again soon. One of them is Christine Hill, who contributes a funny and slightly mystifying installation of posters ("Where exactly are we going?" reads one) related to walking tours of New York City that she will be conducting through the summer. Among the highlights she promises are a McDonald's with a doorman and a former residence of Conan O'Brien. Tour price: $12; information (212) 802-7383 (Cotter).
 
JOAQUIN TORRES-GARCIA, Cecilia de Torres, 140 Greene Street, (212) 431-5869 (through July 31). This show of small paintings and drawings on paper commemorates the 50th anniversary of the Uruguayan-born modernist's death. Torres Garcia's gridded, pictographic works, by which he articulated a comprehensive cosmic philosophy with an unassuming, comic touch, are especially engaging (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
SAINT CLAIR CEMIN, Cheim & Read, 521 West 23d Street, (212) 242-7727 (through July 31). Mr. Cemin, one of his generation's most inventive sculptors (he was born in 1951) presents five marmoreal mock monuments, including a sphinx with a smoothly finished woman's face and a roughly carved body; an archaic, a cartoonish horse pierced by a stainless steel spear, and a square wind-filled sail carved from a single block of stone (Johnson).
 
RITA McBRIDE AND SYLVIA PLIMACK MANGOLD, Alexander and Bonin, 132 10th Avenue, at 18th Street, (212) 367-7474 (through July 30). Ms. McBride's installation focuses obliquely on the concept of the art exhibition. Three sets of curvy, wooden bleachers invite viewers to sit and look at a picture on the wall, which will periodically change (first up was a Cindy Sherman self-portrait as a secretary from 1978). Ms. Mangold's Precisionist painting of a ruler on a wooden floor reflected in a wood-framed mirror and a more recent Cezannesque portrait of a tree echo the woodiness of the bleachers (Johnson).
 
B. G. MUHN, Stux, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 352-1600 (through July 31). Mr. Muhn, who was born in Korea and teaches at Georgetown University, produces crafty, surrealistic paintings combining abstract elements, luminous color fields and images that may be highly finished or loosely sketched. Mood ranges from portentous to absurd as in the picture of a rabbit with a big pink tongue on a tormented-looking bald man's head (Johnson).
 
"SUMMER GROUP EXHIBITION," DCA, 525 West 22d Street, (212) 255-5511 (through July 17). This presentation of 11 Danish artists is remarkable mainly for how derivative the works are. Kehnet Nielsen's abstract paintings look like Clyfford Still's; Bjarne Werner Sorensen's layered networks are like Terry Winters's; Erik A. Frandsen's snapshot-based enamel picture is like a Gary Hume. But Michael Kvium's strange painting of paunchy men in underwear brandishing sock puppets and doing something weirdly erotic has an eccentric personality of its own (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
"EVE'S VOCABULARY," Brookdale Center, Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, 1 West Fourth Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 674-5300 (through July 16). Deborah Rosenthal's paintings from 1988-98 take inspiration from the biblical figure of Eve, but place her -- and sometimes Adam -- in an overall scheme that puts vigorous emphasis on abstraction and decorative patterning. The Matissean colors are vivid, almost tropical, likewise the stylized vegetal forms that often invade the composition. Although they express Ms. Rosenthal's consciousness of her Jewishness, the word "religious" doesn't quite fit. Their buoyancy of spirit is infectious (Glueck).
 
ROMUALD HAZOUME, The Project, 421 West 126th Street, Harlem, (212) 662-8610 (through July 25). The first United States show of this West African artist includes two dozen small, mask-like sculptures made from industrial and commercial materials: detergent jugs, video cassette casings, electric fan blades. Mr. Hazoume is a deft and witty assemblagist of objects and ideas: references to traditional art, consumer culture and an economy of recycling are all touched on here. In the back gallery are seven airy paintings of oracular pictographic forms painted on layers of earth. A welcome debut (Cotter).
 
BYRON KIM, Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42d Street, (917) 663-2453 (through July 16). Mr. Kim likes to imbue modernist modes like monochromatic painting with oblique political overtones. Here he has created subtle, mural-scale wall drawings using gray washes pigmented by dust vacuumed up around the Philip Morris building, orchestrating a marriage of high formalism and low materialism. One wall bears the ghost image of a brick wall with blocked-up windows. The others are entirely abstract (Johnson).
 
"WHEN TIME BEGAN TO RANT AND RAVE: FIGURATIVE PAINTING FROM 20th-CENTURY IRELAND," Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through July 24). This begins with works influenced by Impressionism and Post-Impressionism and ends with routine versions of 80's Neo-Expressionism. Rife with derivative, over-earnest work, it is most valuable as a reflection of Ireland's painful history and its effect on its art. It makes palpable the tensions between artists who wanted to keep abreast of international (mostly French) developments in art and those who disdained modernism and celebrated Irish rural life or the struggle for independence. Its highpoints are few, but include the work of Jack B. Yeats, whose thickly painted Expressionist works succeed in fusing distinctly Irish predicaments and states of mind with an original, contemporary style (Smith).
 
Last Chance
 
ASHLEY BICKERTON, Sonnabend, 420 West Broadway, near Spring Street, SoHo, (212) 966-6160 (through today). These new, bizarre figurative paintings by a former Neo Geo artist are by turns funny, perplexing and sophomoric. "The Vlaminkos" presents three people, each caught in a web of illusion: a tied-up masochist, a corpulent New Age woman complacently meditating in the nude and a teen-age boy simultaneously listening to a Walkman, playing a Gameboy and smoking. Mr. Bickerton captures the spiritual nightmare of modernity with visionary exuberance (Johnson).
 
"ELLSWORTH KELLY: 'SCULPTURE FOR A LARGE WALL' AND OTHER RECENT ACQUISITIONS," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Tuesday). The Modern is celebrating its recent acquisition of Mr. Kelly's sensational "Sculpture for a Large Wall" (1956-57) with other pieces from its holdings by this luminous and original artist. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
* JAMES ENSOR, Shepherd & Derom Galleries, 58 East 79th Street, (212) 861-4050 (through tomorrow). Two dozen exquisite etchings from the early and most innovative period in the career of James Ensor (1860-1949), the visionary painter of masks, skeletons and devils, are presented in this show. Ensor's delight in human venality and foolishness is wonderfully realized throughout, especially in a series devoted to the seven deadly sins that looks as if it could have been drawn yesterday by the underground comic artist R. Crumb. (Johnson)
 
* "MIRROR OF THE MEDIEVAL WORLD," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). This glowing showcase of some 300 medieval objects acquired by the Met over the last 20 years includes silver chalices, ivory plaques, stained-glass panels and carved wooden sculptures. Some have long been on view in various parts of the museum, and others are being shown for the first time. Like any survey of its kind, knockout masterpieces mingle with works meant to fill in historical gaps, and dates are all over the place. But the staggering material wealth and spiritual energy of an epoch come through. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
KENNY SCHACHTER, Sandra Gering, 476 Broome Street, SoHo, (212) 226-8195 (through today). Mr. Schachter, who is best known as a roving curator-entrepreneur, here presents his own artwork, a line of mock commodities called "Shovelware." The best things in this uneven show are a set of dining utensils in the form of miniature tools, like shovels and pitchforks, and an artists' sperm bank: an industrial-strength tank containing frozen semen samples from several semi-famous artists, available for $750 a pop (Johnson).

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:

Museum Fills a Gap In Its Dutch Paintings
When J. Patrice Marandel, the curator of European painting and sculpture at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, attended the Maastricht art fair in the Netherlands four months ago, he spotted exactly what he'd been seeking for the museum's permanent collection: a first-rate painting from the Utrecht School. 
 "Mocking of Christ," by the Dutch master Gerrit van Honthorst, is a haunting image in which the artist used a candle to cast shadows on the figures he painted, in this case to depict the suffering of Jesus dramatically. It is a theme the artist explored several times. But while there are at least five known versions of the painting, this one, Mr. Marandel believes, is among the artist's best.
"When I came to the museum six years ago, I realized that we really needed a painting of this school," he said. "The emotion in this picture and the dignified treatment of the subject make it particularly special. It will be the museum's first Hont horst."
Painted around 1617, when the artist was in Rome working with Caravaggio, "Mocking of Christ" was unpublished and unknown to scholars until Rob Smeets, a Milan dealer, exhibited it at the art fair.
"It was known to Prof. J. Richard Judson, who is writing a new catalogue raisonne of the artist's work," Mr. Marandel said. "We know it had been in a private Dutch collection."
But because of the gaps in its provenance, especially during the middle years of the 20th century, Mr. Marandel said, he spent considerable time confirming that at no point was it looted during World War II.
The painting was acquired for the museum through the Ahmanson Foundation, based in Los Angeles, which has been the museum's biggest benefactor in European paintings. The painting helps to flesh out the Caravaggesque pictures already in the Los Angeles County Museum of Art's collection, especially Georges de La Tour's "Magdalen With the Smoking Flame" (circa 1640) and Valentin de Boulogne's "Musical Party" (1626).
The Honthorst will go on view in the fall, Mr. Marandel said, after some minor conservation and restoration work.
 
Privatizing the Biennale
Over the next several years the Venice Biennale is to go from a Government-run entity to a private profit-seeking organization, one that will hold year-round arts events in all disciplines.
"We're looking for joint ventures with private organizations and corporations to help fund us," said Giovanna Legnani, the general director of the Biennale, who is working with its president, Paolo Baratta, to make the change happen. "If we succeed, we hope this will be an economic model that will be copied at other Biennales around the world."
The Italian Government passed a law in February allowing the Venice Biennale, which costs about $10 million a year to produce, to become a private cultural organization. While the art world thinks of it as an art fair that happens every two years, the organizers of the Biennale actually oversee a host of other cultural activities in Venice, including a film festival every September and biennales in such fields as music, theater, dance and architecture, held sporadically during the summer.
Despite the name biennale, some events occur every year.
"The Biennale is a gold mine that's never been exploited," Ms. Legnani said. "I have a mandate to make it profitable and self-sufficient in four years."
Although it has been 50 percent financed by the Italian Government, with the rest raised through admissions, catalogues and merchandise, over time, Ms. Legnani said, it will become totally self-sufficient.
To lure corporations like Philip Morris to become sponsors, she plans to emphasize the economic impact these events have on Venice, which in turn, she believes, insures high visibility for sponsors. Each year about $3 million is made directly from entrance fees and catalogue sales.
During the height of the Biennale, about $10 million is generated from tourism, spent at hotels, restaurants and retail stores.
Included in the Biennale's plans is a new theater on San Giorgio Island, across the Grand Canal from San Marco, which would hold year-round dance and performing arts programs.
Over the next few years, plans also include keeping the gardens at the tip of Venice -- where the 26 national pavilions are clustered -- open all the time, beginning with a schedule of programs in the Italian pavilion.
"We hope other pavilions will follow," Ms. Legnani said.
 
Not L.A.'s Way
Contrary to speculation, Pace Wildenstein is not closing its Beverly Hills gallery. But it is discontinuing its exhibition program there.
"The gallery is still open and there is art for people to buy," said Arne Glimcher, the chairman of Pace Wildenstein.
It will continue to stock work by the artists it represents, including Agnes Martin, Chuck Close, Kiki Smith and Robert Rauschenberg.
Since Pace Wildenstein opened its Los Angeles branch on Wilshire Boulevard in 1995, the gallery has held more than 50 exhibitions.
"People love to come to the openings, but the Los Angeles life style does not include gallery going, it's simply not part of the culture." Mr. Glimcher said. "We've done very well here, but not from the shows."
The space, designed by the New York architect Charles Gwathmey, never attracted the steady traffic that Pace Wildenstein's two New York galleries do, even though Mr. Glimcher is well connected in Los Angeles. A part-time filmmaker (producer of "Gorillas in the Mist" and director of "Mambo Kings") he knows the many modern and contemporary art collectors who make their money in the movie business.
"There is still an art-buying life in Los Angeles," Mr. Glimcher said. "Just not a gallery-going one. People in Los Angeles prefer to go to the gym."

HEADLINE: DESIGN REVIEW;
Seductive Objects With a Sly Sting

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
With only half a year to go until the millennium arrives, wouldn't it be great to have a worldwide designer yard sale? Out with the Richard Meier plates! Away with the Michael Graves tea kettles! For when the dust has settled from this maniacally industrious chapter in the field of industrial design, only four figures of major artistic stature will be left standing: Ettore Sottsass, Gaetano Pesce, Philippe Starck and Shiro Kuramata. Two Italians, one Frenchman and a gentleman from Japan, the last, alas, no longer living.
This quartet has led us into the epoch of postindustrial design. Their work justifies the expenditure of wood, glass, stone, steel, plastics and other materials toward the service of the present. Everything else is a mistake. 
 Mr. Starck, who moved from Paris to New York earlier this year, is the subject of a small exhibition at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens. The exhibition "Philippe Starck: Furniture and Objects" is among the first fruits of the recent alliance between P.S. 1 and the Museum of Modern Art. The 26 objects on view were collected by David Whitney, the independent curator, and are presented in an installation designed by the architect Philip Johnson. The result is a tribute both to the talent of Mr. Starck and to the evergreen curatorial intelligence of Mr. Whitney and Mr. Johnson.
It has been 65 years since Mr. Johnson mounted "Machine Art," the Museum of Modern Art's first major design show. The objects in the Starck show have been presented as a gift to the Modern's permanent design collection. Mr. Johnson deserves credit not just for sponsoring the roots of the modern design esthetic but also for tracking the evolution of that esthetic into post-modern times. As Marcel Duchamp said, in the future, all the artist can do is point. Mr. Johnson began pointing in the right direction before most of us were born.
Mr. Starck designs under the sign of Scorpio. Visually seductive, usually curvilinear, a Starck design invariably has a sting in its tail. The aluminum legs of the stool Mr. Starck designed for the lobby bar at the Royalton Hotel in Manhattan have the biomorphic voluptuousness of Art Nouveau tendrils. But they touch the floor with barbed points that could pass for giant fishhooks. Media folk angle here.
People in toxic relationships should avoid sharing a Starck-designed bathroom. The designer's sharp-pointed toothbrush appears equally suited for oral hygiene or domestic violence. The Lola Mundo chair, of ebony-stained ashwood with metal legs, is gorgeous, but the screws that attach the metal legs poke through the seat. Is the sitter meant to squirm? Perhaps the chair is a therapeutic device for treating cellulite.
Mr. Starck's work revolves around fear of rejection. His core shape is the horn, an image that figures in many prehistoric drawings. Archeologists regard the horn as a symbol of fertility, a union of the male and female genitals. In the chalk drawings of prehistoric Britain, the horn is brandished as trophy and weapon. The image speaks to the contemporary sensibility that finds extreme bliss and terror in merging with another.
In the last quarter century, Mr. Sottsass, Mr. Pesce, Mr. Kuramata and Mr. Starck have transfigured design. The four have one interest in common. They have all shifted design from the right to the left side of the brain. For Marcel Breuer, Mies van der Rohe and other designers of classic Modernist furniture, the design esthetic was a right-brain affair. Their chairs and tables were rooted in the rational organization dictated by industrial production. It was in their day that the term industrial design was coined.
But in the last 50 years, the economic base has shifted from production to consumption. It has gravitated from the sphere of rationality to the realm of desire: from the objective to the subjective, to the realm of psychology. Mr. Sottsass, Mr. Kuramata, Mr. Pesce and Mr. Starck have applied genius to this cultural shift. Mr. Starck, who was born in 1949, is the youngest of the four, and the only one to break into the mass market with a fair degree of success. His designs fall within the price range of the middle-class buyer. His surrealist sensibility is available to all who can afford to dream.
The exhibition is presented in a beautiful space that P.S. 1 calls the Kunsthalle. Natural light pours in from two sides. The high ceilings are vaulted with brick. Mr. Johnson has designed a simple enfilade down the center of the space, arranging Mr. Starck's objects on white wooden platforms of varying height and width. At the far end of the gallery, a panel displays a large photo of a toothpick designed by Mr. Starck. The picture conveys the grace of a Brancusi sculpture and the menace of a dental appliance. Pleasure and pain, still together after all these years.
In the last decade, Mr. Starck has created the most important contemporary public spaces in New York: his interiors for the Paramount and Royalton hotels. By rights, his relocation to New York should have been saluted with a major show at the Museum of Modern Art. But I prefer to think of the exhibition at P.S. 1 as a vote of confidence in the future of the outer boroughs. I suspect that in the years ahead the most innovative work in architecture, design and urbanism will flourish on the edges of New York.
 
"Philippe Starck: Furniture and Objects" remains at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084, through Aug. 29.

(P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center)

HEADLINE: Panel Sees No Short Cut To a Less Violent Media

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
The topic before a packed auditorium at the New School in Greenwich Village was "Violence in America: Reel Life vs. Real Life."
But the discussion Wednesday evening by a panel of seven mostly arts-oriented writers, lawyers and creative types was more First Amendment versus Second Amendment, with a clear bias in favor of curbing guns rather than free speech. 
 The forum, sponsored by the Creative Coalition, a nonprofit advocacy group representing members of the arts and entertainment sector, was a reflection of the growing unease about violence in the media since the killings at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colo. But if the gathering revealed anything, it might have been that it is much easier to express anxiety about violence in the media than reach a consensus on what to do.
"Traveling around the country, you get the clear sense that parents are upset and confused and that people who have been apathetic are beginning to become vocal," said John Fund, an editorial writer for The Wall Street Journal who described himself as the panel's token conservative. "Maybe it doesn't go any further than that. But I think a conversation is definitely starting."
The conversation on Wednesday was a somewhat chaotic one that veered from guns to V-chips to one audience member's question about whether it was an immoral act to be a guest on the Bob Grant or Don Imus radio shows.
The other panelists were the actor, producer and director Stanley Tucci; the television producer Linda Ellerbee; Deborah A. Forte, executive vice president of Scholastic Entertainment; the director and writer Peter Bogdanovich; Dr. Alvin F. Poussaint, a psychiatrist at Harvard Medical School, and the lawyer Martin Garbus.
Dr. Poussaint said there was "overwhelming evidence" that violence in the media had real-world reverberations.
"Like air pollution, it affects the most vulnerable part of society -- it's like asthma," he said. The problem, he said, is the "lethal mix" of guns, violence, other social ills and a society drenched in violent media.
But Mr. Garbus and others said that there was no way to censor violence in the media except through self-censorship by people in news and entertainment.
Much of the conversation turned to curbing guns rather than curbing violence in the media, with several of the panel members, particularly Mr. Garbus and Mr. Bogdanovich, questioning the practicality in today's world of the Second Amendment's protection of private ownership of firearms.
Amid the gun sparring, there were condemnations of the degree to which violence has become an accepted part of the entertainment mix. Mr. Tucci lamented the disparity in resources between the small, personal films he tries to make and the shoot-'em-up blockbusters that open on thousands of multiplex screens each week.
Mr. Bogdanovich compared the megatonnage of violence in modern films with the understated use of it in the Fritz Lang film "M," in which Peter Lorre plays a child murderer. He said that the 1931 film, with its off-screen violence and chilling, dramatic staging (a child's ball rolling out from behind a bush, a balloon flying into the air), was far more powerful and effective than the explicitly bloody movies of today.
Still, as the actor William Baldwin, one of the co-hosts of the gathering, pointed out, it will be hard to change the situation as long as there is an economic incentive for violence-drenched blockbusters.
"It's called show business, and the operative word is business," said Mr. Baldwin, president of the Creative Coalition.
Even given American society's short attention span, Dr. Poussaint said, there is something striking about the current mood.
"The difference between Columbine and other events is that it's about white suburban kids," he said. "We have 21,000 homicides a year in this country, but this time we can't say it's ghetto kids, it's poor kids, it's single-parent households. We can't explain it away in the usual ways."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Adding Affordable 3-Family Homes to Bedford-Stuyvesant Mix

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
By the middle of the month, two mostly vacant blocks in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn will begin to fill with a housing type so far absent from the neighborhood's revival: 45 three-family homes for people with annual incomes of $30,000 to $70,000.
The houses, with a total of 135 units, will rise on the blocks off Saratoga Avenue between Sumpter and Fulton Streets, near the Broadway commercial corridor in the Saratoga urban renewal area. Since 1996, the area, generally bounded by Bainbridge and Fulton Streets and Rockaway and Ralph Avenues, has been the focus of publicly assisted housing for low- and moderate-income families, with 238 two-family residences completed and 459 houses, mostly two-family, under way or planned. 
 The $15 million three-family home project, E. I. Key Maple Gardens at Saratoga Square, brings a higher-density project to the area. At each of the houses, the owner gets one apartment and rents out the others to help pay the monthly mortgage. The development is named in part for Eula Irene Key, a community advocate.
Three-family homes have been successful in the Bronx and in other parts of Brooklyn since they were included in 1993 as part of the city's New Homes program, which provides subsidies to keep homes affordable. But they have been slow to take hold in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
L & M Equity Participants Ltd. of Larchmont, N.Y., which developed five three-family home projects in the Bronx, was willing to test the concept in Bedford-Stuyvesant with Maple Gardens. The company, whose principals are Sanford Loewentheil and Ronald Moelis, is developing the project with Loewen Development of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Chase Community Development Corporation, a subsidiary of Chase Manhattan Bank, is providing a $9 million construction loan.
Mr. Loewentheil said the partners were betting that they could repeat their success in the Bronx with Maple Gardens. "To insure the marketability of the Bronx houses, we included 900- to 1,000-square-foot basements, and dressed them up architecturally to entice buyers," he said, adding that those elements would be in the Brooklyn homes.
The homes, designed by Danois Architects of Manhattan, will have brown brick facades with a limestone base and feature bay windows, recalling details found in the neighborhood's brownstones. They will also have front and rear yards, a one-car driveway and a duplex apartment and two single-level units.
The 1,500-square-foot duplex, on the first floor and half of the second, will have three bedrooms and a 900-square-foot basement for the owner. A 500-square-foot one-bedroom rental completes the second floor, and a 1,000-square-foot two-bedroom unit will occupy the third floor. Rents are expected to be $500 to $900 a month.
The project is part of the city's New Homes program, whose sponsors include the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development and the nonprofit New York City Housing Partnership. The city and the state each provided a subsidy per house of $30,000 and $37,500 respectively. But to make the project work, the offices of the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, and City Councilwoman Tracy L. Boyland, each added $9,000. The total subsidy -- $85,500 for each house -- lowers the sale price to $238,000.
"The three-family home is a good model in certain areas of Brooklyn," said Greg Brooks, Mr. Golden's chief of staff, noting that it allowed "more people of moderate means to rent as well as a wider income band of interested purchasers to buy."
Of the 127 three-family homes built elsewhere in Brooklyn under the city's New Homes program, 107 make up the Village at Atlantic Center. It is the housing component, ultimately to include 32 more such homes, of the mixed-used Atlantic Center project being developed near the Long Island Rail Road terminal in the Fort Greene section.
Because it is "more difficult to develop in the Saratoga area, we wanted to test the market," Mr. Brooks said. "The homes built proved to be successful, so we are looking at other housing models, like three-family houses."
One advantage of the three-family houses, said Veronica M. White, president of the Housing Partnership, is that "they enable us to provide more houses on the same plot of land." From a planning perspective, three-family homes work in areas where transportation and shopping are available, Ms. White said, noting that Maple Gardens was near a new 20,000-square-foot retail center at Fulton Street and Ralph Avenue.
But they are more expensive to develop, she said, and added that "we were able to leap from two- to three-family homes in the Saratoga area because the state, city, borough and City Council came together to provide the subsidies." The hope is to do more, she said, pointing out that four other three-family-home projects, totaling more than 300 units, were planned in Brooklyn.
Other factors in keeping Maple Gardens affordable, Mr. Loewentheil said, are that the project received a tax abatement from the city that will keep taxes low for 20 years, and fixed-rate mortgages with 5 percent down payments will be offered through Chase. The Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, also underwrites the mortgages to allow buyers to count 60 percent of the rental income toward their monthly mortgage payments.
The developer will provide a $5,000 rebate to help buyers with closing costs, and Chase will provide $6,000, Mr. Loewentheil said, so that buyers then will need $11,900 for a down payment. He estimates that the monthly cost to own the home will be about $1,900, which with the apartment rents, totaling about $1,400, could be cut to $500.
Orville G. Brathwaite, director of Neighborhood Housing Services of Bedford-Stuyvesant and the community sponsor for Maple Gardens, said, "It's the area's first three-family home project, but we're thinking it's the way we need to go in new construction."
Mr. Loewentheil said sales of the homes would begin when construction started in mid-July, with completion to follow 18 months later. He said the partners intended to start work next year on a second three-family home project, with 40 houses, in Crown Heights in Brooklyn.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
A Bad Year for the World's Border Guards

BYLINE: By TINA ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
Among its other casualties, the war in Kosovo punctured the sanctity of state sovereignty -- the idea that a nation's actions within its borders are its own business. This concept has organized international relations since the Treaty of Westphalia in 1648. That year, as Europe's religious empires crumbled, the Continent's powerful states agreed to respect each other's sovereignty, founding the modern state system. That has now been eroding for 50 years, but the events of the past year have been a blow like no other, and one that should be welcomed. 
 Sovereignty's worst day in memory was undoubtedly March 24. NATO began bombing Serbia, probably the first multinational attack designed primarily to stop violations of international law within a country's borders. The same day, England's high court ruled that London could send Augusto Pinochet to Spain to be tried for crimes in Chile, as both European countries had signed an international convention promising to prosecute torturers, no matter where their crimes took place.
Then on May 27, the war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia announced a warrant for the arrest of Slobodan Milosevic. It was the first indictment of a sitting head of state for violations of international law. A year ago, 120 nations, not including the United States, signed a treaty establishing an international criminal court, in which international law trumps national sovereignty.
While sovereignty has been fading since the end of World War II, until recently governments have in general ceded powers voluntarily. European nations have voted their way into defense, political and monetary unions. Globalization has been bringing down economic borders, but whether to open up has been a nation's choice, although one influenced by substantial economic pressure. Peacekeepers and election observers are found around the world, but they do not arrive without the blessing of their hosts.
This year's attacks on sovereignty had widespread approval, but not from Mr. Milosevic or Mr. Pinochet. That is a shift toward respecting a nation's sovereignty only when it respects the rights of its people as international law defines them.
That idea has been growing since the end of World War II. The Nuremberg tribunal introduced the concept that leaders' treatment of their own people was subject to international prosecution. The United Nations -- organized around sovereignty -- also created one of the most important tools for the assault on sovereignty today, the 1948 Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Nations also signed the Geneva Conventions and a treaty promising to punish genocide carried out anywhere in the world. These laws were never enforced because cold-war politics intervened.
Now there are the first stirrings of enforcement. Mr. Pinochet's Government had signed the Torture Convention that nabbed him. The international criminal court will apply laws endorsed by nearly every country. The war crimes tribunals for the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda were established by the United Nations and have been fair. The Yugoslav tribunal has prosecuted Serbs, Croats and Muslims.
NATO's bombing of Serbia was based on the same principle -- enforcing respect for international law. But many people all over the world did not perceive it that way. Because the bombing was not done under U.N. auspices, theories abounded that Washington was really trying to establish hegemony in the Balkans or assure the flow of Caspian basin oil.
The war did not get U.N. Security Council approval because Russia and China called NATO's motives not universal, but political. The brief period of world consensus on the limits of sovereignty is closing precisely because the notion has come far enough to scare many nations. Russia worries it will be criticized or even invaded for its abuses in Chechnya, and China has the same defensiveness over its behavior in Tibet.
The bombing of Serbia was indeed based on political considerations. Yugoslavia is in Europe, the abuses were on CNN, and it is a weak country where quick and effective intervention seemed likely. That this human rights crisis was chosen for intervention over others, however, does not make the intervention less necessary or legitimate. The weight of political considerations, moreover, shows why Russia and China need not fear similar treatment.
Absolute respect for sovereignty, of course, was even more political than the challenge to it posed today. The remarkable development is that some of the actions of the past year have managed to rise above politics. Power politics will always rule international affairs. But the last 50 years have seen the rise of universally endorsed principles of conduct. The extent to which the world chooses to respect them, even when they conflict with sovereignty, is a good measure of civilization's progress.
