HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Saving Public Colleges

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
For weeks, I have had the most important report on the most important university in the life and future of New York City. But I did not read it. I just glared at it.
The cover put me off, hard -- "The City University of New York: An Institution Adrift." Another attack on the publicly financed college that led me to work I have loved ever since? Who needs it? 
 My City College was an intellectually and academically elite school attended by students with family income ranging from not much to very not much. Eventually it was grouped legislatively with 16 other senior and community colleges into the City University of New York -- which now carries the hopes of the 200,000 students who attend it.
I knew CUNY has had deep faults and problems since it opened the doors to all high school graduates in 1969. Academically it has all the cachet of a herring.
I also knew that the color palette of the student body has changed from almost entirely white to 72 percent other shades. For most of their families, CUNY was the first college, and blessed.
I resented the nastiness of the criticism of CUNY, like Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's advice to the students to learn how to work. Try working for food, clothes, carfare at night while working for graduation credits by day. You just won't have the energy left for polo.
When I did read the report after a few weeks, the glare disappeared. This is a report written under the leadership of Herman Badillo, recently appointed chairman of CUNY by the Mayor, and Benno Schmidt Jr., former president of Yale.
My eyes softened when I realized the goal was not to eliminate CUNY or shrink it -- as some students and teachers fear -- but to restore some of its academic glisten, so graduates would again help lead the city and profit from its economic growth.
For me, the most valuable qualities of the report were three varieties of respect. Perhaps the most important: the tone of belief in what students could do for themselves and the city if CUNY gave them the dignity of higher goals of achievements, not the sub-college standards that are good enough now.
Second, the respect of pledging "absolute commitment" to CUNY's "historic organizational mission" to provide first-rate college opportunities for all New Yorkers academically able to take advantage of them.
Third: proposals to help those not ready because of the failure of New York's elementary and high school system to teach so many students more than a humiliatingly low level of writing, reading and arithmetic.
The most important step is the first step: to establish and help students reach acceptable goals not only in college but before they enter it.
Almost all American colleges provide remedial courses. But CUNY's load and the lack of standards of remedial achievement for the college bound drag down CUNY with too many students unqualified for higher education. The report proposes that remedial classes be held not in the four-year senior colleges but in the community colleges, and that passing them must be the requirement for senior colleges -- with national standard entry tests to come.
The way things are in New York, the elementary and high school system often prepares students for failure in college. The report proposes widening the emergency remedy now in some schools: CUNY teachers using summers and other free time for tutorials in reading, writing and mathematics in high schools and the late grades of elementary schools.
That will cost money -- about $10 million -- and so will other proposals. The end of "social promotion" in elementary schools, a cockamamie, basically political idea, shoves all students on to the next grade, ready or not. Technological unification for planning throughout CUNY, a kind of remediation for management.
Writing an important report is difficult; getting the money out of politicians for achievement, not stagnation, that's really hard.
They must remember that when CUNY opened its doors wide in 1969, it did not switch its goals from achievement to mediocrity and failure. Open enrollment has worked out for those who had qualifications, not for those who did not. This report is not an attack on public higher education, but the opposite -- an effort to improve and protect it.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Rangers Fly Off for the Free-Agent Frenzy

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE 

 BODY:
Neil Smith and Dave Checketts began their jet-propelled shopping spree yesterday, seeking free agents to bolster the Rangers' roster. They took the company plane to Winnipeg to negotiate with Don Baizley, the agent for right wing Theo Fleury. Their next stop was suburban Los Angeles to talk to Pat Brisson, the agent for defenseman Stephane Quintal. They were considering another touchdown in California to see Jeff Solomon, the agent for center Bob Corkum.
Smith, the president and general manager of the Rangers, and Checketts, his boss as the president of Madison Square Garden, could accelerate the salary inflation in the National Hockey League through their checkbook roster-building. But that is not their major concern. For the past two seasons, the Garden has been dark for the hockey playoffs, when many teams make their most money. Smith and Checketts need a quick fix of talent to restart that revenue stream. 
 "They cannot permit themselves to miss the playoffs three years in a row," Brisson said from his office in Santa Monica, Calif., as he awaited their arrival.
Unlike Fleury and most other top-name free agents, Quintal, Brisson's client, is not a Group 3 player who is over age 31 with an expired contract. He is only 30 but is free because his contract ended with him making less than the league average salary after 10 seasons as a profession. Quintal earned $900,000 last season with Montreal, about $400,000 below the league average. His category is Group 5.
Fleury ended the season in Colorado, and Corkum played for Phoenix.
Brisson said that several teams -- among them Toronto -- called him yesterday as the free-agent season officially opened. Although Brisson would not be specific about Quintal's salary requests, he said that $15 million over five seasons might be "in the ball park." He added that Quintal could enjoy playing in New York.
"The Rangers would definitely be a team he is interested in," Brisson said. "They are looking for someone to replace Jeff Beukeboom." A veteran defenseman, Beukeboom suffered post-concussion syndrome last season and his future is in doubt.
Quintal is a right-handed shooter who plays the right side. As such, he might make a logical partner for Brian Leetch, the team captain, a left-handed shooter who plays the left side.
N.H.L. salaries have increased substantially in the 1990's, as has the size of the league. There were 21 clubs in 1991; there will be 28 next season and 30 in 2000-1. The average salary in 1993-94 was $558,000. That autumn, the N.H.L. commissioner, Gary Bettman, ordered a lockout that lasted 15 weeks to get a collective bargaining agreement with terms intended to hold down the rate of salary growth. Last season, the average salary was about $1.3 million. The collective bargaining agreement has been extended until the summer of 2004.
Although the union made several major concessions to end the lockout, the players and their agents seemed satisfied with the one major tradeoff in their favor: the freedom for veterans like Fleury to move without restriction. Fleury is expected to request a contract paying him between $8 million and $10 million a season for several years. Paul Kariya of Anaheim, a left wing who was a restricted Group 2 free agent, agreed to a three-year contract this week that is expected to pay him about $10 million a season.
Since the new collective bargaining agreement, the Rangers have had mixed success with free agents. Their major acquisitions were Wayne Gretzky, Mike Keane and Brian Skrudland. Gretzky played three seasons, with diminishing returns, at high salary -- $6 million last season. Keane and Skrudland were traded to Dallas after less than a full season. However, the Rangers have had success in signing their own free agents who could have left. Leetch and Adam Graves signed before the July 1 deadline; Mike Richter returned last season after signing last summer.
 
SLAP SHOTS
JIM DEMARIA, a spokesman for the Chicago Blackhawks, expressed skepticism yesterday about published reports that his team would trade DOUG GILMOUR, the veteran center, to the Rangers. DeMaria said team management was happy with Gilmour, signed last summer as a free agent, and was not shopping him.

HEADLINE: Randolph Guggenheimer, 91; Saved Hospital

BYLINE: By ENID NEMY 

 BODY:
Randolph Guggenheimer, a Manhattan lawyer who helped spearhead the development of a community hospital serving the residents of Harlem, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91.
When the Hospital for Joint Diseases moved from Madison Avenue and 124th Street in 1979, Mr. Guggenheimer and Eugene L. McCabe, a management consultant, worked together to insure that hospital services would continue in the old building, which was renamed North General Hospital. 
 Mr. Guggenheimer had been a board member of the Hospital for Joint Diseases, but he opposed the decision to move because he believed very strongly that Harlem needed a hospital. "I thought, 'I'm a New Yorker, I was born in New York, I love the city, and there is nothing there but Harlem Hospital, which is insufficient,' " he said.
Financial crises threatened North General's existence several times, and at one early point, the National Health and Human Services Employees Union asked its members to continue working despite a missed pay period. Mr. McCabe and Mr. Guggenheimer recruited public officials, philanthropists, bankers, leaders of major medical institutions and local businessmen to take care of the foundering hospital's unpaid bills and to raise both money and standards.
Both Mr. Guggenheimer, who served as the hospital's only trustee for a time, and Mr. McCabe were tireless in pursuing funds, and helped to engineer a New York State bond issue of $150 million for a new building that would serve the impoverished and medically deprived area. At the time, many small community hospitals, overwhelmed with the unexpected demands of AIDS patients and crack addicts, were being closed.
"It didn't make financial sense," said Mario M. Cuomo, who as Governor of New York approved many of the grants and loans to build North General. Mr. Cuomo described the hospital's creation as "a miracle."
The state called the rebuilding of the hospital "the largest public-private construction project in the history of Harlem." In 1991, the new 200-bed North General, the only minority-operated hospital in the state, opened its doors at Madison Avenue between 121st and 122d Streets. The nonprofit hospital specializes in treatment for diabetes, cancer and hypertension.
Several years later, the institution added 300 units of condominium housing for low- and middle-income residents of Harlem.
Both Mr. Guggenheimer and Mr. McCabe took pride in the fact that the new building was completed for some $15 million less than the amount of their state bond financing.
"When we called up the state and asked what we should do with the surplus money, they didn't know what to say," Mr. Guggenheimer once recalled. "It had never happened before. They finally told us to keep it to avoid complications." The money was used to build an annex.
Mr. McCabe was president of the hospital and Mr. Guggenheimer was board chairman, a position he held for some years. He maintained an office in the hospital until his death. An annual award in his name was established by the trustees in 1998, to be given to a member of the hospital staff for excellence in community service. Mr. Guggenheimer received the United Hospital Annual Distinguished Trustee of the Year award and, in 1991, was honored by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Mr. McCabe died of cancer at the age of 61 in September 1998,
In his dedication to Harlem, Mr. Guggenheimer followed the example of his mother, Minna Schafer Guggenheimer, who from 1918 to 1964 produced the annual summer concerts at Lewisohn Stadium on the City College campus. The concert series was a diamond in the New York cultural scene for years, bringing major performers to the neighborhood at admission fees of less than a dollar. Lewisohn Stadium was torn down in 1966, two years after Mrs. Guggenheimer's death.
Randolph Guggenheimer was born in Manhattan on Nov. 14, 1907. His father, Charles S. Guggenheimer, was a partner in Guggenheimer & Untermyer, a law firm his own father had founded.
Minna Guggenheimer, a philanthropist known to New Yorkers as Minnie, raised money, engaged artists and handled negotiations for the stadium concerts. She attended most of them, and was famous for her informality and completely uninhibited intermission speeches. On one occasion, a royal guest got lost and wandered into the wings as he was about to be introduced. Mrs. Guggenheimer chased after him, yelling, "Here, Prince! Here, Prince!"
Mr. Guggenheimer was educated at the Morristown Preparatory Academy in New Jersey and received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale University in 1928. He graduated from Harvard Law School in 1931, joined the family law firm and later became a partner. In 1932 he married the former Elinor Coleman. She has been a member of the City Planning Commission and Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, and was a founder of several national and international women's organizations.
Mr. Guggenheimer enlisted in the United States Air Force in 1942 and served as executive officer of a fighter squadron in Europe during World War II.
Through the years, he was active in a number of organizations, including the Jewish Child Care Association and the Mount Sinai Hospital School of Nursing.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by two sons, Charles and Randolph Jr., and a sister, Sophie Untermeyer, all of Manhattan, three grandchildren and six great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Albany's Vacation From Inaction

 BODY:
New York's state government has taken gridlock to a new level. Budgets in Albany used to be delayed until some other critical deadline forced an agreement. But now even those triggers are not enough to make things work. On Wednesday night, cuts in the state Medicaid program lapsed, sticking the state and localities with tens of millions of dollars in unexpected bills. Protections for New York City loft tenants expired, terrifying many long-term residents with limited incomes. But nothing happened. The Legislature went away for a vacation and a "cooling off" period. 
 Although Gov. George Pataki's staff sometimes jokes that the state would save money running on emergency appropriations forever, these delays are unsupportable. In New York City, the schools are playing a dangerous but unavoidable game by presuming that money for new prekindergarten programs and reduced-size classes in September will eventually be approved, and risking financial catastrophe if it is not. Other school districts are trying to prepare their tax bills in a void.
Lately, the Legislature and Mr. Pataki seemed to have reached the point that a more functional government would have got to in early spring. A final budget agreement seemed near, perhaps in time to break the logjam and pass other critical time-sensitive legislation. But talks collapsed over the issue of Medicaid. The Legislature had approved rather stiff cuts in the state's reimbursement program to hospitals and nursing homes in 1995, and Mr. Pataki had proposed new economies this year. The state's largest hospital workers' union, led by Dennis Rivera, has been running harsh ads against Mr. Pataki, portraying him as an enemy of the old and the disabled.
The state should not be making a new assault on the health care system at a time when New York's hospitals are already under siege by the Federal Government and H.M.O.'s. Mr. Pataki may have already given up on his new cost-cutting agenda. But if he has not, he should do so quickly. The Democratic Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, is pressing for an end to the old cuts as well. He should not try to turn back the clock. Controlling Medicaid costs has always been important in a state where the bill for treating the health care needs of the poor is enormous and ever-expanding.
But if it takes some reasonable concessions to get a budget deal done, Mr. Pataki should compromise as a gesture of good will. Right now the old cuts have expired anyway, pleasing the hospitals but burdening the state with $82 million in unexpected costs over the next three months alone. Local governments will have to pay about $50 million extra. The meter is running.
Stopping the pay of state legislators when they fail to pass a budget on time does not seem to have worked. They have not got their salaries since April, but most of them seem more cranky than cowed. Mr. Pataki, whose bad relationship with Mr. Silver is central to the impasse, still gets his salary. But he should perhaps be barred from making any more out-of-state speaking trips to brag about New York's fiscal achievements until the state has a functioning budget.

HEADLINE: Report Says U.S. Manufacturing Is GrowingWith No End in Sight

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The United States manufacturing sector grew in June for the fifth consecutive month, and a rising backlog of orders at factories indicates that growth should continue, according to a survey of executives released yesterday.
The National Association of Purchasing Management, which represents executives who buy raw materials and supplies for manufacturers, said 16 of 20 industries had reported increases in business. 
 "Both production and new orders exhibited significant growth when compared to May," said Norbert J. Ore, head of the trade group's survey committee.
The purchasing managers' report is closely watched because it gives economists, including Federal Reserve officials, the first reading on how the manufacturing sector and in turn the overall economy fared in the previous month.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said that construction spending, one of the economy's strongest sectors, fell in May for a second consecutive month. Construction is slowing in part because mortgage rates have been rising.
The report said construction spending dropped nine-tenths of a percent in May after falling 2 percent in April. Decreases were reported in single-family homes, apartment buildings, hotels and motels as well as in big government construction projects, it said.
The purchasing managers said their monthly index of business activity rose to 57 percent in June from 55.2 percent in May. It was a much stronger showing than the 54.4 percent that analysts had expected.
A reading above 50 percent in the index indicates that the manufacturing economy is expanding. The index has been climbing since a prolonged downturn ended in February.
The group said its separate price index reached 53.5 percent in June, above the 50 percent mark for the second consecutive month and indicating that the costs of raw materials continue to increase. The index rose to 52.2 percent in May, the first time since December 1997 that manufacturers indicated they were paying higher prices for raw materials.
A majority of those surveyed said new orders were stronger or remained at May levels, while 13 percent said they were lower.
Just 16 percent reported a reduced backlog of orders.
Gary Thayer, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc. in St. Louis, said the purchasing report signaled that "there's still a very healthy economy" and "without any real problems in the pipeline."

HEADLINE: Approval for Nominee to Top Treasury Post

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 1

 BODY:
Lawrence Summers won Senate approval today to become Treasury Secretary, promising to follow the economic course set by Robert E. Rubin.
The Senate voted 97 to 2 in favor of Mr. Summers, President Clinton's choice to replace Mr. Rubin. The vote clears the way for Mr. Summers to take over after four years as Mr. Rubin's deputy. 
 Mr. Rubin could step down as early as Friday.
During the confirmation process, Mr. Summers won overwhelming support from Republicans and Democrats by promising to carry on Mr. Rubin's pro-market and strong-dollar policies.
But lawmakers say Mr. Summers, a 44-year-old former Harvard University professor, has his work cut out for him.
The world's second-largest economy, Japan, is struggling to recover from recession, and growth in Europe is sluggish.
At home, Mr. Summers faces wrangling over Mr. Clinton's tax and trade policies, and Mr. Summers's role in International Monetary Fund bailouts for Russia and other nations caught up in global financial turmoil.
Two Republicans, Wayne Allard of Colorado and Robert Smith of New Hampshire, voted against Mr. Summers.
But opposition melted away for fear that foot-dragging by Congress would unnerve financial markets.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: KOSOVO NOTEBOOK;
Milosevic's Vision of Glory Unleashed Decade of Ruin

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: KOSOVO POLJE, Kosovo, June 25

 BODY:
On the eve of the NATO bombing of Serbia, Slobodan Milosevic turned to the American envoys facing him. "You are a superpower," he said. "You can do what you want. If you want to say Sunday is Wednesday, you can. It is all up to you."
Christopher Hill, one of the officials present, was struck by the words because they seemed to capture the fatalism of the Yugoslav President as he led his people to the abyss. "It was a form of the old Serbian megalomania," Mr. Hill, the American Ambassador to Macedonia, observed, "the one that says you can destroy us, but we will be right." 
 Three months and tens of thousands of NATO sorties later, that destruction is evident in this ragged central Kosovo town where the bleary Serbian faces speak of a sea change in the Balkan equation: A decade after Mr. Milosevic envisioned it here in a speech that whipped up Serbian nationalism and helped cement his power, Greater Serbia is dead.
In its place, a new group of largely ethnically homogeneous states has emerged, with the help of Mr. Milosevic's consistent brutality from Vukovar in Croatia through the Bosnian capital, Sarajevo, to Kosovo towns like Djakovica and Pec.
Mr. Milosevic has been the midwife of his enemies' ascendancy. His tactics of mass killing and eviction of civilians have helped forge a separate Croatia, a new Bosnian Muslim identity and now an embryonic Albanian nation state in Kosovo. Serbia, meanwhile, one of the first Balkan nation states to emerge in the 19th century, is still casting around for stable borders, unable to resolve the dilemma of how to unite Serbs in one country now that the old Yugoslavia is dead.
Greater Serbia -- a land that would incorporate traditional Serb-populated swaths of Croatia and Bosnia -- was Mr. Milosevic's answer to that problem. Now, the rise of Albanian nationalism in Kosovo and the Balkans as a whole has prompted concern in the West. A Greater Albania -- embracing Albania, Kosovo and the western part of Macedonia whose population is heavily Albanian -- is the avowed goal of some Kosovo Liberation Army fighters.
"We spent the 1990's worrying about a Greater Serbia," Mr. Hill said. "That's finished. We are going to spend time well into the next century worrying about a Greater Albania."
Of course, Greater Serbia was always a project pursued with ruthless violence. There is no evidence that Albania has similar will or might. But the buoyant ascendancy of the Kosovo Liberation Army is unmistakable, and some of the weapons it wields come from the military arsenals of Albania that were looted during the country's descent into economic mayhem in spring 1997.
Unlike Bosnia, Kosovo has no model of a multiethnic state, and Pristina has none of the cultural openness that marked Sarajevo. The remnants of peaceful coexistence here were snuffed out in the last two decades; first, the Albanian majority wielded power, then Mr. Milosevic stripped away that autonomy, and his police ruled Kosovo harshly for the last decade. This history will complicate and continually undermine one of NATO's aims in Kosovo: to allow Serbs and Albanians to live together in peace.
In some ways, the Albanian question is the Serbian question in a broken mirror. Like the Serbs, the Albanians are a people scattered in several countries, harboring a deep sense of historical injustice, marked by a pattern of disunity, still in search of stable contours for their nation and stable institutions to govern it.
Throughout Kosovo, the Albanians' flag flutters on smashed factories and city halls, hoisted there by the young men of the K.L.A. From time to time, NATO patrols pass beneath the flags.
Such scenes could scarcely be more fantastically remote from the nationalist vision offered by Mr. Milosevic a decade ago when he came to Kosovo's Field of Blackbirds -- scene of a Serbian defeat by the Turks in 1389 -- to proclaim a glorious Serbian future, one in which the Serbs -- no longer "humiliated" -- would do battle for their "state, national and spiritual integrity."
The battle has been lost. Defeat is now real, bitter as ash. "Milosevic has used us and betrayed us," said Radovan Delibasic, a Serb from Kosovo Polje. "He came here 10 years ago to inspire us with our history in Kosovo. But we have learned that you cannot live from history. Americans have no history and they live wonderfully well."
 
Homecoming
For One Couple, All Hopes Dashed
 Pec was once a beautiful town, threaded by bright streams, backed by mountains. Like Mostar in Bosnia, and all that was most lovely in the Balkans, it expressed the delicate interweaving of Islamic and Christian architecture and traditions that was the legacy of the Ottoman Empire.
No more. Pec is gone, another Balkan bridge between East and West devoured in one of those paroxysms of destruction that have made charred, shattered ruins the most pervasive symbol of Yugoslavia's demise.
Gjevdt Zajmi and his wife, Ganimete, trudge home, past abandoned gardens with trees full of unpicked cherries, capsized trellises with vines still clinging to them, dead animals and the blackened windows that are the baleful eyes of so much Balkan ruin.
Kosovo Albanians, the Zajmis were driven out on March 28, four days after the NATO bombardment began, by three Serbian paramilitary thugs in black masks. The same old story: from Prijedor in northwestern Bosnia to Prizren in southwestern Kosovo, "ethnic cleansing" has few nuances.
A painful odyssey through a mountain village, Montenegro and finally Albania ensued, before this return. "We know everything has gone from the house, but we hope the house is still there," Mr. Zajmi says.
As they turn into their street, however, hope evaporates. Ganimete Zajmi takes in the scene and says simply: "Vukovar."
The death of Yugoslavia has now been sufficiently drawn-out for certain acts, like the Serbian obliteration of the mixed Croatian town of Vukovar in 1991, to pass into popular lore. Mrs. Zajmi is right: The ruin is as unmitigated as in the town on the Danube.
The house was built 30 years ago. The couple's three children were raised in it. The family planted the cherry tree that shades the area behind what was the kitchen. Shared memories, a life, really, lie in pieces in the rubble, and the thought of all this abruptly causes the couple to break down in sobs.
"The Serbs were killing before," Mr. Zajmi, a mild man who worked in an engineering plant, said. "But when NATO came, they went wild, screaming that we all had to leave. Only independence is possible now. Nothing else."
Walking back toward the center of town, they encounter a friend, Alma Dreshaj. She is one of few ethnic Albanians to have remained in Pec throughout the NATO bombing, protected, as she explains, by a kind Serb neighbor, Slavo Dedovic.
Two men pass and overhear her words. They turn on her in rage. "There are no good Serbs," one screams. "How can you say such a thing? They send our children to have their throats cut, and you talk of a good Serb." He seems on the verge of striking Ms. Dreshaj, but is restrained by the other man.
As the time for negotiation ran out last March and Mr. Hill explained that NATO would begin bombing, Mr. Milosevic shot back at him: "Anyone who does that -- bomb -- is going to spend the rest of his life on a psychiatric couch."
Once again, Mr. Hill found the words extraordinary, coming from a man who has appeared so consistently destructive.
The symbolism was apparently more important than the substance. Just as the Serbs were ready to go to war in 1914 for the principle that no Austro-Hungarian police be allowed onto their territory to investigate the murder in Sarajevo of the Hapsburg heir Archduke Franz Ferdinand, so they would fight -- even suicidally -- to stop a NATO deployment.
During the bombing, the Serbian leader tried every ploy to stop the bombardment -- making mischief with the Russians, co-opting the mild-mannered Albanian intellectual Ibrahim Rugova, destabilizing Macedonia, dividing the allies by playing on Serbian sympathies in Greece and Italy.
But he also did the one thing -- the brutal eviction and killing of Albanians -- that kept Western public opinion solidly behind the 78-day bombing and cemented the alliance.
"It is a real question whether, in the absence of the ethnic cleansing, NATO would have been able to keep it up after a couple of weeks," a Western official said. "In a sense, his brutality saved the alliance."
It was a serious misjudgment by Mr. Milosevic, one that led directly to the Western protectorate that masks and in some ways promotes the provisional Albanian government by the K.L.A. in Kosovo today, and also, perhaps, could lead to his downfall.
Those who have seen Mr. Milosevic recently -- including Mr. Hill; Gen. Wesley K. Clark, the commander of NATO forces in Europe, and the Swedish financier Peter Castenfelt -- have found him extraordinarily out of touch, surrounded by mediocre aides, living in a world of complete unreality.
"Milosevic kept saying to me, 'We just need seven days to wipe out the Kosovo Liberation Army,' " said General Clark. "He absolutely failed to see that this kind of movement does not work that way."
Before the war, Mr. Hill informed the Yugoslav President of Serbian atrocities he had observed in the Kosovo town of Malisevo, including paramilitary forces systematically burning Albanian homes and stores.
Mr. Milosevic looked upset. He stood up, put his hands in his pockets and started pacing. Mr. Hill recalls him saying: "There is no excuse for that, even if the Serbs in Kosovo are very angry. I accept responsibility. One of the most important tasks of a democracy is to protect its minorities."
This sort of discourse has been part of Mr. Milosevic's rule for 12 years. For in the end, his survival can be explained only by his extraordinary ability to convince many Serbs that they are victims, that others are to blame for all that has befallen them.
But the reality of Yugoslavia's breakup and Mr. Milosevic's legacy is today a hard one: While Slovenia, Croatia and probably now Kosovo have carved ethnic states out of the ruins, the land of the Serbs continues to shrink. On the Field of Blackbirds, a French parachute regiment has deployed, but most Serbs are too poor, isolated and misinformed to care.
 
The Serbs
Another Migration May Fuel a Myth
Hundreds of Serbs now huddle at the Patriarchate of Pec, the old Serbian church with frescoes that speak of the great flowering of medieval Serbian civilization.
Their cars are lined up, ready to leave for good if and when Italian NATO forces in Pec are ready to escort them out.
"We have been here for 700 years, and now NATO bombs and the Albanians have driven us out," said Dragutin Martinovic, the director of a factory. And what of the rampage against Albanians' homes? "All the homes were destroyed by NATO bombs," Mr. Martinovic said. "We did nothing."
There is a terrible sadness in the sight of all these Serbs slumped over old stones on the grounds of their church, their bundles beside them, awaiting some new migration in the long Serbian history of migrations.
More than 300 years ago, in 1689, Patriarch Arsenije led tens of thousands of Serbs north and west from Pec to escape the Turks in a flight that has become part of Serbian myth.
The themes of such myth remain unchanged -- long suffering, heroic isolation, irrational valor, victories in defeat. Perhaps the Kosovo debacle will now be added to the panoply of heroism and suffering.
But unchanged, too, it seems, after 12 years of Mr. Milosevic's rule, is the inability to make these myths coincide with a reality that is stable rather than one that is merely destructive and self-destructive because it exists principally to preserve Mr. Milosevic's power.
When Mr. Milosevic came to Kosovo a decade ago and spoke to hundreds of thousands of Serbs gathered in a celebration of rediscovered post-Communist identity, his inspiration was a battle lost by the Serbs to the Ottoman Turks but later turned into a beacon of Serbian national redemption through defeat because it marked the start of the Serbs' successful struggle to preserve their Orthodox faith during centuries of Islamic rule by the Turks.
"For the time, with Communism collapsing, it was a clever speech that Milosevic made to us in 1989," said Jovo Popovic, a former president of the Pec Town Council who was among those waiting to leave. "He said we deserved glory because from the Turks to Tito, we had suffered injustice. As for the speech's effects, however, just look around you."
Gen. Mauro del Vecchio, the Italian general commanding NATO troops in Pec, believes these "effects" can still be reversed. "We will not take Serbs out," he said. "In fact, we are escorting them back from Montenegro. We cannot allow one form of ethnic hatred to replace another now that the Albanians are back."
His sentiments are noble enough. But the future of Kosovo seems to lie more in the determined expression of Ramiz Norici, who left his restaurant in the Bronx to fight for the Kosovo Liberation Army in his native Pec.
"We are the legal army of a soon-to-be-independent Kosovo," he said, squatting by the ruins of his family's home. "The Serbs have always killed us. Why should we trust them now?"
 
The Future
Can West's Plan Bring Stability?
In effect, because the West waited for years to decide that Mr. Milosevic was at the heart of the problem in the Balkans, it has ended up trying to build a Western model in one of the corners of the Balkans where multiethnicity and tolerance are least conspicuous. The West is also building on the victory of what amounts to an Albanian peasant uprising led by orphaned Marxists and a motley crew of others.
But these are heady times in the Balkans. They bring Javier Solana, the Secretary General of NATO, to dismal Pristina to be mobbed in the streets and to say, "We want to include this area in the beautiful house of Europe, a place of tolerance, looking to the past rather than the future."
His words reflect a unanimous Western decision to invest heavily in the Balkans and to try, after many years, to treat the problems of Yugoslavia's destruction in an overall rather than a piecemeal manner and so extend the zone of European stability southeastward. But can it work?
"It has to work," Mr. Hill said. "Balkan fatigue in Western nations is at an extreme level. We are all sick of it and we know this is the last chance."
In Bosnia, both Mr. Milosevic and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia were made partners in the Dayton accords that ended the war they had helped to prosecute, despite records of atrocities committed by both their forces. Now the West has changed tack in a way that suggests it means business in the Balkans, and has stated straightforwardly that Mr. Milosevic must go.
But the residue of eight years of destruction is bitter indeed and the moderate center in Kosovo hard to find.
Mr. Rugova has been marginalized. Another moderate, Fehmi Agani, has been murdered by the Serbs. The victory of the Kosovo Liberation Army has been the victory of Drenica farmers and expatriate hard-liners over the urban intellectuals of Albanian society in Kosovo. It has been a victory of the independence-then-perhaps-democracy school over the few who held that democracy should come first.
"Albanian history is in many ways the history of clans and families and an inability to establish relationships, loyalties or institutions beyond them," a Western official said.
Much turns on whether the K.L.A. will give up all its weapons to NATO as it has promised to do.
General Clark, the NATO commander, believes that the Albanian fighters "are about 70 percent O.K." But he added that there were many hard-liners of whom NATO had to be wary, adding, "We are not out of the woods in this part of the world."
Zeqir, who will not give his last name and calls himself the commander of the 134th brigade of the K.L.A., left his wife and two children in Switzerland to come and fight.
He says he is certain that Western countries will assist Albanians -- but not, it seems, in the way the West envisages. "NATO countries will help us with arms," he says. "That is no problem. I came to fight so that my children could live in one country, together with all Albanians, and know their language and culture."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Was Kosovo World War III?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
A thoughtful reader, Allan Hoving, sent me a note asking an intriguing question: Was Kosovo actually World War III? "O.K., so it was a short one, as world wars go, just 80 days," he wrote. "But think about it: There was genocide by indicted war criminals, and the threat of nuclear war. Nearly every major power was involved -- even China. And historic realignments have emerged. . . . All this without a single allied combat casualty -- not too shabby for a world war." 
 The truth is Kosovo was not comparable to World War I or II. Those wars were earthquakes. But while Kosovo was no earthquake, it was a bolt of lightning that certainly illuminated the new international system we are now in, the system of globalization.
To begin with, the NATO intervention in the Balkans was made possible by the fact that the two great wars in Europe in this century -- the great tribal war between Germany and France, which was at the heart of World Wars I and II, and the cold war between the U.S. and the U.S.S.R. -- had both subsided, erasing the most important and paralyzing divisions and walls in Europe. The German-French entente made NATO intervention to quash the Balkan civil wars possible, and the collapse of the Soviet Union made NATO's intervention deep into the former Soviet sphere of influence permissible.
The falling of walls, and globalization, played another role in this war as well. When the war in Kosovo erupted, several people asked whether it didn't make obsolete my Golden Arches Theory of Conflict Prevention, which pointed out that "No two countries that both had a McDonald's had ever fought a war against each other since they each got their McDonald's." After all, Belgrade had McDonald's, as did every NATO country. My answer was, let's see how the war ends.
Look what happened. As the Pentagon will tell you, air power alone brought this war to a close in 78 days for one reason -- not because NATO made life impossible for the Serb troops in Kosovo (look how much armor they drove out of there), but because NATO made life miserable for the Serb civilians in Belgrade. Belgrade is a modern city integrated with Western Europe, with a population that wants to be part of today's main global trends, from the Internet to economic development, which the presence of McDonald's symbolizes.
Once NATO turned out the lights in Belgrade, and shut down the power grids and the economy, Belgrade's citizens demanded an end to the war. It's that simple. Not only did NATO soldiers not want to die for Kosovo -- neither did the Serbs of Belgrade. They wanted to be part of the world, more than they wanted Kosovo to be part of them. They wanted McDonald's re-opened, much more than they wanted Kosovo re-occupied. So, yes, there is now one exception to the Golden Arches Theory -- an exception that, in the end, only proves how powerful is the rule.
This war also illustrated just how much the world is now dominated by U.S. power. Russia and China, as much as they chafed at this war, were unable to do anything about it. I was in the lobby of NATO's Brussels headquarters last month when I saw a Russian woman journalist there, walking in circles next to the Coke machine, talking on her cell phone in Russian. She reminded me of Russia's troops in Kosovo, trying to assert their identity in a world of pax Americana. But that's why this war also highlighted the backlash brewing against America, which is now referred to as "the capital of global arrogance," not only by Iranians, but by Russians, Chinese and half our NATO allies.
But while there is much that was post-modern about this war, there was something pre-modern as well -- the barbaric mass-murdering and rapes that the Serb military engaged in in Kosovo. This was old-fashioned evil, although even it had a certain bizarre 21st-century twist.
The Serbs quickly realized that U.S. satellites were now so good they could track every mass grave they dug, down to the shovels. "So in the end they were even more brutal," said David Scheffer, the U.S. Ambassador at Large for War Crimes Issues. "The Serbs tried to erase the evidence of their behavior by burning bodies, excavating graves, destroying documents and even abducting Kosovar witnesses and taking them away with them." But modernity may catch up with them, notes Mr. Scheffer, because forensic technology is now so sophisticated: at one mass grave site -- Izbica -- F.B.I. experts have been able to document what happened from scraps of evidence, even though all 155 bodies were removed.
So, no, Kosovo wasn't W.W.III. It didn't change the world, but it has illuminated how much the world has changed.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Budget Bog And What Put Pataki There

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 1

 BODY:
On its face, New York State's long-running budget stalemate is simple enough. Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, wants to cut, while the Democratic Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, wants to add.
The budget is three months overdue, but some day, the Governor, the Speaker and the Republican State Senate leader, Joseph L. Bruno, will agree on a plan of around $73 billion. That is a 14 percent rise over three years, a healthy clip that would ordinarily be enough to keep everyone happy. 
 So why are legislators, especially Democrats, furious with the Governor? With a $2 billion surplus and a galloping economy, why does the Governor want to cut education and health care?
A piece of the answer is that after a sharp spending increase last year, as he ran for re-election, Mr. Pataki has no choice but to practice restraint this year.
The larger answer, according to independent fiscal analysts and a lot of legislators in both parties, is that two years in a row, the Governor has bungled the politics of dealing with the Legislature.
"I think we could have arrived at the same result without making everyone angry," said Diana Fortuna, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit organization, "and without still being here in July, waiting for a budget."
Michael McKeon, Mr. Pataki's press secretary, said it would not have mattered if the Governor had handled things differently. "The idea that the Assembly Democrats would be satisfied with reasonable spending increases just belies facts," he said.
But take the state's last two fiscal years, and Mr. Pataki's current proposed budget. Subtract the money supplied by the Federal Government, and the year-by-year increases in state spending are 3.5 percent, 11.7 percent and 1.8 percent. Plotted on a graph, it looks like a roller coaster's path, and that is mostly the Governor's doing.
Renee Boicourt, managing director for state ratings at Moody's Investors Service, said, "I can't think of another state that has had such wide fluctuations in spending."
Mr. McKeon insisted that it was the overview that counts, not the annual steps. That ignores the Capitol's internal workings, which are as much psychology as politics.
A little history: there were very late budgets in 1995 and 1996, the first two years of the Pataki administration, when the Governor was trying to make deep budget and tax cuts, and close a yawning deficit. In 1997, the budget was the latest in history, but that was due almost entirely to the unrelated fight over rent controls. Last year, with the state awash in money, the Legislature passed a budget just two weeks late, the best showing in five years.
The roots of this year's angst lie in the last two years.
In 1997, lawmakers enacted major tax cuts and promised new education programs like expanding prekindergarten, all to be phased in over five years. Combined with tax cuts passed last year, they made $5 billion a year in promises that will come due in the next few years.
"That's the real problem," said Frank J. Mauro, director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a nonprofit group in Albany. "That's what's driving Pataki's austerity now."
But a little less austerity would be needed if the Governor had not been so generous last year. Incumbents seeking re-election in boom times are expected to raise spending, but even by that standard, Mr. Pataki's proposed 8 percent increase, which over the fiscal year turned out to be 11.7 percent, was high.
Mr. Pataki balked last year when the Legislature added more spending, but he knew as well as anyone that a Governor's proposal is always seen as a floor for the Assembly and the Senate to build on.
After the Legislature passed the budget, the Governor vetoed $1.6 billion in items, inflicting a wound to his relations with legislators that still has not healed.
This year, he proposed a rise of only 1.8 percent, to $72.7 billion, infuriating Democrats again. But the promised tax cuts, and last year's fat budget, left him little choice.
Now accept, as the Governor says, that the tax cuts are non-negotiable. What if he had proposed a smaller increase last year, leaving the Legislature room to add at least some of its pet projects? What if, instead of a big increase one year and a small one the next, he had sought steadier growth?
"Everybody wouldn't be so mad at each other," Mr. Mauro said. "All this grief might not be necessary."
Then again, it wasn't the Legislature that Mr. Pataki was trying to make happy last year. It was the voters.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Reviving the Economics of Fear;
InBad Times, Consumers Might Simply Refuse to Spend

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Anyone who lived through the Great Depression or studied economics in its aftermath quickly learned that even when the Government prodded people to spend more, they would not do so in frightening times. Then came the prosperous decades. Americans began to spend freely, in good times and bad, and the image of the recalcitrant consumer faded from college courses. Now, suddenly, it is coming back.
Robert J. Gordon, a Northwestern University economist, is helping to resurrect the old concept. In last-minute revisions to the latest edition of his textbook for undergraduate economics majors, he upgraded the discussion of the resistant consumer from a single, skeptical footnote to a respectful consideration. "When you go 50 years without a phenomenon being relevant, it dies out of the curriculum," he said. "Now it's relevant again." 
 What makes it relevant is the situation in Japan, where the central bank has reduced interest rates virtually to zero, yet consumers have stubbornly held back from borrowing or spending. Businesses have been similarly resistant. Not since the early years of the Great Depression has any major industrial nation gone through such an unnerving experience of offering, in effect, to give away money and finding few takers.
That is hardly the case in the United States, where the Federal Reserve on Wednesday raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, and where consumers continue to enjoy a long spending spree. But even if a total collapse of consumer confidence seems improbable in America any time soon, it is increasingly viewed by mainstream economists as a real possibility.
"One could imagine that happening here," said N. Gregory Mankiw, a Harvard economist and textbook author who nevertheless puts the odds of a consumer freeze-up in America at less than 1 in 100, and does not yet mention the concept in either his beginning or intermediate economics texts. "I deal with rules, not exceptions," Mr. Mankiw said. "My market is mainly American students, not Japanese."
Mr. Mankiw, who is 41 and has known only economic prosperity in his lifetime, is on sabbatical this year. But if he were teaching, he said, he would put aside his grave doubts and, making an exception, lecture on the phenomenon of unshakable consumer resistance -- "in the context of Japan."
Mr. Gordon, who is 58, is already giving fresh emphasis in class to a concept that has received little attention since the 1970's. And so are other professors, although the idea of an utter consumer shutdown runs so counter to the standard, modern-day beliefs of their profession.
"I will make my students aware of the problem; in fact, I informally began to talk about it this past year," said Mark Gertler, a New York University economist. "A lot of students at N.Y.U. come from abroad, and they are interested in practical problems. When they see a connection between theory and what is actually happening, in this case in Japan, they get quite excited."
The professors are, in effect, dusting off a phenomenon first described by the British economist John Maynard Keynes in the 1930's and soon termed, in economic jargon, a liquidity trap. It means that the demand for goods and services consistently falls short of a nation's capacity to produce them despite short-term interest rates as low as zero. The central bank loses its power to steer the economy. That may be hard to imagine in the United States today, where the Federal Reserve, with its constant attention to interest rates, has helped to keep consumer spending robust for the better part of a decade.
"I know that when you flood the place with money, people will spend it," Mr. Gordon said.
But even as Mr. Gordon and other economists insist that conditions in America will never drive interest rates down to zero, they are being prodded on two counts to raise that very possibility in the classroom. One prod is Japan, where rates are indeed that low, yet people are not borrowing or spending. The other is Paul Krugman, 46, a much-quoted traditional economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who has broken with conventional wisdom and now argues that what is happening in Japan can happen in America.
That change in thinking did not come until Japan was already in deep trouble. "What sensible people like me believed just a couple of years ago was that basically demand -- the lack of it -- was not a problem; inflation was," Mr. Krugman said.
Holding to this view, he traveled to Japan to see conditions for himself. He constructed a mathematical model, a standard tool of modern economics, to demonstrate that printing more money and lowering interest rates, even down to zero, would succeed in stimulating demand and expanding an economy. "Instead, I succeeded in proving to myself that this was not necessarily true," he said. He concluded that a liquidity trap was possible after all. It was no longer just a historical curiosity -- a fading memory of the Depression and the teachings of Keynes. It had happened in Japan.
Among professional economists, Mr. Krugman was not the first to conclude that Japan had fallen into a liquidity trap. A small group of Keynesian economists already had this in mind. And as early as 1996, some conservatives, among them John Makin of the American Enterprise Institute, who does not consider himself a Keynesian, wrote that Japan was caught in a liquidity trap. Interest rates controlled by the Bank of Japan, that country's central bank, had declined to nearly zero in 1995 from 7 percent in the early 1990's, just after Japan's stock market and real estate bubbles burst, shocking the nation.
A similar shock could frighten Americans enough to freeze up their spending, Mr. Krugman argues. A sharp and rapid decline in stock market prices, or another hedge fund failure, like that of Long-Term Capital Management last summer, or another big default, like Russia's -- any of these could do the trick. American interest rates would not have as far to fall as Japan's to get to zero. The short-term rate controlled by the Fed is 5 percent today.
"How much spending would Americans do," Mr. Krugman asks, "if the Dow Jones industrial average got up above 13,000 and then dropped to 7,000? Certainly a lot less than now."
However late he may be to come to his new position, Mr. Krugman has one of the loudest voices in his profession. His influence stems, in part, from his prolific writing and his gift for explaining economics to noneconomists in simple sentences and easy-to-understand metaphors.
Drawing on these skills, he has been punching away at a set of beliefs that has dominated mainstream economics since the 1970's. With Milton Friedman and Robert Lucas at the University of Chicago taking the lead, an old pre-Keynesian view emerged in new theoretical clothing. People were declared to behave rationally. If for some reason they pull back as spenders, then prices drop until they buy again. There is always a price that pleases rational shoppers, who will then buy the existing supply of goods and services. Markets clear, as economists put it. And if they do not clear right away -- if companies resist cutting prices and a slowdown develops, even a recession -- well, the Government can step up spending, or the Fed can cut rates and give the process a kick.
"For most of the people getting their graduate degrees in economics today, this explanation is comfortable," said David Romer, a 41-year-old economist at the University of California at Berkeley.
But no serious provision is made in this thinking for what Keynes foresaw. He theorized that consumers would stubbornly resist spending, a sensible move for a worried, hard-pressed family but irrational for the economy as a whole. Companies find themselves forced to cut production, and layoffs, lost wages, debts and defaults accelerate the slide toward a recession or even a depression.
Mr. Krugman has just expressed his concerns in "The Return of Depression Economics" (W. W. Norton & Company), his fifth book for a general audience. For his colleagues, he has explained his new mathematical model in technical papers, including one in the current issue of the Brookings Papers on Economic Activity entitled, not so technically, "It's Baaack: Japan's Slump and the Return of the Liquidity Trap."
That paper has become a focus of the growing debate among economists over liquidity traps and what to do about Japan -- and whether its problem is truly a liquidity trap. Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, for one, blames inept Government policy and a damaged banking system for Japan's troubles -- not a liquidity trap. He asserts that the Fed, if put to a similar test, could revive consumer spending in America's healthier, more flexible system. For him, liquidity traps can be avoided, however possible they might be in theory.
"Japan's current economic problems," Mr. Greenspan told a Congressional committee two weeks ago, grew out of that nation's "failure to address the damage to the financial system in a timely manner." In similar fashion, he said, "while the stock market crash of 1929 was destabilizing, most analysts attribute the Great Depression to ensuing failures of policy."
But Mr. Krugman wonders whether America is so immune from the perils of liquidity traps, even if policy makers take the right steps. "How can we be sure," he writes, "that next year, or the year after, our own system may not turn out to have hidden flaws, that we ourselves may not be vulnerable to crisis?"

The former University of Chicago economist, who played a key role in developing the view of a rational, self-correcting marketplace.
 
John Maynard Keynes
The British economist who described the phenomenon known as a liquidity trap. He theorized that demand for goods and services could consistently fall short of a nation's production capacity, no matter how low interest rates go.
 
Paul Krugman
The Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist, who has concluded that Japan has fallen into a liquidity trap and that America could too. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A School Regains Stellar Reputation;
Students Outshine the Elite In Standardized Test Scores

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY 

 BODY:
On a muggy day in July 1987, two busloads of students, teachers and administrators traveled from their ramshackle school building in Queens to a sprawling cemetery in Brooklyn to memorialize the man for whom their recently revived high school was named: Townsend Harris.
A New York chinaware merchant who became the first United States Ambassador to Japan, Townsend Harris died in 1878 in relative obscurity, and his grave at Green-Wood Cemetery in Sunset Park went unattended for decades. The entourage from the school, which had reopened in 1984 after being shuttered for 42 years, refurbished the grave, installing a black marble plaque and a stone lantern. 
 The ceremony was a symbolic moment for a school that critics had fought to keep closed. The proposal to reopen Townsend Harris came at a time when the city was looking to move away from such schools that essentially skimmed off the best students. So critics mounted a campaign urging parents not to send their children there.
But they did. And today, the school is embraced by residents and educators alike. In 15 years, Townsend Harris has climbed to the top of academic charts in the state and across the country, and four years ago moved into a glinting new building on the Queens College campus in Flushing. It even outshone the venerable Stuyvesant High School in this year's State English Regents exam.
"In the beginning, there was a lot of political pressure that really was not in our favor," said Malcolm G. Largmann, the school's 62-year-old principal. "There was a rumor every June that we would not be back. But by the fifth year, it was clear that we were here to stay."
Teachers and parents largely credit Dr. Largmann, a strict disciplinarian who runs a rigid academic program, for Townsend's success. They also say that the school's humanities-based curriculum propels its students academically and gives them an edge on standardized tests like the Regents and the S.A.T.'s. According to state statistics for the 1997-98 school year, all of the school's graduating seniors went on to a four-year college.
A old-guard tweedy intellectual who grew up in Borough Park, Brooklyn, Dr. Largmann has brought mostly veteran teachers to a staff that has a low turnover. But the school's achievement is underscored by the fact that students must apply to gain entry. Although the school does not use an entrance exam, its admissions formula considers test scores and grades among other criteria.
Students have access to unlimited resources at Queens College, and seniors can take college courses. "Our reputation is that of a tough school," Dr. Largmann said. "If a student applies here, they know what's expected."
Indeed, the school's more than 1,000 students quickly become aware of the strict code of discipline and study when they enter as freshman. They have no study halls. Most schools start the day with homeroom, but Townsend Harris students start with their first class. Many spend the first three years studying into the wee hours of the morning and are known for carrying some of the heaviest backpacks in the city. Though they complain about the pressure, many students are driven by it, giving the school a palpable esprit de corps.
"The teachers are very demanding," said Anthony A. Prince, a 17-year-old of St. Albans, Queens, who graduated last week and will attend Brown University in the fall. "They expect the best of you, and it's something that pays off in college. I've spoken to graduates of Townsend Harris who say the transition period from high school to college is a breeze. It's actually less work and less stressful. The teachers put the work on here, but it pays off in the end."
Dr. Largmann, a short, thin, gray-haired man, often stops into classes unannounced to hold discussions and roams the halls to make sure everyone is in class. Students tend to scurry when they see him. One day recently, students lingering around the outdoor amphitheater during lunchtime fled when Dr. Largmann walked outside to show a visitor the school's seven-story beige brick exterior. They returned when he left.
Alan Fu, a 17-year-old from Bayside, Queens, who was editor of the school newspaper said that Dr. Largmann is less stern when he is among upperclassmen.
"He's really a good guy," said Alan, who will attend Northwestern University in the fall. "He's just very demanding."
Some parents fear that the school's air of intensity and obedience could force students to lose individuality.
"Academically, it's an excellent school," said Eddie Marritz, an Upper West Side resident whose daughter, Leda, 17, commutes to Townsend Harris. "There is an authoritarian tone, which I think squashes certain forms of individualism. This is a high school for humanities, but I think in general it can benefit from more arts."
Like its predecessor but unlike other selective schools, Townsend Harris seeks to give students a classical education in liberal arts, requiring each to take two years of Latin or ancient Greek and three years of a modern language. Community service is also required.
Lynne Greenfield, the assistant principal supervisor of the humanities division, describes her department as the backbone of the school. She said it was instrumental in helping eleventh graders outscore students at other elite schools on the English Regents exam in January. About 78 percent of the school's juniors passed the exam with distinction compared with about 67 percent at Stuyvesant and 66 percent at Bronx High School of Science.
"You don't prepare specifically for the test," said said. "We just prepare kids to read critically and to write well."
Townsend Harris is not considered an elite school because it does not have an admissions exam, but it can compete with them. In 1997, it tied with Stuyvesant for second place in performance on the Regents exams and just one point behind Bronx Science, according to school report cards released by the state. Since 1988, its students have won six Westinghouse Science awards, a high school competition that is now sponsored by the Intel corporation.
Debra Michlewitz, a 47-year-old English teacher at Townsend Harris who lives in Queens, said she bought a house zoned for Benjamin N. Cardozo, a high performing high school in Bayside, so that her son, Michael Pasinkoff, could attend it. But Ms. Michlewitz, who has worked at Townsend Harris for 11 years, said she changed her mind when she began working at the school. Michael, 18, graduated last week from Townsend Harris and will attend Rutgers University in the fall.
"Over time, parents have become aware of the school," said Ms. Michlewitz. "We do team teaching. We talk to kids about Euclidian math, and the Regents sequential math exam now requires students to explain their answers in writing. This is nothing new for our students."
The school did not have a dynamic start after it reopened. It was strenuously opposed by neighborhood and vocational high school officials and parents in Queens who thought it would lure away the best freshmen. As a result, it developed a complex admissions formula that uses a student's neighborhood as a factor. Though most come from Queens, students from underrepresented neighborhoods like Flatbush, Brooklyn have a better shot at getting in.
"At first, the residents were against it, but now it's an accepted part of the community," said Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President who has actively supported the school.
It first reopened in a cramped yeshiva on Parsons Boulevard in Queens, miles away from the original building that opened in 1849 at 23d Street and Lexington. Townsend Harris, created for sons of the merchant class, started out as a one-year preparatory school for the predecessor to the City College of New York, the Free Academy. In 1906, it became a full-fledged city high school, offering a rigorous program for intellectually gifted students.
It rapidly gained a national reputation, producing graduates like Dr. Jonas E. Salk, the developer of a polio vaccine ; Kenneth J. Arrow, a winner of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science; Herman Wouk, the novelist and Richard Rodgers, the Broadway composer.
In 1942, Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia ordered that the school be closed over budget cuts. In 1980, a group formed the Townsend Harris Alumni Association and began working to re-establish the fabled school.
The group chose Queens College as its sponsor and established ties with the Japanese Consulate, which had reverence for Mr. Harris because he forged Japan's trading relationship with the West. Dr. Largmann, an assistant principal at Tilden High School in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, was tapped to run the school.
In 1987, the Townsend Harris Alumni Association discovered that Mr. Harris' grave had gone unattended for decades. They contacted Japanese officials, who agreed to help pay for the grave's six-foot, gray granite marker to be cleaned and for the plot to be refurbished.
A ceremony was in order. In the middle of July, Dr. Largmann and his staff had to scramble to find students and teachers to attend.
"It was really a special moment," Dr. Largmann said as he recalled the ceremony. "Townsend Harris has overcome a lot."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Budget Bog And What Put Pataki There

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 1

 BODY:
On its face, New York State's long-running budget stalemate is simple enough. Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, wants to cut, while the Democratic Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, wants to add.
The budget is three months overdue, but some day, the Governor, the Speaker and the Republican State Senate leader, Joseph L. Bruno, will agree on a plan of around $73 billion. That is a 14 percent rise over three years, a healthy clip that would ordinarily be enough to keep everyone happy. 
 So why are legislators, especially Democrats, furious with the Governor? With a $2 billion surplus and a galloping economy, why does the Governor want to cut education and health care?
A piece of the answer is that after a sharp spending increase last year, as he ran for re-election, Mr. Pataki has no choice but to practice restraint this year.
The larger answer, according to independent fiscal analysts and a lot of legislators in both parties, is that two years in a row, the Governor has bungled the politics of dealing with the Legislature.
"I think we could have arrived at the same result without making everyone angry," said Diana Fortuna, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit organization, "and without still being here in July, waiting for a budget."
Michael McKeon, Mr. Pataki's press secretary, said it would not have mattered if the Governor had handled things differently. "The idea that the Assembly Democrats would be satisfied with reasonable spending increases just belies facts," he said.
But take the state's last two fiscal years, and Mr. Pataki's current proposed budget. Subtract the money supplied by the Federal Government, and the year-by-year increases in state spending are 3.5 percent, 11.7 percent and 1.8 percent. Plotted on a graph, it looks like a roller coaster's path, and that is mostly the Governor's doing.
Renee Boicourt, managing director for state ratings at Moody's Investors Service, said, "I can't think of another state that has had such wide fluctuations in spending."
Mr. McKeon insisted that it was the overview that counts, not the annual steps. That ignores the Capitol's internal workings, which are as much psychology as politics.
A little history: there were very late budgets in 1995 and 1996, the first two years of the Pataki administration, when the Governor was trying to make deep budget and tax cuts, and close a yawning deficit. In 1997, the budget was the latest in history, but that was due almost entirely to the unrelated fight over rent controls. Last year, with the state awash in money, the Legislature passed a budget just two weeks late, the best showing in five years.
The roots of this year's angst lie in the last two years.
In 1997, lawmakers enacted major tax cuts and promised new education programs like expanding prekindergarten, all to be phased in over five years. Combined with tax cuts passed last year, they made $5 billion a year in promises that will come due in the next few years.
"That's the real problem," said Frank J. Mauro, director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a nonprofit group in Albany. "That's what's driving Pataki's austerity now."
But a little less austerity would be needed if the Governor had not been so generous last year. Incumbents seeking re-election in boom times are expected to raise spending, but even by that standard, Mr. Pataki's proposed 8 percent increase, which over the fiscal year turned out to be 11.7 percent, was high.
Mr. Pataki balked last year when the Legislature added more spending, but he knew as well as anyone that a Governor's proposal is always seen as a floor for the Assembly and the Senate to build on.
After the Legislature passed the budget, the Governor vetoed $1.6 billion in items, inflicting a wound to his relations with legislators that still has not healed.
This year, he proposed a rise of only 1.8 percent, to $72.7 billion, infuriating Democrats again. But the promised tax cuts, and last year's fat budget, left him little choice.
Now accept, as the Governor says, that the tax cuts are non-negotiable. What if he had proposed a smaller increase last year, leaving the Legislature room to add at least some of its pet projects? What if, instead of a big increase one year and a small one the next, he had sought steadier growth?
"Everybody wouldn't be so mad at each other," Mr. Mauro said. "All this grief might not be necessary."
Then again, it wasn't the Legislature that Mr. Pataki was trying to make happy last year. It was the voters.

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about the budget stalemate in Albany included an erroneous figure from the State Comptroller's office for the increase in New York State spending during the last fiscal year. It was 8.4 percent, not 11.7 percent.

HEADLINE: Don't Impoverish Serbs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Restraint on Rebuilding Serbia" (editorial, June 29): History has shown that economic sanctions are ineffective in changing governments and most effective in impoverishing people, as in Cuba and Iraq. In fact, poverty has tended to drive countries closer to tyranny, as in Germany after World War I, and democratic reform has been driven by wealth. In the United States and France, the liberal revolutions were organized by emergent middle classes. 
 With much of Serbia's economic infrastructure in ruins, and an absence of foreign trade, the poverty of most Serbs is almost guaranteed. The Serbs, along with the people of other embargoed states, should be allowed to do business with the rest of the world in order to raise their level of expectation for their governments.
 
DANIEL MAURO
Frankfurt, June 29, 1999

HEADLINE: Spielberg and Partners Drop Long-Troubled Plan to Build Big Studio Complex

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 2

 BODY:
In a move that reflects a mood of industry retrenchment and ambivalence about its own grandest ambitions, Dreamworks SKG has abandoned its plan to build Hollywood's first new studio complex in more than 60 years. The company cited difficulties in arranging acceptable financing to create its planned campus of state-of-the-art sound stages as part of a sprawling 1,000-acre development near Los Angeles International Airport.
The $250 million sound-stage project was the brainchild of Steven Spielberg and his fellow moguls Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen, the three of whom founded Dreamworks five years ago and with great fanfare announced plans for the studio, to be built on the site of Howard Hughes's old aircraft factory, in late 1995. But from the beginning the proposal was plagued by financial and political wrangling, environmental lawsuits and doubts about its viability, and Dreamworks threatened to abandon the site last year in a dispute with the developers over the price of land. 
 Late Thursday the studio's co-founders said they were dropping the project at the new development, known as Playa Vista, because of the problems with financing, together with rising interest rates and construction costs, and this morning's headline in Daily Variety, the industry journal, summed up the mood: "Hasta La Playa Vista, Baby."
"We have learned a great deal during the past four years, and it is clear that the move is no longer in Dreamworks's best interest," Mr. Katzenberg said in a statement. "It was simply not meant to be."
But three of the Dreamworks investors -- Mr. Geffen, Mr. Spielberg and Paul Allen, co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation -- are billionaires and could have arranged the money necessary to build the new studio, had they chosen and had their company been generating a stronger cash flow. So Hollywood executives were abuzz today with the conviction that Dreamworks's decision to abandon the project signaled a broader rethinking of the fledgling studio's goals.
Though Mr. Spielberg said in his own statement that "not building at Playa Vista in no way deters us" from the goal of building a new studio, Dreamworks officials said that in the short term, the company would probably simply expand its offices on the Universal Studios lot in the San Fernando Valley, and at the Dreamworks animation campus in nearby Glendale. Mr. Spielberg's partners -- especially Mr. Geffen, who made his fortune in the recording business, with its low overhead costs -- have long been thought to harbor less enthusiasm for building their own movie production complex than for just renting existing sound stages.
"The financing was the last straw," one Dreamworks official said. "But it was the combination of all the delays, the uneasiness about the financing, the increases in construction costs, the changes in the industry and the changes in our own thinking."
In its short history, Dreamworks has had mixed results, producing hit movies like "Saving Private Ryan" and "Antz" and the successful television sitcom "Spin City," but also disappointments like the movie "In Dreams" and the series "Ink." Further, in the four years since the project was announced, production activity in Hollywood itself has cooled considerably, as studios have shifted filming abroad to save costs. That has freed up once-overcrowded sound stages in Southern California.
"The fact is we've never had any trouble getting a stage for any of our pictures," the Dreamworks official said.
At the same time, the Dreamworks partners are said to be most happy with the financial performance of their Gameworks unit, which operates upscale computer-game arcades in shopping malls and was created without the benefit of any elaborate headquarters campus or fancy fiber-optic network of the sort envisioned for Playa Vista.
The Playa Vista developers, which are backed by a consortium of investors led by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and Goldman, Sachs & Company, said they would proceed to build their own sound stages for lease on what would have been Dreamworks's 47-acre parcel, using as a base the old hangars where Howard Hughes built his flying boat, the Spruce Goose. Already, movies like "Titanic," "Men in Black" and "Independence Day" have been filmed in part on the Hughes site.
"The phone is ringing off the hook this morning, to be quite honest with you," said a spokesman for Playa Vista, David A. Herbst. "We will retrofit the Hughes buildings, but we will also build others. We're dusting off our plans and re-examining them to see what the needs are."
The Playa Vista site, which is also scheduled to include 3,200 residential units and 3.2 million square feet of commercial office space in its first phase, is one of the last remaining large tracts of undeveloped land in greater Los Angeles. City officials spent considerable effort to help the developers lure Dreamworks to the project as anchor of a planned media campus, rewarding them for success in that task with $35 million in job tax credits. The developers will now lose that money, but expect to reapply to the city after creating their own studio plan, Mr. Herbst said.
Dreamworks closed on a $20 million purchase of its Playa Vista land in April, and the effort to build the first wholly new studio since Warner Brothers moved to the San Fernando Valley in the 1930's appeared to be back on track. But, Dreamworks officials said, they were ultimately unable to settle on financing terms for building the studio complex with investment partners, including the Union Labor Life Insurance Company, a labor pension fund group. Negotiations produced too many roadblocks, including a provision specifying that if the project came in over budget, Dreamworks could lose control of the land to the other investors.
"There were far too many controls on the deal and our ability to coordinate it," one official said.
Instead, Dreamworks will retrench in its existing operations, with live-action feature production based at Mr. Spielberg's longtime Amblin Entertainment outpost on the Universal lot; animation at the 17-acre Glendale animation campus, built while Playa Vista was tied up in delays, and the Dreamworks Records operation in Beverly Hills, which is Mr. Geffen's bailiwick. There are now five buildings on the Glendale site, with room to build two more, which would probably house offices.
The larger Playa Vista project, meanwhile, has been beset by lawsuits from a handful of environmental groups, which contend that it would despoil wildlife habitats in the Ballona Wetlands, one of the area's last remaining coastal marshes. Other environmental groups have strongly backed the developers' plan to restore a part of the wetlands, and this week a Los Angeles Superior Court judge rebuffed the latest attempt by the project's opponents to block construction.
