HEADLINE: About New York;
Unlikely Dive Into the Brine: It's a Living

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY

 BODY:
THE rain fell in fat, wet drops on Thursday morning, splattering atop the 15 orange barrels outside Lower East Side Pickles as the proprietor, Joe Davide, squinted at the sky and pronounced business "sour."
It was not much of a day to move "the product," as Mr. Davide calls his barrels of sour tomatoes, sweet red peppers, hot cherry peppers, marinated mushrooms, pimento olives, black olives, and, most of all, pickles. He has sour pickles and three-quarter-sour pickles and half-sour pickles. He has sweet pickles and large pickles and small pickles. He even has specially spiced pickles. 
 "This is something that everybody don't have," Mr. Davide said, lifting the hard plastic cover of a barrel to reveal spicy pickles swimming in the brine.
New York, Mr. Davide is quick to remind, is a pickle town. The pickle might not enjoy the glamour of the bagel or the acclaim of the knish, but just imagine a pastrami and rye without one. Yet if the pickle is everywhere in New York, it is also practically nowhere. The old pushcart pickle district on Essex Street on the Lower East Side has dwindled to a single store as most people now buy their pickles from jars in grocery stores.
But if the writing was on the wall, Mr. Davide didn't read it. He had stumbled into the business 25 years ago as a delivery driver at Guss's Pickles on the Lower East Side, but 18 months ago he left Manhattan to open his own store on East 19th Street off Avenue M in Midwood, Brooklyn. He taped a notice of rabbinical approval to his front window to assure residents in the predominantly Orthodox Jewish neighborhood that though he is Italian and a gentile, his pickles are kosher. He then sat back in a plastic chair on the sidewalk and waited in vain for what might be described as the pickle theory of economics to take hold.
"Who don't eat pickles?" he asked. "Everybody eats pickles."
During his years at Guss's, he learned how to make the brine of salt water, garlic and spices, and how to properly age cucumbers for the right degree of sourness. It was a living, but not always an easy one.
"In the beginning," conceded Mr. Davide, who is now 47, "it was embarrassing. 'What do you do? I make pickles.' I was young then. At that age, who wanted to be a pickle man?" But now he takes a certain pride in his life of pickles. When the telephone rings inside the shop, he answers, "Pickles!" He says customers shout to him on the street, "How do you do, pickles?" or "Pickle man!" He just smiles and stuffs pickles into plastic quart containers.
"We call him the pickle packer," snickered Joe Miller, his brother-in-law and employee.
Mr. Miller is helping out for the summer and his specialty seems to be marketing and public relations ("Miller, like the beer, like I'm high on life because I can't afford any better," he said by way of introduction). He's talking about a Web site and formulating plans to ship special orders of pickles nationwide. Mr. Davide listens to all this, but he isn't convinced.
"I already worked 25 years in the business," he said. "I don't want to kill myself."
HIS pickle shop shares a bathroom with Anything Goes, a discount ladies undergarment boutique on the corner, and, fortunately, the owner, Mark Bayarsky, likes pickles. Often, Mr. Bayarsky sends customers armed with bags of frilly things around the corner for a pickle on him. "When we open up the store in the morning, my whole store stinks of pickles," he said. "But I don't care. I love pickles."
Mr. Davide knows that pickles will never make him rich. He charges $4.25 for a quart of pickles, pricier than grocery pickles, but he says quality is the difference. He is picking up business from a few restaurants and delis, and Ellen Freudenheim, the polymath of all things Brooklyn, included the shop in her new book about the borough, "Brooklyn! A Soup-to-Nuts Guide." His peak times are Friday afternoons before the start of the Jewish Sabbath.
But on slow days he or Mr. Bayarsky will run to the store for a few beers. They usually get a sampler, tasting different brands with different pickles in the name of market research. He knows there is not much future in pickles, but he has come to realize that it is good to be a pickle man.
"Oh yeah, pickles are popular," he proclaimed.
And with that he reclined in his plastic chair and waited for a customer.

HEADLINE: 70% of Blind Lack Jobs; Computer Mouse Shares the Blame

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, July 2

 BODY:
Of the blind Americans who say they want a job, 70 percent are unable to find one even though the labor market is so tight that many employers are begging for workers.
Advocates for the 750,000 Americans who are blind blame discrimination, a drop in Braille literacy and the computer mouse. 
 "The Americans with Disabilities Act seems to have had no impact on this," said Barbara Pierce, a spokeswoman for the National Federation of the Blind, which is holding its annual convention here. The act, passed in 1990, bans discrimination based on disability and requires employers to take "reasonable" steps to accommodate people with disabilities.
In addition to the 70 percent of the blind who are unemployed, the 30 percent who work are considered underemployed in relation to their qualifications, the Labor Department says.
Over the years, technology has made things much easier for blind people. Converting text to Braille, once a painstaking process, can now be done by computers, and some office equipment is available with Braille-embossed buttons.
But other technology has hurt the employment chances of the blind.
Many blind people once worked as receptionists, taking dictation and answering the phone for managers and executives. But voice mail and E-mail have changed the job description, requiring more computer skills. And software that requires the user to move around the screen with a mouse and click on icons is nearly impossible for blind people to learn.
Peg Halverson, out of a job for the last two years, said she could use software that included graphics if someone would put it in a blind-friendly format that relied mostly on keystroke commands and spoke out loud to the user to alert him or her to what was on the screen.
"I want to be employed," said Ms. Halverson, 44. "I want to contribute to society. I'm thinking, 'I have a business degree, I have basically 20 years of administrative experience, and I can't even get a customer service job.' "
Ms. Pierce said software makers that convert point-and-click programs so the blind can use them were a couple of years behind the rest of the computer industry.
Advocates for the blind said another problem had been a decline in the number of blind children learning Braille. In the past 30 years, the percentage of blind children learning Braille in the United States has fallen to less than 10 percent from about 50 percent, the federation says.
The reason: a push in the past two decades to get blind children out of special schools and place them in the mainstream with other students.
The federation backs that process, but Ms. Pierce said many school systems viewed it as a chance to cut costs by hiring fewer teachers for disabled students and rolling back Braille instruction to only once or twice a week.
Another big obstacle for blind people trying to find jobs is employers' attitudes, the advocates said. Many managers think blind people are helpless and cannot be effective workers. "This is pity-based discrimination," Ms. Pierce said.
Advocates said there was technology to help the blind in many jobs.
Some companies may balk when told that a blind employee will require a $3,000 Braille embosser that works like a computer printer that would cost less than $500. But Ms. Pierce said, there are state, Federal and private programs to help employers pay for such equipment.

HEADLINE: Clinton and South Korean Leader Warn the North Against Testing Missile

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
President Clinton and President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea used a brief meeting in Washington today to make a show of solidarity against North Korea and to warn it against testing another long-range missile in coming weeks.
"We are maintaining close coordination on all issues, on economic issues as well as security issues," said Mr. Kim, the onetime dissident who was elected President just as South Korea plunged into its economic crisis two years ago. "And I do hope that this close cooperation sends a clear message to North Korea." 
 For all the talk of cooperation, a senior Administration official, briefing reporters on condition of anonymity, refused to discuss South Korea's own expanding missile program. It has become the subject of increasing tension between Washington and Seoul, with Clinton Administration officials fearing that the North will regard it as a provocation.
"I am not prepared to discuss anything about a South Korean missile program," the senior official said testily after being pressed by reporters.
A week ago the Administration warned North Korea that a test of its long-range Taepodong missile would result in "very serious consequences." The official speaking today said such a test would create "serious obstacles to peace."
Asked how the United States, South Korea and Japan -- the last test flew over Japanese territory -- might respond, he ruled out suspending oil shipments or aid to the North in building light-water nuclear reactors, part of a 1994 deal under which the North is supposed to freeze its work on nuclear weapons.
The official said it would make no sense for the United States to violate the 1994 accord and invite the North to do the same by resuming its weapons project.
Later in the day Mr. Kim met with former Defense Secretary William J. Perry, President Clinton's special envoy for North Korean affairs, for an update on Mr. Perry's recommendations to the White House for dealing with the North. Last month Mr. Perry went to Pyongyang, the North Korean capital, to offer a deal under which the United States would gradually lift economic sanctions that have been in place since the Korean War of 1950-53.
In return the North would have to agree to stop testing and exporting missiles and to end military provocations against the South. The State Department described North Korean officials as interested in Mr. Perry's proposal. But only two weeks later, a dispute between North and South Korean fishing boats turned into a naval firefight in disputed waters west of the Korean Peninsula. More than 20 North Koreans were killed.
Mr. Kim also came here to proclaim that his country's economic troubles appeared to be well on their way to ending. Mr. Clinton congratulated him, but the White House description of the meeting made it clear that American officials remained worried that the process of reforming South Korea's economy had bogged down.

HEADLINE: New Phase Under Way In Battle Over Banking Law

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Now comes the endgame in the 20 Years War between Democrats and Republicans, Treasury Secretaries and Federal Reserve chairmen, and lobbyists from three of the nation's most powerful industries over legislation to overhaul the financial system.
Business interests and Government agencies, in a situation reminiscent of the trench warfare of an earlier era, spent years fighting to a stalemate over the legislation. The lawmakers benefited mightily in the process, using the battle among insurers, bankers and securities firms to enrich their campaign coffers by hundreds of millions of dollars. Until two months ago, they had delivered very little in return. 
 Now, however, the financial industry's investment may be paying off. With the House of Representatives' overwhelming approval on Thursday of a banking bill that would repeal 65 years of laws intended to bar banks, insurers and securities underwriters from entering one another's businesses, there is a growing consensus that this year might be different. The Clinton Administration generally likes the House legislation, and that increases the odds that a new law will be passed.
"We were very pleased with the bill, the overwhelming majority that supported it and the clear sign of what can happen when the Administration works with both sides of the aisle," said Gary Gensler, a Treasury Under Secretary. "There is finally a real chance for meaningful reform."
But it will still take what was once unthinkable for the legislation to become reality: an agreement between Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who heads the Senate Banking Committee, and President Clinton.
Last fall Mr. Gramm blocked a Senate measure, robbing Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, who was the committee chairman at the time, of a significant legislative victory. After he failed to win re-election, Mr. D'Amato was succeeded as head of the banking committee by Mr. Gramm, who, bucking the predictions of many on Wall Street, quickly and effectively won approval of his own version of the legislation two months ago.
The bill he produced has two provisions that the White House says would lead President Clinton to veto it. One provision gives a decided preference to the Federal Reserve over the Treasury as a top regulator for banks. The other exempts thousands of banks from requirements that they make loans to minorities and others traditionally denied access to credit.
That provision is expected to be highlighted by Mr. Clinton as he embarks on a nationwide tour next week to areas of poverty and high unemployment, in an attempt to encourage investment in some of the poorest communities.
Neither of the provisions objectionable to the White House is in the House bill, which was approved late Thursday evening by a 343-to-86 vote.
The House bill's passage was a setback for Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. He has been unyielding in his view that any new banking legislation must include a provision that organizes financial conglomerates so that banks and securities firms are affiliates of a holding company.
The practical significance of Mr. Greenspan's preference is that under such a corporate structure the Federal Reserve would become the dominant regulatory agency, and the Treasury would lose much of the authority it now has as overseer of nationally chartered institutions. Mr. Greenspan has testified that he feels so strongly about the point that he would rather see no new legislation than legislation that takes the approach favored by the Treasury, which would preserve a role for the Administration as a regulator.
The House legislation follows the Treasury's approach, while the Senate bill takes the Greenspan position.
Lawmakers, Administration officials and lobbyists began to figure out how to reconcile the competing measures today.
"Gramm's strategy has been to bargain very hard and take to the conference bargaining table as many chips as he could," said Edward Yingling, the top lobbyist for the American Bankers Association.
While Mr. Gramm has suggested a willingness to negotiate, it is impossible to know whether he or the Administration will blink, or whether they will ultimately be able to reach a compromise.
"Anyone who tells you that they can predict what Gramm will do is full of beans," said John H. Hanley, director of legislative strategy for the Independent Community Bankers Association.
Lawmakers say a Congressional conference to iron out the differences between the House and Senate measures may begin later this month or in August. The most positive force pushing for a law is undoubtedly the remarkable unity of the insurers, the bankers and the securities underwriters.
"We used to absolutely beat the hell out of each other on the bill," Mr. Yingling said. But as judges and regulators have interpreted the rules loosely enough to enable some affiliations between banks, insurance companies and securities firms, the lines separating those industries have blurred.

HEADLINE: Rubin Is Kidnapped, but, Hey, Who Cares?

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
In his last 24 hours as Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin scolded Congress for legislation that would make life easier for money launderers, cleaned out his office and then watched in mock horror as President Clinton's closest advisers played out their fantasy: That Mr. Rubin had been captured by Japan's Ministry of Finance and held for a bizarre ransom.
The kidnapping was the plot of a video entitled "Free Bob: A Documentary," which had its premiere in the State Dining Room on Thursday night during a farewell party given by President Clinton. 
 The White House was working today to make sure that the first showing was also the last. But it will be hard to keep bootleg copies from leaking out: This may be the only economic thriller to ever star, playing themselves, the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan; the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger; Defense Secretary William Cohen, and Jesse Jackson, who is called in, naturally, to negotiate Mr. Rubin's release.
The video opens with David Bloom, the NBC White House correspondent, reporting that Mr. Rubin is being held hostage in Tokyo by retired officials of the proud Japanese bureaucracy who demand that he say something -- anything -- positive about the Japanese economy. It is only a slight leap of the imagination, because last year Japanese officials repeatedly complained that Mr. Rubin's searing criticism of Japan's economic mismanagement was undercutting the Japanese Government, destabilizing its markets and contributing to the ouster of a prime minister.
Cut to the White House, already in crisis- management mode. Mr. Rubin, according to intelligence reports relayed back to the Central Intelligence Agency, will not bend. Under intense questioning by the Japanese, he will only repeat: "My name is Bob Rubin. I am a U.S. citizen. Markets go up and markets go down. I have nothing more to say."
An options memo is prepared for the President, but first there must be a turf war between the White House national security team and the White House economic team. Mr. Berger argues with Gene Sperling, the chairman of the National Economic Council and the producer of the video -- not about how to rescue the imprisoned Treasury Secretary, but over whose name goes on top of the memo.
"This is a foreign policy matter," Mr. Berger deadpans in his office. "Japan is a foreign country."
"I'm tired of this" shoots back Mr. Sperling, playing out a battle that occurs, presumably in slightly more subtle fashion, every week in Washington. "The demands the Japanese are making are economic." Mr. Berger concludes the scene by saying, "If we can't agree on this, then let him fry."
(Mr. Sperling, in addition to his acting role, was the producer, director and screenwriter. "I don't want to be called the President's economic adviser anymore," he said today. "I do film.")
Throughout the Administration's arguments, the President's press secretary is sent out to assure the world that "we're working as a team." Meanwhile, Mr. Clinton is trying to finish a crossword puzzle.
Mr. Cohen appears in the Pentagon press room to offer up the entire Navy budget, $82 billion, to pay for Mr. Rubin's hotel room bills at the Okura Hotel, his luxurious prison across from the American Embassy in Tokyo. (It might take that much: Getting a shirt pressed at the Okura runs about $20, and an informal lunch for two at the sushi bar downstairs easily tops $250.) Mr. Greenspan finally appears to deal with Japan's demands for America's gold reserves.
"Where would you like it delivered," he inquires.
"Alan Greenspan and Woody Allen have one thing in common," one of Mr. Clinton's top economic advisers said today, assessing the Fed chairman's acting abilities while insisting on anonymity. "They both know how to play only one character."
In the end Mr. Jackson is appointed as a special envoy to mediate a solution, and goes off to Japan talking about finding "common ground between the yen and the yang." When his mission is accomplished, he declares: "Free at last, free at last. Thank God almighty, Bob's free at last."
Indeed he is. Lawrence H. Summers, Mr. Rubin's longtime deputy, was sworn in as the next Treasury Secretary today in the Oval Office. Mr. Summers has already received congratulations on his new post from Japan's Ministry of Finance.

HEADLINE: Is $1 Trillion Windfall as Ephemeral as a Breeze?

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON with MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 2

 BODY:
Where did Congress and the Clinton Administration find $1 trillion?
The White House released a new analysis of the Federal budget this week that projected a windfall of more than $1 trillion over the next 15 years on top of the previously anticipated $4.9 trillion cumulative surplus in that time. The Congressional Budget Office then released a similar study that looked at the fiscal picture over shorter periods and closely paralleled the Administration's estimates. 
 For members of both parties, the news that the surplus was continuing to swell beyond what had been projected just a few months earlier was a little like winning the lottery and then having Ed McMahon show up on the doorstep the next morning with a check from Publishers Clearing House. There is so much money on the table that they do not quite know what to do with it.
Rest assured that they will figure something out.
But it is hard to contemplate the pile without wondering where it came from and whether it is for real.
The answers lie deep in the economy, with factors like business efficiency and the huge gains being generated by Wall Street, and deep in the Government bureaucracy, where teams of analysts make educated guesses about fiscal trends.
Early each year the White House's Office of Management and Budget and the Congressional Budget Office separately produce estimates of what the Government's fiscal condition will be over the subsequent 10 or 15 years, based on their best assessments of how much tax revenue the economy will generate and how much spending current programs will require. Each of them then updates its estimates each summer.
The data that go into making the predictions rarely change substantially within a single year. But because the American economy is so big, and because any changes affect the outlook for years to come, even tiny changes can yield huge swings in revenue and spending projections, and therefore in the size of projected surpluses or, until recently, deficits. So algebra, not economics, drove much of the improvement in the new forecasts. Chalk that up to the magic of compound interest taught to every high school student.
Yet on the new projections hang all kinds of policy and political decisions, like how big a tax cut the country can afford and of what kind, how much money is available for education and health care and what can be done to shore up Social Security and Medicare.
The debate over arcane budget matters is so intense, said Rudolph G. Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, because "adjustments that are small to professional economists can have immense political importance."
Take the most recent round of changes included in the Administration's economic forecast. They seem technical, even arcane, and their link to Federal budget surpluses might seem tenuous. But they get at some fundamental improvements in the American economy and its ability to create the jobs and profits that generate tax revenues. They include an increase in the Administration's estimate of growth in productivity, or how much each worker can produce in a given period. When productivity improves, so does the economy's ability to expand without inflation -- and therefore to generate a steady increase in tax revenues.
In its new analysis, the Administration estimated that productivity growth would be 1.6 percent annually through 2002, up from 1.3 percent in the analysis it prepared in February. Over the longer run, it estimated that productivity growth would slow somewhat, to 1.4 percent annually, a figure that is still higher than its previous long-range estimate of 1.3 percent annually. The Congressional Budget Office made similar increases in its productivity estimates.
The growth in productivity also helped fuel the Administration's new estimates of economic growth. From this year through 2004, the Administration is estimating the economy will expand by an annual average of 2.5 percent, up from 2.2 percent in the Administration's last budget analysis in February. Moreover, the economy is already bigger at this point than the Administration or Congress had predicted early this year.
There is a hint of how the changing economy affects revenues -- and where the flood of new money is coming from -- in the experience of the last few years. Most of the surge in revenues is coming from individual income taxes. For next year, for example, the Administration now expects individual tax receipts to total $921 billion, up more than $21 billion since the February estimate. Corporate income tax receipts are expected to come in somewhat lower than previously anticipated, reflecting slower profit growth.
One reason the individual tax take is rising is that more people are working, and wages are rising at a healthy pace. But part of the growth in individual income tax receipts stems directly or indirectly from the long bull market on Wall Street. Individuals are reaping substantial capital gains, and more and more people are being compensated with stock or in ways that reflect the performance of their employers' shares.
The effect of the rising stock market can be clearly seen in receipts from inheritance taxes levied on estates, many of which contain big holdings of stocks and bonds that have appreciated in value tremendously in recent years. The Administration estimated that estate and gift tax revenue next year would be $31.4 billion, up from $27 billion in its February estimate.
As for the accuracy of the surplus projections, there are two issues: whether Congress or the Administration is slanting its estimates for political reasons and whether even the best nonpartisan economists can predict fiscal results even a year ahead, much less a decade or more.
Both parties present the figures in ways that advance their agendas. President Clinton has introduced 15-year projections this year in part so he can allocate tax revenues from the distant horizon to deal with long-term problems like Social Security while leaving money available to deal with other issues sooner. Before this year, no one had tried anything longer than a 10-year forecast.
But because there are two competing sets of projections, neither the Administration nor Congress could tinker much with its projections and get away with it. In fact, they often come up with remarkably similar results; their forecasts this week for the cumulative 10-year surplus were within $20 billion of each other, a tiny rounding error.
That is not to say, however, that either of them is likely to be correct. Their long-term forecasts have proved to be wildly inaccurate, and even their short-term forecasts often prove to be off by tens of billions of dollars. Three months ago, the Congressional Budget Office predicted a Government surplus of $111 billion this year. It recently increased the estimate to $120 billion.
So no one can count on the projections. Still, the Administration and the Congressional Budget Office can claim that their assumptions and projections are reasonable, which may be as good as it gets for the purpose of policy decisions whose implications play out over decades.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: PROTESTS;
Crowds Denounce Milosevic In Opposition Stronghold

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

DATELINE: NOVI SAD, Serbia, July 2

 BODY:
Whistling and jeering, about 10,000 people filled the main square of Yugoslavia's second-largest city tonight to demonstrate against Slobodan Milosevic and heard a parade of local opposition politicians threaten that if he does not resign as president soon, they will throw him out.
It was the first large public gathering in this Danube River city since NATO bombs knocked out three bridges that were its economic arteries. The city is the capital of the province of Vojvodina, the richest food-producing region in Yugoslavia. 
 Like Kosovo, Vojvodina was autonomous under Tito, but was stripped of that autonomy by Mr. Milosevic, and now the city is controlled by his opponents.
The crowd and the politicians had little to say about the bomb attacks. Instead, as in the bomb-damaged Serbian city of Cacak, where the first opposition rally since the war took place on Wednesday, they blamed all their troubles on Mr. Milosevic.
Mixing sarcasm, black humor and threats of violent defiance, speaker after speaker blamed the Serbian leader for a decade of fomenting lost wars, for ruining the economy of Vojvodina, for forcing their children leave the country to find work and for fouling up local efforts to repair the bridges.
Their repair has become a new theme separating Belgrade, which wants to control the construction work and the money for it, and the opposition and western Governments that are offering help.
"When we decide to throw him out by force, he will not be there by morning," said Nenad Canak, president of the League of Social Democrats, a Vojvodina-based party that help organize the rally.
With the aroma of fresh popcorn drifting through the main square on a splendid July night, the mood of the rally was jubilant, as the crowd celebrated surviving the 11-week war.
The evening, though, also had an edge of rage. The crowd erupted in jeers as speakers complained that Mr. Milosevic's regime was sucking taxes from this province to subsidize his wars and creating fuel shortages that are hobbling the ability of farmers to harvest their crops.
Novi Sad and much of the region have voted against Mr. Milosevic and his ruling Socialist Party for much of this decade. But unlike Albanians in Kosovo, the opposition has not been violent.
"Did we die of fear or are we still alive?" Mr. Canak shouted as he started off the demonstration. Those in the crowd, young, middle-aged and old, shouted back that they were very much alive and furious to be part of Mr. Milosevic's Yugoslavia.
"My greatest wish is for Vojvodina to be a republic, but this is not the moment for that to happen," Mr. Canak told the crowd.
No police officers were in sight tonight in or around Novi Sad, unlike during the earlier rally in Cacak. The police there turned away busloads of protesters and carloads of reporters outside of town. The police here did arrest four men on Thursday for handing out fliers about tonight's rally. One was beaten up before they were all released.
A number of people said they came to tonight's demonstration because they believe that, in the end, the only way to get rid of Mr. Milosevic is to force him out. They said that street demonstrations will probably have to turn violent if they are to have any effect.
"We would like it to be peaceful, but Mr. Milosevic rose to power in blood and he will only go out in blood," said Jelena Radovanov, 27, a biologist who said she has been looking for work since she graduated from college here four years ago.
Ms. Radovanov, who came to the rally with her sister, Dobrila, a doctor, said she should have fled the country years ago, but now felt that the reputation of people from Yugoslavia was too tainted for her to emigrate.
"They look at us like we are wild animals," Dobrila Radovanov said.
Vojvodina is one of the most ethnically mixed parts of Yugoslavia, with Serbs constituting about half of its population of two million, but with large numbers of ethnic Hungarians, Croats, Slovaks and Romanians. Intermarriage is common. The Radovanov sisters are half Serbian, half Hungarian.
Asked if she blames the Americans for bombing her city, Jelena Radovanov said, "Not even a tiny bit. I am sorry for the bridges. I cried when they went down. But if that was the price we had to pay to stop the killing in Kosovo, then I am willing to pay it."
Her sister interrupted to say, "We are not all bad in this country. The world shouldn't hate us so."
The substance of tonight's demonstration was the problems the city is having in trying to fix the bridges before winter. Novi Sad, which is divided from some of its suburbs by the Danube, now has to haul people back and forth across the river on barges pushed by tugboats.
Vienna has agreed to give Novi Sad a temporary bridge and to pay $10 million to erect it, Mr. Canak told the crowd. But he said that the Yugoslav Government is insisting that the Austrian money be funneled through Belgrade, where Mr. Canak said he fears it will stolen.
He also said that the Yugoslav Government has denied visas to six Viennese engineers who want to come to Novi Sad and started planning construction of the bridge.
The fight over the bridges in Novi Sad gets at the central question of how -- or if -- the West should get involved in aiding Mr. Milosevic's Yugoslavia after the war.
The United States and many European countries have said that, until Milosevic is removed from power, they will give only food, medicine and perhaps help in restoring electricity.
But opposition leaders argue that these limits will backfire, punishing Mr. Milosevic's victims and goading Serbs into rallying around their government. Some opposition leaders have been trying to persuade European countries to funnel aid through cities, such as Novi Sad, where the opposition is strong. They say carefully targeted help can increase popular support for getting rid of Mr. Milosevic.
Interference by Belgrade in the construction of a bridge for Novi Sad suggests that even if Western countries want to help individual cities in Yugoslavia, it will not be easy or quick to do so.

HEADLINE: Mexico's Senate Blocks Election Reforms

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, July 2

 BODY:
Lawmakers from Mexico's governing party have killed a package of election reforms that would have monitored spending in the presidential primary campaigns now under way and allowed Mexican expatriates to vote in the national elections next year.
In April the measures were passed in diluted form by the lower house of Congress, which is controlled by the opposition. But on Thursday senators from the party of President Ernesto Zedillo, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, mobilized the majority they enjoy in the upper house to stun the opposition by blocking the reforms from even going to the floor for debate. 
 The session ended in a shouting match, with opposition Senators yelling: "Cheaters! Cheaters!" and the Senate leader banging down his gavel on the proceedings and marching out abruptly.
The opposition defended the reforms as crucial to fortifying the democratic framework for the presidential election on July 2 of next year, which will be the most competitive ever held in Mexico.
The senators from the governing party, which has won every presidential election since the 1920's, denounced most of the measures as unconstitutional and said they had simply moved to spare themselves a politically damaging but ultimately meaningless public debate.
The measure would have created campaign finance limits and reporting requirements during the primary period. And it would have eased the formation of opposition coalitions, to counter the governing party's electoral might.
It would also have given the vote to Mexicans outside the country; 10.1 million Mexicans, voters potentially disenchanted with the governing party, live in the United States.
For a month the Mexican Congress has been in special session, past the end of its regular term. Its main purpose was to pass some sort of electoral reform. Today, one year before the presidential election, was the last day that the legislation could have been approved by the Senate in time to take effect for that vote.
Although the governing party succeeded in softening the reforms in the lower house, it finally voted against them in that house anyway. The legislation was expected to meet defeat in the Senate, where the party holds 75 of 127 seats.
But the opposition senators were counting on the debate to give the public its view of the issue.
"We are in a democratic transition where reforms to open up and scrutinize the system are of paramount importance," said Senator Luis H. Alvarez, a member of the right-of-center National Action Party. "We especially wanted to tighten campaign financing to keep drug traffickers out of the elections. But the PRI didn't agree, and they stopped us in an incredibly heavy-handed way."
One part of the reform would have authorized the Federal Elections Council to draw up plans for Mexicans living outside Mexico to vote in the presidential election. Government officials have said it would be a logistical nightmare to set up a voting system for the millions living in the United States by next July. And they have warned that American citizens and elected officials might be antagonized by so many Mexicans' displaying their allegiance to their home country's politics.
Senators of the governing party insisted that a constitutional amendment, not just a new law, would be required to authorize the overseas vote. Opposition leaders argued that the the measure was being fought because most Mexicans in the United States were believed to oppose the governing party, blaming Mr. Zedillo and his allies for creating the economic hardship that forced them to leave Mexico.
The reforms would also have set, for the first time, campaign finance limits and reporting requirements during the primaries. Mexico's political parties are holding primaries to pick their presidential candidates for the first time ever.
In addition, opposition parties would have found it easier to band together to form coalitions. Even though opinion polls show that opposition voters make up the majority in most states, the governing party continues to win elections because the opposition is split between the National Action Party and the left-of-center Party of the Democratic Revolution.
"Some coalitions are already legal under Mexican law," said Senator Eduardo Andrade Sanchez, a member of the governing party. "But if the opposition thinks we are going to make it even easier for them to gang up against us, they're crazy."
Senators from the governing party adopted the tactic of simply staying away from the session on Thursday, using the strength of their numbers to prevent a quorum. Under the rules of the special session, with no quorum there could be no debate and no second chance, so the measure was dead on arrival.
"The opposition wanted a reform tailored to its interests," Senator Andrade said. "And when they didn't get it, they wanted to tangle us in a debate to accuse us of being opposed to change. So we didn't let them."

HEADLINE: An Uphill Struggle at City College

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:
At its founding as the Free Academy more than 150 years ago, City College was viewed as a radical experiment in providing social mobility to immigrants and other disadvantaged young people. The experiment was a stunning success, and the accomplishments of its brightest students brought the college fame as a Harvard for the proletariat.
For many disadvantaged students, the college still represents a pathway to the middle class, but much of the focus at the college has shifted to the myriad and difficult problems of the least prepared students. Far from being on a par with the Ivy League, its critics now charge, it is little more than a poorly run remedial mill. 
 With their move this week to replace City College's president, Yolanda T. Moses, CUNY's trustees hope to engage in another experiment: to see if they can restore City College's luster when its enrollment is sliding, most of its students need remedial instruction and its programs in architecture, engineering and teacher education all face questions about their accreditation.
"In the eyes of everyone, City College is still the flagship of the university, and if there are problems there, it reflects poorly on the whole university," said Herman Badillo, CUNY's new chairman and a City College graduate himself. "We have to take forceful action to improve City College and bring it into the top tier again. We have a long way to go."
There is clearly much to be done.
Christoph M. Kimmich, CUNY's interim chancellor, says the tasks include rebuilding the college's management, gaining reaccreditation for the college's professional programs and deciding how the campus will cope with CUNY's plan to remove remedial classes from the senior colleges.
With about 70 percent of its entering freshmen failing one or more of the university's placement examinations, City College stands to lose many students in September 2000 when the new policy is scheduled to take effect on its campus.
Dr. Kimmich says the acting president must also insure that the college's momentum in several new science and engineering research efforts is not lost. That will take more financial support from both Albany and Washington.
"We cannot miss the opportunity to stimulate ongoing and new research," he said. "If we interrupt that, it would be a serious loss."
Whoever is named interim president will not have an easy job. On a campus at which the faculty is sometimes described as difficult and contentious, unpopular changes are likely to face lively challenge. Because City College is so visible, the process is likely to take place under a spotlight. And it comes as sensibilities are already on edge because of sharp criticisms of the university by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, CUNY trustees and others.
In addition, City College is more complicated to run than many of CUNY's other campuses, since it is a research institution with several doctoral and professional programs.
"City College is basically a university unto itself, though it is treated as just another college," said John Graziano, a music professor who is chairman of the college's Senate.
At the same time, many students and faculty members are eager for change, and hope their next president will be a talented manager with a strategic vision.
"The next president has to be a person with a lot of respect and savvy, because he or she will have to come up with a mission for the college and will have to make many, many painful decisions," said Mizanoor Biswas, a City College graduate student in economics who is president of the University Student Senate and a CUNY trustee.
"The board is quite adamant about helping in any way they can," Mr. Biswas said. "They would like to see the college succeed."
In Mr. Badillo's view, what needs to be done is not rocket science. He suggests that the next president should start by reviewing every program and making sure that faculty members set high standards; he said they should not follow the example of the professor profiled in James Traub's 1994 book about the college, "City on a Hill," who gave passing grades to students who were doing poorly.
"I want to make sure there is accountability, and that professors do not just pass everyone along," he said.
Dr. Kimmich, CUNY's interim chancellor, is hopeful that efforts by Dr. Moses and others at City College to draw up a new strategic plan during the last year will not get stalled by the change in leadership.
"The early draft focused on the institution and its strengths in its two professional schools, its acknowledged strength in the sciences and its strong liberal arts core," he said. "Those seem to be the very powerful core for a future City College."
But he acknowledged that in an era in which colleges are judged more by the quality of their students than by the education the students receive, a critical question is whether City College can transform itself without significantly raising its admission standards and altering its student body.
Or, as Dr. Kimmich put it, "Is there a way to attract a student body that is able to take more advantage of the faculty who are there today?"

HEADLINE: After a Month's Lull, Employers Report Strong Job Gains for June

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
After idling in May, the great American job engine is purring again.
Despite another big drop in factory jobs, the nation's employers added more than a quarter of a million new workers to their payrolls in June. The overall gain, of 268,000, followed a decline of 5,000 in May. Nearly two of every three Americans were at work last month, a record. And the pay of rank-and-file workers jumped 5 cents an hour, to $13.23. 
 With the labor market tighter than at almost any other time in the last three decades, Americans who have jobs are acting a bit cockier -- something that they had refrained from doing until recently. In June, the so-called quit rate -- the fraction of people looking for work who left their last jobs without having lined up another -- rose to 14.5 percent, the highest level since the end of the long, strong 1980's boom. The rate is a classic barometer of consumer confidence, which by other accounts has recently strengthened.
In short, the economic picture that persuaded Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and his colleagues to nudge up a key interest rate on Wednesday was not materially altered by the report issued yesterday by the Labor Department. The economy may no longer be in overdrive, as it was last winter. Yet it still has enough momentum to keep spending and production stronger than the Fed would like, given its worry that the longest peacetime expansion ever will rekindle inflation.
Stock and bond investors reacted cheerily to the news, and major market indexes hit new highs. Page B1.
"The economy is still very strong," said Joshua Feinman, chief economist at Deutsche Asset Management. "Whatever concerns Alan Greenspan had about a shrinking pool of workers, he's still got them."
Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman said simply, "The sun is shining brightly."
In June, the Bureau of Labor Statistics survey of households (on the basis of which the unemployment rate is calculated) showed that the number of new entrants to the labor force rose even more, by nearly 400,000, than the number of new jobs -- yet another sign that Americans are more confident than ever that work is there for the asking. The number of discouraged workers -- those who are not looking because they think there are no jobs for them -- has dwindled to just over 200,000 in the entire country, down 90,000 from a year ago.
The unemployment rate edged up slightly to 4.3 percent in June from 4.2 percent in May. But Katherine Abraham, the Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which issues the monthly jobs report, said the uptick was not statistically meaningful and called the unemployment rate essentially unchanged. It has remained between 4.2 percent and 4.4 percent since November.
Among the unemployed are plenty of people looking for better positions. A bigger portion of people who are job hunting -- not those who retired or returned to school or decided to stay home with a child -- quit their jobs without having other positions. This rate, now at 14.5 percent, is still shy of its peak of 16.5 percent, reached in January 1990. But it is a lot higher than in mid-1996, when it was below 10 percent.
The biggest beneficiaries of the current demand for labor are groups of workers who have traditionally suffered the most joblessness. The unemployment rate for blacks, already at a record low, dropped by a couple of tenths of a percentage point last month, to 7.3 percent, half the rate during the last recession. Joblessness among Hispanic workers, 6.8 percent, also remained close to a record low.
The jobs report was only one of many recent signs that the economy continues to barrel along at a pace well above its long-term trend, which most economists consider to be 2.5 percent to 3 percent a year. With income growing rapidly and corporate profits firming, spending by consumers and businesses has remained robust, and despite the yawning gap between the amount of goods imported and exported, domestic production has been picking up, too.
The only sector of the economy that had been suffering from serious weakness and had restrained overall growth -- manufacturing -- is pretty clearly on the mend. The most recent reading by the National Association of Purchasing Management suggests that output has expanded for five consecutive months even as inventories shrank relative to sales and as order backlogs swelled. And the Commerce Department reported yesterday that factory orders bounced up 1.1 percent in May after dropping by 1.4 percent in April.
The policy makers at the Fed will be looking at such numbers before their scheduled meetings later this year. "Will the world look different on Aug. 24 or Oct. 25 than on June 30? We don't think so," said Ed McKelvey, senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, which estimates that the gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 4 percent in the second quarter and predicts that the Fed will probably raise rates again.
Admittedly, the rebound in industrial production has not translated into more hiring. Factory payrolls shrank by 35,000 in June, mostly because of job losses in aircraft, electronics and apparel, bringing the total number of manufacturing jobs that have vanished in the last 15 months to nearly half a million. But hiring typically lags behind sales increases as companies initially try to fill the extra orders by adding hours and improving efficiency.
Indeed, the Labor Department said overtime edged up to 4.7 hours a week in June from 4.6 hours in May. It is also possible that manufacturers are letting temporary-help suppliers, which are classified as service firms, do the first round of hiring. "We're probably not accurately capturing the number of people actually at work in factories," Mr. Feinman speculated. The temporary-help industry added 19,000 workers in June, the ninth consecutive month of increases.
Construction employment rebounded in June after dropping sharply in May. (It turns out that the May decline was mostly a reflection of warm weather last winter that disrupted the usual seasonal hiring pattern.) Though the housing boom has cooled with higher mortgage rates, contractors hired 26,000 workers last month, many of them plumbers, roofers and electricians,
As usual, the part of the economy that did the bulk of the hiring in June was the sprawling service sector, which includes everything from the corner copying store to giant multinational banks. These companies hired a total of nearly 300,000 workers. On one end of the pay and prestige spectrum, banks, brokerage firms and other financial institutions added some 13,000 workers. At the other extreme, retailers added some 50,000 workers, nearly half of whom wound up waiting on tables or working cash registers in restaurants or bars. Seasonal businesses -- amusement parks, lawn services, hotel chains -- did lots of hiring, too.
Amazingly, the tight labor market has not brought on much inflation. Even with the 5 cent increase in average hourly earnings, pay is up just 3.7 percent from a year ago. That is about half a percentage point less than the pay increases employers were handing out last summer.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow, S.& P. and Nasdaq All Set New Closing Highs
On a day when investors and traders had their sights set on the long holiday weekend, the Dow Jones industrial average rose almost 73 points, reaching a new high for the first time in seven weeks. The two other major stock indexes set records for the third consecutive day. And in the bond market, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond was unchanged at 100 11/32, with its yield holding at 6 percent. 
 The Dow industrials finished up 5.6 percent for the week, the average's best performance since October 1998. The Dow average closed at 11,139.24. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 10.26 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,391.22. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 34.84 points, or 1.3 percent, to 2,741.02. Page C3.
 
G.M. and Ford Sales Increase in June
General Motors and Ford reported that their car and truck sales edged higher last month, as the entire auto industry recorded its best June in history and its second-best month ever. Sales, at 1.6 million vehicles, were 2 percent above levels of a year earlier. C4.
 
Internet Computers Are Breached
Hackers broke into network computers run by the Internet's new governing body, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, in an apparent attempt to fan the flames of a continuing struggle for control of the lucrative business of assigning Internet addresses known as domains. The F.B.I. was said to be investigating. C4.
 
Brazilian Senate Aids Bank
Brazil's Senate approved a measure erasing $3.4 billion in questionable securities from the books of Banco do Brasil, possibly averting insolvency at the 191-year-old bank, Latin America's largest. But the measure, which transferred responsibility for the securities from the bank to the federal treasury, has worried investors. C2.
 
Belo Buys Some MAC Assets
A. H. Belo, which publishes The Dallas Morning News and The Providence Journal, said that it would buy $315 million in assets from MAC America Communications. The acquisition will include KTVK, an independent television station in Phoenix, and the right to operate KASW, an affiliate of the WB television network in Phoenix, through a local marketing agreement. The acquisition will also include a 50 percent interest in the Arizona News Channel. C3.
 
Coca-Cola in Second Polish Recall
Coca-Cola is removing all half-liter bottles of its new mineral-fortified Bonaqua Plus purified water from stores in Poland because Government scientists have detected coliform bacteria in the product. About 180,000 bottles of the water had already been distributed by the bottler, Coca-Cola Beverages. The recall was Coca-Cola's second in Poland this week. C2. 
 
Dreamworks SKG Ends Studio Plan
Citing financing difficulties, Dreamworks SKG has abandoned its plan to build Hollywood's first new studio complex in more than 60 years on the site of Howard Hughes's aircraft factory near Los Angeles airport. A7.
 
Airport Technicians Criticize F.A.A.
Hundreds of technicians who maintain the nation's air traffic control computers picketed at 53 airports, handing out leaflets accusing the Federal Aviation Administration of causing big delays by botching its modernization program, not hiring enough technicians and not consulting them on the new equipment. A12.
 
U.S. Markets Closed Monday
The stock market and other financial markets in the United States will be closed Monday in observance of the Fourth of July. Most overseas markets, however, are open. United States markets will reopen on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: WORLD BUSINESS BRIEFING: ASIA;
HONGKONG STOCKS SURGE

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Hong Kong stocks posted their biggest gains in three months yesterday, led by banks and developers, on signs lower interest rates will continue to revive demand for loans and apartments. The Hang Seng index rose 652.44, or 4.8 percent, to 14,184.58, its highest close since Oct. 9, 1997, and its biggest one-day gain since April 7. HSBC Holdings P.L.C. and Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd. paced gains after the United States Federal Reserve indicated on Wednesday that it was not likely to raise rates a second time soon, after announcing a quarter- point increase. Hong Kong's market was closed on Thursday.

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 199 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
How World Stock Markets Fared in the Second Quarter

BYLINE: By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

 BODY:
Two years after Thailand devalued the baht -- touching off the Asian currency crisis and sinking the region into an economic ravine -- signs that Asian economies have begun to revive was the big story in the second quarter.
 Indonesia, among the hardest hit at the height of the crisis, was among the best performers as the rupiah gained strength throughout the quarter and the country exhibited signs of political stability by holding its first free elections. 
 Hong Kong, too, was up strongly as the Government announced the creation of a mutual fund to dispose of its huge stock holdings, easing fears that it would flood the market and drive down prices. At the same time, investors spent most of the quarter concerned about the possibility of rising interest rates in the United States, tempering their enthusiasm.
 Outside of Asia, markets were relatively quiet. In Brazil, which devalued its currency in the first quarter, mixed signals left investors alternately bullish and bearish on the country's near-term prospects. The economy contracted more slowly than expected, but a series of rate cuts were not enough to meet investor expectations.
 DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
BRIEF INTERVIEWS WITH HIDEOUS MEN, by David Foster Wallace. (Little, Brown, $24.) In their depictions of characters whose deviant behavior puts them an angstrom away from undiluted sociopathy, these stories employ an incisive moral sensibility to dissect WASP-y male self-absorption.
 
THE FIRST WORLD WAR, by John Keegan. (Knopf, $35.) A military historian narrates the conflict once characterized with nave optimism as the Great War, elegantly conveying what it felt like to live, and die, in Europe's muddy trenches.
 
I COULD TELL YOU STORIES: Sojourns in the Land of Memory, by Patricia Hampl. (Norton, $23.) Essays exploring the nature of personal narrative seek to complete, and illuminate, the following analogy: memoir: truth; memory: (Answer: received history.)
 
JONATHAN SWIFT: A Portrait, by Victoria Glendinning. (Holt, $35.) A life of the obscure country vicar and inveterate bath taker turned dirty-minded public rogue suggests that its subject may have suffered from one of the earliest recorded cases of obsessive-compulsive disorder.
 
MATISSE: Father & Son, by John Russell. (Abrams, $39.95.) In a biographical diptych informed by previously unpublished family correspondence, Matisse p<heart>re and Matisse fils emerge as twin titans, one at making art, the other at selling it.
 
TIMBUKTU, by Paul Auster. (Holt, $22.) Bereft of his longtime companion, this novel's flea-bitten protagonist longs for nothing more than a bed, a bone and a biscuit but will settle for perpetual enlightenment.
 
TIME OUT OF MIND: The Diaries of Leonard Michaels, 1961-1995. (Riverhead, $24.95.) The multiply and turbulently married author of "The Men's Club" set down his observations on three decades of friends, wives and children in a stack of notebooks, which he carried with him wherever he went so that no one would read them. Now you can.
 
TOUGH, TOUGH TOYS FOR TOUGH, TOUGH BOYS, by Will Self. (Grove, $23.) Short fiction, at once amusing and appalling, that glories onomatopoetically in the yucky and unmasks revulsion as a species of the genus Desire.
 
THE VIEW FROM ALGER'S WINDOW: A Son's Memoir, by Tony Hiss. (Knopf, $24.) In his steadfastly loyal, often painfully raw portrait of his father, the author maintains that the man he recalls as a loving and humane figure could not possibly have been a Soviet spy.
 
WHO'S IRISH? Stories, by Gish Jen. (Knopf, $22.) Focusing on the lives of Chinese immigrants to the United States, these short stories are concerned with the confusion of identities and tangle of loyalties that ensue when Old World parents confront their hyphenated children.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: July 4, 1999

SECTION: Section 7; Page 11; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2543 words

HEADLINE: E.R.

BYLINE: By Maureen Dowd; Maureen Dowd is an Op-Ed page columnist for The Times.

 BODY:

Eleanor Roosevelt
 Volume 2: 1933-1938.
 By Blanche Wiesen Cook.
 Illustrated. 686 pp. New York:
 Viking. $34.95. 
 For many years I had, hanging in my kitchen, a wonderful picture of Eleanor Roosevelt, smiling saucily in a cream satin Jean Harlow-style gown. Though she was proud to be F.D.R.'s "hair shirt," she liked pretty clothes. And I loved seeing Eleanor looking glam. It was annoying when the P.C. police dictated that her statue at the Roosevelt Memorial in Washington could have no jaunty fox fur. She is a figure of such poignancy and inspiration, rejected by her mother, betrayed by her husband, oppressed by her mother-in-law, holding her shyness and loneliness at bay with Sisyphean efforts for those in need, I liked to think she had moments when she just felt swell.
In Volume 2 of her biography of Eleanor Roosevelt, covering the years 1933 to 1938, Blanche Wiesen Cook continues her diligent pentimento, getting at the tender, sprightly creature behind the starchy, strident image, chronicling how the timid housewife and mother of five shed her chrysalis and turned into the New Deal's relentless "Eleanor Everywhere."
She refused to play the wallflower, transforming herself into a party-loving First Lady, elegant in silver lame and black satin gowns. One night, after a black-tie dinner, she and Amelia Earhart went skylarking in their long dresses, flying from Washington to Baltimore. The aviatrix in white evening gloves let Mrs. Roosevelt, who had taken flying lessons, handle the controls until the Condor did a serpentine turn. She acted with breezy informality, once shocking Howell G. Crim, the chief White House usher, by showing up in a yellow bathing suit to give him letters to mail. "Eight years later," one of his subordinates wrote, "Mr. Crim was still aghast."
Eleanor Roosevelt was 48 when she became First Lady and came to the cap- ital, labeled "that small ungenerous town" by her ferociously feminist biographer. "Before she entered the White House, E.R. cast about for models to understand her new role and decide just what she might do from within the confines of the President's house," Cook writes. "The record was grim, and every one of her predecessors sickened or died in the place. Washington was a lethal town for wives, with an odious history for women."
Not much has changed. Just in recent memory, Barbara Bush, Alma Powell and Tipper Gore have all confessed to going through periods of depression, and an often angry, sad and bitter Hillary Rodham Clinton has channeled Eleanor Roosevelt for solace on the difficulty of trying to break out of that First Lady straitjacket.
On the day of her husband's first inaugural, Mrs. Roosevelt told re- porters, "No woman entering the White House . . . can lightheartedly take up residence here." She designed the White House china and chose the flowers, but perhaps because she was abandoned, again and again, by those she loved, she was driven to help the neglected and rejected in society.
She did not triangulate. She did not worry if she was popular. She did not smile at her husband adoringly. She did not, as more modern First Ladies have so assiduously done, feign agreement with her husband on every issue. "From that time to this, no other First Lady has actually rushed for her pen to jab her husband's public decisions," Cook writes. "But E.R. did so routinely, from her first condemnation of the misogynist clause in his 1933 Economy Act which resulted in the dismissal of federally employed wives, to her major 1938 essay 'This Troubled World,' which was a point-by-point rejection of F.D.R.'s major international decisions."
It is remarkable, when you think of Hillary Clinton's treacly ghostwritten newspaper column, to see just how vinegary Eleanor Roosevelt's newspaper pieces were. In February 1933, as Franklin was preparing his first Presidential acts, Eleanor was already attacking him in her column and an unsigned editorial in a newspaper she had founded, arguing that taxes should not be lowered in the face of dire social needs, and that there should be more public spending. F.D.R., Cook writes, "demanded space in the March issue to answer his wife and defend his first legislative acts. Between his mother and his wife, F.D.R. was accustomed to outspoken opinionated women. But he did expect public unity on politically volatile issues."
Adjusting to her husband's romantic entanglements, first with her friend and social secretary, Lucy Mercer, and then with his own secretary, Missy LeHand -- F.D.R. moved a large seven-drawer highboy in front of the doors that connected his wife's study to his bedroom -- Mrs. Roosevelt did not get jealous or bitter. "Whatever she actually felt, E.R.'s public attitude toward Miss LeHand was that of first wife to second wife in the culture of extended ruling families," Cook observes. As Mrs. Roosevelt wrote in her memoir, "You Learn by Living," in a veiled reference to Missy, she was occasionally unable to "meet the need of someone whom I dearly love," and then "you must learn to allow someone else to meet the need, without bitterness or envy, and accept it."
She fought off hurts, disappoint- ment, dread and her "Griselda moods," and turned her office into a radical parallel universe: "With the women activists of the Democratic Party, E.R. spent hours preparing lists of notable candidates for every level of government work. She wrote columns, stunned radio audiences, created endless controversy. The First Lady-elect was in the news almost every day -- upsetting the complacent, encouraging people to imagine new liberal efforts to confront the Depression."
She did not engage in the shadowy manipulation practiced by other opinionated First Ladies. While her husband rarely credited or acknowledged her influence, even when he was cribbing her ideas, he encouraged her prodding. "Lady," he said, after arguing with her one night, "this is a free country. Say what you think. If you get me in Dutch, I'll manage to get myself out. Anyway, the whole world knows I can't control you."
Unlike Hillary, Eleanor ignored personal insults, sloughed off negative news stories, waved off critics who called her part of a Communist brain trust of the New Deal and Republicans who called her a Bolshevik, kept the ability to laugh at herself and galloped ahead. Her mission came ahead of her image, and she knew how to use the press to shape public opinion. When the White House had to cut its budget by 25 percent, she fired white employees, on the theory that the whites would have an easier time finding jobs than blacks. When she arranged for a housing project for the poor in West Virginia, she insisted on indoor privies, noting that in matters of simple dignity and decency, you should not be able to tell the rich from the poor.
Cook's first volume fascinated with the tragedies and struggles that shaped Eleanor's nature, and with its rich characters -- Anna Roosevelt, Eleanor's beautiful mother, who always treated her daughter like an ugly duckling and who died at the age of 29, when Eleanor was 8; Elliott Roosevelt, her charming and adoring father, who succumbed to alcoholism at 34, when Eleanor was 10; her passionate feminist teacher at boarding school in Paris, Marie Souvestre; and Franklin Delano, a mama's boy and preppy dismissed by the girls in his set as "Feather Duster."
This volume is interesting but less compelling, and should have included the war years. The writing is dutiful at points, and because Eleanor's character is formed now, and she knows her causes, there is less drama. It offers a litany of Eleanor's vigorous fights on discrimination, housing, health care, education and women's rights, and gives an exhaustive account of her romantic friendship with Lorena (Hick) Hickok, the heavyset, mannish Associated Press reporter who loved martinis and bourbon and cigarettes. Hick covered Mrs. Roosevelt on the campaign trail and then became her most "intimate friend," sometimes living at the White House. "E.R.'s friendship with Lorena Hickok was the most ardent and absorbing relationship of her middle years," Cook writes.
Mrs. Roosevelt believed strongly in the right of public figures to private lives. "Every human soul has its own secrets and its own right to keep them buried if it wishes," she said. But Cook, a professor of history at John Jay College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, who dedicates her book to her mother and, she says, in part to the "lives of example" of Bella Abzug and several other women, tries to draw Mrs. Roosevelt out of the Sapphic closet. She cannot say for sure that her close friendships with two lesbian couples and with Hickok were sexual, but she decides they "embraced amorosity." In the first volume, Cook, quoting a letter from Hick telling Eleanor, "I remember your eyes, with a kind of teasing smile in them, and the feeling of that soft spot just northeast of the corner of your mouth against my lips," concludes, "Sigmund Freud notwithstanding: A cigar may not always be a cigar, but the 'northeast corner of your mouth against my lips' is always the northeast corner."
THE letters, meant to help Hick write Eleanor's biography, are, Cook declaims, an "arc of love and longing, ardor and disappointment." The First Lady addressed Hick as "darling," "dear one" and "dearest," wrote "je t'aime" and "je t'adore," read poetry aloud to her when they went on holidays and confessed spurts of jealousy. She writes Hick that she missed her warmth in bed when she wasn't there, and she had to use a "sleeping bag and a hot-water bottle." She dangled the possibility that they might live together after the White House, ending one letter, "Darling, I ache for you," and another, "And I love to feel you love me just as you do & I do." She tried to pay for Hick's new Plymouth convertible, but Hick returned the check. Eleanor wrote back, "I could spank you."
Just as the press did not report or take pictures of F.D.R.'s paralyzed legs, they cut Mrs. Roosevelt some slack. They sometimes trailed her, with one Princess Di-like car chase, but she could usually get rid of them. She rented an apartment in Greenwich Village, built her own little house near her mother-in-law's house in Hyde Park, N.Y., and took off on driving holidays with Hick and other friends.
The First Lady, who also maintained a close friendship with her former bodyguard Earl Miller, eventually decided she did not want an exclusive relationship with Hick, because it interfered with her intensity about politics. "She wanted, above all, to be unconfined," Cook writes.
F.D.R. was charming to Eleanor's lady friends. Almost the only time he put his foot down about her escapades was when Eleanor wanted to drive down from New York to Washington for his first inauguration in her blue Buick convertible with Hick and the dogs. He explained she had hostess duties.
Though she immoderately admires her subject, Cook details her frosty side -- When her clear blue eyes turned to ice, warmth drained from the very walls of the room" -- and finds some flaws. She sees Mrs. Roosevelt's passive-aggressive side in the rowdy dogs she agreed to get rid of only after they lunged at several children and bit a diplomat and a senator and a reporter, and in her refusal to replace Henrietta Nesbitt, the head housekeeper in the White House, who insolently served undercooked and overcooked gruel to an epicurean President for 12 years. It got to the point where the hungry President had to order out from neighboring hotels or rely on gift baskets sent by friends. Like George Bush with his broccoli, F.D.R. made national headlines when he had a "tizzy-wizzy," as his wife put it, over watery spinach. "In anticipation of ghastly repasts," Cook writes, "some White House guests routinely dined before they arrived."
Cook finds most fault with her subject on her silence on the growing violence against Jews in Hitler's Germany: "Silence is the ultimate collusion." The First Lady had been instructed by the State Department to say nothing on other international crises. Cook can only speculate why the usually irrepressible Eleanor Roosevelt muzzled herself: "F.D.R. relied upon and required the enormous German and Catholic vote; and the support of the Southern Democrats who dominated Congress. . . . Eleanor relied on her Jewish friends, including Elinor Morgenthau and Bernard Baruch, who feared that domestic Jew-hatred would be intensified by protests against Germany's official anti-Jewish decrees. . . . Whatever the reason, the United States' determined silence of 1933-38, combined with Britain's appeasement and collaboration, allowed Hitler to believe he had no serious opponents."
Like others in the WASP hierarchy, Mrs. Roosevelt displayed a casually anti-Semitic attitude in private. Forced to attend a party for Bernard Baruch when F.D.R. was Assistant Secretary of the Navy, Eleanor wrote to her mother-in-law, "I'd rather be hung than seen at" it, since it would be "mostly Jews." Afterward, she reported back: "The Jew party was appalling. I never wish to hear money, jewels and sables mentioned again."
Her ugly comments diminished, Cook says, as her friendship with Baruch and other Jews flourished. She was grateful to Baruch because he "looks on me as a mind, not as a woman." By the time of the New Deal, she was coming around, risking criticism to meet with Jewish groups, supporting an array of Jewish causes and writing articles urging tolerance. "It is the secret fear that the Jewish people are stronger or more able than those who still wield superior physical power over them, which brings about oppression," she wrote in Liberty magazine. "I believe that those nations which do not persecute are saved only by confidence in themselves and a feeling that they can still defend themselves and their own place in the world. Therefore, I am forced to the conclusion that the Jewish people though they may be in part responsible for the present situation are not as responsible as the other races who need to examine themselves and grapple with their own fears."
Besides Hick, one of her closest friendships was with Louis Howe, F.D.R.'s brilliant, gnomish strategist. Howe taught her two great lessons: "Never admit you're licked" and "If you have to compromise, be sure to compromise up." In a letter to Hick, the First Lady said that Howe "wanted to 'make' me President when F.D.R. was through, and insisted he could do it."
In 1936, she summarized for women in public life what she had learned:
"You cannot take anything personally.
"You cannot bear grudges.
"You must finish the day's work when the day's work is done.
"You cannot get discouraged too easily.
"You have to take defeat over and over again and pick up and go on.
"Be sure of your facts.
"Argue the other side with a friend until you have found the answer to every point which might be brought up against you.
"Women who are willing to be leaders must stand out and be shot at. More and more they are going to do it, and more and more they should do it."
She added that "every woman in public life needs to develop skin as tough as rhinoceros hide."
Are you listening, Hillary?
