HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

A Tenant's Storage Space
 
Q. As a rent-stabilized tenant in a New York City co-op for 21 years, I have used the tenants' luggage and trunk storage area in the basement. The co-op is now interviewing contractors to remodel this storage area into pay-for-use storage bins. I need this space but cannot afford to pay for it. Can the co-op take the space away from me and/or start charging me for it? . . . Yvonne Cunningham, Manhattan.
 
A. "The reduction of a tenant's storage space is usually a hotly contested issue," said Daphna Zekaria, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer. "And it's an issue that is usually resolved by the Division of Housing and Community Renewal upon a tenant's complaint of a decrease in services." 
 Ms. Zekaria said that the Rent Stabilization Code prohibits the reduction of services supplied by a landlord as part of a rent-stabilized tenancy. And generally, she said, the D.H.C.R. will order a rent reduction to compensate for the elimination of a service, provided that the service not considered "de minimis."
The determination of whether a reduction of storage space is de minimis, she said, would be made pursuant to a D.H.C.R. memorandum specifically addressing the issue. In short, Ms. Zekaria said, the memorandum states that unless the storage space is provided for in a separate rider to the tenant's lease (as opposed to a general clause in a standard residential lease), or unless the owner has provided tenants with individual storage boxes, bins or separated gated areas within three years of the filing of the tenant's complaint, a rent reduction will not be ordered.
If the tenant's lease rider contains a provision for storage space, Ms. Zekaria said, the tenant would also be able to file a civil action in State Supreme Court requesting the court to order the landlord to continue to provide the service. Since the letter-writer is a tenant in a co-op, Ms. Zekaria said, and since the co-op apparently intends to continue to make storage space available, albeit for a fee, the tenant's landlord could continue to provide the storage area simply by renting the space from the co-op and letting the tenant use it.
 
Co-op Sponsors' Renting Apartments
 
Q. It seems that some sponsors who converted their buildings to co-ops have now, in effect, reverted the buildings back into rental buildings by leasing and re-leasing apartments that were not sold at the time of the conversion. This impacts negatively on the value of units owned by shareholders who purchased their apartments because new purchasers have difficulty getting mortgages in buildings with high numbers of non-owner-occupied apartments. Are there any laws governing the amount of time a sponsor can rent an apartment? . . . Carol Miller, Manhattan.
 
A. James G. Samson, a Manhattan co-op lawyer, said that there is no law that specifically requires co-op sponsors to sell unsold units by any particular point in time.
However, Mr. Samson said, the courts have ruled that a co-op corporation can sue a sponsor for monetary damages for fraud or breach of contract if the sponsor fails to make a good-faith effort to sell unsold units.
He explained that since the offering plans for most conversions stated that the sponsor was offering all the units in the building for sale, buyers could reasonably be led to believe that all apartments in the building would ultimately be sold to individual residential owners.
Failure of the sponsor to make a good-faith effort to do so, he said, would constitute a breach of the offering plan. While it is typically quite expensive for a co-op to maintain such a lawsuit -- legal bills can run into hundreds of thousands of dollars, he said -- the battle usually ends up being even more expensive for the sponsor.
Mr. Samson explained that a sponsor who owns the shares of unsold apartments has an obligation -- like any other shareholder -- to pay his or her share of the expenses of the co-op, including the co-op's legal fees.
"That means that if a sponsor owns 50 percent of the units in a building, he ends up paying 50 percent of the co-op's legal expenses and 100 percent of his own," Mr. Samson said. "That's why many of these cases end up settling."

HEADLINE: In the Region /New Jersey;
Office Space for Sublet Jumps as Companies Revamp

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
LIKE families trading their current home for a larger or smaller one as their space needs change, companies have been rearranging their corporate houses at an increased rate in the last six months due to mergers, acquisitions or consolidations, brokers say.
That has led to more than doubling the amount of sublet space filtering back onto the 11-county northern and central New Jersey office market, which now stands at 4.3 million square feet, according to Grubb & Ellis, a national commercial brokerage. Subleases represent 17.4 percent of the overall available office space in the state today, according to Cushman & Wakefield, another national brokerage. 
 A main contributor to the sublet space supply is AT&T. The company's work force of 25,000 employees, down from 31,000 since it splintered into three companies, is being consolidated into buildings it owns. "So a lot of the leased space we had is no longer needed," said Ritch Blasi, an AT&T spokesman.
He said his company had 715,000 square feet of such space on the market, including a 400,000-square-foot building off Interstate 78 in Berkeley Heights.
Among the other companies reconfiguring their space needs is the Hoechst Corporation, a pharmaceutical and chemical concern, which is subletting a 210,000-square-foot building in Warren Township. Alpharma, also a pharmaceutical company, is subletting 37,000 square feet in Fort Lee, while the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is subletting a 165,000-square-foot building on the Jersey City waterfront.
The bankruptcy earlier this year of Pinnacle Health Enterprises of Reston, Va., which managed the HIP Health Plan of New Jersey, and the H.M.O's liquidation last March has also put 207,000 square feet of medically oriented office space back onto the market. Much of the space has reverted to the original leaseholders, including Horizon Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New Jersey, and is being marketed for sublease.
No one is sounding any alarms about the increase in sublet space, which is considered among the signs of a softening market. But brokers say they are watching it.
"Of the market indicators we track, it's the only one pointing in the wrong direction," Arthur Della Salla, regional research manager at Grubb & Ellis, said of sublet space. "All the other indicators are pointing in the right direction."
The state's economy is strong, businesses are growing and rents continue to rise, although not as rapidly as in the last two years. Average overall asking rents are $22.68 a square foot a year, up from $22.30, six months ago. The average rent for Class A space, newer space in prime locations, is
$25.73, according to Grubb & Ellis.
At the same time, new buildings, many built on speculation, are adding to the buildup of space.
"Up until nine months ago, New Jersey had an undersupply of space," said Robert J. Rudin, executive managing director at the Saddle Brook office of Insignia/ESG, a national commercial brokerage. "That led to new construction at the same time sublet space was coming on the market, creating a slight oversupply of space."
SOME 3.8 million square feet of space are now under way, with a million more feet completed in the last nine months, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Meanwhile, in the second quarter, 454,263 more square feet were put on the market than were absorbed.
Cushman & Wakefield also said that the vacancy rate for Class A space rose to 9.9 percent in the second quarter from 6.6 percent a year earlier.
The increase was most pronounced in the I-78 corridor in Somerset County, where a spate of new construction and sublet space has been put on the market, pushing the vacancy rate to 18.4 percent from 7.7 percent, data from Cushman & Wakefield show.
The question, many brokers said, is whether the buildup of space is a temporary blip or a long-term trend. The other unknowns that could affect the market are whether interest rates continue to rise and whether the state's tight employment grows even tighter, said Jonathan Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization, a commercial brokerage in Woodbridge.
But brokers, like developers, are betting the situation is short term.
"Leasing activity is not its highest level and absorption is not fabulous," said Donald P. Eisen, executive managing director of the New York region for Cushman & Wakefield. "But there is caution in the market, which is good because developers are not feeling they can do anything they want and the market will get them out of trouble."
Mr. Rudin of Insignia/ESG added that speculative construction might stop for a while, allowing space to be absorbed. "This is not an oversupply situation like the 1980's, when the market was depressed and vacancy rates hit 18 percent," he said. "So the window will quickly close."
Meanwhile, sublet space has become a factor in the market. One appeal of such space is that it is generally offered at discounted rents because companies want to fill it quickly to minimize their expenses, brokers said. The trade-off is that the new tenant usually has to accept the space as is, they said.
The impact of such space varies, depending on the amount of vacant or new space in a given submarket. In the I-78 corridor, for instance, where new buildings have sprouted or are under way, subleases are adding to the competition. They include AT&T's 400,000-square-foot building in Berkeley Heights and Hoechst's 210,000-square-foot building on Independence Blvd. in Warren.
A new building completed in December, the Connell Corporate Center III, with 245,000 square feet, is the third of three buildings -- the first is the one AT&T is subletting -- on the 170-acre business campus off I-78 being developed by the Connell Realty and Development Company of Westfield. It ultimately will contain 1.7 million square feet.
"No, we're not competing with ourselves," Lee S. Martino, a vice president at Connell said of the AT&T sublease. "But the additional inventory in the area has had an impact. It's about supply and demand, and now there is more of a supply."
Mr. Martino said the new building recently attracted tenants, including Microsoft and Schering-Plough, which together signed on for 129,000 square feet.
Not far away, the Wellsford Commercial Properties Trust, based in Chatham, last April completed the renovation and expansion of a two-story, 92,000-square-foot building into a four-story structure with 120,000 square feet. It is part of a two-building complex on Mountain Avenue in Berkeley Heights.
The second building, with 175,000 square foot, has been fully leased since Wellsford acquired the complex in 1996.
"Subleases create greater competition, so you have to fight harder for deals," said Leo Paytas, director of leasing at Wellsford. But the impact will be short-term, he said, noting that in the last one or two months "new space requirements have come onto the market."
He said part of his company's strategy was to offer the Mountain Avenue space at rents 10 percent below market.
Lower rent is also what will attract tenants to the Hoechst building, said Mr. Rudin of Insignia/ESG, which is marketing the space. He said the company would leave the two-year old building, where 13 years are still remaining on the lease, late this year to relocate to a building it owns on Route 24 in Summit.
In tight markets like the Jersey City waterfront, or those like Fort Lee where limited new construction is taking shape, subleases provide a "viable alternative," said Leonard T. Miller, a director at Cushman & Wakefield. He is making that pitch to tenants as he markets the 37,000 square feet of space Alpharma is subletting at the Fort Lee Executive Park on Route 4 because it needs to move to larger quarters to meet its expansion needs.
That is also the case for the medical-oriented space left behind from the HIP-Pinnacle bankruptcy, said Mr. Schultz, who is marketing four out of the nine spaces. They are in Brick, Clifton, Parsippany and Jersey City and together total 90,000 square feet.
"The space is a commodity," he said, "because it offers tenants an opportunity to enter a market at a less expensive cost."

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
That Family Figure Watching Over Us Is Not Big Brother

BYLINE: By SARAH BAYLISS; Sarah Bayliss is an associate editor of Artnews magazine.

 BODY:
CONTRARY to popular belief, Uncle Sam wasn't born on the Fourth of July but on Sept. 13, 1766, in Arlington, Mass. And he had many guises before James Montgomery Flagg painted a stern, white-haired man proclaiming, ungrammatically, "I want YOU for U.S. Army."
Uncle Sam's namesake was Samuel Wilson, a meat packer who settled in Troy, N.Y., and supplied food to American troops during the War of 1812. 
 According to legend -- and to an eyewitness report published in The New-York Gazette and General Advertiser in 1830 -- a workman joked that the letters "U.S." on Wilson's shipping crates stood for "Uncle Sam" Wilson. The anecdote spread and led to the patriotic symbol now reproduced in political cartoons, advertisements, posters and fine art. Images of Uncle Sam, including portrayals by Currier & Ives, Thomas Nast, Charles Dana Gibson and Andy Warhol, can be seen in "Uncle Sam: The Face of a Nation," at the New-York Historical Society in Manhattan through Aug. 21.
In truth, Samuel Wilson's life had little to do with Uncle Sam, except that he was a tall, enterprising Yankee. As he evolved into a star-spangled icon, Uncle Sam surpassed Lady Liberty, Columbia, Yankee Doodle and Brother Jonathan as the most popular personification of America. Since then, he has endorsed American products from Liberty Bonds to cleaning powder to Ex-Lax. Star-spangled hats can be found on old Grateful Dead albums, and Allen Ginsberg wore one in 1966 for a Central Park peace rally. Today, the red, white and blue top hat pops up as a screen icon for Turbotax, the popular software used to calculate income-tax returns.
In the 19th century, Uncle Sam represented rural, down-home America -- most of the country -- in contrast to Britain's portly mascot, John Bull. In some cartoons, Uncle Sam and his shabby alter-ego, Brother Jonathan, were interchangeable. More often, though, Uncle Sam represented the Federal Government and Brother Jonathan the common man. "Uncle Sam Sick with La Grippe," an 1836 cartoon by Edward Williams Clay, finds him wearing a flaglike robe, weakened by a financial crisis. A humble Brother Jonathan appears outside a window, greeting the doctor. Thomas Nast, the political cartoonist whose comic inventions included the Democratic donkey and the Republican elephant, is credited with popularizing Uncle Sam's goatee. In Nast's "Uncle Sam's Thanksgiving Dinner" (1869), the avuncular host presides over a banquet table of guests symbolizing different nations, including stereotypes of Chinese, Spanish and Irish families.
If some early portrayals of Uncle Sam now seem racially insensitive -- many show the lanky patriarch attended by crude caricatures of African- and Asian-Americans -- he carried great authority during times of national crisis. "Lady Liberty came to be associated with the single topic of immigration," says Grady Turner, co-curator of the New-York Historical Society show. "She doesn't rally you to patriotism going into war. Uncle Sam is a warrior figure." Perhaps that is why Mr. Flagg chose him for his now-famous World War I recruitment image, created for a 1916 cover of Leslie's Illustrated Weekly Newspaper and reprinted the next year on posters.
With some four million copies distributed during World War I and more than one million during World War II, it was the most famous, and most parodied, American poster of all time.
Today, Uncle Sam's severe patriotism is too old-fashioned for the Army's "Be all that you can be" campaign (though he does appear, saluting, on a new 33-cent stamp). "Uncle Sam is a historical keepsake," says Douglas Smith, a public affairs representative for Army recruitment. "We don't want to portray ourselves as a World War I or World War II recruiting agency. The modern concept of the Army is that you serve your country and your service comes with benefits back to you."
It's also likely that Uncle Sam's Yankee heritage doesn't hold sway with current American racial demographics. "A nation that sees itself as diverse can't rally behind an old white man from the Northeast," says Mr. Turner.
Maybe not, but it can parody and adapt him for a variety of purposes.
Since the 1960's, Uncle Sam has championed causes from the discriminatory to the ridiculous. "Uncle Sam has become the symbol of radicalism and counter-culture movements," says Elena Millie, the curator of the poster collection at the Library of Congress and of a 1994 Uncle Sam poster show.
"When people see him, they say: 'Oh. What's he doing for us now?' " In spoofs of Flagg's picture, Uncle Sam has endorsed the Ku Klux Klan, civil rights and the admission of homosexuals to the military. A 1968 poster supporting Pope Paul VI's ban on birth control among Roman Catholics featured Uncle Sam admonishing Americans against taking the Pill. Ben and Jerry's 1994 search for a chief executive officer for their ice cream company had him saying, "We want you to be our C.E.O."
Indeed, Uncle Sam's survival probably rests on the fact that any fringe group can claim him as a spokesman. "Uncle Sam can mean everything to everybody -- he can have great power," says Mike Darnall, the author, with the illustrator Alex Ross, of the graphic novel "Uncle Sam," published by DC Comics earlier this year. In the book, a tattered and confused Uncle Sam wanders through time in a dank American landscape, at one point getting into a fistfight with his own double. "I like to think that there was a certain civility in a country represented by gentle old Uncle Sam," says Mr. Darnall. "But we're living in a world where Senators call the President a scumbag. If Uncle Sam existed today, he would cover his ears in shock."
Mr. Turner notes that many children arrive at the New-York Historical Society show without knowing who Uncle Sam is. "He led to his own decline," Mr. Turner says, "by being a stereotype and consorting with other stereotypes."
Uncle Sam's future is still bright in some regions. Since 1961, Troy, N.Y., has been the official home of Uncle Sam, declared so by a 1961 bill pushed through Congress by Senators Jacob K. Javits and Kenneth Keating of New York, to the consternation of some modern-day Arlington residents who want to revive interest in Samuel Wilson's birthplace.
Sept. 13 is Uncle Sam Day in Troy, and Fred Polnisch, a local Uncle Sam impersonator, is busy keeping Samuel Wilson's story alive. Crowds love to hear about Uncle Sam Wilson, he says, almost as much as they like his star-spangled shoelaces. And if they don't know a lot about American history, they do have one strong association with Uncle Sam. "Some people ask me why I'm taking all their money for taxes," says Mr. Polnisch. "I tell them to write to their Congressmen."

LENGTH: 1331 words

HEADLINE: Summer Is Here, But Where Are The Lifeguards?;
To Fill the Chairs, State Learns to Be Inventive

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
WITH only about 100 people on the beach and the water temperature a frigid 58 degrees last month, Rob O'Brien, a lifeguard at East Beach at Cove Island Park in Stamford, did not have to worry about anyone venturing out too far.
Though he has been a lifeguard for five years and is also a qualified water safety instructor, Mr. O'Brien, who is a college student, makes less money as a lifeguard than he could as a clerk at Home Depot or a waiter at a restaurant. But his love of the beach, coupled with a sense of responsibility, brings him back to a lifeguard stand in Stamford every summer. 
 Given a strong economy and plenty of summer jobs, not all college students are as willing as Mr. O'Brien to forsake higher-paying jobs to work for an average of about $7.50 an hour as lifeguards. As a result, as the summer beach season gets into full swing, some beaches in the state, particularly at state parks, don't have enough lifeguards.
That's the case at Hammonassett State Park in Madison and Sherwood Island State Park in Westport. Norwich doesn't have enough guards for the pond in Mohegan Park and Fairfield could use a few more for the town's six beaches.
"At last count, we still needed about seven guards for jobs, which pay between $6.50 to $10 an hour," said Bill Mattioli, the water safety program coordinator for the Department of Environmental Protection, which oversees state parks. "We've tried to recruit at high schools, Y.M.C.A.'s and other places in search of guards, but it's more difficult than ever. Not only to young people want jobs that pay more, but a lot of them also don't want to assume the responsibility you have as a lifeguard."
The problem, which began about five years ago, has gotten so bad that some communities have had to find new ways to recruit. Stamford paid the $125 fee for a life-saving course to people who agreed to become lifeguards. Norwalk went after members of the high school swim team and Darien advertised on the Internet. The state even lowered its age requirements by a year, now allowing 16-year-olds to become guards. What few communities are doing, however, is raising the pay to make the job more attractive.
"There's no question in my mind that compensation levels have to be addressed," said John Roman, the aquatics director for four beaches and two public outdoor pools in Stamford, noting that Stamford pays its lifeguards between $7.50 and $10.75 an hour. "There's a misconception that lifeguards sit in a chair all summer and work on their tans, when in truth the job is a profession that requires intensive training."
Most lifeguards know that they could make more money elsewhere.
"I like the fact that the job entails responsibility and the fact that you build friendships with the other guards and become part of a team," said Peter Smith, a 19-year-old college sophomore who is a third-year lifeguard at Calf Pasture Beach. "True, the money isn't much, but I supplement what I make here by giving swim lessons at the Y on one of my three days off."
Rob Smith, the manager of Hammonassett State Park, said getting lifeguards used to be easy.
"Eighteen years ago, we had 32 guards, which was enough to cover the whole beach, but now we have 18," Mr. Smith said. "That means we can cover only about a mile and a quarter of the beach, which is two miles long, and have to fly yellow flags over the uncovered areas," -- the yellow flags signify that lifeguard stations in those areas are not staffed and that people must swim at their own risk.
Because of the difficulty in obtaining guards, Mr. Smith said he has been forced to hire more young people. "The average age used to be around 23, but now it's about 20," he said. "And this year, for the first time, we lowered the minimum age to 16."
Glenn Dochtermann, the park supervisor at Sherwood Island, said that he has had to fly more yellow flags the last few years.
"We used to have as many as 18 lifeguards at Sherwood Island, but we're down to only six the last few years, and we get as many as 15,000 people on a Saturday or Sunday," Mr. Dochtermann said. "Because of the shortage of guards last year, in addition to flying the yellow flags, we also had guards patrolling the beach by jet skis just beyond the swimming area. And we've also had to use kayaks and pontoon boats, since we haven't had enough guards in the chairs.
"To try to get guards this year, we recruited in schools and also distributed flyers in supermarkets and other places," Mr. Dochtermann said. "So far, we've managed to get 14 guards, which at least is a lot more than we had last year. Then, too, the state is paying lifeguards the same money as when I came on in 1989" -- between $6.50 and $10 an hour."
Mr. Mattioli of the Department of Environmental Protection said safety has not been compromised at the state parks, which can draw 35,000 people on a weekend day. "There's plenty of room to swim in areas where the beach is guarded," he said. "And that's what most people do."
Some communities, such as Norwich, have raised salaries this year. "We raised our rates a dollar to between $9 and $11 an hour,"said Luis DePina, the director of the Norwich Recreation Department, whose lifeguards oversee the pond in Mohegan Park. "But we're still short a few guards."
Pam Raila, the acquatics supervisor at Calf Pasture Beach in Norwalk, has something of a recruiting edge. "I go after members of the swim teams at Norwalk High School," said Ms. Raila, who is coach of the girls' swim team at the school.
Ms. Raila's recruiting efforts are reflected in the makeup of her lifeguard staff. Of the 16 guards, all nine young women who work full-time are swimmers at the high school as is one of the seven young men. "And of our 16 guards, all but one are back from last year," she said.
Stamford, with 65 lifeguards, is at full complement, but the city had to scramble to get their guards.
"It required a lot of hard work," said Scott Beauregard, the city's Assistant Superintendent for Recreation.
"We knew we could be in trouble this year because of all of the jobs out there for college and high school kids. So we actively recruited by distributing flyers at the high schools in town and also contacting guards we had had last year. In addition, we ran three 40-hour lifeguard training sessions, which cost $125 for the 21 people who took the course, with the understanding that we would reimburse the cost to those who signed on as lifeguards and stayed with us through the summer. As it developed, 12 of those who took the course are now guards."
Apart from distributing flyers at Greenwich High School, Fred Walters, the acting superintendent for marinas and facilities in Greenwich, said he does not actively recruit lifeguards.
"We manage to get the 36 we need at our four beaches," he said, "but it's nothing like 20 years ago when you'd get 40 applications for 20 jobs. Also, we also have to compete with the private clubs, which like to hire kids from the high school swim teams to be lifeguards and also serve as coaches and swim teachers."
Other affluent towns like Darien and Westport also have managed to fill their allotment of lifeguards.
"We contact guards from the previous year and also advertise on the Internet, and we finally got all 17 spots filled," said Marikate Murren, the recreation official in charge of hiring lifeguards in Darien.
Stewart McCarthy, the director of the Parks and Recreation department in Westport, said he was amazed that his department was able to hire the 50 guards needed at Compo Beach and for the community pool at the Longshore golf, tennis and swimming complex owned by the town.
"We give these young people an incredible amount of responsibility, and they're also exposed to hepatitis and A.I.D.S.," he said, "and yet they do it for between $7.25 and $10 an hour. But they do have a good work environment and get a sense of accomplishment for what they do. And to most of them, that's important."

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY;
TellingThem What They'll Pay to Hear

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst is a novelist and financial journalist. His column tilting at conventional business wisdom appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I ONCE knew a woman who couldn't seem to get her career off the ground. Her personal finances were a shambles, and she had little experience in the world of business. Naturally, she became a management consultant.
It crossed my mind to short the stock of any companies she visited, but I was afraid I'd get in trouble with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 We live in paradoxical times. Executive compensation is spiraling out of control, yet the more companies pay their chief executives, the more help they seem to need with basic questions like "What business are we in?" and "Where do we go from here?" Companies appear to be equally at sea about how to organize themselves -- hardly surprising, given that so many of their workers seem to produce nothing tangible.
The upshot is an army of management consultants, ready to feed what The Wall Street Journal recently called "the business world's seemingly insatiable desire to engage in organizational self-analysis." Kennedy Information Research Group, which tracks management consulting, says the global market grew 22 percent last year, to $89 billion, three-fifths of it in the United States; in 1980, the figure was just $2 billion.
But the industry, if you'll pardon the expression, isn't sitting on its laurels. "Management consulting continues to hunt for the 'next big idea,' " says a report on Kennedy's Web site. "Re-engineering has faded, replaced by E.R.P. integration, Knowledge Management, E.V.A. and supply chain work." Don't ask -- by the time you figure out any of these fads, they'll be over.
I don't mean to be a spoilsport. Hiring a consultant makes sense for many specialized tasks, from writing an annual report to designing a parking lot. But why do so many companies need outsiders to tell them how to run their businesses? It's as if top management, which lives in the same therapy-crazed culture as the rest of us, has decided that it must pay someone in a nice suit to nod sagely and tell it what it already knows, because it has trouble hearing the same message from anyone else.
There are now 70,000 management consultants in the United States, and about 150,000 executives at sizable companies in the kinds of jobs that would bring them into contact with consultants. That comes to just over two consulters for each consultant.
Those figures come from a paper by Staffan Canback, himself a consultant, published last year in The Journal of Management Consulting. "The tremendous growth of the management consulting industry over the last 20 years cannot be easily explained," Mr. Canback wrote. But he has a theory: The complexity of business today leads to high "costs associated with organizing economic activity," as he puts it, accounting for as much as 45 percent of gross domestic product in developed societies, according to one estimate he cited. Controlling these costs devours management attention and generates demand for consultants.
But what good is done by paying millions to a chief executive who then turns for help to a bunch of wet-behind-the-ears M.B.A.'s?
 PERHAPS hardest to justify are the executive compensation consultants, some of whom are said to charge $750 an hour. Graef S. Crystal, a critic of excessive executive pay and a sometime consultant himself, thinks compensation consultants may be best of breed when it comes to getting paid for smoke and mirrors, since they invariably recommend raises for the executives whose compensation they are hired to assess.
By comparison, consultants who flog "organizational development" are a bargain, offering services that, if no more useful, at least cost less. The thirst for their services seems impossible to slake. Mr. Crystal cites a remark by Eugene Zuckert, a former Secretary of the Air Force: "The perfect organization is the one you don't now have."
In a few minutes' surfing of the Web, I found a consulting firm that says its strength is "analyzing and re-engineering the Emotional Economics of our clients' workplaces." Another "offers programs and services in organizational change and development, facilitation, strategic planning and leadership training." The sites don't say what these firms charge, but I can't imagine they're cheap at any price.
Then again, all societies pay dearly for their shamans. Why should the world of business be any different?

HEADLINE: YOUNG THEATERGOERS;
Tears and Cheers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Until reading Wendy Wasserstein's article about her project to introduce theatergoing to New York City students, I could have honestly said that the newspaper had never made me cry "A Place They'd Never Been: The Theater," June 20 . But the reactions and feelings expressed by the eight students she took under her wing had me in tears. 
 Exposing the young to the theater should become the pet project of every producer, director, playwright, choreographer, designer, actor, singer, dancer and theatrical union in New York today. What could be more rewarding?
A grassroots effort like this one, sponsored by the Theater Development Fund, is a thumbed nose to those who would kill funding for the National Endowment for the Arts. Members of Congress who would do so should be ashamed not to understand that participating in our cultural heritage is absolutely essential to enriching it.
Moreover, an organized move like T.D.F.'s could help bring the magnificent invalid back to robust health and at the same time do more toward eradicating economic barriers between New Yorkers than any talk about the importance of theater by old white people on the Tony Awards.
Actions speak louder than words, and if those at the top of the theater food chain really want to see things grow, a project like Ms. Wasserstein's is the most practical, rewarding and enjoyable way to work toward that worthy goal.
I wish there were some way that I, as an individual, could volunteer to sponsor students through some organization like T.D.F. I would gladly pay for the tickets myself just to be able to share the wealth, so to speak. Sign me up, Wendy, and if it's deductible on my taxes, sign me up twice.
 
JOHN MICHAEL PACE
New York

HEADLINE: YOUNG THEATERGOERS;
Celebrity Power

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Ms. Wasserstein's effort to bring high school students to the theater is commendable but hardly gets to the root of the problem. Theater tickets are indeed expensive, but T.D.F. and its TKTS booths in Duffy Square and at the World Trade Center make it economically accommodating for folks determined to get to a play.
Until the city, state and Federal governments provide dollars to get the arts back into the school curriculum, the theater will be perceived as something beyond most students' reach. Involve a youngster in a school orchestra, an art class or a drama club, and they will be hungry to see how the professionals do it. 
 The theater could use its celebrity to pressure elected officials. Taking kids to a play should be a pleasurable supplement: the priority should be to effect institutional change.
When you consider the money we spend to incarcerate youngsters, we should match it dollar for dollar to educate our youth at all levels. For too many New York City public school students, doing time on Rikers Island is a greater probability than their attending a Broadway play.
 
DAVID ROTHENBERG
New York
 
The writer is the president of David Rothenberg Associates, a theatrical publicity firm.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 5; Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1768 words

HEADLINE: At a Wedding, It's Still Not In to Be Out

BYLINE: By BOB MORRIS 

 BODY:
SO it's 1999 and you're gay. So what? Your boss is gay. Ellen's gay. Will of "Will and Grace" is gay. Rupert Everett, who is gay and played a gay man in "My Best Friend's Wedding," is now playing Mr. Right in "An Ideal Husband." The media understand you. Your neighbors do, too. So do your parents. You're well integrated and well connected. In fact, without being boring, you're as self-actualized as any post-modern urban gay person can be.
Then one day -- poof! -- you're reduced to a quivering mass of neuroses. You've been invited to a wedding. Not a commitment ceremony for same-sex couples. But a straight wedding, where you're seated with some pleasant, provincial people who want to know which side -- bride or bridegroom? -- you're on, and then start asking your partner question after question about what he's doing there until they force him to declare, for all to hear, that he's not your business partner. 
 "For gay people, weddings are always a reminder of being outsiders," said Charles Silverstein, an Upper West Side psychologist and the author of several books about homosexuality. "Even when people are welcoming, as they usually are these days, weddings can be extremely alienating experiences. They raise all sorts of ambivalence and take on a meaning far greater than any party ever should."
It seems more ironic than romantic that June, the month for weddings, is also the month for gay pride. Nothing tests gay pride more than straight weddings, many gay men and women say. For those who live in any of the nation's ever-so-inclusive gay-friendly cities, weddings provide that increasingly rare opportunity to feel ashamed, or at least self-conscious.
Marriage, of course -- from Romeo and Juliet, Henry VIII and the Duke of Windsor to Dennis Rodman and Adam Sandler in "The Wedding Singer" -- is a frequent source of trauma, and wedding anxiety is a nondiscriminatory phenomenon that crosses religious and sexual lines. But for gay men and women, the quintessential rite of heterosexual life presents a unique set of anxieties.
Kamal Ayyildiz, a Manhattan writer, was invited to be a member of a wedding party by a bride he had known since the fifth grade, but the bridegroom's parents were not happy when they learned he was bringing his companion. At the rehearsal dinner at a country club in Roanoke, Va., Mr. Ayyildiz said, he and his boyfriend were the only two of the 40 guests not assigned seats. They ended up circling around and around the room, to their mounting embarrassment.
"It turned out that the groom's mother had panicked at the idea of a gay couple and didn't have places for us," Mr. Ayyildiz said. Eventually, the bride's parents offered seats at their table.
Mr. Ayyildiz's experience was an exaggerated example of what most gay people report at weddings, where brushes with overt homophobia are rare; much more common are subtle, often unintended -- and sometimes self-inflicted -- causes for uneasiness.
"When you're around people who aren't around gay people that often," said Steven Druckman, a freelance writer, "you start watching everything you're doing, even how you lean back in your chair and put your arm around your boyfriend's shoulder." Mr. Druckman and his partner are recuperating this weekend after an entire month of weddings, where, he said, he endured more than a few withering looks.
"Often one of the families doesn't want you there, so you end up feeling like pariahs," he said. "I wanted to dance with my boyfriend, but he said he didn't think it was right. You can't just assert yourself at such a large social gathering."
Even Ronald Hellman, an openly gay Manhattan psychiatrist, who was united in a big family-oriented commitment ceremony last month with his male lover, a Reform rabbi, could not quite work up the nerve to dance at a straight wedding held the week before his.
"We're about as out as we can be, but we couldn't dance," Dr. Hellman said. "Dancing is very ritualistic, and it's very heavy. You need to know you're in a safe gay space before you do it."
Brad Bessey thought he was safe when he was invited to walk a bride down the aisle at a recent wedding. Then the bridegroom's family objected because he was gay. So the bride decided to defuse their anxiety by seating Mr. Bessey, a producer for "Entertainment Tonight," with her fiance's family at the rehearsal dinner. He didn't flinch. Rather, he turned up the charm.
"When I'm at a wedding," he said, "I will do everything in my power to make sure that people feel good about each other."
In modern society, in fact, from Oscar Wilde to Isaac Mizrahi, gay people have often developed senses of humor as defense mechanisms, making them particularly entertaining as hosts and guests. They are often called upon at weddings to serve as toastmasters, or to offer last-minute style tips about the bride's bouquet or the bridegroom's mother's shade of lipstick.
"It always seems to be our job to loosen things up and provide a spark," said Ted Kruckel, a press agent, who also believes that gay men buy the best presents. "Weddings are by their nature staid. Gay people bring a sense of levity to the event because it's so irrelevant to our lives.
"And of course, we're needed. I often find myself being asked to make a toast that will be a nice tonic to the tedium of the proceedings."
Wayne Nathan recalled working with the florist Robert Isabell on the splashiest New York wedding of the late 1980's, that of Laura Steinberg and Jonathan Tisch, in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Gayfryd Steinberg called a week before her stepdaughter's wedding to say it was "too formal and stuffy," Mr. Nathan said. To counteract the pomposity, he hired a Brazilian band on stilts and booked a snow machine to blow white feathers around. "That was my great contribution as a gay man to New York culture," he said.
Mr. Nathan's sardonic tone is echoed by other gay men and women, who say they are subtly irked by what they perceive as a double standard: called upon to enliven the weddings of others, they are legally forbidden, of course, from having weddings of their own. Mr. Druckman, who is getting back in the saddle for another wedding next weekend, said that as much as he hates the affairs, he wouldn't mind having one of his own if they become legal. "That way, I can get my own blender," he said.
When her brother announced that he was getting married, Ann Northrup felt a little resentful as well. "There I was in a relationship for 15 years, and my brother was telling me that there are so many economic advantages to marriage that it seemed like the smartest thing to do," said Ms. Northrup, an Act Up member and a host of a cable show called "Gay U.S.A." "I cursed him out, and he ended up apologizing for the next 20 minutes." At his wedding reception, she made a toast that got her a laugh. "I announced that my brother and I shared the same taste in women," she said.
The playwright Jon Robin Baitz, meanwhile, recalls being in the middle of a toast at his brother's wedding, when he noticed that he was speaking to a sea of frozen faces.
"I was joking about maturity and commitment," said Mr. Baitz, who has been in a gay relationship for many years. "I thought I was just being honest. But I guess I didn't realize that I was talking about love in a cynical way that was very gay and inappropriate. I often end up feeling like I've stubbed my toe at weddings."
Many gay people feel uneasy when they are not invited to take a companion to weddings. One New Yorker has been invited to a wedding this month by a woman he has known for years. But the bridegroom's family is pressuring the bride to discourage him from bringing anyone with him.
"I completely want to participate in her wedding," he said. "But all my other friends have been invited to bring a guest. You don't want to make a fuss when people are already stressed out to the extreme with family politics at a wedding. But I really don't want to go alone. I guess the book of etiquette hasn't been written for people like us."
Ann Landers may not be able to give gay marriage her full support ("It flies in the face of cultural and traditional family life as we have known it for centuries," she has written). But salespeople at Tiffany's, Macy's and Barneys are doing everything they can short of breaking into song to make gay people feel good about registering for commitment ceremonies. Barneys even has a form to fill out that doesn't use the words bride and bridegroom, but rather partner and partner. There's a new book called "The Essential Guide to Lesbian and Gay Weddings." There are clergy members who will officiate (although not necessarily in an official capacity) and a vast segment of society that is looking for ways to open up to same-sex couples and wish them well. Still, many gay people aren't interested in aping the ceremony and social institution of marriage until it becomes legally binding.
Ultimately, for all their resentment and paranoia (not always justified), many gay people know that weddings are a trial that everyone must bear, gay and straight. Dan Savage, who writes a syndicated advice column, "Savage Love," gets lots of letters about weddings. "They've become so institutionalized that they're hollow and empty and depressing for everyone," he said, "and not just for the gay people who feel slighted because they can't have their own legal wedding that's hollow and empty and depressing, too."
Two years ago, Mr. Savage went to the wedding of his boyfriend's fundamentalist Christian brother in Spokane, Wash. He arrived ready to explode at the slightest offense, and ended up feeling, in addition to bored, welcome and at ease.
"These days, tolerance is the norm," said Mr. Savage, who chronicled his experience for Out magazine. "So spending all your time at a wedding trying to figure out who really likes you and who doesn't is exhausting and paranoid. I think that in the absence of the real tolerance we hope to find, the appearance of tolerance can be just as good."
Marcy Blum, a well-known wedding planner, agrees. "If gay people are acting paranoid or unhappy at weddings," said Ms. Blum, who often finds them acting otherwise, "it doesn't help an already tense situation." While she says she has never seen any homophobia at the weddings she has planned, Ms. Blum has seen lots of bridesmaids who looked as if they were ready to kill or die, often both.
"Hey, it's not easy being a gay person in a straight world," said Ms. Blum, who is 45 and divorced. "But it's not easy being a single woman, either."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 1028 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
The Smokestacks Are Back

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
AN OIL driller, a maker of industrial cutting tools, an acquisitive steel producer and a paper company. Those were the kinds of blue-collar stocks that fueled returns of the top-performing mutual funds in the second quarter.
Such value stocks, as well as small-capitalization issues, came roaring back during the spring, shoving aside the large-company growth stocks that had dominated the market for so long. 
 The managers of three of the top-performing funds talked about the quarter just ended and looked ahead to the rest of the year.
 
Think Like an Industrialist
"After a year of emphasis on growth and large-cap companies, when investors were not at all interested in value or small-cap companies, valuations simply reached the extremes," said Dennis Delafield, 63, co-manager of the $102.1 million Delafield fund with Vincent Sellecchia, 47. Delafield, which owns small- to mid-cap value stocks, was the No. 15 performing United States diversified stock fund for the quarter, up 28 percent.
"Investors might not care about the companies we own, but industrialists do," he said. "They look at companies with free cash flow and modest valuations, and they acquire or invest in those companies. And that's what happened."
Mr. Delafield made money when Getronics, a Dutch company, acquired Wang Laboratories, in which he owned shares. The company, based in Billerica, Mass., was known for word-processing systems but now services desktop computer systems and networks. Getronics bought 91 percent of the company in mid-June for $29.25 a share, a 50 percent premium to its price at the start of the quarter.
Another winner was Kennametal, a Latrobe, Pa., maker of industrial cutting tools. Its earnings for the fiscal year ended in June 1998 were depressed because of a troublesome acquisition and the market's general disregard for such stocks last year, he said. The stock has rebounded 76 percent since March as a cost-cutting program began to bear fruit and the company named a new chief executive.
Mr. Delafield is now looking for clues to the direction of the world economy. "What happens the rest of the year depends on what happens in Europe and to interest rates," he said.
 
The Bargain Hunter
"The market is going through a rotational correction," said Jim Crabbe, 54, co-manager of the $98.7 million Liberty-Crabbe Huson Special fund with John Johnson, 62. The fund, a small-cap blend fund, returned 29.6 percent in the quarter, for ninth place among domestic diversified equity funds. "Some parts of the market are still very overpriced, but there are some tremendously good bargains, particularly among smaller companies," he said.
The fund's performance surge stands in stark contrast to its five-year return through June 30 -- negative 1.08 percent, annualized. The fund had been hurt severely because it shorted big stocks; it stopped doing so about a year ago, but that didn't solve the fund's problems. Last year, he said, "we owned a lot of economically sensitive stocks, and we got our clocks cleaned."
Among Mr. Crabbe's biggest recent winners was Marine Drilling, a Houston company that performs offshore drilling for the oil and gas industry. The company's share price plummeted when oil stocks were pounded at the end of last year. But that changed this spring. "There was a cutback in drilling for quite some time," he said, "but as people saw the price of gas increasing, they anticipated the company would start drilling again." The stock gained 24 percent in the quarter.
Another success for the fund was Ispat International, a Dutch steel producer, up 56 percent. Ispat bought Inland Steel, the American steel company, in the spring of 1998.
Mr. Crabbe expects the stock market's gains to continue broadening, reaching more small stocks. And the economy, he said, should keep growing. "There doesn't seem much danger that it won't continue plugging along at a pretty good rate," he said.
 
Ready for the Bounce
Investor optimism about the world economy was a big factor in fund performance for the quarter.
"Investors started becoming more aware that the U.S. economy was very strong and that world economies, especially Asia, were flat to getting better," said Robert J. Martorelli, who runs the $547.2 million Merrill Lynch Phoenix fund, a mid-cap blend fund that took the No. 12 place among domestic diversified equity funds, returning 29.1 percent. "In that kind of environment, cyclical companies tend to perform well."
Mr. Martorelli, 42, said he was buying oil and gas and other cyclical stocks at the end of 1998 and early 1999 "because that's where the value was."
Among his biggest winners was the LTX Corporation of Westwood, Mass., a maker of equipment for the semiconductor industry. LTX experienced slackening demand during the economic debacle in Asia last fall, but its stock rebounded as Asian economies stabilized, Mr. Martorelli said. He added that he liked LTX because demand for its new type of chip-testing device was growing rapidly along with the market for multifunctional chips used in increasing numbers of products. The stock rose 177 percent in the quarter.
Another success was Champion International, the paper company based in Stamford, Conn. Mr. Martorelli said he bought the stock in March because it was selling for the biggest discount to asset value among companies in its industry. Nothing happened in company operations to cause the subsequent rise in the stock price, he said, but investors thought paper prices had bottomed.
"Champion has a lot of earnings leverage, so a relatively small gain in paper prices produces incrementally larger gains in earnings," he said. Champion shares rose 17 percent in the quarter.
Mr. Martorelli expects value stocks to continue climbing as the economy keeps growing. "Strong economic expansion takes the cyclical risk out of our stocks, so investors can look at paper, chemical and steel companies and know that the demand for the products will be there," he said. "Besides, relative to the growth stocks that we had to watch grow endlessly over the last three to four years, these stocks are just cheap."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Which Waythe Fed? Sorting Out the Signals on Interest Rates

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE inflation debate has been whittled down to a single issue.
No longer does anyone fret much about shortages in the great array of goods and services that Americans consume. Sure, there can be temporary scarcities and bottlenecks, and short-lived price spikes. But in the eyes of the Federal Reserve, only one kind of shortage has the potential to be inflationary in the late 1990's: a labor shortage. And that, too, may be losing its teeth. 
 There is indeed a labor shortage. The statistics are clear, the main one being the unemployment rate, which came in Friday at 4.3 percent for June. People are getting jobs everywhere, even in the inner cities where entrenched joblessness is finally giving ground. In Boston, for example, inner-city people ride streetcars to the last stop, then take taxis the final few miles to jobs at suburban companies. To get the workers, the employers pay the taxi fares.
Such tactics, which allow companies to tap the nation's remaining pools of idle workers, help postpone the day when corporate America might really have to bid up wages.
"Things are definitely better in the inner city," said Katherine S. Newman, an anthropologist at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government who works in such neighborhoods. "But you would have to see the lines of the unemployed shrink by a lot more than they have before you would see major increases in wages."
By past standards, after 24 months with the unemployment rate under 5 percent, those major increases ought to have appeared already, if not in the inner cities then elsewhere in the country. Pay is rising, of course, but not yet by enough to force companies to try to raise prices. Until that happens, the Federal Reserve cannot justify pushing up interest rates sufficiently to slow the hiring by slowing the economy.
There are those who argue that a significant acceleration in wages is just around the corner. But strangely, even though the unemployment rate has fallen below 4.5 percent since last November, wages and salaries have risen more slowly in recent months. There is deceleration, not acceleration. The same deceleration also applies to the corporate cost of health insurance and other benefits. And economists are scrambling to explain the anomaly.
"There is no smoking gun," said Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute.
For starters, everyone agrees that companies have become a lot more agile at fending off wage increases, while labor's bargaining power has declined along with union representation. As one substitute for raises, companies offer stock options, which do not show up in the Labor Department's employment cost data. And one-time signing bonuses lure workers without obliging an employer to raise the pay of comparable workers already on the payroll.
Labor productivity is clearly part of the explanation. It has risen smartly in the last two or three years, which means that workers are producing more for the same hourly pay, at least for the time being.
At a grittier level, service companies, particularly telephone call centers, distribution centers and clerical operations, have become more mobile. For example, dozens have relocated to northern Kentucky, where unemployment was relatively high, and to towns in Maine where shuttered shoe factories and paper mills left pools of not-very-expensive workers. Government subsidies also encourage companies to move.
IN a new study, two labor economists, Alan B. Krueger of Princeton and Lawrence F. Katz of Harvard, find that the unemployment rate may be kept artificially low by the very sharp rise in the male prison population. Prisoners are not counted as either employed or unemployed; if they were on the street, many would show as unemployed.
Then there is the aging of the work force; older workers are less likely to be unemployed. And don't forget the growing temporary-help industry, which keeps people off unemployment rolls between permanent jobs.
Adjust today's unemployment rate for these three factors, and it would be around 5 percent, the study finds.
On a different plane, some experts explain the deceleration in wage growth by arguing that workers have become used to a low inflation rate and therefore settle for smaller raises, which seems strange when people are so much in demand.
Or perhaps job insecurity inhibits them. The National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago asks people how likely they think they are to lose their jobs. "The percentage of those who answer 'very likely' has not fallen all that much since the last recession," said Thomas Smith, director of the center's General Social Survey.
The list of explanations will certainly grow if the nation's tight labor market keeps failing to push up wages significantly. No one will collect these explanations with greater interest than the Federal Reserve's policy makers. They cannot push up interest rates much beyond last week's quarter-point rise without a significant rise in labor costs as justification.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Serving Up Hearty Meals of Information on Wheels

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
Charlene A. Patterson, 19, can rattle off a list of attractions in upper Manhattan the way other college students might list their favorite ballplayers: the Yeshiva Museum, the African-American Wax Museum, the Morris-Jumel Mansion, the Studio Museum. But even though she grew up in Harlem, Ms. Patterson had not heard of most of these places until a few weeks ago. "To tell the truth, I've lived here all my life and really didn't know there were this many things in the community," she said.
But anyone stopping by her visitors' cart at Broadway and 165th Street, near the Audubon cultural center, might find her wealth of information staggering. 
 "You'd be surprised how many people don't know what's in their own community," she said. "We try to tell them there's a museum right here 10 blocks away from you, and you don't need to go all the way downtown to experience the arts."
The information cart she tends is one of four that were placed in strategic locations in upper Manhattan last week as part of a new effort to promote tourism and economic development. Sponsored by the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, the Union Settlement Association and the Manhattan Borough President's office, the program, called Uptown Ambassadors, involved training and paying 10 college students from Harlem, East Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood to help tourists and residents navigate their neighborhoods.
"Tourism has the potential to have a significant economic impact on upper Manhattan's communities," said Rodney E. Lopez, director of communications for the empowerment zone. "So this initiative is designed to make sure that this important information about the area's historic sites and attractions is available to whomever wants it."
At each of the four carts -- at Audubon, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard and 125th Street, and Dyckman and 200th Streets -- one English- and one Spanish-speaking student at any time provide brochures from cultural institutions, menus for local restaurants, notices about events at bars and clubs and information about historic sites. The students are paid $8 an hour.
Uptown Ambassadors is the start of a larger effortplanned for this fall by the empowerment zone called the Upper Manhattan Visitor Network. The carts, which cost about $16,000 each, were bought by the Manhattan Borough President's office. The entire Uptown Ambassador project cost slightly more than $100,000.
Mirianna Pisano, Union Settlement's program director for Uptown Ambassadors, said about 150 people visited the carts each day since the program began on Tuesday. "People came despite the rain," she said.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
Which Way the Fed? Sorting Out the Signals on Interest Rates

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE Federal Reserve is not in the business of trying to confuse investors. With testimony, speeches and comments from its chairman, Alan Greenspan, and other Fed officials, the central bank's leadership has done its best to telegraph all its moves in recent years. That is why there was no surprise when the Fed announced on Wednesday that its short-term interest rate target was rising a quarter of a percentage point, to 5 percent.
But the other half of the announcement was a surprise, and it left many investors scratching their heads -- which ought to add to market volatility on the road to the Fed's next policy meeting in August. 
 Along with the rate increase, the Fed said it had changed its outlook on interest rates from a bias toward higher rates -- a stance adopted at the May policy meeting -- to neutral.
For investors, the first question is what the switch means. The second is what the Fed was thinking. Surely, the policy-making Open Market Committee knew that the change would be interpreted positively by investors and give the stock market a boost, making a gentle slowing-down of the economy -- the ostensible purpose of raising rates -- that much harder to achieve. Sure enough, all three major market indexes hit new highs by week's end.
Many investors saw the switch to neutral as a signal that one rate increase would be enough to brake economic growth and curb inflation. But that is hard to believe, given recent economic and price data.
Some 268,000 nonfarm jobs were created in June, the Labor Department reported on Friday, while hourly earnings rose 3.7 percent over the last 12 months.
The manufacturing sector -- whose earlier slump had helped restrain wage pressures -- is rebounding and gaining momentum. With the stock market now recovered from its spring selloff and consumer confidence at a 30-year high, it is difficult to conclude that consumers, the backbone of this expansion, are about to rein in spending.
The new surge in oil prices, which last week jumped above $19.50 a barrel, should raise inflation concerns. With that jump, and a rebound in industrial commodity prices, we could be in for another shocking leap in the Consumer Price Index. The 0.7 percent surge in April helped prompt the Fed's bias toward higher interest rates in May and the actual increase that followed.
A look at the Fed's recent history shows that a move to neutral does not rule out another rate increase, or even indicate that inflation outlook is improving.
For example, the Fed went to neutral after each formal meeting when rates were raised in the 1994-95 run-up, a period when the Federal funds rate, the overnight interest rate on loans between banks, jumped from 3 percent to 6 percent in seven separate moves.
MOREOVER, the language used to explain the shift to neutral after the Fed's previous quarter-point rate increase, in March 1997, made clear that the neutral bias referred only to the next few weeks, until the committee was scheduled to meet again. "While additional policy tightening might be needed at some point, it did not appear very likely that developments during the inter-meeting period would require a further policy move," the minutes of the committee meeting said. According to the minutes, members who argued for a bias toward higher rates said they could accept the neutral stance as long as there was "careful monitoring of new developments for any signs of the need for prompt action." In other words, nothing was ruled out.
An echo of that emphasis on vigilance appeared in last week's announcement, in which policy makers said they must "be especially alert."
Which leaves the question of why the Fed spoke up about its shift to neutral, knowing that investors would put the most positive spin possible on the news.
One explanation is that the Fed was locked in by its new disclosure policy. In the past, such a change in stance was not divulged until after the subsequent policy-making meeting, about six weeks later. But beginning this year, the Fed has announced changes in its leanings on interest rates immediately when the moves were considered significant.
Or the Fed may be trying to slow the economy with as little disruption as possible. Mr. Greenspan said last month that he was not aiming to prick any stock market bubble. He also said it is not the Fed's practice to plan a series of interest-rate increases in advance. Both goals were advanced by the return to a neutral stance on the rate outlook.

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD;
On Japanese TV, the A B C's of Money

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
THE world of high finance could hardly believe the news on the front page of The Financial Times last month. Goldman, Sachs & Company, as snooty as Wall Street's notoriously snooty white-shoe firms get, was sponsoring a TV program for Japanese homemakers? Surely someone had confused the firm with Procter & Gamble.
Yet on the last Saturday afternoon in June, there it was. TV Tokyo broadcast a one-hour special to introduce "Money Angels," a weekly half-hour drama that unlocks the mysteries of financial planning for Mrs. Watanabe and her neighbors. And every so often, up popped an ad for Goldman's mutual funds. At least for a half-hour on Saturday afternoons in Tokyo, the firm is trading its white shoes for house slippers. 
 Despite a title that evokes Farah Fawcett, the program is a serious attempt to explain the basics of household financial planning in a country where many consumers are baffled by compound interest, never mind dividends or debentures. In American eyes, sponsorship of such a program might seem silly and out of character for a firm like Goldman, but in the context of Japan, it is an ambitious example of a company paying more than lip service to the widely touted mantra, "Think globally, act locally."
"In this market, we think this is going to be an interesting and potentially very successful way of reaching the consumer," said Mark Schwartz, who was recently promoted to head Goldman's business in Asia. "We would never do something like this in the U.S. because it's not appropriate there, but here it makes a lot of sense."
Why? For one thing, Japanese homemakers have a tight grip on the country's $11.1 trillion in household assets. They determine how their household budget is allocated, where savings are deposited and what, if any, investments are made.
For another, Japanese consumers are hungry for basic information. "There is a very high level of interest here, not specifically in investing but in what this world of investing and financial planning is all about, and especially how it works," said Yasuyo Yamazaki, Goldman's ebullient head of asset management in Japan. Some 90,000 people attended the 600 investment seminars Goldman held in Japan last year.
People here are acutely aware that as they are living longer, the population is aging, and both public and private pension systems are grossly underfunded. Less understood, and harder to explain in a country where prices are falling, not rising, is the notion that piling up cash in a savings account that earns less than 1 percent interest -- the going rate here -- will not likely assure a comfortable retirement.
Mention concepts like risk and reward, portfolio diversification and asset allocation to a typical Japanese homemaker, and be prepared for a bewildered stare tinged with ever-so-slight disapproval: In Japan, risk is a four-letter word.
The program revolves around three women, Hinako, Yuko and Kuroda-san, the "money angels," who are meant to function as consumer advocates. A well-known actress, Fukumi Kuroda, plays Kuroda-san, the head of a consulting firm whom clients often ask about financial matters.
In the first episode, a mother and father tell their stunned children that they should not expect any inheritance, since the parents will not be able to finance their own retirements. The children appeal to the money angels for help, and so begins a series of visits to real-life financial consultants and others who demystify market principles by explaining ways to pump up savings.
"The topics are deliberately broad," Mr. Yamazaki said. "The most important thing is for this show to educate the viewers, because the more intelligent they are, the better it will be for us."
ALTHOUGH Goldman has no retail brokerage outlets of its own, and must rely on Japanese brokerage firms and banks to sell its funds, Mr. Yamazaki's operation is the sixth-largest mutual fund company in Japan, and 5 of the country's 10 most popular funds are Goldman's, according to one survey.
Mr. Yamazaki, a born showman, has achieved that by using unorthodox marketing methods -- unorthodox at least for Goldman. He and his sales force spend a lot of time roaming the banks and brokerage firms that sell Goldman's funds. He writes a column, "Asset Management with Zack Yamazaki," for a weekly newspaper read by more than six million people, and receives about 500 letters a month from readers.
Goldman was receptive when TV Tokyo, the station loosely affiliated with Japan's leading financial daily, Nikkei Shimbun, approached it with the idea for "Money Angels" last year, because Goldman had already sponsored a program on a satellite channel and was pleased with the response.
"It's not as if we didn't approach Japanese firms at all," said Masato Ikeuchi, executive vice president of Television Tokyo Channel 12 Ltd. "But their reaction was, well, dull. They understand where the industry is heading, but they've not yet reached the point where they want to spend money on advertising and marketing." In any case, in their present state few Japanese financial institutions could afford it.
One viewer's reaction illustrates what "Money Angels" is up against. Tazuko Makio, 72, who lives with her retired husband, said the program was clear and informative, if a bit stiff, and illustrated issues from the consumer's side better than news programs did. But Mrs. Makio won't be buying any mutual fund shares. "Those things are for people with a lot of money," she said; her nest egg will stay in accessible, riskless savings accounts.
"Money Angels" represents more than just an innovative approach to an idiosyncratic market. It is also one more sign of Goldman's adaptation to the rigors of being a public company. In order to smooth out its earnings stream, Goldman is trying to build up its asset management business, which lags far behind those of its rivals, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley. But the effort is likely to scuff its white-shoe image a bit.
Mr. Schwartz denies that backing "Money Angels" raised any eyebrows at the firm. But others say Goldman's executive committee is sensitive about how its support for the program will be interpreted.
Analysts say stepping out in new directions will be good for Goldman, whatever the impact on its traditional image. A more homespun demeanor may help the firm cultivate a whole new crop of clients to add to its roster of blue-chip corporations.
Goldman may even be taking a lesson from the very companies that have long sought its advice. "Look, the mutual fund business is very different from the other businesses of Goldman, Sachs," Mr. Yamazaki said. "It's a consumer business, and we're learning from Sony, Tiffany, even McDonald's."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 964 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Filling a Skill Shortage, Close to Home

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
WHEN Dan Lopez was a freshman at Oak Grove High School in San Jose, Calif., a teacher asked his class if anyone was interested in being the first to try a new program that would prepare students for careers in the travel and tourism industry.
It sounded like a lot of work. There would be extra classes and internships in the field over the summers. But the internships were paid, and Mr. Lopez, whose parents had not attended college, hoped participating would improve his chances. 
 "I thought it would open up another avenue that would be possible not just in the here and now but in the future," said Mr. Lopez, who followed through and joined the program, sponsored by the National Academy Foundation. Now 23, he is working this summer as a manager at a Homewood Suites hotel and will be a senior at San Jose State University in California in September.
Mr. Lopez is also looking forward to meeting President Clinton this week, as the foundation gets a high-profile endorsement for its pioneering work linking high schools and corporations to prepare students for jobs in growth industries.
The President is scheduled to announce plans on Thursday for an Academy of Information Technology, to be financed in part by Lucent Technologies and based on the model established by the foundation, a nonprofit organization founded and championed by Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Citigroup.
Since the establishment of a financial services academy in 1982 at John Dewey High School in Brooklyn, nearly 20,000 teen-agers, most of them from minority groups, have graduated from academy programs, which now involve about 300 schools across the country. About 90 percent of the graduates go on to college.
"I'm a great believer that this country has been an incredible place for creative people and entrepreneurs, and I think it's very important that people who have that kind of opportunity give back to our society and make it a better place," Mr. Weill said by telephone. "The things that work best are when you get the private and public sector working together in concert."
It is a theme that resonates with the President's agenda this week. Mr. Clinton is planning to visit several of the nation's most economically distressed regions with industry executives who are already investing in them in some way -- and who will exhort others to do the same.
Gene Sperling, director of the White House's National Economic Council, said the goal is to prompt corporations to see underdeveloped communities as new markets, rather than targets of charity. "The focus of this trip is untapped potential," he said. "We are exhorting corporations to understand that these are mutually beneficial programs. Giving disadvantaged youth the opportunity to learn job skills is as critical for future economic growth as it is for social fairness."
The President is scheduled to start the visits tomorrow in Appalachia. Then, in East St. Louis, Ill., he will meet with Hugh McColl, the chairman of Bank of America. Later, Mr. Clinton will go to Pine Ridge, S.D., and Phoenix. The last leg of the trip will take him to Watts in Los Angeles and to Anaheim, Calif., where the National Academy Foundation will hold its annual teacher training session and awards ceremony.
THE plan for the technology academy comes on the heels of a Commerce Department report affirming the frequent complaints of information technology executives that there are not enough qualified workers to meet the demand. The industry has also come under criticism recently from Representative Jesse Jackson Jr., Democrat of Illinois, and others for not employing more blacks and Hispanics.
"Information technology is a complicated area of curriculum that most schools are not focusing on," said David Ford, president of the Lucent Technologies Foundation. "We believe this will help address the industry's need."
Lucent has agreed to donate over $1 million, or one-quarter of what it will cost the National Academy Foundation to develop the program. The plan calls for 10 schools to start the pilot program in September 2000. But the foundation will first have to solicit the remainder of the funds from other information technology companies, in an industry whose newest companies are not exactly known for philanthropy. Mr. Weill and Lucent's chairman, Richard McGinn, who are close friends, plan a meeting to encourage other donors to step forward.
The technology academy would be the third theme curriculum for the foundation. The first, which trains students for jobs in the financial services industry, was created by Mr. Weill in 1981, when he was chairman of Shearson Loeb Rhoades. The Academy of Finance opened in 1982 and expanded in 1986 to include an Academy for Travel and Tourism. Citigroup contributes about $2 million annually to the foundation's programs. Other underwriters include American Express, the Merrill Lynch & Company Foundation, Bloomberg L.P., Sallie Mae, the McGraw-Hill Companies and Marriott International.
The formula, which also requires active participation by local business executives, appears to have worked.
"Before I was in the academy, I thought business was only one thing, like being in an office all day with a bunch of numbers," said Eloisa Chavez, 18, a graduate of the Academy of Finance and Martin Luther King Jr. High School in Manhattan. Ms. Chavez, of the Bronx, who now attends Williams College, said an internship at Standard & Poor's taught her that business is as much about people as it is about math.
The academy provided other kinds of training, too. "Every Wednesday, our Academy of Finance coordinator would tell us to dress up as though you were going to a business job," she said, "and if you didn't dress up, he would get on your case."
