SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3480 words

HEADLINE: The Harbor Crunch;
Barges. Tugs. Cabin Cruisers. Tour Boats. Can the Coast Guard Keep Up With All the Hubbub in New York's Waters?

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
THE Fourth of July weekend is always hectic in New York Harbor and elsewhere along the city's 578 miles of shoreline. But these days, any warm weekend will bring small navies of pleasure craft onto the busy waterways, where they compete for space with everything from colossal container ships to sightseeing boats to people parasailing around the Statue of Liberty.
With an economy that seems to be shipshape and cleaner waters lapping at their shores, New Yorkers are returning to the city's rivers, canals, kills and coves in swelling numbers. Fast ferries crisscross the water like furious insects, while cabin cruisers dodge kayakers and swerve around sailboats. Meanwhile, tug and barge traffic is booming. 
 So who's keeping the peace out there? Much of the burden falls on the United States Coast Guard, which in New York is stationed at Fort Wadsworth, a former Navy base at the foot of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Staten Island. But many commercial and recreational boaters say the Coast Guard, which has experienced major budget cutbacks in New York in the last four years, including a reduction in staffto 520 from 2,300, is barely able to keep up with the burst of maritime activity, especially during the summer. And they wonder whether the Coast Guard will be able to handle expected growth in commercial and recreational traffic in the coming years.
Some of the burden of managing the busy waterways falls on the New York Police Department Harbor Unit. "We work very closely in conjunction with the Coast Guard to keep the peace," said the unit's commander, Capt. John Cassidy. With 150 officers and 16 boats year round and an extra 25 or 30 officers and 10 boats during the summer, the police concentrate mainly on recreational boaters and enforcing state laws, Captain Cassidy said, while the Coast Guard tends to focus more on commercial vessels and compliance with Federal laws. "But that's not to say we don't overlap," he said.
"Fortunately, I haven't suffered the staff and budget cuts that hit the Coast Guard," Captain Cassidy said. "I know the Coast Guard feels their resources are stretched to the limit, and I for one would like to see more of them out there."
Many harbor users agree. Linda O'Leary, vice president of American Waterway Operators, a national association of tug, tow and barge companies that represents 300 barges and 150 tugboats in the New York-New Jersey area, which are responsible for 75 percent of all vessel trips in and around the harbor, said: "It's messy out there. The Coast Guard is getting smaller, and the harbor is getting busier. We haven't reached the point of complete collapse, not yet. But we'll be there very shortly."
Officials of the Coast Guard and other government agencies, like the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, say that neither the quality nor level of services provided has been hurt. But there is concern about the future.
"This isn't the same port it was five years ago, and it absolutely is not the same port it will be five years from now," said Richard E. Bennis, the captain of the Port of New York and New Jersey and the highest ranking officer of the consolidated area command, called Activities New York. He said the Coast Guard continued to "carry on with all of our commitments and missions." But, he added, "We don't have enough people and we don't have enough assets to do every job. So we look at where the greatest risks and greatest threats are, and concentrate on those things."
Though it is a branch of the armed forces, the Coast Guard is under the jurisdiction of the Department of Transportation. In 1995, the Clinton Administration announced a four-year plan to reduce Coast Guard expenses nationwide by $400 million and to cut its work force of 39,200 by 4,000.
In New York, the Coast Guard's budget has been cut by more than half, to $20 million, mainly because two of the service's commands were moved to ports in Virginia. In October, three of the service's seven cutters -- 65-foot tug boats used for patrols, inspections and law enforcement -- are scheduled to be decommissioned; two high-endurance cutters have already been sent to other ports.
One big target of the cuts was the Coast Guard base at Governors Island, which was closed in 1997, though most of the vessels and personnel stationed there were used throughout the East Coast. The Coast Guard has since moved its remaining operations, the Activities New York command, to Fort Wadsworth.
This command stretches from Sandy Hook in New Jersey, across Lower New York Bay and Jamaica Bay to the Nassau County line in Long Island, north through the Port of New York and New Jersey and then all the way up the Hudson River to Lake Champlain on the Canadian border.
In addition to managing vessel traffic, the Coast Guard conducts search-and-rescue missions and marine environmental protection operations. It also licenses merchant marines and private ferries and performs boat inspections.
That's not all. The Coast Guard is also responsible for port security and maritime law enforcement, including drug interdiction (with a canine corps trained to fly in harnesses from helicopters). And it participates in counterterrorism activities with other agencies. Then there are the safety programs for commercial, passenger and recreational boat operators, maintenance of aids to navigation like buoys and range lights, and ice-breaking.
Every year, on average, the Coast Guard in New York monitors some 250,000 vessel movements from a high-tech command center at Fort Wadsworth that includes 17 remote video cameras stationed around the area. The Coast Guard is also responsible for insuring the safe passage of more than 40 million commuter ferry passengers a year.
And it creates security zones and blocks vessel movements during New York events like Presidential visits, the opening of the United Nations General Assembly and the Fourth of July fireworks. Planning is already under way for Op Sail 2000 a year from now, which will include a 60-nation flotilla and a huge fireworks display that is expected to draw some 40,000 boats to the harbor.
The Coast Guard's Activities New York command serves an area populated by 17.6 million people. As Captain Bennis likes to point out, that amounts to just $1.13 per person under the current budget. "Of all the military services, you get the most bang for the tax buck by far from us," he said. "We do everything we can do, even if it takes 60, 80 or 100 hours a week to deliver the goods. But we are stretched to the limit. We can't afford to lose one more dollar or one more billet."
The director of port commerce at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Lillian C. Borone, said that although Coast Guard services "have been cut severely," she was "pretty comfortable right now that it can continue to carry out its mission."
But, Ms. Borone added, "Of course we'd like to see more enhancement of services." And, she said, "we are very concerned that we can continue to assure harbor users that there will be tug availability, that ice-breaking still gets done, that buoy and navigation support continues and that rescue services remain at the current level of capacity."
Ms. O'Leary of American Waterway Operators said that while the Coast Guard was doing the best it could with the resources it had, it was "difficult and painful to see something as vital as Coast Guard services not being allocated the needed funds."
"They are trying to be meaner and leaner and do more with less," she said, "but it's very frustrating when you're trying to protect lives, property and environmental resources in what is undoubtedly the busiest and most significant port on the Eastern Seaboard and your responsibilities are enormous and your resources are a pittance. I'm sure they find it as frustrating as I do."
Ms. O'Leary, who is also vice chairwoman of the Harbor Safety, Navigation and Operations Committee of the Port of New York and New Jersey, said shipping companies and harbor pilots had begun complaining that the Coast Guard was stretched thin.
"With each season, the recreational traffic grows exponentially," she said. "Every new millionaire on Wall Street feels compelled to run out and buy a boat. And that adds to the already interesting mix of kayakers, jet skis and dinner cruises. And now we have seaplanes taking off."
"With all that traffic," Ms. O'Leary said, "it sometimes gets so scary people grab their heart and beg for oxygen."
Harbor pilots, who guide arriving tankers and container ships to port, say near-collisions are not uncommon. The pilots, who guide the big boats past Sandy Hook, N.J., across Ambrose Channel in Lower New York Bay, through the tricky Verrazano Narrows or the polluted and shallow Arthur Kill and into the shifting tides of the Upper Bay or to docking sites in New Jersey or Brooklyn, say recreational traffic often blocks the way.
"The Ambrose Channel seems to have the best fishing around," said the president of the Sandy Hook Pilots Association, Andrew McGovern, who is also chairman of the harbor operations committee. "And you can't see until you're about four miles from a congested area. You can slow down, but you can't stop because you'll lose control of the vessel. Generally, the boats get out of the way. But some figure they can get out of way at the last minute, and their engines won't start."
"We see them all the time," he continued. "Pleasure boats just parked right in the middle of some of the busiest shipping lanes in the world. They park out there on warm afternoons and go fishing and drinking, and they aren't paying attention."
Apparently not everyone is fishing. "That salt air is definitely an aphrodisiac," Mr. McGovern said. "People get out in the middle of the water and figure nobody can see them. But I'm up 100 feet on the bridge and I can see things they don't think I can see. It happens all the time. All the pilots have seen it. And it's a real hazard because those people are definitely not paying attention."
Another hazard is personal watercraft, like jet skis. "The hot sport right now is going up to a moving ship and putting your hand right on it," Mr. McGovern said. "It's absolutely unbelievable." (The Police Department harbor unit recently added a jet ski task force consisting of two sergeants and 14 officers, Captain Cassidy, its commander, said.)
Lately, Mr. McGovern said, there has been "much grumbling" about the Coast Guard from harbor pilots. "They can only stretch themselves so thin," he said of the New York command. "They try hard, but they just don't have the manpower or resources, especially on warm days. You can call up and ask for a patrol boat to clear the channel. But either they are out doing search and rescue work or, if one's available, it's going to be a while before they get to you. And generally it's too late by then. So you just keep going. You blow your horn and pray everyone gets out of the way."
Recreational boaters have their own concerns about New York's crowded waters and the Coast Guard's ability to handle the traffic. Adam Brown, president of the Working Waterfront Association, a coalition of recreational boaters, marina operators and even swimmers, said Coast Guard budget cuts had rendered the service "unable to handle issues of safety given the increased number of operators in the harbor." There were 26,807 motorboats registered in New York City in 1997, the latest year for which figures are available, compared with 22,789 in 1990.
"Nobody anticipated the boom, and it's creating a lot of problems," said Mr. Brown, the founder of a recreational boating safety group called the Harbor Safety Committee. "Some of those cuts were made without really appreciating how quickly the water revitalization efforts would happen. And so many activities that are happening are very local, and that information doesn't filter up to the levels of government where the big funding decisions are made."
For years, boaters around the harbor have complained that high-speed commuter ferries churn up large wakes that crash against boats and docks and damage piers and bulkheads. "The Coast Guard gave us complaint forms, and we filled out 200 of them, but they never do anything," said Jim Gallagher, who owns an old ferryboat, the Yankee, at Pier 26 on the Hudson River near North Moore Street. "Nobody feels like it's their jurisdiction. The Coast Guard won't respond unless a life is at stake."
Lieutenant Chip Lopez said that the service could enforce only Federal laws, which do not cover vessel speed or distance from shore. "They literally flood us with complaints and, unfortunately, we're not equipped to handle it," he said.
If current trends in commercial, passenger and recreational boating continue, the problems will only get worse, many harbor users say.
Currently there are at least 46 marinas, with slips and moorings for some 6,570 boats, according to the New York State Department of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation. Plans for Hudson River Park, which is being built along Manhattan's West Side below 59th Street, call for new spaces for 218 motorboats and 1,590 nonmotorized boats. The park is also expected to draw many day boaters, especially during warm weekends.
Meanwhile, summertime ridership on water taxis and private ferry services (not counting the Staten Island ferry) has grown to more than 30,000 passengers a day from about 4,000 in 1988, said Alan Olmsted, director of the City Department of Transportation's office of private ferry operations.
As for commercial traffic, that, too, may be on the rise. New York Harbor is the No. 1 site in the United States for the movement of petroleum products, and its port is the third largest in the country for containerized cargo shipments. Though ship arrivals fluctuated at around 4,500 a year in the mid-90's, there were 4,943 last year, according to the Port Authority, which estimates that the volume of freighters traveling through the harbor could more than triple in the next 20 years.
And the port has big ambitions. The world shipping industry is planning to adopt the hub-and-spoke system similar to that developed by airlines, people in the industry say. The New York-New Jersey port system is competing with Norfolk, Va., and Halifax, Nova Scotia, to become the hub port on the east coast of North America.
But for New York Harbor to be competitive, it must be able to handle the new generation of supertankers, which require a depth of at least 45 feet. The Kill van Kull and Newark Bay channels, crucial waterways for the harbor shipping industry, are no more than 40 feet deep now. Yet work is already beginning to deepen those waterways. In March, the Army Corps of Engineers awarded a $23.6 million contract to dredge a 1.5-mile section of the Kill van Kull, the first phase of a five-year, $773 million project to make New York Harbor accessible to the big new container ships. The Federal Government is to pay 75 percent of the cost of the project.
In May, New York Harbor received another lift when two big shipping lines, Sea-Land Services and Maersk Inc., announced that they would stay in New York Harbor and expand operations instead of moving to Baltimore.
Later that month, work began in the Kill van Kull, which required the buoys there to be moved. But the sole buoy tender belonging to the Coast Guard's New York command was unavailable because it was being serviced, said Commander Mark Bobal, its public affairs officer, who also serves as chief of its inspections branch. Fortunately, he said, it was Fleet Week and Coast Guard vessels from other ports were visiting. A cutter from the Coast Guard base at Newport, R.I., took time off from ceremonial duties to do the job.
Despite the anticipated growth in harbor traffic, future financing levels for the Coast Guard in New York remain uncertain. During the height of the war in Kosovo, in May, Congress passed a multibillion-dollar emergency military appropriations bill that included an extra $200 million for the Coast Guard. But it is not clear whether any of that money will make its way to New York.
In mid-June the House of Representatives passed a transportation bill that would provide the Coast Guard with about $4 billion in fiscal 2000, an increase of some $153 million over current financing: the first big nonemergency increase in years. The Senate has yet to approve its transportation spending bill.
But even if the Coast Guard gets that additional $153 million, there's no way of telling how the money will be distributed. The process is complicated, based on the needs of the service's various districts. (New York is in District 1, whose headquarters are in Boston). And there is plenty of competition. In its 1998 annual report, the Coast Guard listed improved fishing patrols in the Bering Sea and antidrug and illegal- immigrant operations in the Caribbean and Pacific among its top priorities.
That doesn't mean safety will take a back seat, said a spokesman for Coast Guard headquarters in Washington, Jack O'Dell. "We will insure that New York Harbor receives extra money that will guarantee the port will be maintained and make sure that commerce can move safely," he said. He said he could not discuss details until the money was allocated.
"It's tough," said Representative Vito Fossella, a Staten Island Republican. "Do you put more money to stop cocaine in the Caribbean or to protect kayakers in New York Harbor?" he said. "I think they both have to be priorities. But how will we pay for it all?"
 
Helping the Coast Guard Do Its Job
With hundreds of miles of waterways under its command, there's no way the Coast Guard can be in all places at all times. But local, state and Federal authorities are also out there keeping watch, as are civilian volunteers. And maritime industry officials and recreational boaters are involved in efforts to insure harbor safety.
Law enforcement In recent years, various law-enforcement officials have been working together more closely and coordinating their activities with those of the Coast Guard. Among other things, these authorities police the area for people fishing illegally, dumping waste or operating boats unsafely. They also take part in search-and-rescue operations and staff boating-while-intoxicated checkpoints.
The New York Police Department Harbor Unit, with a fleet that expands in the summer to 26 boats and 175 officers, is the biggest. But there are also patrol boats belonging to municipalities along the Hudson River in New York and New Jersey, state agencies like the New York State Environmental Conservation Police and the New Jersey State Police.
Other agencies also maintain a presence on the water, including the Port Authority Police, the National Parks Service and United States Customs.
The Coast Guard Auxiliary Some 3,470 civilians in and around New York volunteer their time, and more than 300 private boats and 16 aircraft, to help the Coast Guard carry out a number of non-law-enforcement duties.
Auxiliary members receive special training and certification, and their vessels are required to meet certain requirements, including having tow rigs, two-way radios, fire extinguishers, first aid kits and extra blankets, lines, anchors and life jackets. They do not carry weapons.
Auxiliary boats are given special decals and flags to fly while on duty. Auxiliary members perform courtesy marine exams, check on buoys and other aids to navigation and help maintain security zones during special events. They also look out for spills and ice floes and conduct boating safety and education programs. Through these activities, they help free up Coast Guard personnel for other duties.
Maritime Industries About 25 years ago, commercial interests, the New York Maritime Association and government agencies around the port joined forces with the Coast Guard to create the Harbor Safety, Navigation and Operations Committee of the Port of New York and New Jersey to coordinate activities and address issues ranging from port safety and security to navigational aids.
One current project is a plan to create an informational network to pool navigational readings, like vessel tracking, global positioning and weather reports, and make them available in real time to mariners, port officials and the Coast Guard.
Recreational Boaters The Harbor Safety Committee, open to anyone who uses the waterways, was recently formed by Adam Brown, president of the Working Waterfront Association. (The group also belongs to the Port Authority's Harbor Safety, Navigation and Operations Committee.)
One issue on which it has worked with the Coast Guard recently is ferry wakes. Members also try to promote boating safety and help with advance planning for special events.
 DAVID KIRBY

The number of registered motor boats rose 22 percent in New York City and almost 17 percent state-wide from 1992 to 1997, the latest year for which figures were available.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
A Lawyer Opponents Can Like

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
MAYBE Lewis Carroll's Red Queen was right: Sometimes it really does take all the running you can do to keep in the same place.
Maura J. Abeln, general counsel for Owens Corning -- the front-and-center defendant in asbestos litigation -- is finding that out the hard way. For more than a year, she has fought off every potentially lethal attack on the settlement process she worked out so painstakingly with some 80 plaintiff's law firms ready to litigate more than 200,000 asbestos claims. 
 She waited, breath held, until the Supreme Court overturned a class-action settlement with Owens Corning's Fiberboard subsidiary two weeks ago, enabling Owens Corning to add Fiberboard's cases to its own settlement plan.
Now, it's back into the breach again. Ms. Abeln spent much of Thursday testifying before the House Judiciary Committee, which is considering legislation that could steer plaintiffs back into the courts. She melded compassion with practicality, in hopes that her settlements will be grandfathered out of any law.
"All we want is to stay out of the fray and continue with our own program," Ms. Abeln said. "I've got to protect it."
She is protecting the Owens Corning National Settlement Program, a plan for settling asbestos claims on the basis of how long claimants were exposed to an Owens Corning product and how severe their disease has become. She has traveled the country, meeting with plaintiff's lawyers and hammering away at their distrust.
She used humor -- lawyers found stuffed pink panthers, Owens Corning's consumer logo, in their mailboxes, and one received a gift-wrapped peace pipe. She used facts -- she showed them Owens Corning's books, trotted out its executives to answer questions and laid out what the company could pay and how quickly it could pay it.
And, against all odds, she won the enemy over. "I've had as many feuds with industry lawyers as anybody, and Maura is remarkable," said Fred M. Baron, of Baron & Budd in Dallas. "She's like a rodeo cowboy, she gets on that horse and stays with it, no matter how much it bucks."
Actually, the cowboy is not the first metaphor brought to mind by Ms. Abeln. A 43-year-old with a ready smile, she has a way of making anyone believe she is listening, absorbing and processing their every word. "I'm a big fan of Maura's, and it's hard for a plaintiff's attorney to say that about a corporate attorney," said John D. Cooney, of Cooney & Conway in Chicago. "She is blunt, straightforward and invites you to believe her."
Actually, when Ms. Abeln claims to understand the plaintiff's point of view, she means it. Her father, a foreman in a copper tubing plant in Reading, Pa., died of emphysema in 1986. "He'd come home with copper dust on his shoes, and that might have been the cause," Ms. Abeln said. "I see things from the plaintiff's perspective."
Ms. Abeln recalls her childhood as short on cash for luxuries -- she sold shoes and doughnuts in high school to help raise money for college expenses -- but long on the belief in self-betterment. Her mother did not go to college until she was 47, then worked in various social work jobs until she died at 72.
"She was quite the feminist, giving me copies of Ms. magazine when I was just 15," Ms. Abeln said. She said her mother also encouraged her to go to Vassar, "because she wanted me in an environment that showed what women could do."
Ms. Abeln caught on quickly. She had honor-society grades and was involved in the college newspaper and in sports like field hockey and softball. She won a Rhodes scholarship in 1976, the first year that women were accepted. She studied economics at Oxford, married and divorced, then accepted a full scholarship to study law at the University of Miami.
For a while, Miami seemed a permanent home. She married one of her law professors, had two children, and later built a thriving banking law practice as a partner at Baker & McKenzie.
By 1990, though, woes in the banking market left her practice in turmoil. Her mother died of breast cancer and her marriage disintegrated, leaving her to raise her small children alone.
When the General Electric Company's plastics division in Pittsfield, Mass., invited her to be its general counsel, she jumped. "I needed to do something different, and Pittsfield seemed a nice town that was closer to my brother in Allentown, Pa.," she recalled. Moreover, she was getting married again, to someone willing to stay home with her children, and she would be the youngest general counsel of any G.E. division. She was sold.
She got her first taste of personal injury claims when she handled G.E.'s silicone breast implant litigation. But Benjamin W. Heineman Jr., G.E.'s general counsel, remembers her more for her ability to work with people. "She built one of our finest global legal staffs," he recalled. "She knows how to inspire loyalty."
She also knows how to impress the brass. Glen H. Hiner was running G.E. Plastics when Ms. Abeln joined. He left six months later to become Owens Corning's chief executive, but Ms. Abeln had already made a lasting impression. When he realized that Owens Corning's asbestos situation had gotten out of hand, he came calling.
"We'd polarized the plaintiffs bar into a solid position against us," he recalled. "I knew Maura was smart and had a good business sense. But I also knew she could rally people to her side."
When Ms. Abeln came on board in February 1998, jury verdicts were turning against the company, just as its insurance money for asbestos claims was running out. "I have the most important job in this company after Glen's," she said. "If we kept trying to delay cases and deferring payments, we could not survive."
Her future? Although divorced again, she has not soured on marriage -- "I have a real need for emotional security," she said -- and is remarrying next June, to Steven Smith, a software consultant. And she remains as ambitious as ever."I certainly want to be a C.E.O. some day," she said. Mr. Hiner's take on that? "I wouldn't discount the possibility."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Redefining Bush-League Fund-Raising

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
EVEN though he has done it faster than anyone else, Gov. George W. Bush is not the first Texan to raise several gazillion dollars to run for President. He is the sixth or seventh, depending on whether you count Lloyd Bentsen.
Put aside Ross Perot, as Mr. Bush's father would have liked to do in 1992, because the cranky billionaire's chief fund-raising device was his personal checkbook. After that, Governor Bush's broad-brimmed $36.3 million, even adjusted for inflation, puts most other Texans in the shade, though not Lyndon B. Johnson and George H. W. Bush. 
 Mr. Johnson spent $10.5 million in 1964, according to Herbert E. Alexander, professor emeritus at the University of Southern California and founder of the Citizens Research Foundation, a nonpartisan group that studies campaign finance. In 1999 dollars that is about $56 million. But almost all of it went for the general election, after Mr. Johnson had run surrogates against George C. Wallace in three primaries.
By any measure, Governor Bush has probably raised more money at this point in the fund-raising cycle than any previous candidate for President. Even if Mr. Bush's pace slackens a bit, he should pass Mr. Johnson's total by Christmas.
Nor is Mr. Perot's 1992 total of $67 million, mostly for general election costs, out of Mr. Bush's reach -- not even when adjusted to $79 million in current dollars.
But the most telling comparisons are not with either of those Texans.
After all, Mr. Perot spent his own money and Mr. Johnson ran before there were any real limits on campaign financing, especially the $1,000 cap on individual contributions to candidates -- a limit Mr. Bush said last week he wanted raised to some unspecified higher level.
Senator Lloyd Bentsen ran for the Democratic nomination in 1976 and spent about $2.25 million ($6.5 million in 1999 dollars) before giving up as the caucuses and primaries were beginning.
The most famous case of a Texan being the political equivalent of all hat and no cattle is John B. Connally. He had never been elected to anything as a Republican, but raised $13.7 million to run in the Republican primaries in 1980. That's $38 million in today's dollars, a figure Bush will pass sometime this month, if he has not already done so this morning.
But Mr. Connally's blustery campaign never caught on, and he won only a single delegate, Ada Mills, for many years the treasurer of the Arkansas Republican Party. Mrs. Mills became known as the "$10 million delegate" (a nice round number), and is living in Clarksville, Ark., no longer active in politics.
FINALLY there was Senator Phil Gramm in 1996. He raised $13 million by May 1995 and was eagerly advertising his money-raising skills. They didn't do him much good, partly because he was spending money almost as fast as it came in, partly because his message of Republican populism conflicted with his opulent fund-raising and partly because Pat Buchanan had a better pitchfork. Mr. Gramm ultimately spent $25 million and won 10 delegates, proving minimally more effective than Mr. Connally.
It will not be hard for Mr. Bush to get delegates more cheaply than Mr. Gramm, who paid $2.5 million apiece. Dozens of Republican officials who are sure to be delegates are already pledged to him.
The money he has raised so far is not more than anyone has ever spent to win a nomination. Bill Clinton reported spending $36.4 million in 1996 while Bob Dole spent $37.4 million (each amount supplemented by national committee spending).
Adjusted for inflation, Mr. Dole's spending equals $39.6 million today, and the Clinton total $38.3 million. Those figures include Federal matching money, which does not become available until the election year itself.
There is no reason to think Mr. Bush will stop raising money, and he has more than a year to do so before the national convention. Even if he did stop, enough money would probably trickle in to allow him to exceed his father's standards. Bush pere spent $19 million in 1980 and lost the nomination, $27.6 million in 1988 and won it, and $32.7 million in 1992 and won it.
Adjusted for inflation those sums equal $38.1 million, $38.5 million and $38.5 million in 1999 dollars. They are similar because the elder Mr. Bush accepted Federal matching funds, and that obliged him to abide by Federal spending limits.
Bush the younger will almost certainly not take the Federal money and will spend as much as he can.

HEADLINE: Fund Expenses: They're GoingDown, Down, Down;
Conventional Wisdom Is Belied By the Numbers

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
ASSETS were not the only things increasing at Fidelity Contrafund through the early 1990's. While the fund grew sixfold, its expense ratio also climbed.
But after peaking at 1.06 percent in 1993, the ratio began to fall. Now, Contrafund charges investors 0.61 percent every year to manage their money, the lowest amount in more than a decade. 
 Contrafund investors are not alone. The fees that the average mutual fund investor pays are going down.
The trend flies in the face of conventional wisdom, which holds that expenses have been flat, or even rising. Indeed, the industry has come under heavy public criticism for its high fees, which long allowed fund companies' stocks to outpace their funds' returns.
But the decline in fees is real. Kanon Bloch Carre, a mutual fund consulting firm in Boston, calculates that the average expense ratio paid by investors is down 16 percent over the last six years.
There are several explanations: Many investors have shifted assets to low-cost funds -- a byproduct, to a large degree, of their embrace of index funds. Corporate executives who negotiate terms for their companies' 401(k) plans have increasingly favored funds with lower fees. And new, low-cost competitors have joined the market.
Some industry analysts say fund companies will keep facing pressure to lower fees. After all, price competition is typical in maturing industries, as the battle for market share increases and growth slows.
But don't pity the fund companies. They
haven't lost their license to print money, with many fund companies seeing annual returns on equity that still top 25 percent.
You may have heard that fees are on the rise. For example, Morningstar Inc., the Chicago financial publisher, has reported that expenses on the average United States diversified stock fund rose last year to $1.44 for every $100 of assets, from $1.35 in 1993.
But such comparisons treat a $10 billion fund the same as a $10 million fund, and thus do not measure the average investor's costs. With new funds being rolled out at the rate of almost 10 a week for much of this decade -- some of them low-cost funds but most of them small, often esoteric funds charging higher-than-average expenses -- it should not be a surprise that unweighted average expense ratios rose.
By contrast, Kanon Bloch uses asset-weighting in its calculations, giving twice as much weight to a $100 million fund, for example, as to a $50 million one. On that basis, the average United States diversified stock fund now charges 77 cents in annual expenses for every $100 invested, down from 88 cents three years ago and 92 cents in 1993. Such stock funds constitute the lion's share -- 80 percent -- of stock mutual fund assets.
The calculations include only the share classes with the most assets or longest records -- usually the class A shares. But William Dougherty, president of Kanon Bloch, said the expense ratio of other share classes, which make up less than 20 percent of domestic diversified stock fund assets, have also been falling. Moreover, the firm's calculations do not include sales charges, or loads, which have also been in decline.
Mr. Dougherty acknowledged that Kanon Bloch's findings may seem surprising, but said the trend has been clear for years. He calculates that investors are saving $3.8 billion this year because of the decline in asset-weighted expense ratios.
SKEPTICS might say the industry's fees look lower under asset-weighting because of the frugality of the Vanguard Group, the index fund king. Vanguard, as a mutual company owned by its customers, does not have to make a profit for public shareholders. The total asset-weighted expense ratio for Vanguard's domestic diversified stock funds declined by one-fifth during the last six years, to 28 cents for every $100 invested, according to Kanon Bloch.
But it isn't just Vanguard. And it isn't just the Kanon Bloch figures. In a report this year, Scott Cooley, a Morningstar analyst, found that even excluding low-cost index funds and institutional shares, asset-weighted costs for investors have dropped by one-quarter since 1984 for load funds and by about 9 percent for no-load funds. He attributed much of the decline to investors' seeking out lower-cost fund families.
In fact, asset-weighted expenses have fallen at the four biggest fund families -- Fidelity Investments, Vanguard, American Funds and Putnam Investments, which, combined, have 43 percent of the total United States diversified stock fund assets. That decline has come in part because swelling assets have touched off break-point clauses in fund management agreements that call for lower fees. Fidelity, for example, charges a two-pronged management fee, one part of which declines as the company's total assets rise. That part of the fee was 0.2863 percent of assets in December 1998, down from 0.2942 percent the year before and 0.3243 percent at year-end 1993. The company has also given up a portion of its fees to some investors in recent years, because performance has not met targets.
From May 1993 to May 1999, Fidelity's expense ratio for diversified stock funds fell by one-third, to 0.63 percent, while the ratio at the American Funds group declined 11 percent, to 0.61, according to Kanon Bloch. It even fell at the relatively pricey Putnam, to 0.95, a 15 percent drop over the period.
Of course, whatever the fee cuts at some fund companies, they pale next to huge revenue gains, as assets under management in stock funds soared 44-fold, to $3.2 trillion, in the 15 years ended in May, according to data from the Investment Company Institute, the industry trade group.
Noting such huge profits, critics say fees should have plunged, not just drifted downward. A Congressional subcommittee heard testimony last fall, and now the General Accounting Office is investigating the matter at the request of Representatives John D. Dingell, Democrat of Michigan, and Michael G. Oxley, an Ohio Republican. If any legislation is proposed, it will most likely seek to improve disclosure of fees to investors, Congressional aides say.
Mutual fund officials defend the industry's fees, noting that a study last year by the Investment Company Institute found that fund companies had, in fact, been passing along savings to fund shareholders.
Regardless of what Congress does or does not do, the outlook for investors is good. Plenty of factors already at play suggest that investors will, on average, pay lower fees in the future. The factors include these:
 
INDEXING -- Increasingly sought by investors, index funds accounted for an astonishing 43 percent of all new cash flows into stock funds so far this year, according to AMG Data Services, a mutual fund researcher. The expense ratios on funds that track the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index generally range from 0.18 to 0.40.
The popularity of index funds is being tested, now that many actively managed funds are outperforming the S.& P. 500 over several months for the first time in a half-dozen years. But if history is any guide, the outperformance of the actively managed funds will eventually lapse.
 
GROWING SOPHISTICATION -- Individual investors are becoming savvier about fees, especially as they notice commissions for on-line stock trades dropping sharply.
In February, Mr. Cooley of Morningstar took the mutual fund industry to task for not passing along its huge economies of scale. He also noted that investors were increasingly factoring fees into their fund-buying decisions.
"There is this misconception out there that all investors are stupid, that they chase performance and don't pay attention to fees," Mr. Cooley said. But, he added, "we found that people were migrating toward lower-cost funds and lower-cost families."
At Charles Schwab, the huge San Francisco-based discount broker, executives creating an in-house funds group a decade ago studied institutional money managers and observed that they emphasized low management fees more than the retail market did. Figuring that small investors would eventually follow suit, they decided to make index funds their primary offering. That bet proved prescient.
"As investors have become more and more educated about the role of fees, we are beginning to see a trend of fees being more of a determinant in fund selection," said Bill Klipp, president of Charles Schwab Investment Management.
 
COMPETITION -- More low-cost fund options are becoming available. Schwab's funds have become top sellers, posting the ninth-largest net sales of any fund group in the first five months of the year, according to the Financial Research Corporation, an investment researcher in Boston.
Barclays Global Investors, meanwhile, the huge San Francisco-based institutional money manager that specializes in indexing, plans to sell about 50 index funds on the American Stock Exchange beginning next year.
And TIAA-CREF, the low-cost fund and annuity provider that already dominates the retirement markets at colleges and universities, has gotten off to a strong start with a new line of very low-cost retail mutual funds that combine indexing with active management. The expenses on the funds range from 0.30 to 0.49 percent, according to Morningstar.
Over all, however, there has been a slowdown in the number of new funds -- the kinds that seem to have skewed expense ratio tallies in the past -- as well as in the total net assets flowing into mutual funds. Only 11 new funds were rolled out in the first three months of 1999, about one-tenth the rate of the last three years, according to Cerulli Associates, a financial-services consulting firm in Boston.
 
401(K) MUSCLE -- The shift to low-cost funds has been particularly pronounced among the executives and consultants who select investments for 401(k)'s and other employer-sponsored retirement plans. Analysts estimate that these plans contribute about one-third of the new cash flowing into mutual funds.
In years past, analysts say, expenses played less of a role in the selection of funds for 401(k)'s by corporations. But that is changing. "I would say fees to participants have moved up" in importance, said Steve Butler, president of Pension Dynamics, a pension consulting firm in Lafayette, Calif. "In smaller companies where owners and key managers have a major proportion of the assets, I would say costs are the No. 1 factor."
 
CONSOLIDATION -- If analysts are correct and the fund industry is maturing, consolidation of fund companies could also play a role in allowing them to reduce costs, if they care to. After all, the trend lets them spread a greater amount of assets over a similar base of fixed costs.
But more important for building economies of scale has been the high number of mergers involving funds themselves. Hundreds of funds combine every year. While that should raise a red flag to investors -- fund companies can merge a poor performer with a good one and then use the better fund's track record for marketing purposes -- it also makes it easier to lower expenses.
And the merger trend is expected to continue. "I suspect you'll see more of that," said Mark L. Constant, a fund industry analyst with Merrill Lynch in San Francisco.
 
THE MARKETS -- Many analysts think that stock market returns will revert to their historical averages. And when that happens, investors are certain to pay more attention to fees. Over the last decade, the S.& P. 500 has risen an average of almost 20 percent a year. That compares with its post-1926 average of about 11 percent a year. Given that almost anyone in a diversified stock fund has made a lot of money in recent years regardless of the fees he paid, it is surprising that investors have paid any attention to costs.
But "there's going to be a growing cost awareness if the rates of return available in the marketplace turn out to be a lot lower in the next decade," said James F. Rothenberg, president of Capital Research and Management, the Los Angeles investment-advisory firm for the American Funds group. "Then I think people will start to focus a lot more on what are the elements of their results, including what are the costs."
Funds with higher expense ratios will, of course, take a much bigger slice of an investor's profits when returns are lower: losing 1.5 percent of your return to expenses is easy to shrug off when your fund returns 25 percent a year, but not when it returns 7 or 8 percent.
And the cost of fees is compounded over time, even if all other factors remain equal.
Consider the Vanguard 500 Index fund, which has had annual expenses of about 20 cents for every $100 in assets invested over the last decade. Had you invested $10,000 each year, beginning at the start of 1989, you would have had almost $332,000 after 10 years.
But if you took the same fund and replaced Vanguard's low expenses with the average expense ratio of United States diversified stock funds, which was 1.44 percent last year, you would be left with about $311,000, or a difference of $21,000, according to Pension Dynamics.
Despite the asset-weighted numbers, some industry officials, even those who proselytize for lower fees, scoff at the idea that the industry has been broken of greedy habits.
John C. Bogle, Vanguard's founder, bluntly describes the industry's attitude this way: "Croupier, croupier, croupier, where is thy rake?"
And John H. Biggs, chief executive of TIAA-CREF, questions whether fund companies will lower fees anytime soon.
"It's hard for me to imagine them coming down in normal times," he said.
Industry executives note that compensation to fund managers has increased, especially as hedge funds have offered huge packages to top stock pickers. Moreover, public fund shareholders are demanding higher earnings, and the continuing bull market in stocks is keeping investors from complaining too much about fees.
But costs are a certainty, while market-beating performance never is. Study after study has shown that funds with low expense ratios outperform those with higher expenses over time.
"That's something we have found over and over," said Mr. Cooley, the Morningstar analyst.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 26; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1211 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
After a Dark Year, the Asian Sky Is Filled With Fireworks

BYLINE: By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN 

 BODY:
WHAT a difference a year makes. Last Fourth of July weekend, American investors were basking in the glory of 22.9 percent and 30.4 percent gains in their domestic and European stock funds, respectively, over the previous 12 months. But Asia funds were down more than 52 percent.
This year, it is the Asian funds that are lighting up investors' eyes, amid sentiment that most of the region's financial crisis has passed. 
 In the last 12 months, funds that invest in the Pacific Rim outside of Japan soared 69.35 percent, on average, including 38.17 percent in the second quarter alone, according to Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago. Funds that invest in Japan alone were also up substantially -- an average of 55.81 percent over the last year for the 12 months.
By contrast, domestic equity funds rose 14.6 percent in the 12 months and 8.98 percent in the second quarter, while European funds were down 4.72 percent for the year, including a 2.61 percent gain in the quarter. Over all, international stock funds rose 11.3 and 10 percent, respectively.
The portfolio managers of three top performers among funds that buy foreign stocks discussed the turnaround -- as well as new opportunities and possible red flags.
 
The South Korean Bounce
A good gauge of how far up, and how far down, Asian markets have been recently is the Matthews Korea I fund. It was the top-performing international stock fund for the second quarter and the last 12 months, according to Morningstar, with gains of 69.73 percent and 278.5 percent, respectively. But in 1997, the year the Asian crisis erupted, the fund, which has virtually all of its assets in South Korea, was down 64.75 percent.
The South Korean stock market was among the hardest hit during the crisis and one of the earliest to bounce back strongly, said G. Paul Matthews, manager of the fund. A big reason for the rapid rebound was the Government's aggressive economic restructuring.
Three types of companies have driven the fund higher: manufacturing exporters that have benefited from a weak currency, including Samsung Electronics; financial services companies that have adopted Western business practices or sought foreign capital, including Kookmin Bank and Hana Bank, and companies tied to domestic consumption, including phone companies, department stores and utilities.
Mr. Matthews particularly likes Korea Telecom, the largest telephone company in South Korea. It is already fairly efficient, because the Government held down rate increases in recent years. And in a newly deregulated environment, the company will be able to raise phone rates, Mr. Matthews said. The only drawback for prospective investors, he added, is that the company's American depository receipts are now selling at a premium to the local shares, because of limits on foreign ownership of local shares. He bought the A.D.R.'s when they were first offered in May at $27.56 each, representing half a local share. The A.D.R.'s ended the quarter at $40. The local shares, meanwhile, gained 84.6 percent in the quarter, to end at 76,800 won, or $66.35.
Another favorite is the Korea Electric Power Company, or Kepco, the monopoly electric utility in South Korea. The fund has owned local shares since December 1996, when it paid 37,193 won each. They rose 62.5 percent in the quarter, ending at 48,100 won, or $41.56.
 
A Boon in Financial Stocks
Another top-performing fund focused on the Pacific Basin, although with a broader approach, was Montgomery Emerging Asia. In the last 12 months, the fund, with most of its assets in Hong Kong, Thailand, South Korea and Taiwan, has soared 97.44 percent, up 61.16 percent in the second quarter alone. Frank Chiang, the fund's manager, said performance was spurred by sharp declines in interest rates that have sent money into the stock markets.
Some of the biggest gainers have been financial services stocks; Mr. Chiang's holdings include Thai Farmers Bank and the Industrial Finance Corporation of Thailand. He bought shares of Thai Farmers Bank in October at 20 baht. The shares rose 50 percent in the quarter, ending at 114 baht, or $3.09. And he made 300 percent, including currency and capital gains, on Industrial Finance since he bought it at 9 baht a share in January 1998, when the baht was weak. For the quarter, the stock doubled, ending at 23.5 baht, or 64 cents.
Mr. Chiang said he thought financial stocks would continue to profit as the Asian recovery accelerated.
A current favorite is HSBC Holdings, the global, London-based bank with roots in Hong Kong and Shanghai. It has not only weathered the Asian economic storm; it has gained strength by expanding its business in South Korea. He first bought the stock in 1996 at $140 (Hong Kong) a share. It rose 17.7 percent in the quarter, ending at $286 (Hong Kong) or $36.86 (United States).
 
Adjusting to Global Shifts
Some fund managers who scour the world for opportunity are increasing their commitment to Asia.
"Asia looks better today than I've seen it in 10 years," said Paul C. Warren, senior portfolio manager at the Putnam Diversified Equity fund, one of the best-performing global funds over the last five years. It has returned 20.87 percent, annualized, since mid-1994 and is up 19.24 percent in the last 12 months.
In the last five years, the majority of its assets have been in the hot United States stock market, but Mr. Warren is redeploying some money to Asia. At year-end 1998, 51 percent of the fund was in domestic stocks, 41 percent in European and 5.5 percent in Asian; it now has 42 percent in the United States, 37 percent in Europe and 13 percent in Asia. (The rest is in Latin America and Canada.)
Two years ago, Mr. Warren said, three factors were at work: interest rates in much of Asia were a lot higher than in the United States; Asian countries were running large current account deficits -- in essence, borrowing heavily from abroad -- and Asian companies had overdiversified. Now, interest rates in Asia are as low as or lower than those in the United States, current accounts are in surplus and Asian companies are restructuring. As such, "we have a better-than-Goldilocks scenario," he said.
Among Mr. Warren's favorites is Nikko Securities, the third-largest brokerage firm in Japan. Eighteen months ago, it hired a new president, who is cutting costs. As the Japanese economy recovers and retail investors return to the market, "this stock has the potential to be one of our biggest gainers," he said. The fund first bought the stock in late 1998 at around 400 yen a share. It rose 41.8 percent in the quarter, ending at 780 yen, or $6.44.
 
A Count of Caveats
In light of the outsized recent gains for Asia-Pacific funds, investors should be wary, the managers said.
A big part of those returns, they noted, came as local currencies rose from depressed levels. Also, it is still early in the region's recovery, and Asian companies have yet to prove that their reorganizations will translate into consistently higher profits.
Finally, despite the recent surge, many investors who have held Asia-Pacific funds over the last five years still have net losses. The average diversified fund is down 0.22 percent in that period.

HEADLINE: The Nation: Second Opinions;
The Hard Lessons Of Health Reform

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
MIDWAY through announcing his proposal to revamp Medicare last week, President Clinton seemed to notice that there were ghosts in the room.
He recalled the first time he came face to face with the suffering of older Americans forced to choose between medicine and food -- during the rough, recessionary days of the 1992 Presidential campaign, when the plight of the uninsured and the under-insured burst into the public's consciousness. 
 "That was almost seven years ago," Mr. Clinton said, somewhat ruefully, "but it still happens today."
At that moment, Mr. Clinton's new proposal for Medicare, the giant Federal health program for the elderly and the disabled, seemed to be something more than another ritualistic exercise in policy-making by a waning Administration.
It seemed, instead, to be one last attempt to come to grips with a nation's contradictory desires on health care, and an acknowledgement of the hard lessons learned in the past seven years. There were, indeed, a lot of ghosts in the room, from the bright-eyed Clintonians who tried, and failed, to reconstruct the American health care system in 1993, to the confident Republicans who tried, and failed, to overhaul the Medicare system in 1995.
The struggle over health care, in retrospect, was one of the defining political conflicts of the 1990's. And most of its tensions were evident again last week as Mr. Clinton unveiled his plan to fortify Medicare's finances, add prescription drugs to its benefits and spur more competition for its beneficiaries among private plans.
Once again, Congress and the White House faced a debate over how to hold down costs while still delivering high-quality care. Once again, the subtext was how much faith to place in the corporate sector and the power of the marketplace, and how much trust to reserve for the Government.
And once again, politicians were asking how much Americans were willing to spend to insure that the technological revolutions of modern medicine -- like the newest, most expensive prescription drugs -- are available and affordable to those who need them.
In one forum or another, those issues have been debated since a little-known Pennsylvania Democrat, Harris Wofford, put health care reform on the political map by riding it to victory in a 1991 Senate race. For all the struggle over health care, though, only the murkiest consensus has emerged. At the end of the day, said Drew Altman, president of the Kaiser Family Foundation, a health research group, "there's a broad sense that nothing's easy in health policy and there are no magic solutions."
The latest Clinton plan is a sadder-but-wiser guess at what is still feasible and politically palatable among the grand theories and principles that have dominated health care thinking over the past 10 years. It is perhaps most striking for what it doesn't do. As Marilyn Moon, a health care analyst at the Urban Institute in Washington, put it, the plan "doesn't lock us into big-time structural change before we really know where we want to go."
INDEED, the Clinton proposal seeks a mixed solution of managed care (health maintenance organizations and other entities that try to control costs and coordinate care) and traditional fee-for-service medicine (in which patients have a free choice of doctors reimbursed by the Government).
Administration officials say their new plan would protect and buttress traditional Medicare for anyone who chooses it while creating new incentives for competition among private health care plans for Medicare beneficiaries.
"It's not radical restructuring, but it's not incremental reform either," said Robert Reischauer, an economist at the Brookings Institution.
It is, in a sense, another Clintonian compromise, this time between the ardent defenders of traditional Medicare and the true believers in the marketplace, who argue that the Government has never really given managed care plans a fair shot at competing for Medicare business.
But it also reflects a more realistic appraisal of ideas that once looked so promising. In 1993, there was a lot more hubris: When the Administration first attempted to restructure the rest of the health care system, many of its health planners saw managed care and a well-organized marketplace as nothing short of wondrous in their ability to control costs and improve quality.
Today, after a private sector revolution that pushed most working Americans into managed care with mixed results, a lot of that euphoria is gone.
"I think there's hardly anybody left who really believes we're on the dawn of offering dramatically better service to people at a lower price," said Robert Blendon, an expert on public opinion and health at Harvard University.
In fact, this month the Senate will begin debate on legislation to create a "patients' bill of rights" to protect consumers in the new world of managed care.
Moreover, Medicare's experience with managed care in the past few years has hardly been an unalloyed success. Last week, H.M.O.'s announced further pullbacks from the Medicare market as well as benefit cuts and premium hikes, claiming the Government has been underpaying them.
Advocates of making Medicare more like a private health care market say such difficulties are a result of too much Government regulation. But others say Medicare needs to move cautiously, given the difficulties of shifting an older, medically vulnerable population into the private marketplace.
THE Clinton plan also tries to deal with a longstanding question of access to health care: It proposes prescription drug coverage in Medicare, at a time when new pharmaceuticals offer extraordinary promise to older Americans but confront them with extraordinary expense. This proposal, too, reflects the sadder-but-wiser approach to health policy; most expansions of benefits or coverage since the failure of the Clinton effort in 1993-94 have been discrete, focused efforts like this, from protections for people changing jobs in 1996 to coverage for uninsured children in 1997.
It is noteworthy, perhaps, that even when the Government is awash in surpluses, there is very little serious discussion in Washington these days about reducing the vulnerability of the 43 million uninsured Americans.
"If we ever get closer to universal coverage, it'll be through a hundred incremental programs, because of the legacy of extraordinary cynicism and distrust of government," Mr. Blendon predicts.
At the beginning of the health care wars, of course, Mr. Clinton promised to give every American a health security card and the benefits to go with it. The collapse of his plan was seen as such a repudiation of government that few politicians dare broach the subject of universal coverage these days.
Some analysts believe that it will take a crisis -- perhaps a major economic downturn and an even greater increase in the numbers of uninsured -- before that issue rises to the top of the agenda again.
Mr. Clinton may be long gone by that time; the Medicare proposal may be his last on health care. It is almost certainly less than what he thought he would accomplish when health care first arose in the 1992 campaign.
But no one considers passage of his plan, or some equivalent, to be a sure thing.
Among the ghosts in the room last week was President Lyndon B. Johnson, political godfather of Medicare, quoted by Mr. Clinton -- and perhaps invoked for his talismanic power.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Uncle Sam Learns Thrift While America Spends

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN announcing last week that the Federal budget surplus would be even more over the next 15 years -- a mind-boggling $1 trillion -- than anticipated a few months ago, President Clinton likened the Government to a profligate consumer suddenly endowed with the means and discipline to get out of debt and save for the future.
"We have now cut up Washington's credit card," Mr. Clinton said. 
 The actual American consumer, however, is not nearly so fiscally virtuous. Minutes before Mr. Clinton said the Treasury might be able to pay off the most important component of the national debt by 2015, the Commerce Department released statistics showing that consumers are headed in the other direction by spending more money than they earn.
The rate of personal savings turned negative last year; total personal spending exceeded total after-tax income. Even as the economy roared along, with jobs plentiful, wages rising and inflation dormant, the savings rate declined to -1.2 percent in May from -1.0 percent in April, the lowest since the Depression.
The public-private dichotomy may not be quite as stark as it seems. Reaping huge Government budget surpluses and wiping out the national debt are just a hope at this point. Everything depends on some sunny economic assumptions and revenue forecasts proving true (the track record so far is not encouraging), and on Washington's willingness to keep its appetite for tax cuts and new spending in check (ditto).
For their part, consumers are not quite so irresponsible as the savings figures suggest. Although they are amassing debt, their overall financial condition is not deteriorating, in large part because the stock market boom and rising real estate values are making them wealthier, at least on paper, even if their cash flow is out of whack. The technical definition of savings includes bank deposits and money invested in stocks, bonds or retirement savings -- basically any after-tax income that a consumer does not spend. But it does not include the capital gains on investments or retirement plans.
Still, the contrast between promised Government rectitude and personal profligacy is jarring. And it was not the only discordant note last week in economic policy.
On the one hand, Mr. Clinton was making the case that one of the great benefits of fiscal responsibility and debt reduction is lower interest rates, since the Government's reduced borrowing needs leaves more capital available for businesses and consumers. On the other, the Federal Reserve was raising rates to snuff out any smoldering inflationary pressures generated by an economy that is already red hot.
Making matters even more complicated, the updated surplus projections led Republicans to step up their push for a big tax cut, which if enacted would stoke the economy even as the Fed is trying to cool it off. (To add to the conundrum, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, is one of the most fervent advocates in Washington of lower taxes. Congress is likely to heed his call for another cut in the capital gains tax, which would further fuel the turbo-charged stock market, whose lofty valuations have been keeping Mr. Greenspan awake at night for years.)
THERE'S good news, though. These apparent quandaries are the interwoven byproducts of prosperity.
Take the issue of personal savings and national debt. Arguably, the Government owes its opportunity to reduce the debt to consumers, who as much as any other force have kept the economy and the stock market steaming along and generating the flood of tax revenues that has transformed deficit into surplus.
To the degree that Americans are spendthrifts, it is because they are confident about their own prospects. By opening their wallets, they are creating jobs and fomenting competition that leads to innovation and efficiency. And while their credit card balances might be a bit steep, their household balance sheets are quite healthy if assets like stocks and houses are taken into account.
The ratio of household liabilities to net worth actually declined a bit between 1988 and 1998, to 16.7 percent from 16.9 percent, according to Federal Reserve figures assembled by Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, an investment firm based in London. Rising debt was more than offset by an increase in assets, especially stocks, which last year accounted for a quarter of all household assets, up from 10 percent a decade earlier.
A negative savings rate is indeed a potential problem in the long run, and it is only one of several imbalances that have developed over the course of the long business expansion. Should joblessness rise or the stock market head south, households might quickly find themselves on the financial precipice. The same dynamic could apply to the rapidly growing trade deficit, which so far has been a symbol of the American economy's strength and its ability to absorb imports. A downturn could expose the deficit as a weakness of serious proportions.
But even looking narrowly at the savings rate, the news there is not all bad.
While personal savings is in free fall, the overall national savings rate -- by far the more important economic indicator -- has been rising. That is because the Government has become a "saver" in economic terms in the past few years as budget deficits have turned to surpluses and the Treasury has begun paying down the national debt.
Then there is the question of whether debt reduction is even the best way to use the fiscal windfall. Mainstream economic thought says yes. That position dovetails with the broad political consensus that a crucial component to shoring up the ailing entitlement programs, Social Security and Medicare, is getting the Government on sounder financial footing before the vast baby-boom generation retires.
BUT some conservatives say focusing on paying down the debt dilutes support for tax cuts, which they see as a far more potent way of stimulating additional growth. Some liberals fear that concentrating on debt reduction will divert attention from needed investments in education, health care and poverty fighting, all issues essential to the country's long-term prospects.
Hanging over the debate is an even bigger question: Are the surpluses for real?
The answer is that nobody knows. It was only a few years ago that the problem of budget deficits appeared intractable. Today's fiscal optimism could prove equally transitory.

HEADLINE: Why Horse Farms Need To Be Saved

 BODY:
I was glad to read that the County Executive is taking steps to preserve farmland in Westchester ("Trying to Halt the Push of the Bulldozers," June 14). But if Mr. Spano and the Board of Legislators wish to preserve the remnants of the county's agricultural past, they should take immediate action to include "horse farms" under the protection of the state's Agricultural Exemption Act.
The Agricultural Exemption Act (Article 25-AA of the State's Agricultural and Markets Law) was enacted "to conserve and protect agricultural lands as valued natural and ecological resources" as well as "to provide a locally initiated mechanism for the protection and enhancement of this economic and environmental resource of major importance." 
 The act's benefits were originally reserved for more traditional forms of agriculture like growing crops and breeding animals. However, by 1994 it had become clear to state legislators that in New York's less rural counties, horse farms, those that are primarily dependent upon income derived from boarding horses and providing lessons, were among the few agricultural enterprises left to be preserved.
The act was amended effective March 1, 1995, to give counties the option of extending its protections, including real property tax breaks, to horse boarding facilities.
Almost immediately, Putnam County became the first county to opt into the new provisions of the act. Shortly thereafter, Dutchess followed suit. Officials in those counties had determined that it was more economical to preserve horse farms than to develop the land with housing, which would attract a greater population and lead to greater school expenditures. They also knew that a moderate reduction in property taxes would be offset by Federal and state income taxes and county sales taxes collected as new jobs would be created and existing jobs saved. And they emphasized that the benefits to the environment and the general well-being of the community from keeping large tracts of pasture land open were almost incalculable.
In towns like Lewisboro and North Salem, which derive almost no tax revenues from traditional commercial sources, horseback riding accounts for practically all of the nontrade related, moderate-wage jobs. In North Salem, for example, the horse industry is the largest employer and industry.
Westchester's few remaining horse farms preserve scenic vistas and provide recreation. They also pay taxes and create jobs. Any realistic attempt to save agriculture in the county must include these facilities. After being used for centuries to clear farm fields, horses may now be our best means of saving them.
 
DEAN TRAVALINO
South Salem

HEADLINE: Can Nonprofits Also Be For-Profits?

 BODY:
I wonder how many readers noticed the rhetorical sleight-of-hand in "New Arts Space Keeps Faith With White Plains" (June 6). State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, who facilitated the $550,000 state grant to the nonprofit Westchester Arts Council, noted the "council's key role in developing the $54.2 million arts industry in Westchester." But the council anticipates for-profit activities in the building described. Evidently, no one questions where nonprofit ends and for-profit begins or why taxpayers who live elsewhere should pay "for the revitalization of downtown White Plains" if local businesses want out.
Convoluted rationales for allocations of public funds to the arts have become commonplace since the fizzled arts boom of the late 1960's and early 1970's. Next, arts groups tried hard to prove that concerts and exhibitions delivered economic benefits. In fact they did, but only to a limited number of small businesses. Large corporations either received tax rebates or relocated their facilities, without reference to employee interests. 
 With that finding, it became clear that unless major givers foot bills (which they were unwilling to do), government was the only major source of financing left. Bureaucrats in Albany and Washington nonetheless demanded that prospective beneficiaries demonstrate entrepreneurial skills. Thus the tragicomic spectacle of arts nonprofits receiving public funds to demonstrate their capabilities to operate as for-profits, But if they could do that, why would they have gone to government in the first place?
 
MILTON GOLDIN
Tarrytown

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT: FUNDS WATCH;
401(k) Advice on Line

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Are you ever nervous about the choices you've made in investing your 401(k) money? And have you ever calculated how big your account is likely to grow by the time you reach retirement?
Three services, Financial Engines, Directadvice.com and Standard & Poor's Personalwealth.com are among a handful of companies that have sprung up to help investors answer such questions on line. 
 Investors can get a free estimate of a portfolio's value upon retirement at the Financial Engines' site, www.financialengines.com. For $14.95 a quarter, they receive recommendations on how to allocate cash among the funds offered in their 401(k)'s.
"We provide specific recommendations on funds to find the highest expected return for a given level of risk," said Jeff Maggioncalda, president of Financial Engines, based in Palo Alto, Calif.
The company was founded by William F. Sharpe, a Stanford professor and Nobel laureate in economics.
The computer model looks at criteria like fund expenses, consistency of performance and appropriateness of investment style, given the individual's other holdings. It then makes recommendations.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY;
How to Corral an Expanding Tax

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The alternative minimum tax, enacted 30 years ago to make sure that every rich person pays some income taxes, is increasingly a burden on the middle class. But fixing it is easy, according to a report by the staff of the Congressional Joint Committee on Taxation.
Years of inflation have so distorted the tax that taxpayers with as little as $27,404 in adjusted gross income can be subject to the A.M.T. this year, but the issue gets little play from Washington politicians polishing their images as tax cutters. 
 A few years ago, virtually no one making $75,000 to $100,000 paid the tax. But this year, the committee estimated, one in eight A.M.T. taxpayers will be in that income group. Some middle-class taxpayers who are affected by the A.M.T. will not get the full $500-a-child tax credit.
The fix? Index the tax for inflation.
If that is done now, the committee estimated, the 823,000 taxpayers who will pay the A.M.T. this year will grow to just one million in 2009, instead of the nine million projected otherwise. If no changes are made, A.M.T. revenues, now $3.9 billion, will be $19.8 billion in 2009; if indexing were adopted now, they would rise to only $5.9 billion. DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

In Market After Market, a Summer Rally

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
Records dropped like flies in the hot summer sun last week.
 On Wednesday, investors in Japan pushed the Nikkei 225 index to a new high for the year, bolstered by data that suggested a recovery was under way. 
 In Seoul, a rally on Thursday in response to the Federal Reserve's change in bias on American interest rates spilled over to Friday, as the Korea composite index crossed into record territory.
 Also on Friday, the Hang Seng index reached its highest level since Oct. 9, 1997, and had its biggest one-day gain in three months. Malaysia's composite index reached its highest level since September 1997. The Straits Times index in Singapore hit a record. And the Xetra DAX in Frankfurt closed at a high for this year.
 In the United States, the Dow industrials, at 11,139.24, and the Nasdaq, at 2,741.02, surpassed previous highs, marking the best week for stocks since last October.
 Giddy investors may see the makings of an extended rally. We felt we'd see a summer rally in stocks up to 11,500 on the Dow, so we're more than halfway home, Philip Orlando, chief investment officer for Value Line Asset Management, told Bloomberg News. MICKEY MEECE
