HEADLINE: For Swiss, Some Soul Searching After Losing a Bid for Olympics

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 3

 BODY:
Like chocolate, cheese, precision watches, the Red Cross, skiing and banking, the Olympic movement has been linked for decades with Switzerland. The city of Lausanne has long been headquarters for the International Olympic Committee and home to its spectacular lakeside museum.
So it has been doubly infuriating for the Swiss to endure what is widely perceived as the latest blow to their national pride: the decision to award the 2006 Winter Olympics not to the front-running Alpine resort of Sion, but to an upstart Italian rival, the industrial city of Turin. 
 The unexpected and very public blow came when Switzerland was climbing out of a lengthy economic downturn and beginning to come to terms with the painful revelations of recent years that Swiss actions during World War II may well have been less concerned with self-preservation than with profit.
Sion's loss to Turin sparked street protests and nationwide accusations that the vote was an act of revenge for the Swiss member of the International Olympic Committee who blew the whistle late last year on widespread corrupt practices within the Olympic movement. That led to resignations and expulsions of members of its clubby committee.
Sion's bid for the Winter Games enjoyed widespread popular support and Olympic rings in the red and white Swiss national colors adorned everything from toilet paper to trains. So the rebuff was felt nationwide, and the fury enhanced by knowledge that the committee's formal evaluation gave the edge to Sion, while the 52-to-36 vote went heavily against the Swiss resort.
The rejection prompted a wave of self-examination. One mass circulation daily, Blick, published a survey of foreigners' views of the Swiss, ranging from what it described as the Israeli view that the Swiss are anti-Semitic, to the French observation that they are racist and the American perception of the Swiss as colorless and out for themselves.
"We are pedantic and humorless," Blick concluded." We are bad losers -- that's how the world sees us."
Switzerland has long prided itself on what is nationally seen as self-sufficiency, which in foreign affairs translated into neutrality and choosing not to join either the United Nations or the European Union. Today, however, that attitude is increasingly seen as perilously insular.
Federal Minister Adolf Ogi, who oversaw the unsuccessful bid for the 2006 Games, said afterward in published remarks that despite Switzerland's healthy international economic position, it is "politically alone."
Mr. Ogi, who was photographed visibly shaken when he heard the news announced in Seoul, South Korea, said later: "I heard delegates say they wanted the Swiss to lose. People don't like Switzerland."
No sooner was the disheartened Mr. Ogi's interview published when reports surfaced that the country's role in seeking the Games might not have been squeaky clean. A Swiss newsweekly, L'Hebdo, said Swiss tax officials had overlooked past Olympic Committee tax fraud to smooth the way for Sion's bid. L'Hebdo printed what it said was a secret Government memo that Olympic Committee workers declared lower salaries than they received to avoid taxes.
The Olympic Committee has denied any wrongdoing, saying tax arrangements, often murky in Switzerland for the rich and famous, were longstanding and legitimate. Swiss officials also denied wrongdoing.
Last month, a rare alliance of conservative and left-leaning political parties blocked a constitutional amendment that would have enabled Switzerland to sell some of its gold reserves to finance the Solidarity Foundation, which was started to help victims of poverty and disaster.
The opponents argued that any benefits from gold sales should go to Switzerland's sagging state pension fund, not to the special fund.
Mr. Ogi, who oversees Swiss defense and sports matters, saw the recent controversy over the country's role during World War II and the Olympic corruption disclosures as part of a "mosaic."
"It also has to do with our attitude," he added. "We think we are the best, we play at being schoolmasters, we give lessons, we wish to profit but not to get involved. We overestimate ourselves." http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 2162 words

HEADLINE: REASON IS SOUGHT FOR LAG BY BLACKS IN SCHOOL EFFORT

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK

DATELINE: EVANSTON, Ill.

 BODY:
Taking on one of the most troublesome and contentious issues in American education, school officials and educators around the nation have begun discussing why the academic achievement of black middle-class and upper-income students lags behind whites of comparable socioeconomic status.
On some tests, black students from middle-class or wealthier families have done no better than white students who live in poverty. And some especially puzzling data have suggested that at higher achievement levels, the gap between black and white performance is wider than at lower levels. 
 For example, an analysis of 1995 S.A.T. scores, the most recent such analysis available, showed that students of all races did better if their parents had more education. But blacks whose parents had at least one graduate degree averaged 191 points lower than whites whose parents had the same amount of education, while blacks whose parents had no high school diploma averaged 137 points behind whites whose parents had none.
School officials and black education experts are increasingly troubled by the gap.
"How do we explain the underproductivity of middle-class kids, of able and gifted minority youngsters who come out of situations where you would expect high achievement?" asked Edmund W. Gordon, a professor emeritus of psychology at Yale University and the co-chairman of the National Task Force on Minority High Achievement, formed in 1997 by the College Board. "This is not something that a lot of people feel comfortable talking about."
In one of the most closely watched efforts in education circles, more than a dozen middle-class, racially integrated communities across the country, including Evanston, and two in the New York metropolitan area -- White Plains, and South Orange-Maplewood, N.J. -- have formed a network to learn more about the disparity and try to do something about it. They will scrutinize what happens in schools and classrooms, and will also look at research on the home lives, study habits, and attitudes of black students.
In Evanston, a comfortable, attractive community just north of Chicago, Venessa Woods has a firsthand look at the problem.
Ms. Woods, who runs a high school program to help minority students do better, keeps coming across black students from stable, educated, middle-class families who have fallen behind despite seeming to have all the ingredients for success.
"The first thing that came to my head is 'Oh, they're poor' or 'Oh, they're in a single-parent home,' " said Ms. Woods, who is African-American. "To my surprise, the students were living in the better part of Evanston. Students were living with two-parent families who have college degrees. They have computers. They have personal tutors. And they're getting C's and D's, and why?"
Nobody claims to have clear answers. But from conversations with teachers, students, researchers and parents, the reasons seem to be multilayered, going beyond a student's socioeconomic status to include lingering racial inferiority complexes, peer pressure, low teacher expectations, curriculum, parental involvement and access to information, and vestiges of racism in schools.
Some of the most compelling insights come from students like Akilah Rogers, who just completed her junior year at Evanston Township High School taking advanced placement and accelerated classes, and helped organize a day of student discussion about minority achievement this spring.
"I would say that the most African-Americans in one of my honors classes is three," said Akilah, who is 17. Early on, she said, "People were like, 'Oh, you're an oreo.' Getting good grades was always connected to white people. So they're like, 'Are you going to be white and achieve?' "
 
In Chicago Suburb, Numbers Defy Logic
The 14 schools in the network are mostly top-notch, with high per-pupil spending, many middle-class families and diverse student populations. At these schools, middle-class blacks typically perform better than poor blacks and often score above the national and state average for African-Americans. Many are in university towns like Berkeley, Calif., Chapel Hill, N.C., and Amherst, Mass. But they still perform worse on average than whites.
"These are areas in the country where you would think you would get people being high achievers, but it's not happening to the degree it should," said Allan Alson, superintendent of Evanston's high school, who is concerned about what schools like his should be doing differently.
At Evanston, 42 percent of the high school's 2,900 students are black. And while there is poverty here -- about 30 percent of the students, mostly blacks, receive free or reduced-price lunches -- there is also a solid black middle class. Evanston provides after-school, summer and weekend programs for struggling students, and honors and advanced placement courses are open to any student who wants to enroll.
Still, the numbers at Evanston have been disappointing. A study of the first semester of the 1997-1998 school year found that nearly 25 percent of black students had failed at least one class, compared with 4 percent of white students. Seven percent of black students' grades were A's, compared with 25 percent for whites.
In 1996, on a state reading test, 49 percent of African-Americans at the school were reading below grade level, compared with 9 percent of whites. And while the college attendance rate of both blacks and whites here is above the national average, 66 percent of blacks go to college, compared with 95 percent of whites.
Evanston's most recent efforts include hiring more African-American teachers, raising the academic eligibility requirements for participation in sports, increasing the amount of homework, and creating more advanced placement courses.
Students at Evanston and elsewhere say doing well in school is not always accepted by their peers.
Fitzroy Dennison, 18, said he was so conscious of the stigma that he avoided speaking grammatically correct English with friends.
"You learn to switch it off," said Fitzroy, whose parents are from Panama and Belize. "When you're on the streets, you speak Ebonics. When you're at home, you speak Creole. When you're in school, you speak proper English. But when you talk too proper, your peers will call you white and say you're a cracker."
Bruce Eddy, a history teacher at Evanston, recalled that during a class that mixed middle-level and honors students, "a black student came in the room and pointed to a couple of black kids in the room, and one kid got very upset and said, 'He's pointing out that this is an all-white class and there are only a couple of black students in here.' "
 
Some Insight Into the Obstacles
Some clues to the problem might come from students who have achieved in spite of considerable adversity, like Albert Smith, whose family is so poor that he and his parents, four siblings and a nephew often struggle to have enough food.
For Albert, a wiry, energetic 17-year-old, race had a profound effect on his self-esteem in school. As a freshman in history and English honors classes, he said, "the people around me, they were white, and it intimidated me."
"I just thought they were smart because they were white," he added. "I didn't want to raise my hand to answer a question."
That year, Albert's grade point average was 2.7, and he said African-American friends in regular classes treated him like a genius, even when he was not getting the grades he wanted. He started to push himself harder after teachers told him he had potential, and after he started "to become comfortable with all the white people."
By junior year, Albert was averaging 3.6, and he graduated in June, was accepted to several colleges and his classmates voted him best all-around male student.
Albert said he believed that many black students privately respect high achievers, but they "openly praise the people who are doing badly, the people in the gangs, the people who are doing negative things."
He said some seem afraid to try hard because "if they push themselves to the hardest and they don't do well, they think they've failed."
"Then they'll start believing some of the stigmas that are out there in society," Albert said, "that African-Americans aren't as smart as their white counterparts."
Some researchers say differences in home life may affect how well students do. Ronald F. Ferguson, a researcher at Harvard University, has been surveying students at Shaker Heights High School outside of Cleveland, an academically acclaimed school in the new network where most black and white families are solidly middle class. There, while African-Americans make up half the student population, blacks constituted 9 percent of those who graduated in the top fifth of their class, but 83 percent of those in the bottom fifth.
Among other things, Dr. Ferguson found that "black kids watch twice as much TV as white kids; three hours a day as opposed to one and a half hours a day."
National studies have also found differences. One asked students to name the lowest grade they could take home without their parents becoming angry. Blacks consistently named lower grades than Asian, white or Hispanic students.
 
Family Background Comes Into Play
Gloria Ladson-Billings, an education professor at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, said middle-class, college-educated black parents were often the first generation of their families to have such success, so the roots of their academic and economic accomplishments are shallower than many white families.
"For whites, if you go to grandma's house you're maybe going to this huge family library," but for many blacks, grandma's is "a working-class household where people are very proud of what you're doing but they don't have any way of really supporting it."
On their upwardly mobile trajectory, black families may have moved frequently, switching children from school to school, not usually an educational plus.
Dr. Gordon said that because they did not grow up in academically oriented homes, "many minority parents who are serious about their child's education insist that their kids study, do homework, but the same parents are seldom seen by their kids reading a lot or doing anything studious."
Those differences may help account for some test results that showed the gap between black and white achievement on national reading tests and on S.A.T.'s was wider for children whose parents had college or graduate degrees than for children whose parents did not have a high school diploma. (But some researchers say those results might be partly explained by other factors: subtle cultural biases in tests or in schools, the many fewer black parents than white parents with advanced educational backgrounds, or the possibility that black children may have been more likely than whites to overstate or misconstrue their parents' educational history.)
"African-American parents are going to have to step up to the plate and do more," said Martha Burns, an Evanston mother who pushed to get her two children into accelerated elementary school classes, takes them to after-school reading programs and limits television watching. "Anytime you bring this up, people get defensive, insulted and then we just retreat. We really never bring it on the table."
Ms. Burns, a co-president of the P.T.A. council, and experts like Dr. Gordon also said African-American churches and community centers should create more extracurricular academic programs, following the example of, say, Asian-Americans.
But some students and parents say that teachers and guidance counselors, white or black, may, consciously or unconsciously, have lower expectations of African-American students and that this may ultimately translate into self-fulfilling prophecies of mediocrity.
Tanya Bernard, a middle-class 17-year-old who got mostly A's and B's as a junior this year, said that when a counselor discouraged her from taking a Spanish honors class, "I think it may have been a little bit of a racial thing."
Terri Shepard, whose daughter is a student at Evanston, said she believed that early on, many teachers label African-American children as having less potential than whites.
"I don't think teachers expect excellence, and you get what you expect," said Ms. Shepard, a school board member for the lower grades.
That impression, she and others said, can lead parents to distrust schools. The parents may feel less able to act as advocates for their children, less knowledgeable about how to get the attention of teachers, or simply less certain that it will make a difference if they urge their children to strive harder.
"My teachers are not telling me I have to do it; my parents don't tell me I have to do it," said Fitzroy, who graduated this year. "African-American parents, they settle for less, not knowing they can get more for their students."

HEADLINE: Victor A. Bonomo, Maker Of Candy Bars, Dies at 100

BYLINE: By MICHAEL T. KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
Victor A. Bonomo, who created and marketed Bonomo's Turkish Taffy, the brittle candy bar whose wrapper instructed buyers to smack it and crack it into many edible pieces, died on June 26 at his home in Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 100.
The candy, which first appeared as a nickel bar after World War II, became a favorite with the economy-minded. Unlike some of its competitors, which melted in your mouth, Turkish Taffy eroded slowly, and it was so chewy that a single bar could last through most of a double feature at the movies. 
 Mr. Bonomo (pronounced BAHN-uh-moh) was born into the candy business and actually had Turkish roots. His father, Albert J., was a Sephardic Jew who had emigrated from Turkey. In 1897, the year before Victor Bonomo was born, his father started making candy in Coney Island to supply concessions at the amusement park. After World War I, Victor joined his father in running the candy factory on Eighth Street in Coney Island, where saltwater taffy and hard candies were produced.
As World War II ended, sugar rationing gave way and the entire country was eager to indulge its sweet tooth. Bonomo's joined the race to satisfy the surging demand, promoting three candy bars, "Thanks," "Hats Off" and "Call Again," which Tico Bonomo, Victor's son, described as "poor man's Milky Ways."
Then the candy cooks at the Coney Island factory came up with a batter of corn syrup and egg whites that was cooked and then baked.
"It was not really a taffy but what is technically known as a short nougat," explained Tico Bonomo. Nor was it Turkish. "It was not a family recipe and the name we chose, 'Turkish Taffy,' just reflected clever marketing," he said.
It cooled into sheets the size of school desks, which were distributed through Woolworth stores around the country. Clerks at the candy counters used ball-peen hammers to whack the sheets, breaking off shards that were sold by the pound.
Apparently this method of distribution merely whetted appetites for the candy, then available only in vanilla. Mr. Bonomo had the slabs cut into panels the size of 1945 nickel Hershey bars, which were larger than 1999 65-cent Hershey bars. The bars were packaged in wrappers that showed smiling men in fezzes pouring batter into a huge vat. Of course, in Turkey, the fez had been outlawed by Kemal Ataturk in the 1920's, but back in the 50's the design drew no complaints.
The candy grew popular, eventually being distributed far beyond the metropolitan region into much of the rest of the country. Before the widespread use of air-conditioning, Turkish Taffy had some problems penetrating Southern markets, where warm temperatures turned the bars from hard to gooey. The problem was eventually overcome with new wrappers.
In the 1950's, Bonomo's Turkish Taffy advertised on children's television programs, among them "The Magic Clown" and "Wonderama." The ads featured puppets named Bo, No and Mo. It also sponsored joint promotions with the Duncan yo-yo company.
In time, three new flavors appeared: chocolate, strawberry and banana. According to Tico Bonomo, the company sold 80 million to 100 million bars a year in the 50's and 60's and employed as many as 350 workers at the Coney Island plant, where it also produced hard candy.
Victor Bonomo retired in 1970 and moved to Florida with his wife, Zephra, who survives, as do Tico Bonomo and nine grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Bonomo's Turkish Taffy changed hands a few times, in 1980 becoming part of Tootsie Roll Industries of Chicago, which stopped making the candy in 1989. Ellen Gordon, president of Tootsie Roll Industries, said that the company phased out the product when demand declined as tastes changed.
Probably so, but at least some of the taffy-deprived have turned to the World Wide Web to seek solace from each other, writing of Turkish Taffy with yearnings as evocative as those of Proust for madeleines. Consider this posting on a site called WebFoodPros.com from John R.:
"I have been looking for this taffy for a long time; no other taffy compares. If only I could refrigerate a bar and smack it against the table. Come on, Tootsie Roll, make it again."

HEADLINE: Deluxe Motor Homes Reflect Nation's Booming Economy

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: THORNTOWN, Ind.

 BODY:
It is simple, Clarence and Maryann Cornell said. Financially secure, they wanted to travel and they wanted to do it in comfort and style, their two yelping dachshunds in tow.
With that, the Cornells, owners of two stationary homes -- one in Minnesota, the other in Florida -- explained their latest acquisition: a $112,000 Fleetwood Southwind motor home they had just eased into a spot at Old Mill Run Park, a 67-acre campground with a stream and fishing ponds, amid corn and soybean fields here in central Indiana, 35 miles northwest of Indianapolis. 
 Over a long weekend, they will lounge on leather upholstery in a plushly carpeted living room with expandable walls, cook in a kitchen complete with four-door refrigerator-freezer and bathe in a big tub in their bedroom suite.
"With the dogs," said Mrs. Cornell, who is 40, "the only way to do it is with a motor home."
Mr. Cornell, 69, outside lowering the motor home's built-in awning, shrugged and agreed. "That's the gist of it."
In these days of unparalleled affluence, the Cornells can splurge more than most. He is a semiretired executive; their children are grown. But in their taste for luxury on the road, they are far from alone.
Chariots like that of the Cornells -- and bigger ones, costing up to $1 million, with washers, dryers, tile-walled baths, surround-sound stereos and storage compartments beneath the wheels known as basements -- pull into Old Mill Run Park every day. The one thing that does not often pierce this middle-class campground's horizon of metal boxes on wheels is the peak of a spartan camper's tent.
If there is a place in America that captures how the waning century's longest stretch of prosperity has fogged over memories of recessions, unemployment, inflation, gasoline rationing and sinking stock markets, the American campground is as sure a contender as the thriving marinas of Florida or the shoulder-to-shoulder big houses of suburbia.
While roughing it with bugs, sterno stoves and sleeping bags in the bush still lures many of the hardy and fit, the old conventional campground now more often means trailers with window screens, three-burner stoves, air-conditioning and queen-sized beds.
Motor homes, many of them 300- and 400-horsepower "diesel pushers," as they are called, pull the family car to the campsite, or "duallies," big muscular, $40,000 pickups with four wheels in the rear, haul in the trailers.
It all costs money, far more than the gains in income that most Americans have realized over the last decade. But like the boats and the extra-large houses, a deluxe home on the road is something that many of them will stretch themselves thin to have.
"People are buying more now than they ever did in their life," said John Shufflebarger, who as a salesman at the Indy R.V. Center near Indianapolis supplies some of the vehicles that come here. "I don't believe people in the United States are going to let money or gas prices interfere with their entertainment. As long as the economy is as good as it is now, they're going to go out and have a good time."
For three years, Mary Kay Baker, 36, a cheery preschool teacher, her husband, John, 39, a farmer and water-well driller, and their children, Bradley, 11, and Kristen, 15, have been spending weekends and summer vacations here. A year ago, Mrs. Baker's parents, Bill and Ferne Ferrel, started coming, too, in a trailer of their own.
The Bakers, who earn something under $60,000 a year, put 10 percent down from their savings to buy their $21,000, 35-foot Innsbruck trailer. Unlike many Americans, the Bakers do save something, about 10 percent of their income, but they save to spend, not for the rainy days of unemployment or plunging stocks and bonds.
"I don't remember the recession," Mrs. Baker said, sitting at the family picnic table.
Last year, the Recreational Vehicle Industry Association says the booming economy induced Americans to spend $8.4 billion for nearly 300,000 recreational vehicles, from $3,000 pop-up camping trailers to self-propelled motor-home behemoths, most of which cost $50,000 to $100,000.
In the 1990's through last year, the association says, the industry sold two million vehicles, almost half a million more than in the 1980's. All together, the association says 9.3 million are in service and that 1 in 10 households has one.
A year ago, after many years of camping with their children, Ralph Christman, 47, a former farmer and automobile assembly line worker, and his wife, Sandy, formerly the activities director at a veterans' home, bought Old Mill Run Park.
The park has 347 campsites, with 197 of them renting for $950 for the season that runs from April to October. All of these are taken. Most of the other sites, renting for an average of $21 a day, except for those for tents, are at least two-thirds full on weekdays and tend to fill up on weekends. The vehicle sites have small lawns and easy hook-ups to water and electricity and many to cable television and telephone lines.
People come for the swimming, fishing, the golf course and volleyball, bingo and horseshoe tournaments.
"Everybody's carefree," Mrs. Christman said. Children come into the campground store with $20 bills to buy candy and trinkets and spend it all, she said, adding, "Then they go back and get some more."
As production of R.V.'s has climbed, so have the features on which consumers splurge. Many are equipped with one to three expandable sides, known as slide-outs. These are sections of wall, floor and ceiling that with the push of a button pop out from a vehicle's aluminum hide to create more space inside.
Driven or towed, the bigger vehicles require a gallon of gasoline or diesel oil to travel 7 to 10 miles. But relatively inexpensive fuel, $1 a gallon for gasoline or diesel oil at at a station near this campground, has erased memories of the oil crisis in the mid-1970's, when rationing and soaring prices put the recreational vehicle business in mothballs.
The lush economy has blessed Jack Andres, 65, who retired last year as a utilities engineer at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., and his wife, Janet, 59, who was an administrative secretary there.
They sold their home last year and, with savings and profits, have settled into a 28-foot, single-slide-out trailer that they keep here. They also bought a camper that fits into the bed of their pickup that they take on visits to 11 children from two marriages and to Naples, Fla., the site of their modular home.
"It used to be, camping was your cheap summer vacation," Mrs. Andres said. "Camping is a life style for us now."
With the growth of motorized camping, the age of the motorist has dropped. Almost entirely retirees before the 1990's, the average trailer and motor home owner today is 48, said Jeff Beddow, the industry association's spokesman.
At the Old Mill Run Park, the Christmans's clientele is blue collar and white collar. Postal workers and construction workers reside lot to lot with doctors and executives. They seem universally affluent, in outlook and attitude if not in all cases in assets and income.
Judee and David Duncan, both 58, parents of five children, have a 38.5-foot Fleetwood Avion fifth-wheeler, trailer that hitches into bed of a pickup. It is the Duncans' only home.
Mr. Duncan retired from the Navy, having risen to lieutenant commander, and went to work for the Raytheon Company. Five years ago, at 53, while working 70 hours a week managing a missile assembly plant, he had a heart attack.
"We decided to chuck it all," Mr. Duncan said. "We sold our 3,000-square-foot home, bought a fifth-wheeler and have been on the road since."
The low-inflation economy, Mr. Duncan said, protects the buying power of his $35,000 annual pension from the Navy that he and his wife are living on.
For some other campers here, the decade's prosperity has inspired revisionist thinking about the notions of spending, saving and borrowing.
Harold Rumery, 71, basks under his awning, wearing a T-shirt that says, "I'm a two-steppin' country western dancer." He and his wife, Nancy, 68, used to share driving of a Mayflower moving van, and then he became the company's supervisor of driver training.
"I was in the Depression," Mr. Rumery said. "I was born in 1927. I grew up dirt poor." Gesturing from his patio, he said, "We just bought that '99 Chrysler this year," with 10 percent down. "We had a '96 Mercury. But it was gray and she wanted red, so we just bought it."
Behind Mr. Rumery is his 1999, 36-foot, $22,000 Nomad trailer with two slide-outs. "We just bought it, too," he said, again with 10 percent down.
With pensions, Social Security, Medicare, consulting fees, and a lively stock market, Mr. Rumery said, "We believe we've got the ability to do what we want to do."

HEADLINE: In the Rockaways, Hope for a Revival

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
Bill Daly, an 11-year resident on the Rockaway peninsula, has seen ferries come and he has seen ferries go. So it is no wonder that he is a little skeptical of another plan to give the Rockaways daily ferry service to Manhattan.
"There's no real direct route to the city other than the waterway," said Mr. Daly, a stockbroker who commutes more than an hour to Wall Street each day by subway or car. "Any other city in the world would have already tapped into it ages ago, but here we are in New York, and there's nothing." 
 At the urging of City Councilman Alfonso C. Stabile, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey recently completed a preliminary feasibility study that proposes possible ferry landing sites in the Rockaways and suggests an additional stop in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn. Civic leaders and the local community board had been asking for a government-subsidized ferry service for years as an alternative to the A train, which meanders through Queens and Brooklyn to get to Manhattan.
Few details have been pinned down yet, including where subsidy money would come from and exactly where the ferry would depart from and go to, but city officials hope to solicit bids from private operators to run the ferry by next spring.
Although next summer would be the earliest that a Rockaway ferry service could be up and running, many residents are nonetheless pleased that the Port Authority and other local officials have finally shown some serious interest in the idea. Residents and community leaders said they were hopeful that the ferry, combined with a number of new housing developments and plans for a $1.2 billion sports and entertainment complex on the east end of the peninsula, would be a sign that the long-awaited revival of the Rockaways is finally on the horizon.
"Commuting from Rockaway to Manhattan, on a good day, is a misadventure in transportation," said Jonathan L. Gaska, the district manager of the community board that covers the Rockaways. "To attract working-class families to live here, something has to be done to shorten the commute. There's no question that improving transportation and access in and out would help spur economic development out here."
Councilman Stabile said that the isolation of the peninsula has led residents to "feel like they've been forgotten, and in a lot of ways, they have a right to feel that way."
Ever since the Long Island Rail Road shut down a line that connected the Rockaways to the rest of the city in the 1950's, the only public transportation to the peninsula has been the A train and local buses, options that can take up to 90 minutes to get into Manhattan. People who commute by car must go over two bridges, including one that charges a $1.75 toll each way, just to get to mainland Queens. When traffic is bad, the commute to Manhattan by car can take as long as two hours.
"That's like primitive, that's like the Dark Ages," Mr. Stabile exclaimed. "The Rockaways need a shot in the arm, and to me, the ferry is the best solution to improving the transportation." A ferry would take between 32 and 43 minutes, depending on where it leaves from.
In addition to getting the Port Authority to do a feasibility study, Mr. Stabile has also started exploring possible sources of city and state money to subsidize the ferry in order to keep the fare at about $3 each way. A number of private ferry services operated from the Rockaways in the 1980's and early 1990's, but none lasted more than a few months. Mr. Stabile and Port Authority officials surmise that they failed in part because they charged as much as $7 per trip.
United States Representative Anthony D. Weiner, whose district includes the Rockaways, hopes to bring home part of the transportation funding that the Federal Government set aside last year specifically to increase and improve ferry service across the country. He hopes to use the Federal money to build ferry landings in the Rockaways.
Although city and state subsidies for the ferry ride are yet to be determined, Mr. Weiner said he believed that the different levels of government are committed to the ferry because the lack of transportation alternatives has stunted development in the Rockaways for too long.
"At the end of the day, we're going to be able to get city and Federal support for it," he said. "But getting a private operator to see the same kind of potential we see may be the toughest part of this." He said that few private operators have expressed interest in running a service, and said he hoped that the Port Authority's study would help change that.
After reviewing the demographics of the Rockaways, Port Authority officials concluded that there probably are not enough commuters to support a ferry service. So the Port Authority has recommended an additional stop in Sheepshead Bay, where a ferry could add as many as 1,200 commuters to the estimated 5,000 from the Rockaways.
Charles Meara, manager of state and local relations for the Port Authority, said that the operators who ran ferries in the past failed because they operated very small boats that often did not provide a comfortable ride and ran only during the morning and evening rush hours.
That's why the Port Authority is recommending boats that can operate at 30 knots per hour, roughly the size of the ferries that now travel between Manhattan and Hoboken and from Manhattan to Yankee Stadium and can carry more than 100 passengers. The agency's study also recommends full-time service, including weekend hours to attract Manhattanites who might want to avoid traffic-clogged routes when going to the beach.
The ferry service is just one of many long-talked-about projects in the Rockaways that have finally seen some movement recently.
Dozens of two-family homes are being built in Arverne and Edgemere, sections of the Rockaways where thousands of summer bungalows were razed by the city in the 1960's for urban renewal, but which have seen little development until recently. A private developer also has started building 90 homes on land once used by the Playland amusement park at Beach 98th Street.
Plans for a $1.2 billion sports and entertainment complex called Destination Technodome also have moved ahead, with the developers negotiating with city and state officials for infrastructure development. The Rockaway Chamber of Commerce also has been working with a developer to turn the area around Beach 116th Street into an entertainment seaport site, possibly with a gambling boat, dinner cruises and new shops. Beach 116th Street is also one of the recommended sites for a ferry landing.
And the city has finally started to pay some attention to the deteriorating boardwalk along the beach. City crews completely rebuilt the boardwalk between Beach 116th and Beach 109th Streets a few months ago and plan to do more in the fall.
"We're obviously very pleased with everything that's going on," Mr. Gaska said. "Six or seven years ago, Rockaway couldn't get itself arrested as far as any kind of development was concerned. People maybe finally are realizing what a hidden gem we are."

HEADLINE: Flush Times and Hungry Republicans Generate Bush Campaign Windfall

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush's colossal $36.3 million campaign treasury was built on three pillars: a home-court advantage that allowed him to hit up Texas supporters, enthusiastic support from Republican governors, and the vast fund-raising network of his father, the former President.
But it is a fourth pillar that has catapulted the Governor of Texas to fund-raising heights never before seen in Presidential politics: the burning desire of hungry Republicans, made fat by seven years of economic growth and frustrated by Democratic control, to regain the Presidency. 
 In interviews with dozens of people who have donated to Mr. Bush or raised money for him, as well as strategists inside and outside the campaign, the refrain is common: donors sound practically breathless with excitement. They said they had showered the Bush campaign with money because they find the candidate charismatic and, more important, they view him as a winner.
"There's a tremendous amount of money available out there today," James E. Gilleran, 66, chairman of the Bank of San Francisco, said on his way out of a packed Bush fund-raiser in his city on Wednesday. "So all a candidate has to do is evidence the possibility of winning. And this is a guy who exudes the possibility of winning when we've got a Republican Party extremely desirous of winning back the White House."
Mr. Gilleran is a veteran Republican donor. But at the same event, Erik C. Weir, 32, president of a capital management company, said similar reasons had prompted him to attend a fund-raiser for the first time in years. "He's the first candidate in a long time that has a real chance of making it," Mr. Weir said.
At a Bush fund-raising breakfast the next morning in Palo Alto, Gregory W. Slayton, 39, the chief executive officer of MySoftware Company, put it this way: "The Silicon Valley is not about losing. It's about winning."
John Gable, 34, a product manager for Netscape who was at the event, gushed, "I've never written a $1,000 check before. But there's something to this personal connection when he looks you in the eye. There's a there there. It's a craving to be proud."
Because of that hunger for Mr. Bush, he has not had to spend one minute on the telephone pleading for donations -- a luxury not enjoyed by most other candidates. "Pick up the phone and dial for contributions?" Mr. Bush asked in an interview on Friday. "Not at all."
Mr. Bush simply shows up at fund-raising events. And he rarely mentions money at them. He doesn't have to; most people who attend these events have already given $1,000, the maximum individual contribution allowed by law.
In his only mention of contributions, Mr. Bush said at the gala this week in San Francisco, "I want to thank each and every one of you for writing a check." The campaign has raised some money through mailings, and plans to begin telephone solicitations within 30 days, said Don Evans, Mr. Bush's national finance chairman and best friend.
Mr. Evans, an oil company executive from Midland, Tex., said: "This isn't a hard-sell operation. People tell me this is the easiest money they've ever raised. That is the universal theme."
Mr. Evans said that, buoyed by a week of sold-out, record-breaking events, he realized on June 25, on a corporate jet taking the Bush team from one sold-out fund-raiser in Detroit to another in Fort Myers, Fla. that the campaign might pass the $30 million mark. .
At an event earlier in Michigan, for example, Governor John M. Engler marveled that the campaign collected $40,000 at the door from walk-ins -- people who had not bought their tickets in advance. "That has never happened before," Mr. Engler said. "This is a phenomenon that we haven't seen."
In something of a victory lap, Mr. Evans approached table after table at the Palo Alto event, telling donors: "I want to say thank you. It's history in the making."
No Presidential candidate had ever amassed that much money even over an entire primary season; Mr. Bush did it in four months. And Mr. Bush's money machine is only warming up. He has yet to tap potential donors in many states, including New York and New Jersey, which are always vital stops on the money circuit. Mr. Evans noted that the campaign has thus far picked only "the low-hanging fruit" on the finance tree.
The windfall gives Mr. Bush an enormous advantage over his Republican rivals, as well as over Vice President Al Gore, who has taken in only about half as much money. It may also be a harbinger of what could be the most expensive campaign season in history, given the open contest for the White House, a tight race for control of Congress and what appear to be several hard-fought Senate races in New York and other states.
Despite what one Bush aide called the "spontaneous combustion" from donors, the operation is all the more potent because of the critical advantages he has over his rivals.
Mr. Bush tapped into a vast statewide fund-raising network he had cultivated in his two races for Governor. About half the money he collected in the first quarter of the year came from Texas.
While Mr. Bush has not had to hit up donors on the telephone personally, his father, former President George Bush, and other Governors have done some of the work for him.
The fund-raising connections of the Governor's father helped the campaign get off to a swift start. President Bush was no slouch at raising money; he established "Team 100," a loyal network of $100,000 givers that helped the party and his own Presidential campaigns.
In the first quarter of the year, the Bush organization took in roughly 15 percent of its contributions from people who had donated to the elder Bush. The former President has also pitched in by appearing as the star attraction at fund-raising events for his son and by helping raise money for lawmakers who are backing the Governor. The younger Mr. Bush said that on Friday morning he had chatted with his father about the $36.3 million. "He was proud and amazed," the Governor said.
The Republican governors who have played crucial roles are Governor Engler; Mr. Bush's brother, Jeb, in Florida, and Governors Paul Cellucci of Massachusetts and John G. Rowland of Connecticut. They have leaned on their own financial networks to raise money for Mr. Bush, something that the 1996 Republican Presidential nominee, Bob Dole, did not accomplish.
"They're deeply involved with George Bush," Governor Engler said, "and they were not with Bob Dole. I don't think Bob, Senator Dole, understood how you could use governors effectively. It's night and day -- and makes a huge difference."
While the Bush fund-raising operation has been geared more to managing the inward torrent of money than soliciting donors, the Bush organizers have not been as passive as campaign officials suggest. The campaign has established an elite group of about 200 supporters, called "the Pioneers," who have each agreed to raise $100,000 from their friends and associates. (About half have met the goal, campaign officials say.) The campaign refused to disclose the names of the Pioneers. "A lot of people would just as soon not have their name released," Mr. Evans said. "We owe them the courtesy of keeping that private."
Although Mr. Bush has not had to solicit personally, his minions have not been shy. "A pretty amazing thing is that when I first got asked for money and I told the guy I would do it," said one well-connected donor who spoke on the condition of anonymity, "the next day they called me and said, 'Can you put your check in overnight?' It's a mindset. It's one thing to get pledges, but their turnaround must be impressive."
Still, the financial frenzy seems more grounded in Mr. Bush's personal appeal than in the people pushing his virtues. It is all the more striking because Mr. Bush is not particularly well-known nationally and his positions on issues are largely a mystery, although he has presented himself as a "compassionate conservative" with broad appeal.
"He's so untested and undefined, but the Republican elite have in an extraordinary way rallied to this candidate," said David B. Magleby, a political scientist at Brigham Young University. "It is probably in their antipathy to Clinton and their sense that he's head and shoulders above the other candidates. It's the gap between Bush and the others that's quite remarkable."
Asked in the interview whether donors were motivated because they see him as a winner, Mr. Bush said, "I think that's true." He added that "there's all kinds of reasons we've done well."
At a series of fund-raising events in California this week, in which the Bush campaign drew roughly $5 million, he was met by overflow crowds. "The California team was amazed," Mr. Bush said. "The people involved in the fund-raising were smiling the whole time. Most people are stressed out at these things. They were joyful."
Brad Freeman, the campaign's finance chairman in the state, was so giddy about the outpouring that when he introduced the Governor at a dinner in Los Angeles, he joked that outside, "I was approached by a scalper who offered me a ticket for $3,000" to the dinner. He said of Mr. Bush, "Believe me, there's no one I would rather hang out with."
Melvin Sembler, the national finance chairman of the Republican Party, emphasized that he had to stay impartial in the primary races. But he said Mr. Bush was helped "because he does have a wonderful personality."
Indeed, many donors said in interviews that they were drawn to Mr. Bush by what they described as his impressive political skills in person and on television. At every gathering, Mr. Bush's staff has built in time for him to mingle at each table and try to greet every donor personally.
The events draw donors from all ideological stripes -- from foes of abortion to abortion rights supporters -- and even some Democrats.
"It's about charisma," said Mary Jo Wisely, 54, a donor from Sonoma, Calif., who owns a restaurant franchise. "His father just didn't get it. But his son does. And we have a candidate who can win."
Andrew M. Ling, who is senior vice president of GTX Corporation in Phoenix, said he decided to donate to Mr. Bush because of "his charisma." He said, "One of the driving things that people are searching for is restoration of the dignity of the office of the President."
Yet Mr. Ling, who is 39, also said Mr. Bush came to the race with built-in advantages. "He's very lucky," Mr. Ling said. "He has his father's infrastructure. His contacts in Texas and California are formidable."
Mr. Ling warned that despite Mr. Bush's financial advantage, the honeymoon is bound to end when he begins laying out his positions. "He's got to deliver now," he said.
The intake is so beyond what the Bush campaign had anticipated that the campaign plans to announce later this month that it will not need to take Federal matching funds -- and therefore can raise and spend far more money in the primaries. Initially, Mr. Bush had said he would not make the decision until October or November.
Mr. Bush said he was sliding into a nap on a couch in the dark cabin of a corporate jet at about 1 A.M. on June 25 when Mr. Evans told him the news that would be a turning point for his campaign, not to say a milestone in Presidential politics.
"Donny came back and said, 'I think we can put a three before the number,' " he recalled in the interview. "I was reclining and I just kind of smiled. I just kind of shook my head. Then I sacked out. It was a nice note to go to sleep on: a groundswell of support that I never dreamed would happen."
As the donations continue to pour in, the Governor and Mr. Evans insist that they have not pondered what the final figure might be.
"I have no idea," Mr. Evans said. "That's a number I haven't even dreamed about."

HEADLINE: Newark Hails Baseball's Return, but the High Cost of a New Stadium Raises Doubts

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 3

 BODY:
Groundskeepers painstakingly leveled the clay-orange dirt around home plate this week, and masons grouted between the earth-hued blocks at the entrance to the new Riverfront Park stadium, which is bringing minor league baseball to New Jersey's largest city for the first time in 50 years.
Officials here proudly predict that the sold-out opening game on July 16, between the Newark Bears and the Lehigh Valley Black Diamonds, will be the first of many sellouts that will draw thousands to the city and enliven its downtown. They say the park will accelerate Newark's renaissance, which began in 1997 with the opening of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center nearby and will continue with a proposed new stadium for the Nets and the Devils, New Jersey's pro basketball and hockey teams. 
 What could be wrong with this picture?
For one, the 6,000-seat stadium cost $34 million, about 50 percent more than planned. People familiar with the economics of minor league baseball say it is by far the most expensive minor league park in the country, built when minor leagues and their teams are coming and going at a rapid pace. A potential baseball glut, some industry experts say, makes Newark's expensive ball park far from a sure economic bet.
With opening day just two weeks away, city and Essex County officials are discounting warnings of traffic nightmares as they work to pin down contracts to provide several thousand parking spaces, at rates of $3 to $4, near the stadium. Without such agreements, parking rates within four blocks of the stadium could easily surpass the $6 to $7 charged during business hours. That would leave officials hard pressed to keep their promise of an affordable trip to the ball park, where seats cost $6 to $8.
But officials from Mayor Sharpe James to County Executive James W. Treffinger dismiss the gloomy predictions, saying that the parking will be in place and the streets equal to the traffic flow.
They said the cost overruns were largely the fault of local opponents who forced the city to move the stadium from its original site, a landmark park, to a combination of city-owned and private parcels at the northern edge of downtown Newark, off McCarter Highway. This plunged city and county planners into tough negotiations with the owners of the properties, who extracted $7 million for the land.
One million dollars was added to the ball park's cost because about 15 underground oil storage tanks at the new site had to be cleaned up. And the regional boom in construction has made labor more expensive, adding $3 million.
"The cost overruns have been overblown and misinterpreted," said Mayor James, a Democrat, "and they haven't hurt this investment in affordable, family entertainment that will change the image of Newark forever."
Mr. Treffinger, a Republican, said he believed that the investment in the stadium would increase the value of more than 2 million square feet of nearby office space. If the value of those office buildings rises by 20 percent, county studies have shown, tax revenues will increase by $1.2 million a year.
In addition, the city and the county, under a 10-year contract with the Bears, will get 25 percent of the income from advertising and concessions, 75 percent of the price of luxury box seats and $1 from every ticket sold. The publicly run Essex County Improvement Authority, which financed the stadium, will get all the proceeds from the sale of the right to name it. The authority will get 5 percent of the gross revenues after the team's first $4.75 million, and could get as much as 20 percent depending on how much more the team makes.
For Mr. Treffinger, the stadium also solves a political problem. As part of the arrangement to move the stadium to the downtown site, the city allowed construction of a much-needed county jail within city limits. This not only spared Mr. Treffinger the task of putting the jail elsewhere in the county, but it also eliminated the imminent threat of a $300 million fine and penalties from a Federal court ruling requiring a plan to relieve crowding in the county's jails.
"These benefits alone make it worth it to build the stadium for the Bears," Mr. Treffinger said. "But beyond that, when we talked with the New Jersey Nets about their moving from the Meadowlands and building an arena here, the minor league stadium was a crucial part of the attraction for them."
The stadium's cost overruns and the additional burden it places on taxpayers have drawn fire from the editorial pages of the The Star-Ledger, which once supported it. Some elected officials who once backed the stadium have turned critical.
"You don't do a project like this anywhere in the country without recognizing the possibility of additional costs, but not 50 percent additional," said State Senator Ronald L. Rice, a former City Councilman who unsuccessfully challenged Mayor James's re-election effort last year.
For the Bears' owner, the former Yankees catcher Rick Cerone, such complaints are background noise as he climbs into the unfinished sky boxes of the stadium. On clear days he can see the World Trade Center just over the center field fence.
"After 17 years as a player, this was a way to stay in the game," said Mr. Cerone, 45, who grew up in Newark and remembers his late father, Aldo, telling him stories about the Newark Bears and the Newark Eagles of the old Negro Leagues, which shared Newark's 25,000-seat, Ruppert Stadium until 1950. "My father saw me start on this effort before he died three years ago," Mr. Cerone said, "and while they say don't go into business where it is personal, this is personal."
Mr. Cerone said that the early tense days and their uncertainties have given way to fretting about getting the seats installed in time and whether the shimmering Kentucky bluegrass sod will root deeply enough before opening day. He said he was less worried now about the marketing of the team and the stadium, which will draw on 5.4 million people within a 15-mile radius, because he has a waiting list of corporate customers for advertising signs, promotional nights and sky boxes.
Riverfront Park has incorporated some of the city's baseball lore into the design. For example, a bleacher section that Hallmark, a real estate company, has subsidized as seating for youth groups from around the city has been called the "Knothole Gang" after the children who used to peer through the holes drilled in the wooden fence that lined the left field of Ruppert Stadium.
But for all the nostalgia the stadium may evoke, there is no guarantee that it will be an economic home run. Andrew Zimbalist, an economist at Smith College in Northampton, Mass., who specializes in the sports business, said public investments in stadiums, even in well-heeled major league sites, often falter.
For one thing, he said, a stadium winds up taking entertainment dollars that had been going to locally owned bowling alleys, restaurants and movie theaters. Mr. Zimbalist said stadiums also involve maintenance, sanitation and security costs that, along with the debt service, can mean "a negative bottom line year after year."
"But the real risk is the independent minor league, where more of the teams fail than succeed," he said. "Plus there are six other independent minor league teams in New Jersey, some from different leagues, pulling on their market share."
The Bears are part of a boomlet in minor league baseball. They belong to the independent, six-team Atlantic League, one of the current crop of five independent minor leagues nationwide with a total of 48 teams.
Miles Wolf, founder and commissioner of the Northern League, and president of the company that publishes the minor league trade magazine Baseball America, said that major league baseball enjoyed a resurgence in the 1980's with the construction of new stadiums as economic development vehicles for many cities, including Baltimore and Cleveland.
The desire for new-stadium buzz filtered down to the 160 cities that were homes to the minor league farm teams that are affiliated with major league teams. As a result, he said, in the last decade 80 new minor league stadiums have been built around the country.
But Mr. Wolf said that there are more cities interested in minor league baseball than there are major league-affiliated farm teams. Since 1993, he said, 14 leagues have been started with a total of 66 teams. But Mr. Wolf noted that those numbers have been winnowed by mergers and the tough economics of baseball in small cities.
Mr. Wolf said that he hoped Newark's team would not suffer because of the cost of the stadium. "This is far and away the most expensive minor league stadium, major league-affiliated or unaffiliated," he said. "It is too expensive and certainly sets a new standard for a 6,000-seat stadium that shouldn't be more than $19 million, not counting land."
Still, the stadium's backers say its prospects look good. On a recent day, a smiling Mr. Cerone was visited by people seeking autographs and business people seeking to discuss deals. Among them was a group from NorCrown Bank, which has just six branches in Livingston and South Orange. The bank is trying to decide whether the stadium will be the site of its first stand-alone A.T.M.
"We think a lot of people from Essex County will come this way, and from an advertising point of view, a corporate presence here for us will be significant and good advertising," said Monte Ehrenkranz, vice president and branch coordinator. "We just have to decide whether it's worth the investment."

HEADLINE: Son Is Accused of Killing His Father And 2d Man in Their Hospital Room

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
A 49-year-old man calmly walked into a Brooklyn hospital yesterday with a knife and a hammer in a bag slung over his back, then killed his ailing father by slashing his throat, beat another patient to death with a hammer and seriously wounded his sister before he was subdued by security guards, law enforcement officials said.
The suspect, Joseph Raineri Jr., was charged yesterday with murder and attempted murder, the police said. Mr. Raineri had no known history of mental illness, the police said, and only a minor police record -- nothing that would have presaged the attack at Victory Memorial Hospital in Dyker Heights shortly afternoon. 
 His father, Joseph Raineri Sr., 74, died soon afterward. The other patient in the room, 88-year-old Michael D'ambrose, died about 6:40 P.M. at Lutheran Hospital. The police said that the suspect's sister, Linda Raineri, 46, who was visiting, was in critical condition at Victory last night with gashes to her throat.
Security guards and nurses in the fifth-floor ward heard screams from the victims and quickly broadcast an alert. Arlen Fishler, who was visiting her own father on the third floor, said a frantic voice called over the intercom for security and emergency workers. "Then someone announced that all visitors should go to the main lobby," Ms. Fishler said.
Deputy Chief Thomas Green of the Police Department's Detective Bureau said investigators did not believe there was any argument before the attack that might have alerted hospital security earlier. A hospital administrator who would not give her name refused to comment on security measures at Victory, where, as in many other hospitals, visitors come and go relatively freely.
According to the police, Mr. Raineri calmly walked into the hospital shortly before noon and went to his father's room on the fifth floor.
Linda Raineri was already there with her teen-age daughter, Christina, the police said. The Raineris all lived together in a nearby apartment, on 64th Street in Dyker Heights.
Mr. Raineri apparently said little after reaching the room and seeing his family huddled, the police said. He put down his bag and calmly pulled out a large knife, then grabbed his father and cut his throat, the police said. He then turned the knife on his sister, cutting several gashes in her throat, the police said. He then pulled out a hammer and beat Mr. D'ambrose, the police added.
A law enforcement official said several nurses and security guards were also wounded as they struggled to subdue the suspect as he swung his hammer.
Hospital administrators expressed their sorrow yesterday during a news conference at the hospital, saying they had never before experienced such violence in their building.
"We appreciate how swiftly the nursing and security staff acted in possibly stopping other deaths or injuries," said William Recevuto, the assistant hospital administrator. "This is a tragedy, but it could have been much worse."
There is little to indicate a serious problem in the Raineri family before the attacks.
Over the past 10 years, the family lived quietly in their second-floor apartment on 64th Street. Joseph Raineri Sr. was a former farm worker on Long Island who was once employed at a store in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn before retiring because of heart problems, said Czeslaw Zaranek, the building superintendent.
He said Joseph Raineri Jr. drove a taxi cab, and Linda Raineri was unemployed.
According to the police, Joseph Raineri Jr.'s only trouble with the law was more than a decade ago, when he was convicted twice in separate incidents, once for leaving the scene of an accident and once for a misdemeanor assault.
But neighbors said they were struck by his unfriendliness when they greeted him.
"He's a very strange man," Mr. Zaranek said. "He would close his door as soon as I would come by. He would never look anyone in the face.
"He's known me for years. I've done repairs in their house. But he never says hello."
Neighbors recalled his father as just the opposite, a man of smiles who doted on his granddaughter and sometimes walked her to school.
"I just can't believe what happened, because the grandfather was such a nice man," said Irene Bodolato, 65, who lives one floor above the family. "I guess that son just went berserk."
The news of the attack hit hard around Mr. D'ambrose's house on 67th Street, near the Raineris' apartment. Neighbors recalled that Mr. D'ambrose had remained active until the last year or so, when he had fallen into ill health, and had been in and out of the hospital. Until his 85th birthday, Mr. D'ambrose was still able to drive his car and get whatever he needed. As a younger man of 70 or so, he was active in the community, holding parties for the neighborhood children during the summer and urging them to seek his help with homework should they need it.
"He's a good guy, a real good neighbor who always helps out," said Mario Saporano, 20, as he watched Mr. D'ambrose's extended family gather in grief next door. "He and his wife, Dotty, treated us like we were their own kids."
