HEADLINE: Schools Scramble To Find More Space;
Bulge From the Baby Boom Emerges in Closets and Trailers

BYLINE: By DEBRA GALANT 

 BODY:
BLAME it, if you like, on Pearl Harbor.
After all, if it were not for World War II, there might never have been the postwar demographic bulge called the baby boom, which has produced a baby boom of its own. 
 Or blame it on the developers, who have bulldozed New Jersey farms and replaced them with tract houses.
Or on the Federal Government, which has raised immigration quotas to levels approaching those of the late 19th century.
Or on older people, who are leaving the towns where they raised their families for gated golf communities and selling their homes to families bursting with children.
You can even blame it on fertility medicine, which has made it possible, even customary, for women to bear children well into their 40's, and which accounts for all those sets of twins -- 59 sets in Montgomery Township alone -- in the schools.
But whomever or whatever you blame it on, this much is clear. Classrooms in New Jersey -- and the rest of the country for that matter -- are filling up. Fast.
How fast, however, is a matter of debate. Although it's clear that the schools that emptied out between the mid-1970's and early 1990's are filling up again, some communities have been hit harder than others. "How do you know when this cycle is going to end?" asks Martin Feitlowitz, a school architect and demographer. "You don't. All you know is who's in the system now. Going out 10 years, you're going out on a limb. You're talking about kids who haven't been born yet."
The good news is that the current baby boom -- called the baby boom echo by demographers -- is not as big as the last one, which caused classrooms to overflow 30 years ago.
The number of schoolchildren in New Jersey peaked at about 1.58 million children in the 1972-73 school year, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers. After falling to a low of 1.08 million in 1989-90, it is now 1.27 million and growing. Dr. Hughes thinks New Jersey school enrollment could peak at about 1.4 million around 2002-3, and then hover near that level for years.
This new baby boom is smaller than the first because, while lots of boomers are having children, they are having fewer than their parents did. At the peak of the baby boom, in 1957, the average woman produced 3.7 children, Dr. Hughes said. At the trough of the baby bust, in 1976, the average woman produced 1.7. Currently the birth rate hangs at 2.0 -- undramatic, except that it is two children for each woman in the biggest generation in American history.
And demographers can only guess about the behavior of the baby bust generation, which follows the boomers. Now in their 20's and 30's, baby busters are becoming parents themselves, and their behavior will determine whether the torrent of schoolchildren lets up.
Whatever the future, there's the real fact that schools in New Jersey now have to deal with almost 200,000 more students than a decade ago -- an increase of 18 percent.
The adjustment is not easy. For one thing, the stock of buildings has declined since the first baby boom; many districts sold schools in the late 1970's and early 1980's as their enrollments started to thin. And many of the buildings that remain are vastly out of date and literally crumbling, particularly in urban districts, which are filled with schools built to handle the waves of immigration in the 1910's and 1920's.
Even relatively modern schools -- those built to accommodate the original baby boomers -- are seriously outmoded. Dr. Hughes, who grew up in Elizabeth, remembers being acutely jealous of students in the suburbs. "Those new school buildings, one-story, modern aluminum buildings with pastel panels: they looked like paradise to me," he said. But as a grown-up planner, he sees that they seriously fell short, especially in terms of energy efficiency and adaptability for computers in the classroom.
Building new schools has become a lot more expensive, not just because of inflation or the need for fiber optic cables for computers, but because of state requirements about everything from ventilation to ceiling heights in gyms. Mr. Feitlowitz, who has been designing schools in New Jersey for 30 years, said the typical school of the late 1960's could be built for $25 to $30 a square foot. Today it costs $140 to $150 a square foot.
Everybody agrees that it is going to be expensive to renovate old schools or build new ones -- but nobody agrees on how expensive. The Whitman administration has proposed that $6 billion be spent on school construction statewide -- with $4 billion coming from the state and $2 billion from local districts. "Six billion is admittedly an estimate," said the State Treasurer, James A. D'Eleuterio. "But it's a very, very significant commitment by the state."
The New Jersey School Boards Association, however, is worried that the $6 billion far underestimates the need for school construction. And things are complicated by the fact the state is committed, by court order, to finance 100 percent of the construction needs of the 28 poorest school districts, known as the Abbott districts. Estimates for just rebuilding the Abbotts start at $2.6 billion. Where does that leave the state's remaining 583 districts?
R. Thomas Jannarone, consultant for urban affairs for the New Jersey School Administrators Association, points out that many suburban districts -- squeezed by rising enrollments and voter reluctance to raise taxes -- now face serious financial problems. "The irony," he said, "is that's the same situation the urbans were in 20 years ago."
If it is hard to wrap your mind around populations in the millions, it ismuch easier to look at individual districts, or schools. Here is the statistic local school boards like to use when they're trying to convince voters that the baby boom echo is real: look at the number of graduating seniors (who represent the very tail end of the baby bust), and compare that with the size of the kindergarten classes that are replacing them.
The situation is most dramatic in districts where there has been a lot of new housing construction, like Montgomery Township, north of Princeton, or Evesham, near Cherry Hill. More than 1,700 new dwellings were occupied in Montgomery from 1990 through 1997, according to a report by Sara K. Weissman, a consultant on demographic issues for school districts. So it is hardly surprising that in June 1997, Montgomery graduated 120 seniors and the next September replaced them with 240 kindergartners. The district has spent $45 million on school expansion since 1994, and is going to voters again in December for $60 million more to build a new high school.
But even in mature districts with little room to build new houses, monster kindergarten classes are replacing small senior classes. In Millburn, 189 seniors graduated last year and 331 kindergartners replaced them. Glen Ridge graduated 65 seniors last week, and will have 127 pre-kindergarten children enter the system in September. Statewide, the pattern also holds true. In 1997, there were 66,642 seniors and 92,170 kindergartners. And as the schools digest these big chunks of kids -- think of a rabbit moving through a python -- the overcrowding problem simply moves from elementary schools, into middle schools, and up to the high schools.
The mystery is how there could be such sizable jumps of enrollment in places like Glen Ridge, where there is no new housing construction. Mr. Feitlowitz, who has done studies for Millburn, Glen Ridge and West Orange, offered this answer: "Families with young children moving in with young children, and empty nesters moving out."
"New homes are not the enrollment driver," Mrs. Weissman agreed. "They're just the visible one."
All school lunchrooms are noisy, but the one at Edison Middle School in West Orange sometimes exceeds 80 decibels: noisier than heavy street traffic, quieter than a pneumatic drill. It is loud enough to require the school's assistant principal to stand in front of the room with a microphone to call tables up to the lunch line. By the time all 170 sixth graders move through, there will only be a few minutes left to eat that lunch.
Five years ago, there would have just been 120 students in the cafeteria. Next year, the sixth grade class is expected to top 200, so they will have to eat in two shifts, shortening the lunch "hour" to 20 minutes.
And that is just one sign of overcrowding at this middle-class, racially mixed Essex County school, built in 1928. Small, windowless rooms originally designed as closets now hold students and staff. The school's child study team is housed in the former closet for audio-visual equipment. Eight special education students meet after lunch in another former closet, 12 by 20 feet, where theater costumes were once stored. There is no separate room for the school orchestra, which meets in the cafeteria. The library is also used as classroom several periods a day.
Squeezing a regular classroom into the corner of a library is a standard measure for overcrowded schools. It is done in Montgomery, which was a rural farming community until the early 1990's, "when things began to pop," according to Dr. Jamie Savedoff, the superintendent. The school's population has ballooned to 3,200 students from 1,500 in 1993, and it is projected to reach 6,000 by 2008. "Every space within our schools is being used," Dr. Savedoff said. "Teachers' rooms have been turned into classrooms. Small rooms have been converted into classrooms. Auxiliary rooms, which we used to use for library, are turned into classrooms. We've given up art and music rooms. We've put them on carts."
Dr. Savedoff said class sizes had grown too, running as high as 38 in the high school and 30 in the elementary school, although those respective numbers are now down to 32 and 25 with the recent school expansions. "We've been fortunate in that we haven't had to bring trailers in yet," he said.
But he said trailers might be a possibility if Montgomery's $60 million referendum doesn't pass in December.
"People understand," he said. "It's a very pro-education community. People know that you can't put two quarts of water into a one-quart jar. On the other hand, you get into the emotional discussion of when is it going to stop already?" Dr. Savedoff knows that to win this referendum, he must get out there and really sell. Voters in Montgomery turned down a $14 million bond referendum in April 1998.
In Evesham, a growing suburb near Cherry Hill, trailers have already been brought in. Two went in front of one elementary school; one trailer went in front of another. Superintendent John Bigley said trailers were not put in front, as some people think, to persuade voters to approve more school spending, but because it would have been more costly to run sewer and electric lines for trailers behind the schools.
Still, such a visible sign of overcrowding may have helped the district win a $34 million referendum last December, after two other ballot measures -- for smaller amounts -- failed the previous year. "The reality was that we weren't bluffing," Mr. Bigley said. He credited the victory to a large community task force to study enrollment growth, which involved older citizens and other opponents of the original two referendums.
Jerry Tarnoff, the superintendent in West Orange, has not been as fortunate. He has seen three referendums go down since 1995. "What is a district supposed to do?" he asked.
What a district like West Orange has to do -- and in fact did do -- is find a way around the voters. This summer, it will begin some renovations and additions under a $9 million lease-purchase plan. Lease-purchase is a provision that allows districts to apply to the state to raise money (the costs are still borne by property owners) after referendums are repeatedly defeated. But the $9 million lease-purchase construction program is a far cry from the $55 million the district asked from its voters for in 1995. "It becomes a stopgap measure," Mr. Tarnoff said. "I wouldn't want anybody to think that this is going to be the answer."
The pessimistic Thomas Robert Malthus, who wrote his famous "Essay on the Principle of Population" in 1798, would probably cross his arms in smug satisfaction at the way his theories have played out in 20th-century suburban New Jersey. He postulated that populations spiral out of control until checked by famine, pestilence or war. In the modern version of things, however, overcrowded schools and high property taxes, rather than outright scourges, put a check on growth.
Some argue, however, that -- with appropriate planning -- it does not have to be that way. Richard Gulick is the planning director for the town of Randolph, a former bungalow community in Morris County that began to suburbanize in the 1960's. In the mid-1990's, Randolph adopted a "community impact statement" ordinance, requiring builders to determine how their proposed housing developments would affect schools, roads and other services.
"What communities didn't realize was that residential ratables are not good ratables because of the cost to educate a child," Mr. Gulick said. "The cost of education is a back-breaker."
William Dressel, executive director of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, has been lobbying Trenton to allow communities to assess developers to help pay for the added infrastructure -- including schools -- that new developments require. "We're finding that for every dollar of tax revenues received on a residential development, the municipality has to spend $1.67 for services."
As schools struggle with the population rabbit moving through the python, they are increasingly redefining how schools are organized. Educationally, the K-5 elementary school, the 6-8 middle school and the 9-12 high school is the most popular model, and some say the most developmentally sound.
But Livingston, for example, plans to turn one of its middle schools into a stand-alone sixth grade school. Montgomery plans quite a different school configuration for 2003, if its December referendum passes. It would have five educational levels: a K-1 elementary school, a 2-4 elementary, a 5-6 upper elementary, a 7-8 middle school and a 9-12 high school.
Some wonder if this grade-level engineering may be an untested social experiment with unforeseen consequences. A parent and school board member in a growing Somerset County town, who asked not to be identified because the debate had so divided her town, pointed out that while "grade-level centers" sound like ideal groupings, they also break up continuity in a school. Instead of just 40 to 60 new students entering a school in the fall, as would happen in a typical neighborhood elementary school, a school composed of just two grades might have 200 or more new students each year.
"How could a principal who sees 250 kids come into their school possibly get to know those kids?" she asked. "They're coming in one year, they're exiting the next year. Where is the continuity?"
Mr. Gulick, who emphasized that he was speaking for himself rather than the town of Randolph, is also troubled by the social implications of school overcrowding. After the shooting spree in Littleton, Colo., he began to worry about schools growing so fast that principals simply cannot keep track of all the students "The educational system is a very sensitive area," he said. "From a planning perspective, we've been paying so much attention to our environmental issues in the past 20 years that we've forgotten about our social issues."

HEADLINE: Op-Art;
What It Looks Like in America

 BODY:
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos:
Utica, N.Y., was always a place for people from somewhere else. The Germans, Irish and Poles came over, looking for work and finding it in the mills along the Mohawk River. Today the mills are gone and Utica itself is much poorer, its population fallen to 64,000 from 125,000 since 1960. But the currency of hope is still good here. By welcoming more recent waves of immigrants, many of them refugees of war, Utica has gotten in return the new energy sources so vital to economic and civic life. First it was the Amerasians of Vietnam, then the Russians and, in this decade, about 3,000 Bosnians. The Bosnians in particular "pick up on the American entrepreneurial spirit very quickly," opening businesses and buying rundown homes, said Richard Sessler, director of the Mohawk Valley Resource Center for Refugees. The Op-Ed Page asked some of the Russians and Bosnians to photograph scenes that reflect what America means to them. From churches to mall parking lots, from the freedom of the open road to the security of the neighborhood to an old B-52, these are the scenes that stir the soul on July Fourth.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Serving Up Hearty Meals of Information on Wheels

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL

 BODY:
Charlene A. Patterson, 19, can rattle off a list of attractions in upper Manhattan the way other college students might list their favorite ballplayers: the Yeshiva Museum, the African-American Wax Museum, the Morris-Jumel Mansion, the Studio Museum. But even though she grew up in Harlem, Ms. Patterson had not heard of most of these places until a few weeks ago. "To tell the truth, I've lived here all my life and really didn't know there were this many things in the community," she said.
But anyone stopping by her visitors' cart at Broadway and 165th Street, near the Audubon cultural center, might find her wealth of information staggering. 
 "You'd be surprised how many people don't know what's in their own community," she said. "We try to tell them there's a museum right here 10 blocks away from you, and you don't need to go all the way downtown to experience the arts."
The information cart she tends is one of four that were placed in strategic locations in upper Manhattan last week as part of a new effort to promote tourism and economic development. Sponsored by the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, the Union Settlement Association and the Manhattan Borough President's office, the program, called Uptown Ambassadors, involved training and paying 10 college students from Harlem, East Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood to help tourists and residents navigate their neighborhoods.
"Tourism has the potential to have a significant economic impact on upper Manhattan's communities," said Rodney E. Lopez, director of communications for the empowerment zone. "So this initiative is designed to make sure that this important information about the area's historic sites and attractions is available to whomever wants it."
At each of the four carts -- at Audubon, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, Adam Clayton Powell Boulevard and 125th Street, and Dyckman and 200th Streets -- one English- and one Spanish-speaking student at any time provide brochures from cultural institutions, menus for local restaurants, notices about events at bars and clubs and information about historic sites. The students are paid $8 an hour.
Uptown Ambassadors is the start of a larger effortplanned for this fall by the empowerment zone called the Upper Manhattan Visitor Network. The carts, which cost about $16,000 each, were bought by the Manhattan Borough President's office. The entire Uptown Ambassador project cost slightly more than $100,000.
Mirianna Pisano, Union Settlement's program director for Uptown Ambassadors, said about 150 people visited the carts each day since the program began on Tuesday. "People came despite the rain," she said.
 NINA SIEGAL

HEADLINE: DATABANK: June 28 through July2;
In Market After Market, a Summer Rally

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE

 BODY:
Records dropped like flies in the hot summer sun last week.
 On Wednesday, investors in Japan pushed the Nikkei 225 index to a new high for the year, bolstered by data that suggested a recovery was under way. 
 In Seoul, a rally on Thursday in response to the Federal Reserve's change in bias on American interest rates spilled over to Friday, as the Korea composite index crossed into record territory.
 Also on Friday, the Hang Seng index reached its highest level since Oct. 9, 1997, and had its biggest one-day gain in three months. Malaysia's composite index reached its highest level since September 1997. The Straits Times index in Singapore hit a record. And the Xetra DAX in Frankfurt closed at a high for this year.
 In the United States, the Dow industrials, at 11,139.24, and the Nasdaq, at 2,741.02, surpassed previous highs, marking the best week for stocks since last October.
 Giddy investors may see the makings of an extended rally. We felt we'd see a summer rally in stocks up to 11,500 on the Dow, so we're more than halfway home, Philip Orlando, chief investment officer for Value Line Asset Management, told Bloomberg News. MICKEY MEECE

SECTION: Section 7; Page 8; Column 1; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Consider the Sources

BYLINE: By James B. Stewart; James B. Stewart is the author of "Blood Sport: The President and His Adversaries." His latest book, "Blind Eye," will be published in September.

 BODY:

Warp Speed
 America in the Age of Mixed Media.
 By Bill Kovach and Tom Rosenstiel.
 193 pp. New York:
 The Century Foundation Press. $24.95. 
 In his preface to "Warp Speed: America in the Age of Mixed Media," David Halberstam asserts that "the past year has been, I think, the worst year for American journalism since I entered the profession 44 years ago." He is speaking, it goes without saying, of the press's coverage of Bill Clinton and Monica Lewinsky.
This is the subject of "Warp Speed," a book far more focused and provocative than its lofty subtitle might suggest. Bill Kovach, the curator of the Nieman Foundation for Journalism and a former editor of The Atlanta Journal and Constitution, and Tom Rosenstiel, the director of the Project for Excellence in Journalism, use the Lewinsky scandal as a prism to disperse light on the American press. The results are cold-eyed and unsparing. The authors conclude that in the current "mixed-media culture," "a true and reliable account of the day's events" has been undermined and displaced by whatever passes for "continuous news." Power has shifted from reporters to sources whose agendas are often hidden. Argument and opinion, the more strident the better, have supplanted information. And there is a fixation on "the big story" that will deliver a large audience and ratings, with O. J. Simpson as the model.
These conclusions flow from several detailed accounts of specific stories that defined the Lewinsky coverage, starting with the sensational story of the semen-stained blue dress, as good an example as any to illustrate what the mixed-media culture has wrought. It seems fair to say that the public and the news media alike greeted the revelation of the dress with horrified fascination. More than any other single story, it seemed to define the depths to which we had collectively descended as a politically motivated sexual harassment case filed against a reckless President moved from the courts to an independent counsel to Congress.
The existence of a semen-stained dress was first reported on Jan. 21, 1998 (the same day the Lewinsky story broke in The Washington Post), in the Drudge Report, written by Matt Drudge, whom the authors describe as a "professional Internet gossip." Drudge wrote that Linda Tripp had "shared with investigators" the information that Lewinsky had saved a garment with the President's semen on it. It was the Drudge Report that had pushed the Lewinsky story into The Washington Post in the first place, and Drudge embodies much of what Kovach and Rosenstiel lament about the current media culture. Drudge is often wrong but often right; he makes no pretense of filtering information on grounds of taste, relevance or accuracy, and he is fast. A person like Drudge, armed with the technology of the Internet, surely marks a new stage in the democratization of the news media. He is the new gatekeeper.
The next day, Jackie Judd of ABC News reported that Lewinsky had kept a blue dress stained with the President's semen as a "kind of souvenir." Judd based her report on a single anonymous source other than Drudge, who in turn had relied on one or more anonymous sources. Hearsay sources didn't stop many other news organizations. Indeed, 18 percent of the news reports the next day attributed the information solely to another news organization, in this case ABC. Sam Donaldson proclaimed that if Clinton was not telling the truth, "I think his Presidency is numbered in days." Many talk show hosts wallowed gleefully in the unsavory details.
The day after that, Lewinsky's lawyer, William Ginsburg, seemed to deny the story on the record, which brought it fully into the mainstream news media, although this time in the context that it was false. The F.B.I., it was reported, had found no such dress. Speculation abounded that the anonymous source for the blue-dress story, as she was for much of the Lewinsky saga, was Lucianne Goldberg, a confidante of Linda Tripp and avowed critic of President Clinton. The press turned against itself, castigating the decline of standards. As Russell Baker wrote in The New York Times, "Has there ever been a more disgusting media meltdown?" The Committee of Concerned Journalists concluded that the blue-dress story might be a "textbook example of consider the source." Much of the criticism was premised on the notion that the story was wrong.
But it wasn't. It was indisputably relevant and proved to be pivotal evidence in the case against the President. Is it any wonder the blue-dress story left the public angry and confused?
Kovach and Rosenstiel found that contrary to White House claims, "the press usually relied on legitimate sources and often was careful about the facts in the first account," as turned out to be the case with ABC and the dress. The key words here are "first account." For "others then used the reporting from elsewhere to engage in sometimes reckless speculation and propaganda." Predictions that Clinton's days as President were numbered were flatly wrong. So were numerous attacks on ABC for inaccurate reporting.
The increase in opinion, speculation and argument documented by the authors in the American press, especially on television and radio, seems incontrovertible. They rightly note that this kind of programming serves more as entertainment than information and is cheap to produce and disseminate in nearly limitless quantity. News, by contrast, is expensive, especially the kind of investigative reporting called for in the Lewinsky scandal, and in scant supply. This trend seems especially troubling when the lines blur and when the public may be misled, as when Sam Donaldson predicts the President's imminent demise, or the Newsweek reporter Michael Isikoff appears on MSNBC as a paid pundit, or George Stephanopoulos suddenly metamorphoses into a television journalist.
The authors conclude that reporters are relying ever more heavily on anonymous sources, and that they are failing to characterize the possible biases of such sources. "The press should be exercising more caution about anonymity today. Instead, it is exhibiting less," they assert. Still, they acknowledge that the issue of anonymous sources is complicated. After all, in the blue-dress episode, the anonymous source turned out to be correct, and Ginsburg, the on-the-record source, was wrong. The cost of relying only on on-the-record sources would be the loss of a tremendous amount of news, much of it far more accurate and important than the pablum delivered in press releases and on-the-record news conferences. The two-source rule championed by The Washington Post in the Watergate era -- or any other hard and fast rule of that nature -- has always struck me as nonsense. Far more important than the number of sources is their identity. At one point The New York Times had four hearsay sources asserting there was a witness to an intimate encounter between Clinton and Lewinsky, but the paper said it killed the article because it wasn't sure of the facts.
At the same time, it is a truism that more sources are always better, and relying on a single source requires a degree of caution that is in scant evidence at many organizations or even, in the case of a Drudge, nonexistent. Exercising judgment is all the more difficult given the speed with which an undifferentiated mix of rumor, gossip, innuendo and fact appears on the Internet, putting pressure on news organizations to respond or risk getting scooped.
While this short book can only touch on the issue, the authors also lament the degree to which journalists have come to be seen as participants in the culture wars rather than neutral and dispassionate observers. They found a consistent pro-prosecution bias in the Lewinsky coverage, a voracious appetite for conflict and scandal and a zeal for policing the sex lives of political candidates that alienated the public. If polls (as opposed to ratings) can be believed, the coverage of the Lewinsky affair was highly unpopular. Two weeks after the story broke, a majority of people surveyed said they thought "the best thing for the nation" would be to "drop the matter."
In "Warp Speed," Kovach and Rosenstiel have written a fascinating deconstruction of specific stories and rendered a public service to journalism. Their solution for the plight they describe is for news organizations to set standards, communicate them to reporters and the editorial staff and then reach a covenant with consumers that those standards will be maintained. A good first step would be for reporters to do their own work rather than recycling others' reports. How likely are these precepts to be followed? Not very. At the upper ranks of the profession, they will no doubt be welcomed. But elsewhere, they fly in the face of the broader economic, social and technological forces the authors so convincingly document.

HEADLINE: Harlem Gallery Is a Child's Haven

BYLINE: By ESTELLA DURAN 

 BODY:
Nine-year-old Kayon Hicks was blissfully skipping rope with a telephone wire on a Harlem sidewalk the other day and giggling with her friends. But when she walked into Gallery M she was in a different world. Here, she said, she feels like a queen among the queens she sees in the art on the walls.
Jazz music played as she twirled a white lace parasol and quietly studied the figures, from strong African women to hopeful little girls like herself. 
 "I love this place," she said. "It has a lot of joy."
Gallery M is opening the door to a wide world of art for Kayon and other neighborhood children who have adopted it as a hangout. The small gallery, at 123 West 135th Street, around the corner from the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, showcases works by artists who are or have been homeless as well as by mainstream artists and children.
"I really love to see the kids so excited about art," said the gallery manager, Edie Lynch. "They've been coming in here and doing their homework after school or visiting on the weekends, and I've been helping them draw pictures of their own."
The four-year-old gallery, run by Weston United Community Renewal Inc., was originally founded to exhibit the art made by people in the group's residences for the homeless and in rehabilitation centers. It started including pieces by mainstream artists and even a neighborhood child with its most recent exhibition, which runs through July 15.
The gallery was host to a tea party fund-raiser on Saturday to help buy Kayon a $150 artwork she has been longing for, "Little Girl Looking Out a Heart-Shaped Moon," a shadow box by Jimmie Smith, a professional artist. Kayon and her sister, LaKeshia, 10, have been doing chores like polishing display cases at the gallery to earn money to put the piece up in their bedroom.
"The girls were never really interested in art before, so it's nice to know they're going into the gallery and learning," said Sheila Hicks, their mother.
The mixed-media shadow box is one of a series Mr. Smith made featuring his girlfriend's 10-year-old daughter, Jaycee, looking out a window at fantastic scenes that are in stark contrast to the real view outside her window: a junkyard.
Mr. Smith's works are a hit with the children who visit Gallery M, as are the gallery's baskets of jazz CD's and children's books. Other popular items include watercolor portraits by 10-year-old Danielle West, who lives nearby.
"This little girl just came knocking on our door one rainy day before our exhibit opening," Ms. Lynch said. "And she said: 'Please let me in. I'm an artist.'
"We saw her portraits, and she was good. So we included her in the show."
The children also enjoy works in the gallery like the striking oil paintings of slave women in the series "Endurance of the Spirit Women" by Lloyd Stevens, an art director for The New York Times; portraits of entertainers by James Jenkins, who is living in one of the Weston United residences, and jewelry by Gennady Osmerkin.
Herb Boyd, who took his history of Harlem class from the College of New Rochelle to the studio on a neighborhood tour, said he was happy to witness the children's delight.
Mr. Boyd said that although the gallery is fairly new, the children's interest in it shows it is an asset to the community.
"It's great to see the kids in here, because the kids will grow with the gallery," he said. "They will come to value and understand the importance of art. And when they're older, they will do their best to promote and preserve art."

LENGTH: 1614 words

HEADLINE: The Dominant Position of the Gartner Group

SERIES: COUNTING TO 2000: The Prognosticators

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
How much will the battle to tame Year 2000 computer problems cost? When will computer malfunctions hit? Which countries or industries are furthest along -- or furthest behind -- in dealing with the Year 2000 challenge?
One name comes up repeatedly when such questions are posed: Gartner Group Inc. From Congressional hearings to corporate board rooms, Year 2000 progress reports and risk assessments often begin, and sometimes end, with Gartner's research. The consulting firm's thousands of information-technology clients include not just the business elite but foreign governments ranging from economic powers like Japan to the sorely distressed like Russia and Indonesia. 
 That gives the use of Gartner's Year 2000 projections the same cachet that went with corporate decisions to buy I.B.M. computers in the 1960's, even though many Year 2000 experts say Gartner's research process raises as many questions as it answers.
Gartner's Year 2000 star rose rapidly after a 1996 Congressional hearing when it suggested that American companies might spend as much as $600 billion finding and dealing with end-of-century computer flaws, making it the first prominent information-technology firm to put a hard, eye-opening number on the problem in a public forum. The resulting publicity encouraged the firm, based in Stamford, Conn., to expand its research on the subject; today, its rankings and data permeate Year 2000 print and broadcast reports.
"If I took Ronald McDonald and put a Gartner suit on him, he'd be interviewed by all the big media outlets for Y2K expertise," said William Ulrich, a consultant based in Soquel, Calif., using the popular shorthand for Year 2000 issues.
The most prominent figure in the Gartner suit on a given day is often Louis Marcoccio, the company's director of Year 2000 research. A 52-year-old computer management veteran with an M.B.A., a law degree and teaching credentials to go along with three engineering degrees, Mr. Marcoccio's life is a whirl of speeches at Year 2000 conferences, private consultations with Gartner clients, and interviews.
He talks to scores of journalists each week, often for foreign audiences. One recent week included television broadcasts in Japan and Israel and a radio program in Iceland.
"I've had requests to be in movies, and a Canadian rock group wanted to dub me over one of their songs," Mr. Marcoccio said, smiling with a mixture of amusement and dismay at the idea that Year 2000 mania could bring a conservatively attired consultant such brushes with celebrity.
For all the attention, though, Year 2000 issues are such a small part of Gartner's overall consulting business that it is almost irrelevant to investors, according to analysts who follow the company.
Gartner says the sale of Year 2000 research and advice will bring in less than $8 million of the $750 million in total revenue that Wall Street is projecting this year. The eight full-time Year 2000 analysts represent just 1 percent of the 800 information-technology specialists working for Gartner worldwide. Most clients get the research at bargain rates as an addition to other research services.
Gartner's stock is down 37 percent in the last 12 months, compared with a 13 percent climb in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. It has lagged behind the market's rise because of concerns about the growth prospects of the rest of the business and, more recently, about a complicated financial restructuring and stock buyback plan scheduled during the summer.
But however puny from the perspective of the balance sheet, Gartner's Year 2000 effort speaks to giant fears about the inability of some computers, programs and electronic devices to handle dates after Jan. 1, 2000.
Gartner had been advising clients since the late 1980's to get to work on Year 2000 issues, though it was not until 1993 that it tried to analyze the extent of the potential problem.
Company officials said they were startled when the analyst they hired, Kevin Schick, came up with a cost estimate of $300 billion to $600 billion. Mr. Schick, who left Gartner in 1996 and later founded Enterprise Solution Partners, an Internet publisher in Chicago, said he had simply put together Gartner estimates of the lines of computer code in use with data on the average cost of hiring outside programmers to repair faulty mainframe computer software.
It later became apparent that lines of code was too crude a measurement to accurately project a company's Year 2000 costs. In addition, computer users surprised Gartner and most other experts by doing most of their repairs internally instead of hiring outside contractors, which cut their reported costs.
"There's no way spending could get to the upper limits they calculated," said Thomas Oleson, head of Year 2000 research for the International Data Corporation.
Nonetheless, the Gartner estimate has never completely yielded the spotlight that it gained in the 1996 Congressional testimony, in part because its scope was changed. Today it is used as a worldwide figure, not, as Mr. Schick had calculated, the cost for the United States alone, and it includes expenses overlooked in the original estimate, like testing. Later, more cautious projections, like Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's recent estimate that the information technology bill in the United States would be less than $86 billion, still attract far less notice.
"When you are first, and you are recognized as a big provider of data, you are going to catch people's attention," said James Woodward, head of the Year 2000 practice for CAP Gemini America in New York, a consulting and software repair firm that has sponsored independent research on Year 2000 programs at big companies.
Gartner's influence also rests in part on its business strategy. Because it is known for selling assessments and visions of where technology is going rather than particular products, many computer users see it as an independent voice with no ax to grind, like Consumer Reports looking at television sets or autos.
Several smaller competitors, like Giga Information, Jupiter and Forrester Research, offer similar independence but lack Gartner's global reach and huge stable of big-name clients. Gartner, which was founded in 1979, has 9,100 corporate and government clients.
But Gartner, like other Year 2000 researchers, relies heavily even today on unverifiable reports by computer users of their plans and progress in dealing with these problems. Ideally, data would come from much more thorough investigation.
"It takes two or three weeks of a consultant's time to find out where a large company really is on Y2K," said Bruce Hall, who was Mr. Marcoccio's predecessor at Gartner and is now vice president at Trigent Software, a company in Southborough, Mass., that uses offshore programmers to help companies do Year 2000 repairs and other software projects.
Still, Gartner's research extends far deeper than the written questionnaires that many others rely on.
The basis for many of its rankings now, according to Mr. Marcoccio, is quarterly polling of 15,000 companies in 31 nations by 11 universities that do the work in exchange for free consulting services. The companies are asked 330 questions in long phone interviews, considered more reliable than written questionnaires.
The results are then cross-checked against a variety of public and private reports and made available to other Gartner analysts for review.
Gartner does not disclose the rankings of individual companies, but private clients can get breakdowns of how different industries are doing, country by country, and in comparison with clusters of clients that the Gartner Group views as leaders.
"Gartner's methodology leaves something to be desired, but it's as good as it gets," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Bank Securities in New York. "At the end of the day, they are the only game in town when it comes to global assessments."
Not really. For global assessments and many other Year 2000 measures, multinational companies and industry groups have recently put together private research efforts that have better or more recent information than Gartner.
Many large banks and other financial institutions, for instance, take part in Global 2000, which has a 22-member committee headed by James Devlin of Citibank that updates country assessments every three weeks.
"We became more positive on Japan and Germany well ahead of Gartner," Mr. Devlin said, citing one difference. But Global 2000, at the request of Government regulators and several key members, keeps most of its research private. Gartner's results are more widely available and are based on more data, Mr. Devlin said.
That makes them subject to disproportionate influence, according to some Year 2000 experts. "At a minimum, if you are a Y2K coordinator in a foreign country, you need to know what Gartner is saying about you," said Bruce McConnell, head of the World Bank's recently formed International Y2K Cooperation Center in Washington and a critic of the weight often given to Gartner Group ratings.
Gartner readily concedes that those it rates have every right to be concerned about how its research -- especially the public summaries of it -- is being used.
"These things are meant to be a flag, not a basis for decisions," Mr. Marcoccio said. He added that Gartner constantly warns clients that a low rating for a country is a signal for them to look more closely at their exposure, not a reason to pull out.

LENGTH: 1164 words

HEADLINE: Nation's Economic Boom A Faint Echo in Appalachia

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, Ky., June 29

 BODY:
"The economic boom?" asked Donna McDonald at her roadside flea market rack of used clothes -- humbly frayed offerings that she has been buying more than selling lately as local customers survive until their welfare checks next week.
Ms. McDonald stared wide-eyed at the question of the boom, as if directions were being sought to some Nirvana far beyond the green highlands and idle coal mines in this hard-core heart of Appalachia. "Not here," she noted of the whirring economy. 
 "Right now a lot of people need extra money and sell me their clothes instead of buying," Ms. McDonald said, explaining the economic cycle as she lives it. "It's tough here; we need jobs and the economy ain't helped," she gently summarized, speaking as the daughter of a coal miner, forced to become one of Appalachia's marginal entrepreneurs.
When President Clinton begins his tour of some of the nation's most entrenched poverty regions on Monday, the entrepreneurial impulse in the eastern hollows of Kentucky will be on his agenda as he makes his first stop in London, Ky., 20 miles to the west down the Daniel Boone Parkway. There he will focus on the bona fide success of Kentucky Highlands, a 31-year-old anti-poverty program whose unusual specialty is the gathering of venture capital via Government loans and charitable foundations to create businesses and jobs in poverty-steeped areas. More than 50 companies and 6,000 jobs have been fostered in nine counties by Kentucky Highlands since Appalachia was first dramatically designated in 1965 as a 13-state swath of intense poverty deserving special regional aid and remedies.
"There's a mystique about Appalachian people: They just don't want to leave this land," L. Ray Moncrief, executive vice president of Kentucky Highlands, said of the poor's tenacity in the tattered coal fields.
As Mr. Clinton arrives, the first President to visit here since Lyndon B. Johnson, the statistical progress measured in the past 34 years by the Appalachian Regional Commission is significant: The poverty rate, once 31 percent, has been halved to 15 percent, just two points higher than the national average. The difference used to be nine points.
"The idea that the Great Society economic development programs didn't work, I think, is just wrong," Jesse L. White Jr., co-chairman of the Appalachian Regional Commission, said of the war on poverty that was begun in the 1960's. President Ronald Reagan crimped the commission's programs, but the regional approach survived and was formally reauthorized by Congress last year after 16 years of uncertain budgeting. Mr. White describes Appalachia's situation as "half-way home and a long way to go."
In the more troubled hamlets, emerald hills resonate as before with the hardscrabble life of residents like Ms. McDonald and her scrawled sign proclaiming "Donna's New and Used Clothes." Appalachia's most resistant areas -- much of West Virginia, southern Ohio and eastern Kentucky -- still have unemployment and poverty rates at least 50 percent higher than the rest of the nation. A checkerboard pattern of diehard neediness in 108 of the region's 406 counties leaves some denizens reacting with a polite shrug to the Clinton visit.
"I guess anybody can go anywhere they want," said Boyd Asher, a whatnot dealer sharing roadside space with Ms. McDonald. "But it seems like his big boom skipped this place," added Mr. Asher, yearning for the steady paycheck of his old coal mining job, lost when the industry moved on.
"That left us down in the dumps," said Mr. Asher, who drives the school bus part-time and hustles used household goods on roads from London to Harlan. "Now the welfare cutbacks in food stamps and all is hurting us bad. The only money around here is during the two weeks after the welfare checks come."
At his side, Matt Collins, retired coal miner and dealer in assorted dishes and novelties, conceded total puzzlement about the economy raging in so many other places. "I just can't never figure it out. Why can't they never get a factory in here?" he said of Clay County, where the unemployment rate is 80 percent worse than the national average. Mr. Clinton, he said, trimmed back traditional welfare on the promise of greater job opportunities.
The President intends to highlight his new venture capital program for impoverished areas. Dubbed New Markets Initiative, it was announced in January as an attempt to use deferred-interest loans and other incentives to draw the private sector more deeply into the Small Business Administration's effort to spawn new business and jobs in distressed areas. Local residents amiably speculate on why this proposal has come more in the twilight than the heyday of the Clinton Administration. But others stand ready to gratefully exploit the occasion.
"It's never too late," said J. C. Egnew, an engineer who quit the space program 27 years ago to settle here and become a businessman, sensing a trainable and loyal pool of factory workers clinging to the land.
With venture capital help from Kentucky Highlands, Mr. Egnew has created five factory businesses and more than 1,000 jobs, producing hunting equipment, military tents and automobile air bags.
"The President is the most powerful man on earth and whatever he decides is important carries a lot of weight," said Mr. Egnew, a community leader in Stearns, Ky., who recently sponsored a new computerized community college center to track the economy globally so the next generation of Highlanders might be better prepared for change.
Asked why one coal-mine hollow inches toward recovery while another does not, Mr. Egnew responded that the dominant factor beyond all the aid programs seemed to be whether a community was willing to dedicate itself to education as the engine of rescue. Otherwise, he said, expectations remain low, political leaders rarely emerge, and innovative ventures are never conceived. Such a community, he said, "leans on those crutches" that date from the worst of Appalachian times in the Depression.
Patty Kidd, a 36-year-old worker in Mr. Egnew's Outdoor Venture business, is a coal miner's daughter who seized a job opportunity as the rarest of Appalachia's resources. "I'm home-grown in this country, and I kind of progressed with the times," she said, describing how she landed a start-up job as a sewing machine operator and worked her way up to supervisor and now plant production manager overseeing all three work shifts. Ever more galvanized, she also obtained a business degree in night school.
"It would be great for the President to get a good picture of our region," said Ms. Kidd, mindful of the luck of the draw in life. "If Mr. Egnew hadn't believed in the people here, what would I be today?"
Ms. Kidd confessed to sadness lately with the high school graduations depositing a fresh crop of teen-agers to hang around with scant promise of a career. "Mr. Clinton's visit couldn't hurt anything around here," she said.

HEADLINE: Federal Seers, Telling Nation's Fiscal Fortune

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 3

 BODY:
Kathy Gramp peered beneath the stacks of paper on her desk and poked through the drawers, an expression of bafflement on her face. Her calculator was at large.
"It's here somewhere," she insisted, rolling her eyes. She seemed to appreciate the strangeness of this particular piece of equipment vanishing, given her job. Ms. Gramp is one of the workers at the Congressional Budget Office who crunch the numbers that tell the country's financial fortune. 
 Then again, Ms. Gramp, who refers to herself as "chatty Kathy" and points to the strands beneath her headband when she mentions "senior, gray-haired analysts," tries not to take her task, or herself, too seriously.
On a wall just outside her office, she and her colleagues have hung various symbols and objects that they jokingly refer to as the real tools of their predictive trade. There is a Ouija board, a crystal ball, a bag of tea leaves, a pair of dice and, incongruously, a plastic replica of a breakfast food.
"A waffle," Ms. Gramp explained. "We waffle."
That is true only to a point. But Ms. Gramp's comic riff underscored a larger reality.
Behind the lofty, quasi-mystical budget numbers that sporadically rise from the nation's capital sit scores of everyday people like Ms. Gramp -- distracted, self-effacing and fully aware of the intrinsic, inevitable flaws in their convoluted guessing game.
That game produced some especially startling results earlier this week. Revising calculations they had made earlier in the year, officials at both the C.B.O. and the White House's Office of Management and Budget, which produces its own set of figures, announced that the Federal surplus over the next 10 years would, in fact, be hundreds of billions of dollars larger than they had previously thought. In fact, the total surplus over that period was projected to be about $2.9 trillion, roughly $1 trillion of which was up for legislative grabs.
These numbers almost instantly altered the political landscape. There were fresh hopes and refined designs for the long-term fiscal survival of Social Security and Medicare. There was new momentum for sweeping tax cuts.
And there were, for the confounded observer, several questions: How did this happen, and who were the instigators?
Ms. Gramp is one, although her piece of the pie is minuscule. One of about 200 people employed by the budget office, she analyzes and projects how much the Federal Government will spend each year on an array of programs related to science, basing her estimates in large part on the spending caps that Congress enacted in 1997 and mathematical formulas that predict when the people who receive Federal grants are likely to actually cash those checks. (Believe it or not, some wait awhile.)
To produce a complete portrait of Federal expenditures in the future, her figure joins comparable estimates from people who specialize in other areas.
"That's Deb -- she does national parks and wetlands and endangered species," Ms. Gramp said one afternoon this week as she navigated a warren of offices on the fourth floor of a building relegated to a distant corner of Capitol Hill: a Congressional Siberia of sorts.
"There's a transportation analyst behind you," Ms. Gramp added as she rounded a corner.
The other half of the puzzle is revenue, also known as taxes, and that is where the indefatigable economy has produced income for the Federal Government that has been exceeding expectations for the last few years.
Rich Kasten works in this area, and he does so somewhat invisibly, which is a judgment not on his influence or personality but on his desktop. Every square millimeter has a leaning tower of paper rising from it, and the shortest tower is at least two feet tall. Only the top of Mr. Kasten's scalp can be seen from the door of his office.
Mr. Kasten has a doctorate in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, but he concedes that his job has as much to do with arithmetic as with abstruse economic theory.
"What you need for this," Mr. Kasten explained, "is a little bit of economic training, a lot of common sense and something like an instinct for numbers, so you can spot new trends."
Much of what Mr. Kasten does -- and what is done by the economic forecasters in the C.B.O. and the O.M.B., who provide the template for him and other players in this process -- is extrapolate from the present into the future, using history as a guide and making informed judgments about changes on the horizon to tweak that model and amend their calculations.
Rudolph Penner, a former director of the Congressional Budget Office, explained: "I might look at what these equations tell me, but I might stare at an equation and say, 'Well, we've never had a stock market like the one we're having now.' I'm going to adjust the results. I'm going to assume that consumption will be a little higher.' That's a judgment. That's where the art comes in."
The further that analysts gaze into the future, the faultier their assumptions are bound to be; they cannot, for starters, anticipate new legislation that may affect the economy, tax revenues and expenditures.
Robert D. Reischauer, another former director of the budget office, said that a 10-year projection "is our best judgment of where we will end up if we remain on automatic pilot."
But, Mr. Reischauer added, "Our whole political system is designed to fly the plane, not to allow it to continue on automatic pilot."
Then, of course, there are the unexpected pockets of turbulence. Lately, they have been happy spasms. For example, in early 1994, the Office of Management and Budget projected a Federal budget deficit for 1998 of $190.5 billion. Instead, the Federal Government had a $69 billion surplus.
What went wrong -- or, rather, right? Joseph J. Minarik, the chief economist for the O.M.B., explained that additional revenue was brought in by an unexpectedly surging economy, dizzying stock market and "the power of compound interest." On top of all that, the Federal Government tightened its spending.
"The future is uncertain," Mr. Minarik said with a smile and a shrug. "I cannot quarrel with that."
Mr. Minarik, who once was a tax analyst for the Congressional Budget Office, has a doctorate in economics from Yale. But economics degrees are not prerequisites for peering into the fiscal future.
Jeff Holland, who interprets the probable impact of economic forecasts on the Federal budget for the C.B.O., has a master's degree in public policy from Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh.
Much of his job, he said, boils down to numerical calculations, but not the kind that require a supercomputer or other arcane technology. He often works with Lotus software on a Dell computer, and to break the occasional monotony, he plays rock music over the speakers attached to the machine. The stack of compact discs on a cabinet in his office include Aerosmith, Blondie and the Pretenders.
Ms. Gramp is just down the hall, in a section of the budget office noted for its ersatz art gallery. For each and every kind of Federal outlay that the analysts there study, there is a corresponding framed poster of a famous painting or print.
Vincent Van Gogh's "Fishing Boats on the Beach at Saints-Maries-de-la-Mer" represents Federal expenditures on fisheries and water transportation. Georgia O'Keefe's "Cliffs Beyond Abiqui" symbolizes spending on public and Indian lands.
Outlays for national disasters have no visual analogue. "We're still trying to find a good picture of a tsunami," Ms. Gramp said.

HEADLINE: An Alarming Prosecution in Iran

 BODY:
President Mohammad Khatami hopes to strengthen the rule of law in Iran and repair ties with the West. But his efforts are threatened by the dubious espionage charges that clerical prosecutors brought against 13 Iranian Jews. Mr. Khatami, who has been trying to limit his conflicts with conservative clerics before an important parliamentary election, has been cautious in speaking out on this case. But this is a case he cannot condone if he wishes to improve ties with the West.
The arrested Jews are accused of giving military information to Israel and the United States. Until the past few days, they had been held incommunicado. They are still being denied family visits, kosher food and legal representation. Although no trial has yet been held and no incriminating evidence made public, influential Iranian clerics have all but declared the 13 Jews guilty and called for their hanging. 
 Under Iran's Islamic Constitution, the Jewish community is an officially recognized religious minority. Currently, about 25,000 Jews live in Iran, a nation of nearly 70 million people. More than 50,000 Jews have emigrated since the 1979 revolution. Those who remained have had to contend with two decades of government hostility to Israel and several previous espionage prosecutions against Jewish Iranians, although none on this scale. Now there is worry that militant clerics frightened by Mr. Khatami's more tolerant views could strike back against vulnerable Iranian Jews. Mr. Khatami has tried to reassure the Jewish community and has spoken out publicly in defense of the legal rights of its members. But he has not challenged the abusive handling of this case. Outside Iran there have been many expressions of concern. Israel has worked hard to mobilize international attention. The United States has called on Iran to free those arrested, as have Germany, France and the European Union. The Iranians should understand that the persecution of Jews will throw Iran's relations with the West into a new freeze, crippling Iran's attempt to revive its stagnant economy.
Mr. Khatami seems loath to risk accusations of endangering national security by interfering with the prosecution of alleged spies. But so far, this case seems to be less about foreign espionage than about a campaign by Mr. Khatami's domestic enemies to sabotage his program of reform and dialogue with the West. The Iranian people have already paid a high price for the international isolation they have endured for two decades. It would be a pity if Mr. Khatami's reforms were now undermined by a contrived spy case.

HEADLINE: Japanese Thrift

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Reviving the Economics of Fear" (Business Day, July 2), on whether the United States might suffer a Japanese-style liquidity trap in which consumers stop spending, ignores basic differences in history and economic culture between the two countries. 
 For nearly a century, the Japanese Government, schools and women's groups have promoted a "culture of thrift." Housewives keep ledgers, and consumer credit is limited. Heeding official warnings of inadequate social security, families save at high levels (from 12 percent to 23 percent in recent decades). Predictably, the Japanese react to economic uncertainties by severely cutting spending and saving more. It is difficult to imagine free-spending Americans, who now save at negative rates, doing the same.
 
SHELDON GARON
Princeton, N.J., July 2, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of Japanese history at Princeton University.

HEADLINE: Faraway Friends 'Adopt' a Reservation's Elderly

BYLINE: By MINDY SINK 

DATELINE: PINE RIDGE RESERVATION, S.D., July 4

 BODY:
Thaddeus Hust and his wife, Rebecca Thomas, chose their grandfather because they shared an interest in gardening with him.
For the last two years, the couple from Durango, Colo., have been exchanging letters, phone calls and seed packets and helping to support Bernard Little White Man, a 71-year-old widower, through the Adopt-a-Grandparent Program. 
 Today, Mr. Hust spent about two hours grilling sausages at the organization's annual breakfast here, where some of the group's 300 members came to meet the elders they sponsor.
"We always felt this connection, this empathy for the Native Americans," Ms. Thomas said. "Then we heard about this grandparent idea, and it just seemed like such a wonderful way to help the elders."
The Adopt-a-Grandparent Program was started in 1987 by a freelance photojournalist, Gail Russell, who had visited this reservation while on assignment for a magazine. Through friends here she learned of three elderly women who had frozen to death in their homes during a winter storm. It was not clear whether the women could not afford propane for heat or could not make the trip to get supplies.
"We were shocked about the news, and I asked some of the grandmas I knew on the reservation to tell me why the programs they had didn't work," Ms. Russell said. She said she had no plans to start an organization until an elderly friend, Nellie Red Owl, asked her, " 'Wouldn't someone up your way like to adopt a Grandma?' And it just clicked."
Ms. Russell founded the Mountain Light Center, a nonprofit organization that runs the Adopt-a-Grandparent Program. Now she often makes the 12-hour drive from her home in Taos, N.M., to deliver food and other supplies to the reservation. And she organizes a get-together for grandparents and sponsors during the Oglala Sioux's annual powwow.
The Adopt-a-Grandparent Program began with 12 elders from the Wakpamni community here. Now more than 250 elders and their families in Pine Ridge are sponsored, along with about a dozen elders in New Mexico.
Word-of-mouth and a new Web site have helped attract new members, most from the United States, but some from Japan and the Netherlands. Ms. Russell hopes to double the membership this year. The budget for 1998 was $150,000, of which $63,000 went directly to the elders; an additional $75,000 in goods was donated.
"A lot of members say they always wanted to help Native Americans in some way, but there was no structure they were comfortable with," Ms. Russell said.
That was the case for Pete Smith and his girlfriend, Marja-Liisa Bykonich, of Longmont, Colo.
"We see so much outpouring to help others in this country, it goes out to Kosovo or wherever," Mr. Smith said, taking a rest after cooking several bowls of scrambled eggs at this morning's breakfast. "And this is the forgotten part of America, these people that were conquered and just forgotten about."
Members of the program can either pay a membership fee of $50 annually and have no involvement with elders, or they can choose an elder and establish a relationship.
"Some write their adopted grandparent, others send money, some send new blankets or sheets," Ms. Russell said. "There is no prescribed do this or that." In one case, a couple from Washington helped build a house for an adopted grandparent.
The elders are chosen by sponsors from lists provided by Ms. Russell that describe the person's health, hobbies, clothing sizes and other information. To qualify for the program, a person must live on a reservation and be at least 60 years old or handicapped. Members can sponsor more than one elder, and elders can be sponsored by several people.
"I have about three sponsors," said Emily Has No Horse, an 80-year-old widow, who was munching on heart-shaped blue corn waffles that Ms. Russell made this morning. "One woman, Barbara, in California, sends me materials for quilting, or sometimes helps with the electricity bill or pays for propane."
Sitting behind Mrs. Has No Horse was Amelia Yellow Thunder, 70, who showed off the red, green and blue plaid cotton skirt that one of her sponsors had sent her. Both of the women said their only income was about $500 a month from Social Security.
This level of poverty is typical on the Pine Ridge Reservation, which President Clinton was scheduled to visit this week on a tour of disadvantaged regions. About 24,000 of the Oglala Sioux's 38,000 enrolled tribal members live here, including about 15,000 elders, tribal officials say.
Unemployment is about 85 percent here, with a median annual income of $3,400, said Bart Merdanian, a legislative liaison for the tribe. In addition to the financial straits, there is a high incidence of diabetes, heart disease and alcoholism on the reservation, Mr. Merdanian said.
"Our grandmother, Rosemary Good Voice Elk, is diabetic and is in a wheelchair," Ms. Bykonich said. "Her house was hit by the tornado this year, and they lost part of the roof, one bedroom and a front window. I didn't see any beds there when we went by yesterday, but we didn't come right out and ask because they have their pride, too."
Ms. Bykonich said several children and grandchildren also lived with Mrs. Good Voice Elk.
Speaking over the sound of powwow chants and a summer thunderstorm, Ms. Russell said: "The Native American way of life is a circle, and we try to have the energy of the organization in the same way. The sponsors say they are getting so much more than they are giving, so it's like life."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Bush's Right-Hand Man Is a Friend With a Midas Touch

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
BACK in Midland, in the harrowing, exhilarating oil days of rising gushers and falling prices, they all had nicknames: Dennis Grubb was "Wemus," George W. Bush was "Boosto" or "the Bombastic Bushkin," Joe O'Neill was "Spider" and Donald L. Evans was usually "Evvie" or "Donnie."
But sometimes, just to annoy the future politician in the rambunctious Mr. Bush, the friends used to call Mr. Evans by another name: "Governor." Back then, in the 70's and 80's, it was Mr. Evans' earnest, organized demeanor that seemed more suitable for an executive office. 
 "It could just as easily have been Donnie," said Mr. Grubb, then an oilman and now an entertainment promoter, referring to the sense of political destiny now gathering around Mr. Bush, the Governor of Texas. "He could have been any kind of politician or elected official he wanted, just like George. And now I think he'll make a great chief of staff."
It is a little early, of course, to start casting a Bush Cabinet, even if Mr. Evans' perfectly graying temples make him a TV-movie dream of a distinguished White House official. But as the chief fund-raiser of Mr. Bush's Presidential campaign, Mr. Evans announced something last week that impressed the political world like few other achievements: the campaign had raised $36 million in just four months, more than any other candidate had ever collected in the entire primary season.
With money now scrutinized as carefully as opinion polls, this announcement only heightened the sense of inevitability carefully cultivated by Mr. Bush's advisers, and gave the impression that Mr. Evans had wrought some kind of financial miracle. More than once, he has heard it said that Mr. Bush had found his Jim Baker, the close friend and aide of Mr. Bush's father, the former President. This kind of talk brings an exasperated smile to Mr. Evans' face.
"I'm not that," he said. "I'm just the money guy. If anything, it's more appropriate that somebody call me the Bob Mosbacher of the campaign" -- a reference to another wealthy oilman and adept fund-raiser who became President Bush's Commerce Secretary in 1989. (Mr. Evans does not rule out a possible move to Washington in the future.)
To a large extent, of course, Mr. Evans, who will be 53 later this month, is a rather fortunate money guy. He has collected checks from 75,000 of the nation's most prosperous citizens at an economic peak, and on behalf of a charmer with a well-known name who is considered a Republican savior. It is in his nature to minimize his achievement, but in this case, there is some truth to his modesty.
"This is the easiest fund-raising I've ever done in my life," Mr. Evans said in an interview at campaign headquarters in a plush office building down the street from the state capitol, far more comfortable than the usual utilitarian jumble. "Usually political campaigns are a tough sell, and you always worry that someone's going to ask you for something in return. This time, you call someone and they say, 'Oh, I'm so glad you called me. I was wondering how to make a contribution.' "
But it is also clear that Mr. Bush chose his national finance chairman carefully, entrusting his family's extensive network of money raisers to his best friend, a man with a similar background and sensibility. Mr. Evans, chairman of the University of Texas Board of Regents and chief executive of Tom Brown Inc., a Midland oil and gas company, knows almost everyone Mr. Bush knows in Texas, where a third of the treasury was raised. And being the candidate's best friend made it that much easier to set up a network of "Pioneers," who are each raising $100,000, or to call upon governors who have endorsed Mr. Bush to push their state check-writing operations into overdrive.
HIS experience seeking backers for oil ventures had already led Mr. Evans to become the leading fund-raiser for Mr. Bush's campaigns for governor, but their most formative moments together go back to Midland in the 1970's, when both arrived in West Texas simultaneously to partake in what Mr. Evans calls the "entrepreneurial heaven" of the oil business. Mr. Evans had a mechanical engineering degree from the University of Texas and no real background in the field. But his father had worked for Shell Oil in Houston, where Mr. Evans grew up. His wife, Susie, grew up in Midland with Mr. Bush.
He signed up with Tom Brown, a classic independent wildcatter, and spent two months as a roughneck on the company's rigs before moving back to the office and eventually assuming the company's leadership from Mr. Brown. Mr. Evans invested in a few wells with Mr. Bush's firm, and the two became inseparable, riding out the depths of the oil business and regularly shooting baskets and playing golf. Their families were also close, and Mr. Evans said the Bushes were an invaluable source of support after the Evanses' second daughter, who is mentally retarded, was born. Mr. Evans, a Methodist, calls that event one of the greatest things that ever happened to him. (He and his wife later adopted their third child, a boy.)
"It was more than business," he said. "We shared a lot of the same values and beliefs. Both of us were out there at the same age, building our families, pursuing the American dream, both of us believing our highest calling in life is to serve other people, getting involved in United Way, our church, immersing ourselves in the community. Of course, I always knew who the candidate was going to be."
Still, the cadences of his speech reflect his immersion in his friend's world. Instead of "around the country," he says with repeated passion "around this great country of ours." Driven by his fierce friendship, he sees his current calling as a form of public service, with each flurry of $1,000 checks reflecting not political calculation but hope for America.
"Behind every check, there's a willing heart," Mr. Evans said. "To me, it's not a check, it's a person, someone who cares about this great country."
