HEADLINE: Nassau's Paradox: Wealthy but Nearly Broke

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y., July 3

 BODY:
To an outsider, the fix Nassau County is in might understandably cause bewilderment. The economy here is booming just as loudly as in New York City, its neighbor to the west, with unemployment at 2.8 percent, 25,000 new jobs cropping up every year, and sales tax receipts growing at better than 3 percent annually. Its population of 1.3 million is one of the wealthiest in the nation, with median household income of more than $73,000.
Yet the county government is nearly broke. 
 Last week, Standard & Poor's steeply downgraded the county's debt to just a couple of rating ticks above junk-bond status. Desperate to close a $200 million budget gap without drastically raising property taxes, the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, has turned to the Democratic-controlled State Assembly for a bailout, in the form of a new tax on real estate sales.
And the new chairman of the Nassau Democratic Party, Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli, is gleefully putting the screws to Mr. Gulotta, demanding in return that the county let an independent board supervise its finances.
How did it come to this?
"It really is a simple proposition," said Mr. DiNapoli of Great Neck. "They spend more money than they take in."
Since Mr. Gulotta took office in 1987, analysts at the Wall Street rating agencies say, his budgets have routinely resulted in what they call structural deficits: the amount devoted to paying wages, benefits, supply bills and other recurring expenses is not matched by an equal amount in taxes, fees, rents and other predictable sources of yearly income.
Chuck Cutolo, counsel to the Democratic county legislators, who are outnumbered 14 to 5, compared the Nassau Republicans to the Reagan Republicans of the 1980's and the Rockefeller Republicans of the 1960's and 1970's. "What you have in Nassau County are Reagan-Rockefeller Republicans," he said. "They have the aversion to taxes that Reagan had, and the attraction to spending that Rockefeller had."
But it is not the county's considerable spending on parks, roads and other arguably worthwhile projects that draws the most fire these days. Even Mr. Gulotta's fellow Republicans say privately that his biggest weakness has been in negotiating the county's labor contracts -- or in letting negotiations fail, resulting in binding arbitration.
Over and over again, Nassau's police officers have received raises keeping their wages and benefits at or near the top rank among those in departments nationwide. Typically, in April, an arbitrator awarded Nassau's 517 supervisory officers -- ranked from sergeant to captain -- a 24 percent raise over five years, not counting overtime and other add-ons, retroactive to January 1997.
Two weeks earlier, with the county's cumulative deficit swollen to a record $300 million, Mr. Gulotta gave Nassau's 11,000 civil servants raises of 20 percent over five years and new benefits that are expected to raise the county's labor costs by more than $150 million by 2002.
Adding to the county's expenses, critics say, is the notorious penchant for patronage in Nassau, where Alfonse M. D'Amato got his start, where county workers were once pressured to kick back 1 percent of their pay to the G.O.P., and where the Republican chairman, Joseph M. Margiotta, ruled until he was convicted in an insurance kickback scheme.
The county may not have as fat a payroll as it did before the last fiscal crisis, in 1992, prompted more than 2,000 layoffs. Nevertheless, Democrats contend that a carefully wielded knife could easily trim $10 million in salaries for well-connected but overpaid deputy commissioners and unneeded bridge toll collectors. But they say that Nassau is wasting even more in contracts for things like professional services.
The county attorney, for example, employs more than 60 lawyers who are paid a total of $3.4 million, said Legislator Judith A. Jacobs, the minority leader. But civil rights lawsuits, labor talks and other sensitive matters are all routinely farmed out to a few favored law firms that each make hundreds of thousands of dollars more every year, she said.
And a switch to a politically connected health insurance carrier that had promised huge savings instead cost the county nearly $50 million this year.
Finally, draining money out of Nassau's treasury like an open spigot on a water truck is the county's unfathomable tax-assessment system, based on 1938 construction costs and 1964 land values. The Federal Government sued the county last month, saying the system has resulted in higher taxes for black and Hispanic residents than for whites.
Mr. Gulotta, supported by Republican leaders who feared that their middle-class white constituents would have to pay more in taxes, vowed to fight the suit vigorously.
But appeals of tax assessments, known as certioraris, already cost the county more than $100 million a year in refunds, which the county is borrowing to pay. Even the Republican County Comptroller, Frederick E. Parola, said in a memorandum last month that those refunds "are choking the county."
"They've got a debt of $2.5 billion, of which 40 percent is directly attributable to the tax certioraris," said Steven A. Greenberg, a spokesman for the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, who like many others has urged Nassau to change over to a system based on market values.
"They've been borrowing hundreds of millions of dollars for what is essentially an operating expense," Mr. Greenberg said. "And it's not only the taxpayers today but the children, or even the grandchildren of today's taxpayers, who are going to be paying for it."
To make up for a structural deficit, a county executive has few choices: borrow more money, sell off a county asset or receivable for some quick cash, or roll the deficit into the next year's budget. Mr. Gulotta has done all three. Short-term borrowing, for example, has soared 70 percent in the last five years, to more than $400 million. But in recent years, the County Executive's favorite approach appears to have been the nonrecurring revenue item, better known as the one-shot.
So, for example, twice in recent years, Nassau has made deals with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that Standard & Poor's called "tantamount to deficit financing." In the latest, in exchange for $70 million in up-front cash that went toward last year's deficit, the county in April issued $141 million in bonds that the M.T.A. will use to buy new rail cars. The cost to the county, with interest, will be more than $240 million.
Not every one-shot can be completed quickly, however. The sale of a single property in Plainview was budgeted for eight years before an agreement was reached this spring.
For years, the county has been planning to sell its medical center and nursing home, and Mr. Gulotta's budgets have included the anticipated selling price since 1997. That deal -- now worth $10 million less than expected and so laden with strings that Mr. Parola warned that the county could end up losing money -- has still not closed.
There is, of course, another way to eliminate a structural deficit: raise taxes. Last fall, Republicans in the County Legislature actually forced through a modest 3.6 percent to 4.5 percent increase. But if the State Legislature does not approve Mr. Gulotta's proposal for a 1 percent tax on real estate sales, property taxes could rise by much more this fall -- just in time for November, when all 19 county legislative seats and 27 city and town offices will be up for election.
That prospect, in a nutshell, represents the worst fear of Nassau's Republican leadership. From the party chairman, Joseph N. Mondello, on down, officials view general property tax increases, as opposed to other taxes affecting smaller groups, with something akin to terror.
Mr. Gulotta learned that lesson in 1992, when he was pilloried by Mr. Mondello and others after proposing a tax increase of nearly 26 percent to solve the county's last fiscal crisis -- one ultimately solved with a combination of a smaller tax increase, layoffs and a state-approved, deficit-closing bond issue.
For seven straight years afterward, while the rates of other categories of taxes have risen, Mr. Gulotta cut or froze the general property tax rate.
The bond rating agencies may not have appreciated that policy, since spending continued to rise. But Standard & Poor's does not vote. And politically, even Mr. Gulotta's detractors say his strategy has worked beautifully.
"Our legislators, and the Republicans as well -- they'll go to an event, and the person who gets the biggest applause will be Gulotta," said Mr. Cutolo, the Democratic counsel. "I think it's because he never wanted to say 'no' to anybody. He listens to the applause, and he says to himself: 'This is good. Not saying "no" pays.' And he looks at the election returns, and not saying 'no' pays. And he's learned from that: you don't say 'no.' "

HEADLINE: For Queens Immigrant Family, This Fourth Was a First

BYLINE: By DAVID BARSTOW 

 BODY:
Ali and Samra Sabir came to the United States with two suitcases and $2,000. This was 15 months ago. Yesterday, the Sabirs took their first day off together.
They packed a picnic in a plastic bag and wheeled their two children in a borrowed baby stroller to the Unisphere, which hovers like a giant spacecraft over Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens. 
 The Sabirs sat facing the United States on the Unisphere globe.
Pakistan, their homeland, was out of sight.
But this was fitting. Like dozens of other immigrant families in the park yesterday, the Sabirs came to celebrate their new home. As with the shiny new Sears credit card in Mr. Sabir's wallet, a Fourth of July picnic represents a simple way to feel connected to this vast land. It is a chance to fit in, to join effortlessly in the annual rites and rhythms of an often bewildering country.
"That's why we came here," Mrs. Sabir, 27, said, smiling and laughing, and a little giddy to at last have a day -- a whole day! -- with her husband of nearly three years.
This being the first time they celebrated the Fourth of July -- Mr. Sabir's boss at the grocery store made him work last year -- some traditions did not come naturally.
Mrs. Sabir wanted to make lasagna. She had heard this was typical American picnic fare for the Fourth of July. But she had never made lasagna before. She asked Pakistani friends for tips.
"I try to know about lasagna," she said. "I think my husband will be very happy. But I cannot do it. It is too much. It takes too long."
So she settled on a mixture of old and new: a chicken and rice recipe from Pakistan, Lay's potato chips from the United States. Their 18-month-old son, Zunnair, wandered with the bag of Lays toward his 5-month-old sister, Rida, who ignored him.
"Why not we should also enjoy the Fourth of July?" asked Mr. Sabir, 28, laying firm claim to a new holiday and a new set of cultural traditions.
Only a few years ago, the thought of living in the United States -- let alone celebrating America's independence -- seemed a remote possibility for the Sabirs. First cousins, the Sabirs had an arranged marriage and a small house in Chak Jhumra, a modest city in the province of Punjab. Mr. Sabir worked as a physician's assistant. Each Aug. 14, they celebrated Freedom Day, marking the birth of Pakistan in 1947. They envisioned a life devoted to family, their Muslim faith and cricket, Mr. Sabir's passion.
And then something unexpected happened.
Defying long odds, they won a special lottery for work visas in the United States. "We think it is a blessing of God," Mrs. Sabir said. "The U.S.A. is strong, and everybody wants to come here."
Without really thinking it through, they sold their belongings, packed their bags, gathered their savings and flew to New York. First they stayed with a friend in Jersey City; then they moved into a tiny studio apartment in Flushing.
Mr. Sabir found work in the Gold Sword, a nearby grocery store. He works seven days a week stocking shelves, working the deli counter, running the cash register.
At first, Mrs. Sabir was nervous about venturing forth. "I did not want to come out," she said. "I was afraid." But with her husband working all the time, she was forced to go out, which is when she realized something.
"I can go alone everywhere without my husband," she said.
By this, she merely means that she feels safe from criminals, something she did not feel in Pakistan. Mrs. Sabir enjoyed the sense of order here, the way people formed lines in stores, the way the nurses seemed so efficient at Flushing Hospital when she gave birth to Rida.
"Here," Mr. Sabir said, "you feel equal. We appreciate every person in this country."
On this Fourth of July -- a day for counting blessings and fitting in -- it was easy to overlook the painful moments, and there have been plenty. First of all, the Sabirs are terribly homesick. Second, the dream of prosperity remains elusive. Mr. Sabir earns about $300 a week; their rent alone is $561 a month. They have barely inched up the economic ladder compared with their living in Pakistan.
Beyond money is the challenge to their values. Devout Muslims, they are offended by the sight of couples kissing in public. Mr. Sabir draws a careful distinction: he wants his family to remain in America and eventually obtain citizenship, but he does not want them to become Americans. He shudders at the thought of his wife wearing sleeveless dresses, or high heels.
He was thinking about these things one afternoon when he took his wife and children to the Statue of Liberty. There, staring up at the torch, then turning out toward the sea, Mr. Sabir felt a strange stirring. It was the feeling of belonging, he said.
"I feel very good," he said. "I had no idea why I was coming to the United States, but when I was there, looking up, I figured it out."
And so Mr. Sabir has charted a course for prosperity. He plans to obtain a license to drive a limousine. He plans to improve his English by engaging anyone he can in conversation.
He says these things with determination, and even on this day of rest, it turns out, he was quietly pursuing his ambitions in the most American of ways -- networking.
After the picnic, Mr. Sabir and his family headed across a field to join the members of the Universal Cricket Club. The club is made up mostly of young, affluent professionals from Bangladesh, men who have been educated in the United States and who glide easily between East and West.
The captain, Mesbah Ahmed, wears a cap from Deutsche Bank, where he said he works as an investment banker. The team manager, Maruf Siddiquee, is an accountant. A year ago, Mr. Siddiquee had noticed Mr. Sabir watching one of their games. Pakistanis are known for their prowess in cricket, and it was considered a huge upset when Bangladesh beat Pakistan last month.
"Every time I'm in a cab and the driver is Pakistani, I ask, "Do you play cricket?' " Mr. Siddiquee said.
So he asked Mr. Sabir, who, as it happened, was captain of his city's cricket team in Pakistan. "The best team of all the city teams," his wife said proudly. After a few trial bowls, Mr. Siddiquee and Mr. Ahmed were suitably impressed with Mr. Sabir. They asked him to join their team for their first match, which was yesterday against Brothers Union.
Mr. Sabir was looking forward to the match -- "I love cricket so much" -- but he also was hoping to make new friends, new connections. Yes, the wives and girlfriends of his teammates were wearing sleeveless dresses and platform shoes. But Mr. Siddiquee and Mr. Ahmed seemed like just the men he would need to know if he ever wanted to make it beyond the grocery store, and even beyond the limousine business.
"Maybe they will help me," Mr. Sabir said, getting ready to take the cricket pitch on his first Fourth of July celebration.

HEADLINE: Administration Calls for Warning Labels on Eggs

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration has proposed that warning labels be put on eggs to alert consumers to the possible serious illnesses, including salmonella poisoning, that eggs can cause.
"Eggs are a good source of protein and can be a healthy and economical contribution to a well-balanced diet," Dr. Donna E. Shalala, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said. "However, they need proper handling or they could potentially be the source of food-borne illness." 
 Salmonella is a common source of food poisoning, and many cases have been linked to eggs. The bacteria can cause nausea and diarrhea, symptoms especially dangerous to the very young, the elderly and others with weak immune symptoms.
About 40,000 cases are reported annually, but the actual number is believed to be much higher because many mild cases are not diagnosed.
In 1997, more than 100 Americans died from salmonella food poisoning.
The labels would alert consumers that eggs "may contain harmful bacteria known to cause serious illness" and would advise buyers to keep eggs refrigerated and to cook them thoroughly. The Government will receive comments on the proposal, issued Thursday, from the public for two and a half months before issuing a final decision.
The Agriculture Department and the Food and Drug Administration said that starting Aug. 27, all eggs and egg products must be refrigerated at 45 degrees or below. A plan to be developed by Nov. 1 will aim to improve the safety of shelled eggs and egg products, the agencies said.
The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, released a report last week that said the Government's oversight of egg safety left Americans vulnerable to outbreaks of salmonella.
The report suggested that egg safety, now handled by four agencies, should be consolidated within a single Federal department.

HEADLINE: Departing Foreign Aid Chief Says Cuts Are Dangerous

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
The departing director of the Government's major foreign aid agency has criticized the Clinton Administration for allowing itself to be "pushed around" by Congress and warned that legislative cuts in foreign aid had created a crisis for the United States.
In interviews, the director, J. Brian Atwood, took advantage of his imminent departure as administrator of the Agency for International Development to offer an unusually harsh assessment of the Administration and Congress, faulting them for an aid budget that he called dangerously inadequate. 
 "We have a crisis," said Mr. Atwood, who steps down on Friday after six years at A.I.D., which oversees most economic and humanitarian aid programs. "There are a lot of people around the world who depend on the United States, and we are just a very uncertain trumpet right now."
Without a larger budget to help struggling nations, he said, "you'll see democracies being defeated and radical leaders coming into office."
"Clearly," Mr. Atwood added, "you could see more countries becoming anarchies in Africa. You certainly could see that as a possibility in Russia."
In the Clinton Administration, the overall budget has declined, from $14.1 billion in 1993, when Mr. Clinton took office, to $13.7 billion this year, a decline that is more dramatic when inflation is factored in. The A.I.D. staff has been cut by one-third in that period, to 7,000.
A bill that the Senate passed on July 1 would reduce the budget by an additional 6 percent next year, to $12.9 billion. The United States spends less on foreign aid as a percentage of its gross national product than any other developed nation.
Mr. Atwood, a former career diplomat who has long been affiliated with the Democratic Party, said the White House and State Department understood the need for a larger aid budget, and he praised Mr. Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright. But he said the Administration had overall not been willing to put up enough of a fight against the Republican leadership in Congress to restore money cut from the budget.
"We have allowed ourselves to be pushed around too much," he said. "I wish we that we had expended more political capital."
The White House had no comment on Mr. Atwood's remarks.
Mr. Atwood also offered pointed criticism of Jesse Helms, the North Carolina Republican who heads the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, accusing him of "a negative exercise of power" that has hindered American foreign policy.
He also contended that a fringe of conservative lawmakers had taken control of American policy toward the United Nations, resulting in the United States's owing an estimated $1 billion in back dues. Many United Nations critics in Congress, Mr. Atwood said, practice "backdoor isolationism" and "didn't have a passport and bragged about it."
In May, Mr. Atwood withdrew his nomination to become Ambassador to Brazil, saying that it was clear that Mr. Helms would never allow his committee to consider the nomination. The two men had clashed over Mr. Atwood's success in blocking the Senator's plans to merge the Agency for International Development into the State Department.
"'I don't feel any malice toward Jesse Helms," Mr. Atwood said. "I'm a fatalist about things. So I'm not angry in that sense."
But Mr. Atwood said he was speaking critically because "I'm passionately concerned about the direction the world is heading."
"I believe we've become complacent," he said. "And I believe a large part of it is because of a failure of American leadership."
A spokesman for Mr. Helms, Marc Thiessen, had no comment on the criticism. "We wish him well in all his future endeavors," Mr. Thiessen said of Mr. Atwood.
Mr. Atwood said Mr. Helms "exercised negative power, not positive power, and usually that means that he exercises it in the context of the confirmation process."
"What I regret," Mr. Atwood added, "is that the system itself allows a single person to have so much power and that people aren't willing to hold people accountable for what they're doing to the foreign policy of the United States."
Mr. Atwood said it was startling that at a time of historic prosperity here, economic research indicates that the world's poor are actually losing ground. He pointed to statistics that the ratio of rich to poor around the world is 65 to 1, or for every $65 earned in industrial countries, $1 is earned in poor ones.
"Right now we're fat and happy," he said of the United States. "And we're growing very complacent, because we think we hear a lot about the democratic revolutions around the world. But what we don't hear about is this growing gap between rich and poor, and that is a poisonous mix. That is going to create crises in the future."
Mr. Atwood was also critical of the Administration for not having done more to defend the United Nations on Capitol Hill and to fight for the full repayment of the back dues. The Senate has passed a bill to repay $800 million in arrears in exchange for a commitment that the United States will reduce its overall contribution to the regular United Nations budget, from 25 to 20 percent.
"I use the word unconscionable," he said of the Government's treatment of the United Nations, adding that the cuts forced on the United Nations had wreaked serious damage, notably to the Office of the High Commissioner for Refugees. Mr. Atwood, who oversaw American humanitarian relief efforts in Kosovo, said the High Commissioner's office had provided "very bad leadership" in the early weeks of the crisis, when hundreds of thousands of Albanian refugees fled.
"The U.N.H.C.R. was not doing its job in the early days," he said. "They didn't have the resources. They didn't have the people. I say that their management failure was the direct result of our failures in providing them with resources."
A spokeswoman for the High Commissioner, Robyn Groves, acknowledged that "there were major problems in the early days" of the crisis.
"We admit there were weaknesses," Ms. Groves said. "I think that at base you have to look at resources."

HEADLINE: Israeli Cabinet Appointments Seem Aimed at Consolidating Barak's Control

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 5

 BODY:
By appointing loyal old-timers to two key posts in his Cabinet and keeping a third for himself, Prime Minister-elect Ehud Barak appeared today to be trying to consolidate his hold on power as he completed his Government.
Most experts here are saying Mr. Barak, 57, a highly decorated former general, is acting very much like a military commander. He is flanking himself with a Foreign Minister and a Finance Minister who are not expected to challenge or overshadow him. 
 While this could lead to a more disciplined, even accomplished Government, some believe that it also could portend an autocratic leadership style for Mr. Barak, who will serve as his own Defense Minister.
"Ehud Barak did not distribute senior portfolios to members of his faction," Sima Kadmon, a political analyst, said in the daily Yediot Ahronot today. "He cloned himself for all the major roles."
On the other hand, Mr. Barak made appointments to key social ministries -- Justice, Education and Interior -- that signal a clean break with the past. They also hold a promise of democratic-minded reform in institutions that deal with touchy issues, like the religious-secular power struggle, the question of who is Jew and the future Constitution.
Mr. Barak, after completing his ministerial appointments today, is expected to be sworn in with his Cabinet on Tuesday.
 President Clinton, who was traveling in Kentucky on Monday, briefly interrupted a tour of an electronics factory to speak to Mr. Barak on the phone for about 12 minutes, a White House spokesman said. But they did not set a date for Mr. Barak to visit Washington.
Mr. Barak faced his first defeat today, a frustration to his efforts to shore up his control. His party, One Israel, voted down his choice for the powerful role of Speaker of Parliament -- an inexperienced politician, Shalom Simchon, who one expert said was being set up to serve as Mr. Barak's "suicidal Shiite soldier on the Parliament podium."
Instead, the party -- a reconstituted version of the old Labor -- selected an ambitious Labor Party veteran, Avraham Burg, who is unlikely to be malleable. Yaron Ezrahi, a political scientist, said that while it is too early to gauge how Mr. Barak will conduct himself, the Cabinet appointments are telling.
"Look at the Cabinet as Barak's business card," he said. "It tells us two things. First, that he takes very seriously his role as leader of change. And second, in the ministries in which he wants to have direct influence, that he has a strong tendency to surround himself with people who are so loyal that they will not get in his way."
Mr. Barak today appointed Avraham Shochat, 63, of his own One Israel Party to be Finance Minister for the second time, disappointing much of the business sector.
David Levy, 61, was appointed Foreign Minister for the third time on Sunday, leaving professional diplomats somewhat indifferent.
Both men are considered somewhat outmoded in their fields, and neither is considered likely to forge bold initiatives without explicit direction from above.
When news of Mr. Shochat's appointment leaked out Sunday, the Tel Aviv stock exchange immediately dipped downward.
This was a sign that many investors fear his reputation as a policy maker who would prefer to stimulate the economy with Government spending that would expand the deficit, rather than to continue the departing Government's increasingly successful battle against inflation.
His admirers, however, saw as positives the rapid growth rates and surging foreign investments that characterized his previous term. And Mr. Shochat, in brief comments today, indicated that he might pick up where he left off.
"I'd like to reassure the business community," Mr. Shochat said today, "that we're going to pursue a very responsible policy that will be good for the economy, a policy of growth."
Also today, Mr. Barak appointed Yossi Beilin, a leftist political scientist and one of the most independent thinkers in his party, to be Justice Minister. A high-minded champion of civic culture, Mr. Beilin will take over a Justice Ministry that was considered tainted by the departing minister, Tsahi Hanegbi, who has been under investigation for corruption.
It also gives Mr. Beilin, who has worked hard to build a relationship with the ultra-Orthodox, a key role in managing relations between the judiciary and the religious sector. And he will have a strong hand in shaping the evolving Constitution -- a very sensitive issue for the Orthodox.
In another appointment of a progressive, Mr. Barak previously appointed Yossi Sarid, leader of the leftist Meretz Party, to take over the Education Ministry from the religious party that has been in control.
He also took the Interior Ministry, which handles delicate issues involving citizenship and Jewish identity, from the ultra-Orthodox Shas Party and gave it to Natan Sharansky, the Russian immigrant leader.
Mr. Barak today appointed Shlomo Ben-Ami, an intellectual who was the top vote-getter in the party's internal primaries, to be Internal Security Minister, in charge of the police. Mr. Ben-Ami is not a law enforcement specialist; his strengths are foreign and social policies.
Some perceived this as an insult, but others believed that Mr. Ben-Ami could make needed reforms in the police culture while expanding his domain to include social issues like relations between Israeli Arabs and Jews.
Shas will control the Religious Affairs, Health, Labor and Welfare and Infrastructure Ministries. The settlers' party, the National Religious Party, will run the Housing Ministry.
Mr. Barak is facing severe criticism from women's groups. Although he pledged to include more women in his Government than any previous leader, he ended up appointing only one -- Dalia Itzkik of One Israel, who will be Environment Minister.
And he appointed no Arab politicians as ministers or deputy ministers, although Israeli Arab voters, a crucial bloc, supported him nearly unanimously.
Mr. Barak intends to expand his Cabinet of 18 members to 24 members after taking office, so it is possible he will include more women or an Arab at that time.
Over all, it seems likely that he has interpreted his resounding election victory as a personal rather than a party mandate, and that he is constructing a system that allows him maximum control.

HEADLINE: Rising Lake Slowly Stalks a North Dakota Town

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: DEVIL'S LAKE, N.D.

 BODY:
Jim Yri, a tall, sunburned farmer with movie star looks and the folksy style of Jimmy Stewart, has battled North Dakota blizzards and wheat fungus and, lately, appallingly low crop prices. But now he is in a struggle with a lake that he is afraid he just might lose.
The lake, the namesake for this little town, began rising seven years ago when it was just a sliver on the horizon beyond Mr. Yri's white clapboard farmhouse west of here. 
 At first, he shrugged it off as no more than the natural consequence of especially heavy snowfall and rain. But each year the lake has climbed higher, and now the water is in his yard, creeping toward his basement, like some incredible science-fiction monster, threatening to drive him off the land.
"You plow a field and come back a week later and the water has taken the field," Mr. Yri (pronounced Erie) said the other day.
He and thousands of other people around Devil's Lake on the rolling prairie of northeastern North Dakota are caught up in a strange, gradual flood like nothing modern America has ever seen.
Inch by inch, the lake has been swelling across a gently sloping basin without an outlet, forcing nearly 400 families to move their homes as it swallowed up 80,000 acres of farmland, three state parks, miles of country roads and perhaps a million trees. Devil's Lake has tripled in size and now sprawls over nearly 200 square miles, making it more than eight times the size of Manhattan.
Unlike river floods that crush towns in a flash, the destruction at Devil's Lake has come one or two houses at a time, acre by acre, utility pole by utility pole, never with a single surge stunning enough to make the national news.
"I don't think people realize the severity of what's happening here," said Tom LaMotte, the owner of several businesses in Devil's Lake, a town of 10,000 people that is still above water because the rising lake is being held back by a man-built wall of rock and earth.
Devil's Lake and the Great Salt Lake in Utah are among a very few lakes without natural drainage. Their waters rise and fall depending on rain and snow and the saturation of surrounding lands, scientists say, and North Dakota has been in a prolonged wet cycle. The Great Salt Lake flooded in the mid-1980's with less damage than is now being experienced at Devil's Lake, officials say, and while the Salt Lake has risen over the last three years, it has caused little harm.
The slow-motion destruction by Devil's Lake, coupled with gnawing uncertainty about what the lake will do next -- level off and create a booming resort area or keep rising and destroying -- is straining the economy and people's nerves. If being forced to leave were inevitable, many people would leave now. But no one really wants to go. Most of them have been here all their lives.
They like the quiet beauty of the lake, the vermilion explosions at sunset and the serenity of communities where homes and cars are seldom locked. A good many people recognize that if the lake ever does settle down, their property values are likely to skyrocket because of the resort possibilities. Still, nearly everyone would have been happier if the lake had just remained a nice place to visit on a Sunday afternoon.
Federal and state agencies have poured more than $300 million into temporary measures: building dikes, keeping roads open and moving homes out of harm's way. And in early June, President Clinton authorized spending tens of millions for more of the same. But people are beginning to grumble that the money has been wasted.
"Instead of building up the roads a little more every year, they should be finding some permanent solution," said Jarvis Haugeberg, who runs the grain elevator on a shrinking peninsula in Church's Ferry, 20 miles to the northwest. "But they just keep making new studies and arguing about what to do."
Mayor Fred Bott of Devil's Lake, along with just about everyone else around here, argues for hacking an opening in one side of the lake so it can be drained to a tolerable level, into the Sheyenne River. But environmental groups and people in several North Dakota towns worry that any significant drainage could bring flooding elsewhere. Canadians also oppose the drainage, because the Sheyenne runs into the Red River, which flows into their country.
The Army Corps of Engineers agreed in early June that an outlet should be built. But the corps proposed waiting until Devil's Lake had risen seven additional feet, something the engineers think could take until 2006 but many residents fear could happen much more quickly.
North Dakota officials could hardly believe their ears. Gov. Edward T. Schafer and the state's three members of Congress said that letting the lake rise that much higher would inundate 75,000 acres more and could cost up to $200 million more for dikes and roads. So the debate continues. And so does the uncertainty.
"It's always eating at you," Mr. Yri said as he and his wife, Diane, talked in their kitchen. "There's a lot of mental depression around here. You just don't feel like doing anything. Why bother? Next week it will be under water."
At her small, white-shingled home in Minnewaukan, at the edge of the lake, 20 miles west of here, Elizabeth Stensby, a 72-year-old widow, says she keeps asking herself, "Can I stay or do I have to leave?" Her house, where she raised six children, was eight miles from the lake when the water started rising. Now the water is edging into her back yard.
A golf course just across the highway is under water and the town has trucked in sand to make a beach. A few blocks away, the lake is advancing on the high school football field and the main classroom building. Allan Nord, a carpenter who lives nearby, is talking about opening a bait shop.
Since 1993, Devil's Lake has risen nearly 25 feet, to a level higher than it has been in more than 100 years, scientists said. The wall of clay and rocks holding it back from the town, built mainly in the last three years, is seven miles long. Without the wall, most of the town's small, brown-brick business district and its wide, tree-shaded streets and modest homes would be roof-deep in water, said State Senator Vern Thompson. Yet for many people, the dike is as unnerving as it is protective.
"Like anything that was constructed as quickly as the dike, you wonder, 'Is it really secure?' " said Paul Keating, the owner of the local Radio Shack franchise. "It's holding back 30 miles of water, 25 feet deep. The big dams and reservoirs are concrete. This is just dirt. If we get a major thunderstorm, how much lightening can it take? What would a tornado do to it?"
The Red Cross has been giving classes in what to do in a flood emergency. Its evacuation plan links everyone's address to the nearest landmark to help rescue teams find them. Tammy Rutten, who manages a water-tower-painting business with her husband, Tim, says she always drives with her windows rolled down so that she can "bail out" in case her car goes into the water. And Mrs. Yri has enrolled her children in swimming classes.
Mr. Keating, at Radio Shack, like many owners of small businesses in Devil's Lake, is barely surviving. For some merchants, sales are down at least 25 percent this year. Investors are holding back on starting new projects.
For people as far as 50 miles away, going shopping in Devil's Lake used to mean a pleasant drive through fields of wheat and barley and sunflowers. But those roads that have not disappeared have become scary causeways with waves chewing at their edges. Heavy trucks loaded with rock and clay thunder along from dawn to dusk, and construction detours often turn a 20-minute trip into an ordeal of an hour or more.
But not everyone is suffering. Contractors working on the dikes and roads and moving endangered houses are doing very well. They, in turn, are making the cash registers ring for other businesses, with their workers buying fuel, staying in motels and recreational vehicle parks and eating in restaurants. Fishing and duck hunting have never been better, so tourism is up. Rooms that often languished at the Woodland Resort are booked solid. One farmer has converted his flooded land into a fishing camp, and the Sioux Indians at the Spirit Lake Nation on the southern shore are building a nearly 200-slip marina just behind their gambling casino.
No one here wants to seem ungrateful for the Government help Devil's Lake has received, but many people say they cannot help thinking that if it was not such a small community, if it was not in the middle of nowhere and if it could muster a bit more political clout, the lake problem would somehow have been solved by now.
"The bus being hit by a train doesn't have enough passengers," said Rick LaFleur, who runs a family business that distributes jukeboxes and pinball machines.
Mr. Yri has begun to wonder whether he can keep working the land the way his father did. He has sold off the last of his 50 beef cattle because the water has taken their grazing land, and he is talking about moving his house to higher ground. But he worries that the water will eventually take the main roads and put him out of business.
"Without the roads, we're an island," Mr. Yri said. "People felt the lake couldn't keep rising, but it just keeps coming."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Japan's Executives Say Business Mood Improves
The Japanese central bank's quarterly assessment of business sentiment showed that the perception of business conditions among more than 9,000 executives who responded in June was still negative, but improving. But the survey's so-called diffusion index remained solidly negative, meaning that pessimistic executives still widely outnumbered optimists.
The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stocks rose 1.13 percent, to 18,135.06 -- its highest close in 21 months. Page C4. 

Right Address, Return to Sender
A new regulation from the United States Postal Service that requires holders of private mail boxes to include the prefix PMB in their address has prompted a flurry of indignant letters to Congress. The regulations also require box holders to submit their home addresses to the post office. Around two million Americans rent boxes at 10,000 stores such as Pakmail and Mail Boxes Etc., often to lend their business addresses prestige, sometimes because they have no fixed address. Store owners and mailbox renters say the new rules invade their privacy and pose a financial threat to their businesses. C2.
 
N.T.T. Plans Global Effort
Junichiro Miyazu, the head of Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, intends to use a new law to transform Japan's telecommunications giant into a global player to battle with the likes of AT&T. The new law, which took effect July 1 after a decade of dithering in Japan's Parliament, reshapes N.T.T. and permits it for the first time to compete directly in overseas markets. C4.
 
Cnet Profits, but Loses
Cnet was one of the very first companies to build a business on the World Wide Web, but it has rarely benefited from the special dispensations that investors accord most Internet companies. Market Place. C8.
 
Bid for General Nutrition
Royal Numico, Europe's top baby-food maker, said it was offering $2.5 billion to buy the General Nutrition Companies as it sought to become the global leader in specialized foods. Numico has been growing through acquisitions, and said it saw the best opportunities in nutritional supplements. Together with General Nutrition, Numico will have $3 billion in sales. C7.
 
20 Questions for Madison Avenue
Keith Richards a film critic? And 19 other questions about the advertising business. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C9.
 
Jakarta's Top Bankruptcy Lawyer
Indonesia's new bankruptcy law -- designed by the International Monetary Fund to give creditors a legal cudgel to force the country's deeply indebted and well-connected corporate elite to pay up -- has brought considerable success to one lawyer in particular. C5.
 
New Problem for Coke in Europe
Faint traces of fungicide have been found on five cans of Coca-Cola, the Ministry of Agriculture in the southwest German state of Baden-Wurttemberg said. Separate tests showed that bacteria found in samples of a mineral water bottled by Coca-Cola in Poland were not hazardous. C4.
 
U.S. Markets Reopen
The stock market and other financial markets in the United States reopen today after being closed yesterday in observance of the Fourth of July. Most overseas markets were open yesterday. Among foreign stock market indexes, Russia's has had the strongest performance so far this year, with a gain of 113 percent in dollar terms in the first half. Belgium and Colombia were the laggards, with declines of 21 percent. Yesterday, the story on European markets was oil, as crude oil surged in commodity trading in London and Total Fina's bid for Elf Acquitaine lifted French stocks. Asian markets were also higher. HEADLINE: Conflict in Kashmir Stirs Fund-Raising Fervor Among Indian Immigrants

BYLINE: By SOMINI SENGUPTA 

 BODY:
For years, earthquakes, floods and other natural calamities back home have kindled patriotic sentiments among immigrants in this country, compelling them to open their checkbooks in the spirit of good will. Now, in a moment of unprecedented nationalist fervor, Indian immigrants in New York City and across the United States are sending home dollars to aid Indian Army soldiers involved in the conflict in Kashmir, the contested mountainous terrain on the India-Pakistan border.
Over the last several weeks, Indian immigrants have been lobbying members of the United States Congress, writing letters to the editors of American newspapers and, most notably, writing checks and transmitting thousands of dollars over the Internet to organizations apparently set up to aid Indian soldiers and their families. Appeals abound on such Web sites and in Indian-American newspapers for donations to the "brave" or "martyred" "jawans" -- foot soldiers in Hindi -- who have been killed or injured in battle on the icy mountaintops of Kashmir. 
 "It's amazing what the response is," said Yash Paul Soi, an engineer for New York City's Environmental Protection Department who is the president of the Federation of Indian Associations, a coalition of dozens of regional Indian organizations. The coalition established a fund three weeks ago to collect contributions for Indian soldiers and their families.
"Our roots are there," he said. "We are very proud to be Indian-Americans of course, but those are our roots."
Because of the variety of fund-raising, it is impossible to tell the total amount donated so far.
As of July 1, the Indian Army's Central Welfare Fund had collected more than $23,300, according to the Army Web site.
The Indian Embassy in Washington has been receiving checks in the mail -- about $10,000 in the last three weeks, said its spokesman, Navtej Sarna. It has turned over the funds to the Prime Minister's Defense Fund, the Government body that receives donations during times of national crises. But it is likely, Mr. Sarna said, that Indians in this country have sent much more directly to the Indian Government and charities. Various other groups have each collected tens of thousands of dollars.
Mr. Sarna said the money being raised has far outweighed fund-raising for natural calamities back home in the past.
"This has been much more than anything in recent years," Mr. Sarna said. "It's not comparable to any natural disaster. This is an external threat and perceived as such. That's why the response is that much more nationalistic."
Details on Pakistani-American fund-raising efforts were not immediately available.
The latest confrontation in Kashmir began more than two months ago, when Muslim guerrillas crossed into the Indian-held part of the state. India has accused Pakistan of sponsoring the insurgents, while Pakistan says they are independent operators seeking the Kashmiris' right to self-determination. Kashmir is India's only state with a Muslim majority, and it has been the focus of three wars between India, a secular but Hindu-majority country, and Pakistan, an Islamic nation, since the partitioning of the subcontinent in 1947.
The drumbeat for dollars for Indian soldiers and their families signals a kind of nationalism that has long been a constant fixture in immigrant communities nationwide. The difference perhaps is the extent to which technology has aided the ability of immigrants today to divert precious dollars to various causes back home.
In this case, several Web sites offer instructions on how to contribute. The Icici Bank, an Indian financial institution, has set up an account at a Manhattan bank, the First Union Bank International, where people can deposit checks.
The American arm of the Bharatiya Janata Party, the Hindu nationalist political party, has sent E-mail to its supporters, urging them to contribute to the India Development and Relief Fund, a Maryland-based charity associated with Hindu nationalist groups in India, so that they can write it off on their taxes. The group is hoping to raise $50,000.
So far, the India Development and Relief Fund has raised about $25,000, said its president, Vinod Prakash. Mr. Prakash, a retired World Bank economist who has lived in this country for 35 years, said he hoped to double the amount that he had collected so far.
"It's emotionally very charged," he said.

HEADLINE: The Handwriting On the Post-It Note;
Image and Returns Suffer at 3M

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL

 BODY:
Here at the technology center of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Corporation, scientists are tinkering with stickier adhesives, longer-lasting abrasives, glare-free reflective signs -- indeed, with improvements on virtually every product, from the esoteric to the mundane, that 3M makes.
The road to product nirvana, the scientists say, is a hot new technology called microreplication, a way to place thousands of identical microscopic shapes on the surfaces of all kinds of materials, from sandpaper to flat-panel computer screens. 
"Microreplication is reinventing our core businesses," said Robert S. Finocchiaro, a 3M technical director, who runs the microreplication project.
But the mood is a bit more somber across the street, where the corporate types are. Try as they will, they cannot shake Wall Street's perception of 3M as a boring, low-technology drone whose glory days ended with Scotch tape and Post-it notes.
"You put it next to a machinery company, and the stock performance looks the same," said B. Alexander Henderson, who follows 3M for Prudential Securities Research.
The problem is not just image, though; it is performance. For two years, 3M has consistently missed earnings estimates, and its revenues, half of them from foreign shores, have been stuck at $15 billion. Its shares, which sold near $100 in July 1997, drifted to $70 by April. The stock has rebounded some, closing at $88.875 on Friday, but many 3M watchers say the rise comes from investor disaffection with Internet stocks and hopes for an Asian economic recovery, not from confidence in 3M's management.
"They just don't have the killer instinct when it comes to financial returns," said Jack L. Kelly, who follows 3M for Goldman, Sachs.
Is 3M, once a darling of Wall Street, now just another badly managed also-ran? Or is it still a new-product machine that had a bad case of the hiccups last year?
Critics of the company have accused Livio D. DeSimone, 3M's chairman since 1991, of everything from losing 3M's innovative touch to refusing to cut costs to mismanaging inventories to sticking with humdrum products too long. Some have even put pressure on the board to ask Mr. DeSimone, who turns 63 this month, to step down before the mandatory retirement age of 65.
"He knows an incredible amount about product, but he just doesn't have a good enough grip on daily operations," one analyst said.
Mr. DeSimone -- widely known as Desi, a variation on the start of his last name -- tries to take the criticism in stride, but it clearly annoys him. He says he is cutting costs, tightening procedures and getting products to markets faster.
Although Mr. DeSimone, a chemical engineer who has been with 3M for 32 years, acknowledges that maybe he should have bitten those bullets sooner, he maintains that more of 3M's fiscal woes can be traced to the strong dollar and the weak Asian economies than to his mistakes.
"I became dumb all of a sudden in 1998," he said. "Well, no one thought I was dumb in 1997, and hopefully, I'll be seen as smart again in 1999."
Investors are not so easily persuaded. "The U.S. still accounts for half of revenues, too, and the economy here isn't bad," said one portfolio manager.
And Mr. Kelly of Goldman, Sachs said, "Too often, they try to sweep everything under the convenient rug of currency problems."
The company does have fans. Perkin-Elmer, the life-sciences concern now known as the PE Corporation, chose 3M in February as a joint venture partner for genetic analysis. Robert Sprague, a manager at the Xerox Corporation, cites 3M's extensive manufacturing experience as the reason Xerox recently picked 3M to manufacture its "electronic paper" -- reusable rubbery sheets embedded with billions of tiny electrically charged balls that can be written on with an electronic wand.
And even though he feels the stock is fully valued, Jonathan Rosenzweig, an analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, said of 3M, "They have a knack for taking something that exists, changing it a bit and leveraging it into an entirely new product."
Actually, trying to categorize 3M at all is an exercise in frustration.
Founded in 1902 to mine corundum, an abrasive mineral, the company quickly shifted to processing the leftover grit into sandpaper and grinding wheels. Over the years it branched out into industries as unrelated as thermofaxing, the copying method that preceded xerography, and adhesives. It has pulled out of many businesses, including copiers and a bank it once owned, but it still makes 50,000 products, ranging from optical fibers to wound dressings.
Still, 3M is not a classic conglomerate, one that could easily be broken up. Its 40 divisions are as technologically intertwined as an arterial network. "People who ask how dressings mesh with adhesives don't realize that both are sticky," Mr. DeSimone said.
Dow Jones lists 3M under diversified technology, while the Value Line Investment newsletter groups it with diversified chemicals. And Jeffrey J. Zekauskas, a chemical analyst with Schroder & Company, said, "3M technologies, especially in electronics, are relevant to the analysis of specialty chemical companies." Still, neither he nor any other chemical analyst covers 3M.
Instead, it is watched by the same people who track Xerox, Eastman Kodak and other image and document processing companies -- a business 3M left when it spun off Imation a few years ago.
Mr. DeSimone would like 3M, which pumps 6 percent of revenues into research -- higher than most industrial companies -- to be described an innovator, pure and simple. "We're a specialty materials company that takes related technologies into seemingly unrelated end-products," he said.
Microreplication may be the premier example. It involves placing identical three-dimensional structures on a surface, changing how that surface reflects light, wears down or otherwise acts differently from the undoctored version.
For example, old-style abrasive belts for metalworking must be replaced as soon as the abrasive surface is worn away. 3M now uses microreplication to pile cutting surfaces on top of one another, so that when the top surface is worn down, a fresh cutting surface emerges. The company says its new belts, sold under the name Trizact, last up to five times as long as older products.
Innovation is how 3M has made its name. It was here that Post-it notes were born when one employee, frustrated at losing the strips he used to mark text in his church hymnal, enlisted the aid of another, who was trying to develop a seemingly oxymoronic product, a nonbinding adhesive.
Innovation has not been limited to products. 3M was one of the first companies to install a dual-career ladder, a now-popular method for promoting researchers without forcing them out of their labs into management. (Some 3M scientists complain they are still paid less than their management counterparts; 3M says the complaints are baseless.)
Researchers are allowed to devote 15 percent of their time to projects that pique their interest, even those on which management has pulled the plug. That has caused some analysts to criticize 3M for undisciplined management, but Mr. DeSimone defends the practice.
"If you want to encourage innovation, you have to close your eyes when people are so excited about a project that they refuse to stop," he said, noting that Thinsulate, a big-selling clothing insulation material, resulted from a project he had officially scuttled.
When researchers do come up with something promising, they are encouraged to shop it around to all the businesses. A pharmaceuticals researcher invented a dosage dispenser that mixes two drugs together; the adhesives division adapted it to mix pastes that dry as they are applied. A non-heat-generating lighting system developed at a 3M lab in Japan, primarily for use in supermarket coolers, is selling well for architectural lighting in Italy.
The technology swapping is not by happenstance. Researchers hold an annual event, patterned on a trade show but open only to 3M people, where they run booths displaying their latest inventions.
The automotive division picked up a new way to make headlights when some adhesive researchers displayed a multilayer film. "Many of the 'Eurekas!' at 3M come from this forum," said William E. Coyne, senior vice president for research.
By some measurements, 3M's innovation formula has been wildly successful. The company received 611 patents last year, the 11th most of any American company. Management has long insisted that 3M derive one-third of revenues from products that are no more than four years old, and 10 percent from products that are new each year.
Still, innovation could not protect 3M's financial results last year. Its revenues dipped to $15.02 billion from $15.07 billion in 1997. Operating income fared even worse, dropping to $2.04 billion from $2.68 billion. And net income and per-share earnings were practically halved -- $1.18 billion, or 2.88 a diluted share, in 1998, down from $2.12 billion, or $5.06 a share, in 1997.
"When the dollar is strengthening against every currency, geographic diversity is a burden as well as a strength," said Ronald O. Baukol, 3M's executive vice president in charge of international operations.
Mr. DeSimone has tried hard to shore up the numbers. Last year -- much too late, some analysts say -- he promised to cut 4,500 jobs by the end of 1999, bringing total employment down to 71,500. He sold some small businesses and closed some factories overseas. Now, he is trying to set up the remaining factories to make a greater variety of products, so that 3M can more easily shift production to countries with favorable currency exchange rates.
Perhaps most important, he has introduced a program, called Pacing Plus, to single out research projects with the potential to yield huge revenues -- to "change the nature of competition," as 3M puts it -- and speed them to market. Products from this program, like parts for ink-jet printer cartridges and environmentally safe fluids for cleaning electronic components, accounted for $1 billion in revenue last year, and Mr. Coyne predicted that a third of 3M's revenues would come from such projects -- probably most employing some form of microreplication -- by 2005.
"We've spent too much time on products that provide incremental, not significant, growth," Mr. Coyne said.
Still, 3M is taking pains to see that smaller projects are not eclipsed. Its three-year-old corporate enterprise department finances technologies, like a technique for time-releasing insect pheromones that might one day be used in pesticides, that no division is ready to take to market.
The company is even licensing innovations it cannot immediately use -- an unusual move for the generally secretive company. It licensed a method for making flexible printing plates to DuPont and it is looking for a licensee for a process for making glass panels for flat-screen televisions.
"Years ago we would have made the panels ourselves, but now we realize it's silly to go into glass manufacturing," Mr. Finocchiaro said.
Will 3M, once a regular on lists of most admired companies, regain its Wall Street sheen?
Many analysts say that it is finally on the right track, but they are skeptical nonetheless.
"Yes, 3M has changed," Mr. Henderson of Prudential said, summing up the prevailing Wall Street view. "But the question remains: has it changed enough?"

HEADLINE: A Pledge of Federal Help For the Economic Byways

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: HAZARD, Ky., July 5

 BODY:
The Clinton Years have been lush for lawyers, investment bankers and Internet explorers. But some pockets of America remain largely untouched by the prosperity of the 1990's, and President Clinton is devoting much of this week to bringing them compassion and the hope of new jobs.
Here in eastern Kentucky, where poverty and unemployment run two to three times higher than the national averages, the President today presented a package of proposals intended to spur investment among the idle coal fields. 
 Mr. Clinton hopes to use Federal tax credits and loan guarantees to inspire private companies to build plants and stores in Appalachia to serve a population that the economic boom has largely passed by.
It is a familiar strategy for this Administration, except that the proposed "new markets" are in economically distressed regions of the United States, not in Zimbabwe or Ukraine. The Administration has aggressively used Government tax breaks and loan subsidies to encourage investment by American corporations in developing countries, but it has never focused similar efforts in a systematic way on struggling communities in the United States.
"Even though this is a blessed time for America, not all Americans have been blessed by it," Mr. Clinton said before a heat-wilted crowd in this mountain town. "This is a time to bring more jobs and investment and hope to the areas of our country that have not fully participated in this economic recovery. We have an obligation to do it."
He picked the right place to make his point. David Deal, 58, a laid-off medical supply worker from the depressed coal-mining town of Cumberland, about 40 miles away, said that Government officials always talked about bringing jobs and investment to this region, but that the waiting continued.
"Lyndon Johnson was here in '64 but all the things he was talking about haven't reached down to the people here," Mr. Deal said. "Clinton keeps talking about wanting us off welfare, but he hasn't brought us any jobs."
One of his neighbors, Darlene Hall, 41, said that she was organizing a prayer rally in Cumberland next week to try to enlist God in the search for employment. And Ms. Hall said she had a message for industrialists looking for a stable work force.
"We are not pick-and-shovel uneducated people in the mountains," she said. "We are hard-working people, used to working in the mines. We are educated and we want to work."
With an entourage of corporate executives, members of Congress, Cabinet officers and the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, Mr. Clinton is embarked on a four-day, six-state tour of islands of poverty among the general prosperity. He plans to visit Clarksdale, Miss., a poor town in the Mississippi Delta; East St. Louis, Ill.; the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota; a barrio in Phoenix and the Watts neighborhood of Los Angeles.
He takes a briefcase full of what he hopes are tools to create jobs, including community development financial institutions, empowerment zones and enterprise communities, America's private investment companies, small-business investment companies, new-markets venture capital firms and new-markets lending companies.
Taken together, the new and existing programs are intended to prompt as much as $15 billion in private-sector investment in poor urban and rural areas over the next five years. Most of $1 billion in Federal subsidies to underwrite the programs would require Congressional action, but Mr. Clinton has not sent all the specific legislation to Capitol Hill.
Critics have questioned the timing of the initiative, coming in the seventh year of Mr. Clinton's Presidency, when he longer has need for the votes of suburban soccer moms or the financial support of wealthy donors. He has spent countless days canvassing the prosperous precincts of the nation over the last six and a half years, bringing comfort to the comfortable and shoveling up campaign contributions from equity-rich Democrats in Beverly Hills, Silicon Valley, Manhattan and Palm Beach.
Presidential aides said that Mr. Clinton spent his early years in office insuring the general welfare through fiscal discipline and targeted tax cuts that had cemented the fortunes of the middle class. Now he can turn to the 35 million Americans who remain mired in poverty as the tide of prosperity lifts the boats of others around them, they said.
"The fact that the country is doing so well right now may, indeed, provide a better atmosphere for the President to put this challenge to the private sector," said Gene Sperling, the White House's chief economic adviser. "In a period of prosperity like this, a Presidential message of bringing everybody along may be more well received, and you may be able to do more good now than if you were trying to do that at a time when the country, when everyone around the country, was hurting."
Today Mr. Clinton announced $1.5 million in housing and economic development grants to five eastern Kentucky groups from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The money is intended to provide improved housing for migrant workers, job training and subsidized mortgage loans, the department said.
Before he spoke here in Hazard, Mr. Clinton stopped in Tyner, an eastern Kentucky hamlet of mobile homes and 100 souls in Jackson County.
Mr. Clinton sought refuge from the wicked heat under a spreading walnut tree and spoke with Jean Collett, 48, who recently left her job as a cook at a Dairy Queen to care for her father, Ray Pennington, who suffers from emphysema and breathes with the aid of a portable oxygen tank.
Mr. Clinton sipped from a can of Mountain Dew and held Mr. Pennington's hand as Mrs. Collett explained the hardships of life in their pocket of Appalachia. Bank loans are hard to come by, she said, because lenders demand collateral, of which she has none.
"We don't even apply for them," she told the President.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 2; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Minnesota's Ventura Tries to Lure Weicker Into the Presidential Race

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn., July 5

 BODY:
Five winters ago, Lowell P. Weicker Jr. moved out of the Connecticut governor's mansion, apparently ending a 30-year career as one of the nation's best-known political mavericks. At 6 foot 6 and with a voice to match, he had tormented the Republican Party from within as a United States Senator, then led Connecticut as that uncommon American political animal, an independent.
After leaving Hartford, he settled into life as the lord of Applejack Farm, a former orchard in this town of private drives and tradesmen's entrances, taking plenty of time away for tennis, bird-watching and scuba diving with his seven sons and seven grandchildren. But he never lost his taste for the game that had been his life. He flirted with running for President as an independent in 1996, drawing national headlines, then backed away. 
 Now, strategists for Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota are trying to entice Mr. Weicker to offer himself as a Reform Party nominee for President. And Mr. Weicker, 68, sounds very much like a man who is willing to be enticed. In a conference call last week, he gave two of Governor Ventura's top aides permission to promote his candidacy as they prepared for a Reform Party national convention later this month.
The result could be an entertaining clash of egos in a Presidential race that had begun to look like it might be short on surprises. Ross Perot, the Reform Party's nominee in 1992 and 1996, has remained coy about his own plans for 2000. His support dropped from 19 percent of the vote in his first election to 8 percent last time.
So Governor Ventura, the former professional wrestler whose upset victory as a Reform Party candidate last November gave new hope to independents everywhere, has argued that the party needs new leaders if it is to grow. Working a second front, Mr. Ventura has endorsed a veteran of the term limits movement to replace the current party chairman, Russell J. Verney, a longtime lieutenant of Mr. Perot.
Mr. Weicker's prospects within the Reform Party may depend on the ferocious internal battle that leaders expect at the party's convention, to be held in Dearborn, Mich., from July 23 to 25. As part of his mission, Governor Ventura encouraged Mr. Weicker to run for President during a meeting in Manhattan last month, according to aides to both men. The meeting had been scheduled for half an hour and stretched to more than three, participants said.
"Would I like to run?" Mr. Weicker asked last week as he relaxed on his sun porch in a wrinkled French-cuff shirt with no cuff links. "Yes, sure -- it's been my business, and I still think I'm pretty good at the business."
Unprompted, he began reciting the pros and cons. "Do I care about the fact that you might get your head handed to you?" he asked. "Doesn't bother me -- never has. The opportunity to set a national dialogue on important subjects -- that's hugely appealing. I'm not afraid of handling myself, not afraid of the crunch -- not afraid of the campaign. What's the other side of the coin? I'm enjoying my family and enjoying a life style that I haven't had in my whole adult life."
Family may not prove much of a hurdle. Mr. Weicker's 21-year-old son, Sonny, teased his father, "Dad, you're running again." Mr. Weicker cautioned, "We don't know that, son."
His wife, Claudia T. Weicker, 52, a former Democratic aide on Capitol Hill, said she was trying not to think about it, but seemed ready. "Is there a void?" she asked. "Yes, there's a void. There need to be people spending more time advocating the cause of our children and of our minorities."
Several Reform Party officials said that although Governor Ventura has said he does not plan to run for President next year, he wants the Reform Party to field a credible candidate who will attract at least 5 percent of the vote, preserving the party's Federal financing and ballot status so he can run in 2004.
But the main motive for boosting Mr. Weicker, according to Douglas E. Friedline, who was Governor Ventura's campaign manager and now handles his licensing deals, is to give the Reform Party a face besides that of Mr. Perot. "Perot got us where we are, but now he's a liability," Mr. Friedline said. "Governor Ventura feels we need new leadership if we're going to grow."
Supporters of Mr. Weicker contend that an independent should have broad appeal this year -- partly because of what they believe will be a backlash against the ravenous fund-raising by Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the leading Republican candidate, and partly because of disgust with the behavior by President Clinton that led to his impeachment in December.
Mr. Weicker, who endorsed Mr. Clinton in both his Presidential races, said he favored conviction on the articles of impeachment because the President apparently had lied in a legal proceeding.
"Right now, the country has to rebuild its faith in the Presidency," Mr. Weicker said.
Dean M. Barkley, who was chairman of Governor Ventura's campaign last year and remains a close adviser, said Mr. Weicker would be the most promising candidate short of Colin L. Powell, the retired general, who said through a spokesman that he still had no plans to seek any national office.
"Lowell Weicker shares with Governor Ventura the ability to speak from the heart and to show people that he understands their disgust with the political establishment," Mr. Barkley said, adding that he hoped Mr. Weicker would "run against the political process itself."
Based on the vote Mr. Perot received as the Reform Party's Presidential nominee in 1996, the party qualifies for $13 million in Federal funds for the general election, and can automatically be on the ballot in at least 19 states. Political analysts said that a Reform Party candidate could throw the outcome of the Presidential race in almost any state into doubt by attracting at least 10 percent of the vote.
Governor Ventura sent an E-mail message to the roughly 400 delegates last week endorsing a retired financial consultant, Jack Gargan, 68, for chairman to replace Mr. Verney. Mr. Gargan announced that one of his first steps would be to move the party headquarters from Dallas to his home state, Florida, which was seen as a signal that Governor Ventura was trying to take control of the party from Mr. Perot's forces.
Mr. Verney, the current chairman, said he has not decided whether to run again. Mr. Perot was traveling and could not be reached for comment, his spokesman said.
Reform Party leaders said that aside from Governor Ventura, General Powell and Mr. Weicker, the party's wish list for Presidential candidates is short. The only other names that came up during more than a dozen interviews were former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who now is seeking the Democratic nomination, and B. Thomas Golisano, the Independence Party candidate for governor of New York in the past two elections.
Mr. Weicker is already encountering some static within the Reform Party, in part because he has never been associated with the movement. Some members are trading E-mail sniping at Mr. Weicker as being too establishment for their taste.
That notion might surprise those who remember him as the "Watergate white knight," who conducted his own investigation into wrongdoing by President Nixon, a fellow Republican.
After leaving public life, Mr. Weicker served for three years as a visiting professor at the University of Virginia, his law alma mater. He serves on six corporate boards and heads a study of possible links between environmental conditions and health problems, including asthma.
Mr. Weicker, who swims at 6:30 each morning at the Y.W.C.A. in Greenwich, said he wants to insure a centrist, independent option for voters. In his comments, a supporter might -- just might -- hear the early rumblings of a stump speech.
"The only way you're going to shape up American politics is by a third force, nationally," he said. "Politics -- the intellectual business -- is no different than the economic business. When you have an economic monopoly, you get high prices and bad products. You've got an intellectual monopoly in this country, and you've got bad ideas and bad candidates."

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
For First Lady, Taking Detour On Geography

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
The "Listening to New Yorkers" discussions that Hillary Rodham Clinton is planning for the exploratory phase of her Senate campaign will focus on familiar political issues: health care, public schools and the economy.
In truth, though, there is a more fundamental mission to these forums, and it has less to do with the problems facing the nation than with the problems confronting Mrs. Clinton's candidacy. 
 The real goal, Mrs. Clinton's advisers acknowledge, is less to educate her than to address what they see as her most serious vulnerability -- that she is seeking to represent in the Senate a state where she has never lived.
This is a case where what a candidate says may not matter, and according to her advisers, Mrs. Clinton plans to say very little of substance in the months ahead, starting with the six "Listening to New Yorkers" forums that she has scheduled this week in central New York.
Instead, her intention, aides said yesterday, is to spend so much time in New York, with a procession of cookie-cutter forums intended to produce a daily diet of television images, that her trips to the state become as routine as a visit by the First Lady can be. In that way, her aides hope that Mrs. Clinton, a native of Illinois, will become as familiar a part of the state's political geography as, say, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"In a couple of weeks, people are going to look and say, 'She's still out there,' " Mandy Grunwald, one of Mrs. Clinton's strategists, asserted. "And a couple of weeks later, they're going to look again and say she's STILL out there."
Whether Mrs. Clinton, who will formally register an exploratory committee for her campaign with Federal election officials today, can succeed at this strategy is open to question but is critical to her ambitions in New York.
Aides to Mr. Giuliani, the Republican who is also interested in running for the seat, are dubious that she can, as are some independent political analysts following the race.
Still, there is a factor working in her favor: The calendar. There are 16 months until the vote to replace Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the Democrat who is not running for re-election in 2000, and that is a huge stretch of time in American politics.
On the one hand, such a long campaign presents the risk of overexposure or campaign missteps. But it might also give Mrs. Clinton enough time so that by next year she can, with some credibility, claim ties to a state where she has never lived a day. And even if she can not quite get away with that assertion, it is a reasonable bet that over time, the issue of carpetbagging will lose some of its edge: that an attack that seems highly potent today will seem stale, particularly if it remains as much in the spotlight as it has been so far this year.
And from this perspective, Mr. Giuliani's relentless focus on Mrs. Clinton's residency seems an odd bit of political strategy, as even Mr. Giuliani's own supporters have begun to acknowledge. It is not that they think he should not raise the topic. But by doing it so soon, he may actually be helping to inoculate Mrs. Clinton from attacks on the issue next year, when they will really matter.
It may only be a matter of time until the press, and the public, tire of this topic and move on to other ones, which will make it harder to move the carpetbagger question back to center stage when the 2000 campaign comes around.
There is, one of the Mayor's friends said, no grand strategy being executed: it is only Mr. Giuliani being Mr. Giuliani. Another adviser, Bruce Teitelbaum, the head of Mr. Giuliani's political action committee, maintained that Mr. Giuliani was only responding to the inquiries of reporters.
But Mr. Giuliani certainly seems to encourage the questions.
He has, for example, decided to make a fund-raising trip to Little Rock, Ark. Little Rock is known for many things in American politics, including being the former home of a certain First Lady, but fund-raising is generally not one of them.
Inevitably, Mr. Giuliani's trip will provide the grist for a few more articles about Mrs. Clinton and carpetbagging, which may well be exactly what Mrs. Clinton needs right now.
