SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk 

LENGTH: 3697 words

HEADLINE: Plenty of Dirty Jobs in Politics And a New Breed of Diggers

SERIES: PRIVATE SPIES: The Campaign Trail

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

 BODY:
Feeding an almost insatiable demand for negative information in today's world of bruising politics, private investigators are playing a larger -- though mostly hidden -- role in the public arena, digging up dirt on everyone from regulators to elected national and small-town officials.
President Clinton's use of private detectives has been widely reported. But an examination by The New York Times found that over the past decade they had moved into every corner of public life, hired by politicians and their surrogates, including Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the House Judiciary Committee chairman, Henry J. Hyde, the former Mayor of New York David N. Dinkins, and aspirants for local city councils. 
 The private investigators' thick reports are usually intended to discredit critics and dispose of opponents. But they are also used defensively, to identify and if possible to avoid potential embarrassments.
Today's breed of investigators includes former police officers, as always, but also former F.B.I. agents, ex-C.I.A. employees, former prosecutors and, in a trend that raises new ethical questions, ex-journalists, who can tap old news contacts to get negative information published.
Operating with little regulation or accountability, the detectives spy on opponents by posing as reporters or by sending in operatives who work as volunteers in the campaign. In a world where sensitive computer data can flow freely despite privacy laws, some routinely obtain protected information like phone records and medical histories.
They track down ex-spouses and former associates and employees, often concealing the reason they are asking questions, and they go through trash from offices, campaign headquarters and homes, a practice known as Dumpster diving.
"There's not a garbage pail I won't get in, not an angle I won't aim a hidden camera," said Larry Preston Williams, a former police intelligence officer in New Orleans, who sends every statewide candidate in Louisiana an offer to dig up "white lies" and other information about their opponents.
"I take cases from Republicans, Democrats, conservatives, liberals," Mr. Williams said. "It's all information."
No one knows how frequently private detectives are used in political campaigns. The Federal Election Commission says it cannot monitor campaign spending on them because payments are routinely lumped with fees to lawyers. And journalists who cooperate with detectives often promise confidentiality.
The Federal Government has, however, begun to examine some of the techniques that private investigators and information brokers use to obtain confidential information. In April the Federal Trade Commission filed a landmark suit against a Colorado investigator over the use of deceptions known as pretexts to obtain information about private bank accounts, and on June 25 state authorities indicted him on racketeering charges. Congress is considering legislation to outlaw pretexts.
 Personal attacks have been part of political campaigns since the nation's inception. But for most of this century unwritten rules kept within bounds what was called "opposition research." The typical investigator was a campaign worker or occasionally a moonlighting police officer. Inquiries focused on public information like voting records and court cases.
Those rules vanished after accusations of marital infidelity drove Gary Hart out of the race for President in 1988. Campaigns veered into nastier and more personal areas, and as they did, professional investigators replaced the amateurs and techniques got more aggressive. Today, even candidates reluctant to get into the muck say they feel compelled to respond in kind.
 Robert A. G. Monks, a candidate who hired detectives in a Republican primary for the Senate from Maine, defended the need for full disclosure, even if the information is painful and personal.
"One is thought of as being worse for calling attention to these things," Mr. Monks said. "I think it's wrong for people to run for office without making a disclosure of material facts."
Senator Kennedy offered a similar rationale for hiring private investigators to scrutinize his most recent opponent, Mitt Romney.
"Opposition research is part of the modern campaign process," said a Kennedy spokesman, Will Keyser. "In 1994, Senator Kennedy's record was an open book and his opponent's was largely unknown. It was important and appropriate for the campaign to conduct thorough research into all the available public information."
Ed Rollins, a veteran Republican political consultant who acknowledges using private investigators, said, "Most people today are trying to find as much dirt as they can. There may be less tendency to push the button on the personal stuff, but the digging is going right on."
This demand for dirt in politics arises during a boom era for private investigators in the business world. Started by the corporate takeovers of the early 1980's and fueled by computers, corporate investigators have become an essential part of the information economy.
Annual revenues have quintupled to $5 billion since 1980, according to one industry association, and investigators are pivotal players in everything from hostile takeovers to hiring executives and ferreting out internal fraud. The spillover into politics was natural.
But the best-known firms from the world of corporate snooping say they avoid the political arena for fear that fallout from the cases would damage their reputations and antagonize better-paying business clients.
"I'm not going to tell you that we haven't looked up a name for someone in politics, but it is the policy of the company that we don't do political work," said Michael G. Cherkasky, president of Kroll Associates, the world's largest corporate investigative firm.
"There are certain things that we tend not to do because they are dirty," Mr. Cherkasky said. "We don't do matrimonial, we don't do criminal defense and we don't do political."
Michael J. Hershman, chairman of Decision Strategies Fairfax International, another large firm, said his investigators examined the backgrounds of Vice-Presidential possibilities for the Dukakis and Clinton campaigns, but with their knowledge and cooperation.
"We've taken a strong policy position on not doing political opposition research," Mr. Hershman said, "and I am personally against opposition research, which I believe adds to the scourge of negative campaigning."
One of the few major firms that solicits political cases is Investigative Group International, the Washington company run by Terry F. Lenzner, a former Watergate prosecutor. Though best known as an investigator for Mr. Clinton's lawyers, Mr. Lenzner has also worked for Republicans, including former Representative Michael Huffington in his losing Senate race in California against Dianne Feinstein.
Several years ago, Mr. Lenzner created a division called Campaign Facts to specialize in political investigations. He also maintains a tiny law firm, Terry F. Lenzner P.C., which several former employees said is used partly to provide politically sensitive inquiries an extra layer of confidentiality through attorney-client privilege.
Last year Mr. Lenzner was subpoenaed by the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr to testify before a grand jury about inquiries into Mr. Clinton's critics and two of Mr. Starr's prosecutors. Mr. Lenzner said he was not a target of the grand jury but, stung by the controversy, now even he is considering cutting back on political work.
In an interview, Mr. Lenzner said political cases represented only a fraction of his firm's revenue, though he defended such work.
"I perceive it to be analogous to a hostile takeover case where we are hired by a company to gather information to convince shareholders to vote for our client," he said. "You are looking at substantive issues that are relevant to the voters."
 
The Defense
Lawmaker Worried About Thrift Role
 Representative Hyde, the House Judiciary chairman, turned to a private detective when a critic was trying to draw attention to his role in a failed savings and loan.
In an interview, the detective, Ernie Rizzo, a former police officer in a Chicago suburb, provided details of his work for Mr. Hyde for the first time -- and described his disdain for politicians.
"Politicians are the easiest people in the world to set up," Mr. Rizzo said. "They're all whores. You stay with them for a week and you'll catch them doing something -- women or money or something. Forget about the millions spent in political campaigns. You don't need that. Everybody got to the top by stepping over somebody. Find the weakest link and attack it."
Mr. Rizzo, as a lone operator, is typical of detectives who handle political work. A character who would be at home in a Damon Runyon story, he is outgoing and flashy; his holographic business card is emblazoned with the image of a spy and six phone numbers, including one for his boat.
Mr. Rizzo said he was hired in late 1995 by James Schirott, a lawyer defending Mr. Hyde in a Federal suit against him and other former directors of Clyde Federal Savings and Loan. The thrift's failure in 1990 cost taxpayers $67 million.
Mr. Schirott, he said, told him the Congressman was concerned about a man turning up at hearings on the suit. Mr. Hyde wanted to know who the man was and what he knew. The lawyer gave Mr. Rizzo a name, Tim Anderson, and an address in Libertyville, a suburb of Chicago.
"The first thing I did was I pulled phone records," Mr. Rizzo explained. "I saw Anderson was making 30 or 40 calls a day to the media. I told Hyde, but he still didn't know who he was. I saw the media calls, so I decided to pretend I was from the media."
He said he telephoned Mr. Anderson, claiming to be a producer for "20/20," the ABC news program. Mr. Anderson agreed to meet him near O'Hare International Airport.
Getting a target's phone records is often the starting point of an inquiry, investigators say. While Mr. Rizzo was convicted of illegal wiretapping in 1977 for taping conversations in divorce cases, privacy experts say phone records fall into a gray area in most states. Mr. Rizzo said he got the records from someone at a telephone company, and the Illinois Attorney General's office said no state law was violated. A spokesman for Ameritech, the regional telephone company based in Chicago, said that the company did not provide customer records to anyone without a court order and that any employee who violated the rule would be fired.
Mr. Rizzo said he flew to New York and took a flight back to Chicago in case Mr. Anderson watched the airport for his arrival. But Mr. Anderson was not suspicious. A former banking consultant, he had contacted dozens of journalists trying to expose what he believed were the political roots of the savings and loan scandal.
Mr. Anderson said he gladly gave Mr. Rizzo his material on Mr. Hyde -- a bound file containing 388 pages of court records, newspaper articles and documents obtained through the Freedom of Information Act.
Among the documents were minutes of Clyde Federal board meetings that showed Mr. Hyde playing a more active role than he had acknowledged publicly. In one instance, he approved an investment in speculative options trading that eventually lost $10 million.
Mr. Rizzo, however, also wanted to know about Mr. Anderson, especially any vulnerabilities he had. So, the detective said: "I warned him that Hyde was going to come after us and I had to make sure he didn't have any skeletons. I got him telling me all his weak spots."
Mr. Rizzo said he gave the file to Mr. Hyde and was paid by a political ally of the Congressman, not by his lawyer.
Last October, The Chicago Tribune disclosed Mr. Rizzo's duping of Mr. Anderson. In his interview with The Times, Mr. Rizzo revealed that just two months later, in December, he employed the technique again because Mr. Hyde and his allies feared that Mr. Anderson might use the disclosure to disrupt the Clinton impeachment hearings.
"The day before the impeachment trial started in the House, I sent two guys back in," Mr. Rizzo said. "They posed as reporters. We wanted to know if Anderson was going to sue Hyde or make any other noise. But he told them he wasn't going to sue. He was on a crusade. It was hilarious."
Mr. Hyde refused to be interviewed for this article, but a spokesman disputed several aspects of Mr. Rizzo's account.
The spokesman, Sam Stratman, said Mr. Hyde was told that Mr. Anderson had been investigated, but that Mr. Rizzo did not deliver his findings to the Congressman. Mr. Hyde never met Mr. Rizzo and had no knowledge of his techniques, the spokesman said. Mr. Stratman also said $2,000 of $20,000 in fees paid to Mr. Schirott was for Mr. Rizzo's services. Mr. Schirott did not return numerous phone calls from The Times over several weeks.
In 1997 the Federal Government settled its suit with the former Clyde Federal directors for $850,000. Mr. Hyde maintained he had no responsibility for the thrift's failure and he did not contribute to the settlement.
Mr. Anderson is carrying on, working for $7.50 an hour at Enterprise Rent-a-Car to provide time for his crusade, even though his wife has pleaded with him to give up and return to his profession.
Indeed, Mr. Anderson said the Congressman's investigation had strengthened his resolve.
"I'm an innocent member of the public and the head of the Judiciary Committee hired a detective to spy on me," he said indignantly.
 
The Success
Helping Defeat David Duke
 Compared with flashy Mr. Rizzo, Larry Preston Williams is a model of decorum, given to three-piece suits and understatement.
An ex-lawyer and former New Orleans police officer, Mr. Williams estimates that political cases represent 15 percent of his business as a private investigator. While clients occasionally send him after national politicians, his usual target is a candidate for local or state office in Louisiana and other Southern states.
"The number of cases has picked up in recent years," he said. "The aggressiveness has picked up. The willingness to use information publicly to simply obliterate the opposition forever has increased."
Mr. Williams will happily plow through a subject's garbage, but his time is more often spent wading through public records looking for lawsuits, unpaid taxes, property ownership, divorces, arrests and the like. He charges $50 to $150 an hour, depending on the complexity of the case. A routine investigation costs $3,000 to $4,000.
What turns up most often is mundane, too: candidates or officials who misrepresent work history, education or military service. Baby boomers are particularly likely to fabricate service in Vietnam or a Purple Heart, he said.
In one case, a candidate for the New Orleans City Council hired Mr. Williams to investigate whether an opponent met residency requirements. The results of the two-month inquiry filled a folder two inches thick and ranged from letters from former employers verifying employment dates to lists of credit cards and phone records.
Mr. Williams leaked the information to reporters, leading to newspaper articles that questioned whether the candidate, Ellen Hazeur, met the residency requirement. Voters did not seem to care; Ms. Hazeur won.
Mr. Williams compiled a thicker dossier on David E. Duke, the former Ku Klux Klan leader whose Republican candidacies for the Louisiana Legislature and Congress have roiled the state's politics for the past decade.
The investigation turned up some early evidence linking Mr. Duke to neo-Nazis, and his client, a prominent Republican, used the report to orchestrate a campaign publicizing Mr. Duke's white supremacist ties.
For clients willing to spend $50,000 or more, Mr. Williams advises hiring a detective to start digging a year before the election. That enables them to start a trickle of negative information about their opponent that builds to a crescendo just before the election. He would not identify any clients who took that course.
 
The Backlash
An Instigator Places Last
 For W. John Hathaway, the negative information was not a trickle but an explosion. Running for the Republican nomination for senator from Maine in 1996, he watched in shock as two major newspapers published articles the same day reporting that he had been accused of having a sexual relationship with a 12-year-old baby sitter.
Six years earlier, when he lived in Huntsville, Ala., a girl who sat for Mr. Hathaway's children had claimed she had a sexual relationship with him. He denied the accusation. Two District Attorneys and the state Attorney General investigated and decided not to prosecute at the request of the girl's parents. In a recent interview, Mr. Hathaway again denied the accusation and said he had expected it to remain secret because no charges had been filed.
But rumors began to circulate during the primary, in which Mr. Hathaway was one of three Republicans vying for the seat left open by William S. Cohen. The others were Robert A. G. Monks, an established political figure in Maine, and Susan Collins, a political newcomer.
As the primary approached, Mr. Monks became alarmed, he said in a recent interview. His polls showed Mr. Hathaway the likely winner, and nothing had surfaced about the baby sitter's accusation. He turned to Mr. Lenzner, whom he had known for years, authorizing him to dispatch detectives from I.G.I. to Alabama to investigate.
"It isn't as if it was a secret," Mr. Monks recalled. "It was a piece of information that was something that people didn't want to have anything to do with."
A person involved in the I.G.I. investigation said detectives interviewed the girl's mother and other people and provided a report to the Monks campaign. Five days before the primary, The Boston Globe and Portland Press Herald published articles about the accusation, reporting that Mr. Hathaway had denied the charges and had never been arrested.
After the articles appeared, Mr. Hathaway accused Mr. Monks of leaking the story. Mr. Monks admitted hiring a detective, but denied that his efforts led to the articles. Even that admission took a toll on Mr. Monks. He finished last, with Mr. Hathaway second and Ms. Collins, who had refused to comment on the controversy, winning.
"The whole thing blew up in Monks's face," said Christian P. Potholm, a government professor at Bowdoin College. "People felt that this was not something that a Bill Cohen or a George Mitchell would have done."
It is not clear whether I.G.I. played a role in either article. Investigators usually turn over information to the client and let the campaign decide how to handle it.
Stephen Kurkjian, the lead reporter on The Globe's article, said that he might have talked to an I.G.I. investigator, but that an editor had sent him to Huntsville on a tip.
"I had the story without them," Mr. Kurkjian said.
Steve Campbell of The Press Herald would not identify his initial source, saying: "It didn't matter where it was coming from. I was more concerned with whether the rumors were factual."
In the recent interview, Mr. Monks said his staff had discussed the information with reporters. He still denied that the investigators were behind the articles, but he acknowledged opening a Pandora's box by sending them to Alabama.
"Once someone had stuck their hand in the thicket," he said, "the information began to flow."
 
The Fallout
Battling in Court In a Libel Case
No incident better demonstrates the power of private investigators than the runoff for Houston mayor in 1991 between Bob Lanier, a millionaire businessman, and Sylvester Turner, a Harvard-educated lawyer and State Representative.
Six days before the vote, Houston's ABC affiliate broadcast a report questioning whether Mr. Turner had a role in an insurance scam in which a former law client had faked drowning. It said Mr. Turner had drawn up the man's will shortly before he disappeared and had been involved in efforts to collect his insurance money. It quoted Mr. Turner as saying that he was a victim of the scam and had cooperated with investigators.
Pollsters from the University of Houston interviewing voters the night the story was broadcast watched Mr. Turner's numbers plunge.
"Until then, the race was very close, with a slight but statistically insignificant advantage to Turner," said Richard Murray, who supervised the poll. "We could see the direct effect. Turner dropped eight points."
Mr. Turner blamed Mr. Lanier for the report, an accusation that the campaign and the TV station denied. Mr. Turner never recovered and lost by the eight-point margin.
Mr. Turner later sued the station and its investigative reporter for libel, and in trial in 1996 the link between the Lanier campaign and the broadcast was finally discovered. A private investigator on Mr. Lanier's campaign finance committee had delivered a one-page summary of the accusations to the reporter and arranged for him to receive court files about the faked death, according to testimony.
After the election, the investigator and a second detective who also played a role in providing the story to the TV station received a multimillion-dollar contract from the Lanier administration to collect overdue parking fines.
The jury found that the broadcast was false and that the station had shown a reckless disregard for the truth, and it awarded Mr. Turner $5.5 million, a figure the judge reduced to $3.25 million. Last December, an appellate court set aside the verdict, ruling that Mr. Turner was a public figure and that there was no clear and convincing evidence of a reckless disregard for the truth in the broadcast. Mr. Turner has appealed.
In an interview, Mr. Turner criticized the private investigators.
"They did not care anything about the person, or family, or common decency," he said. "They were hired to do a job -- and they were successful."
 
Private Spies
 This is the second in a series of occasional articles looking at the growing role private investigators are playing in government and business.

NATO and Moscow Agree On Russian Role in Kosovo
NATO and Russian military commanders resolved their differences over Russia's role in the peacekeeping operation in Kosovo, clearing the way for about 3,600 more Russian troops to enter the province. Officials said the first planeloads could begin arriving today. The Russians agreed -- with great reluctance, officials said -- to serve under the nominal control of the allied commanders of each sector where they will operate, but they reserved the right to refuse to carry out orders. A1
 
The Kosovo village Bela Crkva buried its dead in a bitter, tearful ceremony. Most of the 64 people laid to final rest had initially been buried furtively, at night, by other villagers near where the victims were shot to death, reportedly by Serbian forces hours after the NATO bombing began. The reburial came after war crimes investigators completed their work in the town. A1
 
Trouble for Pakistani Leader
Opposition political parties at home criticized Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif for promising in Washington to withdraw Pakistani-backed forces from the Indian side of the cease-fire line in the disputed territory of Kashmir. Mr. Sharif's pledge seemed to be viewed by most Pakistanis as a sell-out of the Kashmir cause or an ill-fated move in a diplomatic game of chess. A3

Mexico Results and Predictions
The candidate of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which has won every presidential election since the 1920's, won election as governor of the state of Mexico, the country's most populous. His victory challenged thinking that the party, known as the PRI, was flagging and would be unable to mount a viable campaign for the presidency next year. But a PRI loss in another governor's race also showed opposition parties the power that can come from their joining forces. A8
 
Somalia Cracks Down on Crime
Four self-appointed Islamic courts in Mogadishu began a huge counterbanditry operation as part of efforts to restore order in the capital, officials said. The courts have already closed dozens of illegal checkpoints, where the city's various rival militia groups terrorize local residents and extort money. (Reuters)

New Political Players
Private investigators are playing a larger role in the public arena, digging up dirt on people like regulators, elected national and small-town officials. Their reports are usually aimed at discrediting or disposing of their clients' critics or opponents, but they are also used defensively, to find and avoid potential embarrassments. And their ranks are increasingly being joined by ex-journalists, who can tap old news contacts to get negative information published. A1

SECTION: Section A; Page 13; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1512 words

HEADLINE: Gore Campaign, Trailing Among Women, Sharpens Its Pitch to Them

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 5

 BODY:
The first thing Al Gore mentioned in every speech last week was that his oldest daughter was past her due date and about to make him and his wife of 29 years grandparents. (Wyatt Gore Schiff, 6 pounds 3 ounces, finally arrived on the Fourth of July, timing that the Vice President will surely mention in future speeches.)
The second thing he told crowds was that he had been reared by a mother who grew up poor, got on a bus to Nashville with her blind sister in tow, waited tables for quarter tips and, in 1936, became one of the first women to graduate from Vanderbilt Law School. 
 When he listened as a child to the daily back and forth between his parents, "it was clear to me that men and women were equal -- if not more so," Mr. Gore said, drawing whoops from his listeners at every stop.
In his run for the White House, the Vice President is aggressively pursuing female voters, the increasingly important bloc that so far seems to favor George W. Bush slightly. And the pitch is not terribly subtle.
Whenever possible, Mr. Gore is introduced to his audiences by a woman. (Christine Meyer, the mother of a 3-year-old cancer survivor, did the honors before his Philadelphia speech last week supporting cancer research. "I said my husband is really the speaker," Ms. Meyer said in an interview, "but they said no, we want you to do it. They wanted a mom's perspective.")
Mr. Gore steps onstage to the tune of "Rock This Country," a country song by a female vocalist, Shania Twain. A campaign video focuses primarily on him as husband and father, with his daughter Karenna Schiff repeatedly assuring viewers that her dad is so funny.
Then comes his standard stump speech, chock full of talk about day care, early-childhood education and gender equality. "This pledge," he says, "is in honor of my mother: an equal day's pay for an equal day's work."
He promises also to "fight for the ability to balance work and family" and "to shield our children from gun violence." And his biggest applause line is usually his vow to "make sure we have high-quality preschool available for every child."
This wildly woman-friendly agenda is not a poll-tested new focus for the Vice President. Mr. Gore has worked on these issues throughout his public life, co-sponsoring early versions of the Family and Medical Leave Act in the Senate and a series of bills on women's health in the House as far back as the early 1980's.
He opposed Federal financing of abortion early in his House career, but has been a supporter of abortion rights for many years and was a Senate co-sponsor of a bill that would have made a Federal statute of Roe v. Wade. He has surrounded himself with accomplished women who have become some of his closest aides, and he is considered by his staff to be an unusually family-friendly employer.
Still, his campaign is without question reacting to polls suggesting that at least at this early date, American women, who have heavily favored Democrats in recent elections, seem to prefer Mr. Bush, an opponent of abortion.
David Beckwith, a Bush spokesman, said the Governor's "compassionate conservatism" appealed to everybody. Even when Mr. Bush ran for governor in 1994 against a female incumbent, Ann Richards, there was virtually no gender gap, Mr. Beckwith noted: 49 percent of Texas women who went to the polls, like 53 percent of the men, supported Mr. Bush.
Though women favored Bill Clinton over Bob Dole by 16 percentage points in 1996, one recent CNN poll had them backing Mr. Bush over Mr. Gore by 11 points. (The Vice President was farther behind among men, by 21 points.)
Political consultants from both parties see the Gore numbers at least in part as evidence of displaced anger over the President's relationship with Monica Lewinsky. Even Mr. Gore's new pollster, Celinda Lake, agrees that the Lewinsky scandal appears to be suppressing his ratings with women.
"There's been a delayed reaction to the Clinton factor that's unfair to Gore," said Ms. Lake, who specializes in tracking female voters and was brought on last week to help the campaign figure them out. "But to women, the personal is political. As they get to know him, they'll see he's quite un-Clintonesque in that regard."
In an interview, the Vice President expressed surprise that anyone could think he might somehow wind up taking the fall for the Lewinsky scandal. "I don't buy it," he said.
Certainly his campaign is working hard to make sure that does not happen, recruiting women to fill the seats at his events, to come and hear his direct appeals. "Working to close that gap," Ms. Lake said, "is one of the most important tasks of the campaign."
After receiving from the headquarters of Mr. Gore's Pennsylvania campaign "three begging phone calls indicating they need women," Maureen Kelly, a Pittsburgh lawyer, agreed to attend a fund-raising luncheon last week, at a discounted rate. Patricia McGrail, another lawyer, attended with her and also got a discount, paying $300, she said, for the $1,000 ticket.
Ms. Kelly responded positively to Mr. Gore's remarks, and said: "I feel bad for him. People are going to associate him with Clinton, when in fact he embodies the values most women want to see."
In private, Mr. Gore talks about the important women in his life with a respect that does suggest, as several women who heard him speak last week said, that "he gets it."
As he chatted on Air Force Two, in a conversation that was initially off the record, the Vice President's mind was on his pregnant daughter. Would he cancel his schedule when she went into labor?
"I don't know," he said. "You want to run to the hospital and be right there with her, but then again. . . .
"Got to give her her space," he said, laughing at himself. "Her mother has perfect pitch on this stuff, so I guess I'll just follow her lead."
(Mr. Gore also disclosed that while environmentalists are split over Pampers vis-a-vis cloth diapers, he favors the easy way out. "That's not a hard call," he joked. "Global warming is hard. Pampers are easy.")
Most of the women attending Gore campaign events at this point are active Democrats, of course. But during three days of almost nonstop campaign events last week, a number of women said, essentially, that they felt he was pandering, yes, and maybe even desperate -- yet also totally sincere.
While commentators have primarily looked at the ways in which Mr. Gore is not enough like Mr. Clinton as a campaigner, his audiences seemed to be focusing more on what the Vice President said than on how he said it. They liked the story about his mother, and they loved the line "I'm running to make America not just better off, but better."
At a reception in Philadelphia, one supporter, Lynne Gold-Bikin, said she had been appalled by the poll numbers showing women favoring Mr. Bush -- "that Texan," as she called him.
"How any woman," she said, "could prefer the Governor of the state that pushes Tom DeLay and Dick Armey, who are so anti-woman I can't even think about it, over this man who is pro-choice and has this wonderful, exciting wife? I don't understand."
In Miami, at yet another fund-raising luncheon, Mayor Alex Penelas announced to Mr. Gore: "The real person who should be introducing you is my wife. If you say you're not voting for Al Gore, she'll punch you in the nose. And she's the Republican in the family."
When she did come to the microphone, Mrs. Penelas was as believable as she was enthusiastic: "Most people I tell them my father was Basque, they say, 'What is that?' " When she told Mr. Gore, however, "he told me all about their customs, he gave me an education on the Basque people -- now I say, that's knowledge."
Mr. Gore took it from there, and started in with how excited he was about becoming an abuelo (a grandfather), racing through this one Spanish word as if someone had told him that the key to fluency was talking fast.
Afterward, Elsa Lopez, a single mother among his listeners, said she felt he had been talking to her. "We need quality day care," she said, "not some ranch to farm these kids out on."
"Education, and choice -- my daughter just turned 4, but I decided to have her -- these things are all key," said Ms. Lopez, a former Republican who now works for the teachers' union and said she was thrilled to have received a free ticket to the $1,000 event.
Not all women were wowed, of course, by the candidate or his focus on them.
"He kept bringing up women's issues," said Ms. McGrail, the Pittsburgh lawyer, who is a Democrat and the mother of three.
"I felt like he was dealing with soft issues," she said. "I'm 44 years old; I'm too old for that. I wanted to hear about something more relevant to my life, like economic development."
In fact, the presentation she heard seems to have convinced Ms. McGrail that Mr. Gore is probably too sensitive to lead the country, and at this point she is thinking of supporting Elizabeth Dole.
"Not because she's a woman," Ms. McGrail said, "but because I think she'd be a strong leader. She's tough."

HEADLINE: Why a Car Is Better Than Cash

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Robert H. Frank (Op-Ed, June 30) suggests that as a highly skilled employee, you'd probably like to receive a BMW instead of a pay raise, since "you've wanted to make such a purchase but your spouse insists on remodeling the kitchen instead." 
 However, most employees qualifying for BMW's are men.
When raises are replaced by gifts used by husbands, their wives benefit less from their husband's success at work.
Men who entered marriages in which both spouses made equal salaries are pushing for bonuses they can play with, hoping that their wives won't mind the reduction in their contribution to the family's earnings. I would be surprised if successful companies that are directed by women compensate their employees by giving them luxury cars.
SHOSHANA GROSSBARD-SHECHTMAN
San Diego, July 1, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of economics at San Diego State University.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Irish Company Expands

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Two New Jersey companies, Millington Quarry Inc. of Millington and Dell Contractors Inc. of Paterson, have been bought by CRH P.L.C. of Dublin, Europe's third-largest building materials company. CRH paid $123 million in cash for the companies, extending its push into the United States market.
CRH said the total costs of the acquisition will rise to $146 million, including costs for disposing of some assets. Millington Quarry and Dell, which does road work, had combined 1998 sales of $149 million and combined operating profits of $18 million, CRH said. 
 CRH's Oldcastle unit in the United States is expanding amid sluggish economic growth in Europe, and amid expectations that the United States construction market will continue to boom as the Federal Government plans to spend about $180 billion on roads within six years.
Tom Hill, president of Oldcastle, said CRH will integrate the purchases into its current businesses in the region to reduce costs. About half of CRH's annual sales are in the United States market, it has said.
CRH acquired Tilcon Inc. in New Britain, Conn., in 1996 and New York Trap Rock in New Hamburg and West Nyack, N.Y., in 1997.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 5; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1661 words

HEADLINE: High Noon: Restaurants Fight to Draw a Crowd

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
A BUSINESS lunch today is positively Spartan compared with those fabled three-martini events a quarter-century ago. The martinis have been replaced by iced tea, mineral water, possibly a single glass of wine. The hearty dishes that lingered until dinner, like pot-au-feu, have become grilled chicken or a salad. The leisurely two-hour interlude has slipped back to an hour or less and, for many, into carryout at the desk or sandwiches in the conference room.
As lunch has come under increasing pressures of time, budgets and health concerns, many restaurants have realized that they must adapt, or face empty tables. They have chosen to give customers what they want, like two appetizers and a beverage in 45 minutes, or a meal ready to go in a container. And they are having some success. 
 In an effort to fill its tables at noon, Lespinasse, one of New York City's temples of gastronomy, recently sent a promotion to its customers: "In the 70's you had lunch. In the 80's you did lunch. In the 90's you skipped lunch. Perhaps it's time you redefined lunch." The restaurant has done just that: three light courses for $36 in one hour.
"People want to eat fast and furiously," said Eberhard Muller, the chef and owner of Lutece. "Years ago, you could serve the French classics, but you can't sell them anymore. Now it's salads, grilled fish, grilled meats, less starch, more protein and healthier than ever and 'please make it fast I have to be back at the office in one hour.' "
Except for prix fixe meals, most people eat no more than two courses, often just an entree. Lunch has become a time to abstain, dinner a time to splurge.
"It's an image thing," said Chris Cannon, a partner at Judson Grill. "It makes them look serious and healthy in front of customers." It's a far cry from the days when a boozy haze was the desired effect and not much work was done in the afternoon.
"Now, it's tons of water, iced tea and cranberry spritzers and $22,000 coffee machines that make six kinds of coffee: cappuccino, espresso, double cappuccino, double this, double that," said Alan Stillman, who owns Smith & Wollensky, Maloney & Porcelli and Manhattan Ocean Club. But wine by the glass is selling, and to protect that single-glass toehold, some restaurants have enlarged and upgraded the choices.
When Union Square Cafe opened in 1985, it offered two wines by the glass; today there are 10. Eleven Madison Park, a sister restaurant, offers 36. "People are drinking only one glass of wine, but they are willing to pay," said Charles Palmer, owner of Aureole on the Upper East Side. His list includes a $26 glass of a 1996 Chateauneuf-du-Pape.
Restaurants that want to stay in business cater to the changing demands of their clientele, even if they don't approve. If a good customer wants a meal boxed up to eat at the desk, even the fanciest places will oblige. In the old days, Mr. Muller said, when a guest asked for sauce on the side, chefs would refuse. Today the customer is always right.
"We still have a three-course prix fixe lunch for $38," Mr. Muller said, "but now if someone wants two courses we won't refuse. If someone wants a bowl of soup and a salad, be my guest. My lunch business, based on these subtle changes, is much better than three years ago, by being in tune with what people want to eat and their time."
Even in steakhouses, only about a third of the lunch entrees are steak; at dinner they account for 85 percent of the meals.
"You have to give the appearance on the menu of healthful dishes," said Mr. Cannon of Judson Grill. "But people don't want a spa menu, because they don't want to feel like they are going to some spa." Which is exactly what the Four Seasons, considered by many to be the power center of the midday meal, learned several years ago.
"The spa menu was a great idea for a year or so," said Julian Niccolini, a managing partner. "People are interested in eating healthy food, in very fresh, freshly prepared organic food. They are interested in flavors. Great food doesn't have to be with sauces."
In fact, said Rocco DiSpirito, the chef at Union Pacific, simple is better. "People may not be able to enjoy interesting or complicated food at lunch," he said, because they don't have the time. "We've simplified our lunch menu so you're not needing the waiter to explain everything to you."
Elaine Markson, a Manhattan literary agent, appreciates efforts at simplicity. "When I first started, lunch was incredibly exciting," Ms. Markson said. "Now, I try to make it as healthy as I can. No drinking. Water, water, water, unless I have a foreign guest. If I'm trying to be good, it's two appetizers and coffee. Now I'm not looking at the breadbasket. Desserts are out, out, out, unless you are with someone who is very thin and wants you to share a dessert."
Time and health are not the only influences on the changing lunch business. There are hundreds of new options to fill the gaping culinary and price differential between the Four Seasons and the corner deli. Not the least of these is the corporate dining room, an increasingly standard feature at large companies. Conde Nast, which moved to its new headquarters at Broadway and 43d Street last month, will soon be operating an elaborate Frank Gehry-designed dining room for its staff and for in-house entertaining. Investment bankers like Credit Suisse First Boston are providing employees with in-house dining as well as a health club, a hair salon and a dry cleaner.
These amenities save companies time and money. "It's the most efficient utilization of time from our standpoint," said Luther Terry, a managing director of Credit Suisse. The executive dining rooms are also used to entertain clients, providing privacy that a public restaurant cannot.
"Corporate dining rooms were considered ostentatious once," said Clark Wolf, a restaurant consultant. "No longer."
The booming economy has also created hundreds of new restaurants, and, Mr. Wolf said, the number of seats exceeds the demand. In some neighborhoods the competition among top restaurants is particularly fierce. Over the last six months, 700 seats have been added in the Madison Park area: Union Pacific, Patria and Gramercy Tavern have been joined by Veritas, Tabla and 11 Madison Park. Cena, a highly regarded restaurant in the neighborhood, closed last week for lack of business.
"It's very difficult to get people in the door," said Mr. DiSpirito of Union Pacific. "We used to average 70 to 80 for lunch; now the average is 50. We were counting on the Credit Suisse to be a big source of revenue, but I don't think they leave their desks."
They don't need to leave their building, anyway, the same one that houses 11 Madison Park and Tabla, Danny Meyer's two new restaurants.
Mr. Meyer, too, was counting on the 2,000 employees of Credit Suisse. A shrewd businessman, he decided that if they wouldn't come to him, he would go to them. In the next few weeks, he will begin delivering $12 box lunches (sandwich, dessert and beverage) to those people and selling to anyone who wants to pick one up.
Even restaurants that must be booked weeks in advance for dinner are finding that they need incentives to draw people in for lunch. The annual one-week promotion when dozens of the city's top restaurants offer a prix fixe lunch -- $19.99 this year -- is frequently extended for the entire year. At the Gotham Bar and Grill, the $19.99 lunch accounts for about half the lunch business, said the owner, Jerome Kretchmer, whose other restaurants include Park Avenue Cafe, Judson Grill and Mesa Grill. "It gets lots of people to come," he added.
Paul McLaughlin, a managing partner of Oceana and Molyvos, called last year's $19.98 lunch at Molyvos a "win-win situation, with 250 people a week out of 800 or 900 buying that lunch, which will probably be a permanent feature."
Other restaurants offer limited, less expensive menus at the bar. A three-course lunch in the lounge at Le Cirque 2000 is $25. Le Bernardin began the Timely Lunch Menu 18 months ago, and Eric Ripert, the chef, insists that it can be served in less than 30 minutes. The $32 three-course prix fixe has increased business from about 80 or 90 noontime customers to more than 100.
To be sure, in the throngs of rushed and hungry New Yorkers, there are holdouts -- most often in publishing and advertising, where people still "do lunch."
Paul Gottlieb, the publisher and president of Harry Abrams, remembers the old-style lunch fondly. "Lunch was always a moment of relaxation, a time to catch up," he said. "It still is, for me, a moment out of the day."
Ms. Markson, the literary agent, has been eating lunch out five days a week for 27 years. "Lunch is absolutely the lifeline," she said. "It's the leisure of lunch that makes the deal happen. I don't know what I'd do without it."
And there are still some restaurants that don't need to offer incentives to fill up. Judson Grill, Union Square Cafe, Michael's and the Four Seasons, which all cater to those who do lunch, are almost always booked. Regulars think of those places as their private clubs, where they are known and feel comfortable. The Four Seasons is the ultimate lunch club, but even it is relatively quiet on a getaway day.
"The only day we have a problem is on Friday," Mr. Niccolini said. "People want to get out of town as quickly as possible, and in the summer they don't want to come to work at all on Friday. People are making so much money, many don't have to, and because of the Internet they can work at home."
Indeed, just when lunch patterns seem to have settled in, something comes along to unsettle them. Corporate dining rooms are one thing, but the Internet may take an even greater toll on restaurant lunch. Who needs to go out for poached salmon when the deal can be done in a flash on line?
And despite evidence to the contrary, at this very moment, martinis are making a comeback at the Four Seasons.

HEADLINE: Sugar in the Everglades

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Master Plan for the Everglades" (editorial, July 2):
Conspicuously absent from the Clinton Administration's plan for the restoration of the Everglades is an end to price supports on sugar, which have aided sugar growers and corn sweetener manufacturers but have all but destroyed the Everglades and cost taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars in taxes and higher food costs. 
 Price supports keep domestic sugar prices high, thereby making it profitable to grow sugar on less productive land.
Allowing prices to fall to the world market price would free marginal land now used for growing sugar and reduce the need to use chemical fertilizers, pesticides and herbicides.
 
NORMAN DOUGLAS
Milford, Conn., July 2, 1999
 
The writer is an economist.

The students do not want to start substantive talks until Monday. Julia Preston (NYT)

The cargo truck union says it will continue the work action indefinitely until the Government backs off the 1.5 percent tax on automobiles, trucks, boats, planes and motorcycles. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

The court has condemned Peru's prosecution of accused rebels in military courts administered by judges. The bill was quickly approved by a committee and is expected to win the backing of the full Congress. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

HEADLINE: The Amazing Vanishing Surplus

BYLINE: By David Frum; David Frum is a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The United States Government has a very 90's problem. Although it is taking in vastly more revenue than it ever imagined possible (almost $2 trillion a year!) it is having surprising difficulty buying all the things it thinks it needs.
There's that new four-wheel-drive prescription drug program and the summertime excursion in Yugoslavia. The children ought to attend better schools, and the F-15's in the home-security system are sounding awfully wheezy. But after paying all the country's current expenses, there is barely anything left over, $99 billion in 1999, and we did promise we'd put it all into the retirement account. . . . 
 It's embarrassing to imagine what Grandpa Ike would have had to say about all this. His annual income never exceeded $100 billion, and yet he still managed to save democracy from Communism, build the Interstate System and pay down the national debt.
Fortunately, there's a plan to pay for it all, and in the trademark 90's style. Not with money in the bank -- who has that? -- but with the bonuses and options the Federal Government is expecting down the road, a total of $1 trillion in budget surpluses over the next 15 years. The Government may not have sufficient cash to restock the cellar with cruise missiles after firing off that batch in May, but as soon as those surpluses vest, it will be rich, rich, rich.
The trouble is, the surpluses are largely imaginary. President Clinton is exploiting the delusion of wealth to come to lure Americans into making commitments to major new programs -- including that new prescription drug Medicare benefit -- that the country cannot afford.
Most of the doubts about the surpluses have thus far focused on the sunny economic assumption they rest on: that growth will continue strong and steady until the year 2008 at about 2 1/2 percent a year, uninterrupted by any major recession. Yet what's really wobbly about the surpluses is not economic, but political.
The foundation of the surpluses is the 1997 budget deal, which vowed to impose squeaky tight controls on the growth of non-Social Security, non-Medicare, non-defense spending, or what Washingtonians call "discretionary domestic spending." This discretionary spending includes the Federal Bureau of Investigation, meat inspection, enforcement of immigration laws, disaster relief, aid to education and jaunts by the First Lady to New York State.
In other words, just about everything the Federal Government does other than pay pensions. The United States spent $285 billion on those items in 1998. The 1997 deal promises that it will spend no more than $316 billion in 2009, an 11 percent increase over 11 years.
How realistic is that promise? Well, over the previous 11 years, from 1987 to 1998, discretionary domestic spending jumped 75 percent. Congress is in effect saying that it will raise this spending over the next 11 years by almost 90 percent less than it raised it over the past 11 years. Factor in inflation and the promise becomes even more exacting. Congress will have to cut the F.B.I., meat inspection, aid to education, etc. by more than 20 percent in real dollars over the next 11 years.
You can already hear the squeaks of distress from Capitol Hill. Representative John Porter, the liberal Republican from Illinois who is chairman of the subcommittee that decides how much to spend on health and education, is demanding that the limit on his segment of the budget be raised. A menacing number of his colleagues support him.
If Mr. Porter and those who think like him prevail, the projected surpluses will dwindle away. Domestic spending will rise, and interest payments on the debt will fail to fall. Interest payments are now projected to tumble to $71 billion in 2009 from $243 billion in 1998 as the surpluses retire big chunks of the Federal debt. But if those surpluses dwindle, then the debt does not shrink so quickly, and interest payments stay high.
This whole game of 15-year economic forecasts has been a sham from beginning to end, intended to divert attention from facts to dreams. The facts are that the Federal Government cannot afford at anything like current rates of taxation to pay the pensions and health care expenses of the baby boom generation after it starts to retire in 2013. The facts are that there is not a lot of room to raise those current rates of taxation, which are already crushingly high: the 15 percent payroll tax and the 40 percent maximum rate of Federal income tax today gobble up a higher proportion of the national income than Federal taxes did during World War II.
Like a 90's paper millionaire getting ready to lock himself into a mortgage on a monster chateau on Lake Washington, President Clinton is proposing to lock the country into vast new spending commitments on the strength of a notional income source.
This is an irresponsible, even reckless distraction from the task that Mr. Clinton has repeatedly set himself: to salvage the already badly overextended Social Security and Medicare programs from their imminent crises. It is likewise a distraction from what ought to be the Republicans' top priority: reducing tax rates to something like peacetime levels.
It's time to blow the froth off the latte and make some prudent plans. Otherwise, the Government is going to find itself three or four years from now in the same jam as its citizens: pacing fretfully at 2 o'clock in the morning through a $100,000 kitchen renovation, wondering how on earth it talked itself into the delusion that it was going to finance its obligations with a big, soggy mass of Surplus.com shares.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES;
Oil Price Up As OPEC's Cuts Seem to Hold

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Crude oil rose to a 19-month high yesterday, near $20 a barrel, on signs that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will adhere to its promised production cuts in the months ahead.
King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil-producing nation and OPEC's most influential member, said on Monday that his country would stick with its output cuts. Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates also said the output reductions should be maintained. OPEC is leading efforts among world producers to trim supply by more about 7 percent. 
 "OPEC has a new spirit now, there's a rebirth of the organization," said Marianne Kah, chief economist for Conoco Inc. "I don't see them turning the faucet back on, even though prices have improved."
Crude oil for August delivery rose 9 cents, to $19.78 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the highest price since November 1997. Prices rose as high as $20.08 in electronic trading before the floor opened. Oil has gained 66 percent this year.
In London, Brent crude oil for August delivery fell 8 cents, to $18.10 a barrel, on the International Petroleum Exchange. Brent surged 52 cents on Monday when United States markets were closed for the Fourth of July holiday.
OPEC made 94 percent of its pledged output cuts in June, up from a revised 90 percent in May.
Saudi Arabia is only one of several producing countries encouraging compliance with the pledges.
Ubayd Saif al-Nasiri, the United Arab Emirates oil minister, said that OPEC should not "exploit" the increase in oil prices by raising production.
Kuwait called on OPEC to maintain its high level of compliance with oil output cuts -- even though prices have surged this year -- because global demand for oil remained weak, the country's official news agency reported on Sunday.
And Russia, which is the world's third-biggest oil producer but is not a member of OPEC, said on Monday that it cut exports by 6 percent in compliance with its pledge.

HEADLINE: Democracy Sprouts in Ghana; Now for the Harvest

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

DATELINE: ACCRA, Ghana, July 2

 BODY:
"Messiah," declared the sign on a street corner here, above hand-painted portraits of Jesus Christ, Nelson Mandela, Bob Marley, President Clinton (beloved here for making Ghana his first stop on his visit to Africa last year) and this country's longtime leader, Jerry J. Rawlings.
If President Rawlings's portrait can be found on this street corner, as well as on other corners of this capital where street artists sell their works, it is evidence of the enduring appeal of the man who since 1981 has guided Ghana out of collapse and through two presidential elections. 
 That a framed photograph of the President can not be found in every small store in the country -- a common practice in many African nations where presidents have acquired their position through decidedly undemocratic means -- is perhaps further indication of Mr. Rawlings's genuine popularity.
"But," said Ben Smith, the artist who painted the "Messiah" portraits, "he's been too long on the seat. From the head of state down, everyone has to respect the Constitution."
Ghana's Constitution limits the President to two terms, and calls by even Mr. Rawlings's most fervent supporters to respect the law suggest that a democratic culture is taking root. Many African and Western officials see Ghana as a success story, a country that has steadily liberalized politically even as many of its neighbors have stumbled.
Next year in Ghana, if all goes according to plan, something will occur here that is rare on this continent: the President will step down and elections will produce a successor. But many opposition politicians and even members of Mr. Rawlings's party are complaining loudly that the President and his inner circle are maneuvering to insure that he remains the dominant force in the nation's politics.
Western officials and foreign donors, who made Ghana a model for free-market innovations in Africa over the years, are nervously watching whether their investments will pay off with a smooth transition. They will also closely watch the election-year spending by the Government, whose largesse in the last two elections derailed Ghana's economy.
"Certainly it is a country and a Government that have generally been moving in positive ways, both in terms of the economy and democratization," said an American official here. "But we continue to see democracy as an evolutionary process, and one generally fair and free election doesn't make a democracy. So that's why the 2000 elections will say a lot about democratization in Ghana."
When Mr. Rawlings, a former flight lieutenant, seized power in 1981, Ghana was suffering from economic collapse and millions of people had left the country in search of work. But under the guidance of international institutions like the World Bank, the economy became one of the most stable in the region. The country became the United States' largest trading partner in sub-Saharan Africa, after South Africa and Nigeria. Roads, electricity and drinking water reached millions more of the 18.5 million people.
Political liberalization followed. After he was elected President in 1992, in balloting that the opposition described as unfair, Mr. Rawlings was re-elected in 1996 in a vote that was considered fair by his opponents and by international observers. And in the last three years, a Parliament of several parties and a vigorous press have emerged.
But with the end of the Rawlings era in sight, his party, the National Democratic Congress, has sent signals that have led people to question whether the President is really ready to let go of power.
In the last year, party members have floated several ideas that appeared calculated to test the public's willingness to accept a direct or indirect continuation of a Rawlings rule. Amending the Constitution to permit Mr. Rawlings's tenure to be extended was suggested, followed by the idea that his wife, Nana Konadu Agyeman Rawlings, already a powerful political figure, would be the party's presidential candidate.
What's more, after Mr. Rawlings eventually expressed support for his Vice President, John Evans Atta Mills, as his successor, many of the President's critics perceived the move as a way of retaining unofficial control. That belief deepened in December when his party formed a consultative committee and made Mr. Rawlings "lifelong" chairman.
The party has played down these developments, saying, for instance, that the committee chairmanship is strictly honorary. Huudu Yahaya, general secretary of the National Democratic Congress, said the President's opponents had merely seized on these issues to portray the party as increasingly authoritarian.
"The only thing he would need now is for his legacy to be sustained," Mr. Yahaya said of the democratization. "Rawlings has become an international statesman. He's made a lot of pledges outside. He would not want his pledges to go down, because other heads of states in other countries have asked us how this can be sustained."
But the President's critics, including those inside his own party, are not convinced.
After Mr. Rawlings announced his support for his Vice President, a group inside his party calling itself the Reform Movement criticized the inner circle, saying it was increasingly autocratic and corrupt. The group announced early this year that it was breaking away from the National Democratic Congress, and a few weeks ago took the legal steps to become a full-fledged party.
"Since last year, there has been enough information suggesting that the ruling clique is not really considering a full democratic handover," said Kyeretwie Opoku, general secretary of the Reform Movement.
But more significant than internal party wrangling is a growing democratic culture expressed through ordinary people or the press, a contrast with the "culture of silence" of the last decade.
"When the idea of extending incumbency through a Constitutional amendment was floated," said E. Gyimah-Boadi, a professor of political science at the University of Ghana, "it was shot down by the independent media, radio talk-shows and phone-ins. That to me gave hope that there was a political opening and, while we cannot take it for granted that progress will continue, that it was genuine."
Mr. Gyimah-Boadi is also executive director of the Center for Democracy and Development, a year-old nonprofit organization that receives funds from the Ford Foundation and is an example of the growing presence of civil watchdog groups.
In measuring democracy's deepening roots in Ghana, people like Mr. Gyimah-Boadi point to the evolution of the Parliament. After the disputed 1992 presidential election, opposition parties boycotted the Parliament, which became a one-party forum for the next four years. But since 1996, members of several parties have served in the legislature, free to criticize the executive branch and summon ministers for questioning.
The legislature, though, remained relatively weak. Kwadwo Baah-Wiredu, a legislator of the New Patriotic Front, the main opposition party, said members were not given the resources to work effectively. He has no staff and no office, he said.
"This is my office," Mr. Baah-Wiredu said, opening the trunk of his Peugeot, which contained blue and red folders, a cellular phone and a Palm Pilot.
Although all members can introduce bills, not one has ever done so. Instead, the Attorney General's office has introduced all legislation since 1996. So acquiring a role in policy making would be the next step for Parliament, Mr. Baah-Wiredu said.
Despite his criticisms, Mr. Baah-Wiredu added, "We are moving forward, there is no doubt about that."

HEADLINE: Global Sales of Computer Chips Grow 12%

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 6

 BODY:
Worldwide sales of computer chips rose 12 percent in May from a year ago, led by surging sales in Asia and Japan, an industry trade group said today.
Sales rose to $11.3 billion in May from $10.1 billion in May 1998, the Semiconductor Industry Association said. Sales climbed less than 1 percent from $11.2 billion in April 1999. 
 Global sales of computer chips are expected to rise 12 percent this year, led by products used in phones and networks as well as the increasing popularity of the Internet.
Recovering economies in Asia and Japan are helping buoy industry sales.
"May's global sales numbers are a clear indication of the positive and solid growth of our industry," the association's president, George Scalise, said in a statement.
Sales in Asia rose 18 percent from a year ago, to $2.77 billion, while sales in Japan surged 15 percent, to $2.46 billion, the association said. Sales in the Americas region rose 11 percent, to $3.64 billion. Sales in Europe were up only 3.2 percent from a year ago, to $2.41 billion, and fell 2.8 percent from April 1999.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Yield Rises On30-Year Treasury To 6.03%

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell yesterday, sending yields to their highest level in a week, as the Government and corporate borrowers prepared to sell at least $13 billion of debt.
"The Treasury market may have a problem" until the sales are over, said Christopher Sullivan, who invests $475 million in bonds for the United Nations Federal Credit Union. "I don't see much that can drive prices higher." 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 1 3/32, to 89 8/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.03 percent from 6.00 percent on Friday.
The Ford Motor Credit Company, the finance arm of the auto maker, said yesterday it would sell as much as $7.5 billion of debt just weeks after delaying the sale in late June.
The credit company plans to sell $1.5 billion to $2 billion of three-year floating-rate notes and $3 billion to $4 billion of five-year fixed-rate notes. Its parent will also sell $1.5 billion of 32-year fixed-rate bonds.
The Household Finance Corporation, Williams Communications Group and Sanwa Bank Ltd. are also preparing debt sales of $1 billion or more. Freddie Mac, the No. 2 provider of mortgage financing, is expected to sell $2 billion to $3 billion of notes, perhaps as early as this week. Corporate bonds draw demand from Treasuries by offering higher yields.
Many companies stayed out of the market last week as the Federal Reserve met and raised the overnight lending rate between banks by a quarter-point, to 5 percent. They rescheduled sales after the Fed removed its tilt toward higher rates, signaling it was not in a hurry to raise them again.
The Government is also selling $7 billion of nine-and-a-half-year inflation-indexed notes today, more competition for investors' dollars.
Following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Republicans Backing Tax Break For the Care of Elderly Relatives

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
People who care for elderly relatives at home would get a new tax exemption under legislation that Republicans will include in a sweeping tax relief bill expected to begin moving through the House next week.
The proposal outlined today by Representative Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, would also allow people to take income tax deductions for premiums they pay for long-term care insurance. 
 "The need for long-term care in America is great and will only grow larger as the baby boomers start retiring," Mr. Archer, a Texas Republican, said.
The announcement puts the Republicans on the same footing as President Clinton in advocating changes in tax law to help people cope with the rising costs of old age.
Mr. Archer said the proposals would be part of the Ways and Means Committee's tax package, which in its current form would provide tax breaks estimated at $850 billion over 10 years. Mr. Clinton would probably veto a tax-cut bill of that size, but elements of the bill with strong bipartisan support could survive in a smaller measure expected this year.
Tax breaks for long-term care exist in current law, but most cannot be claimed unless the amounts exceed 7.5 percent of a taxpayer's adjusted gross income.
Nursing home care already costs an average of $50,000 a year, Ways and Means Committee figures show. Numbers of people needing long-term care begin increasing fast at age 85, and 20 percent of 85-year-olds already need it. Planners worry that in 2030, the 77 million baby boomers will start reaching 85.
The Republican plan would add a personal income tax exemption -- similar to exemptions for dependent children -- for people who provide long-term care to elderly relatives at home. The exemption this year would be $2,750, but the figure would change annually based on inflation.
Mr. Clinton proposed a $1,000 tax credit for long-term care this year, but it would be phased out for married couples with adjusted gross incomes above $110,000 and $75,000 for singles. The Republican plan contains no such income limits.

HEADLINE: Clinton, in Poverty Tour, Focuses on Profits

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., July 6

 BODY:
Nothing motivates business like the prospect of profits.
That is the fundamental message underlying President Clinton's tour of the nation's impoverished precincts this week. Government tax credits and loan guarantees are fine as far as they go, Mr. Clinton says at each stop, but corporations are not going to invest in the Kentucky highlands, the Mississippi Delta or poor East St. Louis without hope of a decent return. 
 Mr. Clinton drew attention to the opening of a new Walgreens drug store here in East St. Louis -- one of the first new retail businesses to open in this struggling Mississippi River town across from downtown St. Louis in 40 years -- as an example of a corporation taking advantage of the new markets available in the United States' poorest regions.
"Hey," Mr. Clinton told a crowd of several hundred in the parking lot of the Walgreens store as a thunderstorm threatened behind him, "there are business opportunities out here. If you have people who want to go to work and people with money to spend and they're both in the same place, it's a good place to invest."
"Government's not going to do it," Mr. Clinton continued. "Nobody's going to put money here if they think they're going to lose it."
That calculation animated Bank of America, which today announced the formation of a $500 million "catalyst fund" to make equity investments in businesses in poverty-ridden areas. The fund will buy stakes in inner-city and rural real estate projects, urban shopping malls, job-training facilities and other ventures that the bank hopes will have a cascading effect on the areas they serve, a bank official said.
"There's real money to be made in these markets," Cathy Bessant, Bank of America's president of community development, said in an interview today. "All businesses go where profits are easier, and we believe there are booming markets here, regardless of geography."
Ms. Bessant, who is traveling with Mr. Clinton, said that traditional lenders were reluctant to lend in distressed areas because of false perceptions of risk and the lack of established lending relationships with inner-city entrepreneurs.
The Bank of America fund is intended not only to make money for the bank's shareholders, but also to inspire other lenders and venture capital firms to help in the revitalization of areas starved for investment capital, she said.
The President's "new markets" proposal, if passed by Congress, would help protect Bank of America's investments against losses by providing tax credits for new businesses and Federal guarantees for matching loans to such enterprises.
"The goal is not to ask people to make charitable contributions," said Gene Sperling, the White House chief economic adviser, "but to make companies take a second look in our own backyard where there could be profitable business opportunities while also helping rebuild communities that have been left behind."
Mr. Clinton stopped in Clarksdale, Miss., in the Mississippi Delta before flying to East St. Louis late this afternoon. He walked through Clarksdale's desolate downtown and visited a small manufacturing plant recently rescued from bankruptcy.
"This is a good business opportunity here," Mr. Clinton said at a policy discussion at the factory, owned by the Waterfield Cabinet Company. "If we cannot fully develop the Delta now when we have the strongest economy in our lifetime, when will we ever get around to it?"
Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, who is traveling with the President, released a report today on the untapped retail market of the nation's inner cities.
The report concludes that cities like East St. Louis, which have seen their retail bases evaporate over the last several decades, have more than $300 billion in pent-up retail demand, presenting an enormous opportunity for retailers like Walgreens.
With neighborhood stores shuttered, inner-city residents are driving to the suburbs to shop, buying by mail, or, in some cases, shopping over the Internet.
East St. Louis has seen a slight revival in the six years since a riverboat casino arrived here, docking along the grimy riverfront. The riverboat is second to the local hospital as the largest employer in East St. Louis and has brought 1,200 jobs and some spark to this predominately black city of 42,000 people, though the city is still one of the poorest in the nation.
"Now is the time to use Government to tap those markets," Mr. Cuomo said in an interview. He said that Mr. Clinton waited this long to make a major push for inner-city and rural economic development because only now does he have the economic and political clout to pull it off. Also, the electronic revolution has changed the nature of business, making it possible to conduct all manner of commerce from virtually anywhere on the globe.
"He couldn't have done this six or seven years ago," Mr. Cuomo said of the President. "He has the economy at his back, he has credibility in his Government and business is more mobile. These high-tech guys can go anywhere. They don't need water. They don't need ports. They can move to Appalachia, they can move to East St. Louis, they can move to the Bronx."

Clinton to Take In Soccer
 EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., July 6 (AP) -- President Clinton decided today to extend his seven-state trip across the country through the weekend so he can attend the women's World Cup soccer championship in California.
The undefeated American team faces China in the championship at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena.
Mr. Clinton attended a semifinal game last week outside Washington as the United States defeated Germany to advance to the finals.
The White House press secretary, Joe Lockhart, said the women's team had invited the President.
"I think, like all Americans, he's been caught up in their success and wants to be there personally to cheer them on," Mr. Lockhart said.
