HEADLINE: U.S., Avoiding Castro, Relaxes Rules on Cuba

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is quietly moving to expand contacts between the United States and Cuba, pressing a modest opening that largely sidesteps President Fidel Castro's Government.
With a series of small steps -- some announced early this year and others that are being prepared -- the Administration is mainly seeking to ease the hardships of the Cuban people and to allow certain Americans to visit Cuba, open offices there and send money, food and medicine more freely. 
 In coming weeks, officials said, they will lift more restrictions on money transfers and travel and announce the start of direct charter flights between Havana and the New York metropolitan region and Los Angeles, in addition to those that now depart and land at Miami.
The moves have included a tentative new approach to the Cuban Government. On June 21 in Havana, United States and Cuban officials agreed to begin working somewhat more closely to combat a sharp rise in drug trafficking in and around the island, and they proposed other measures that American officials said could foster more cooperation.
The initiative falls well within the limits on American policy that were set in 1992 and 1996 by laws that stiffened the 37-year-old economic embargo on the island. Some new steps had been considered earlier but were scrapped in the outcry after Cuban fighters shot down two civilian planes in 1996, killing four Cuban-Americans who had planned to fly over Havana.
"There is a conscious decision in this Administration to do what needs to be done," a senior official said. Referring to Cuban-American opponents of Mr. Castro's Government, he added, "This is a policy that has been held hostage to interest groups for way too long."
Some officials said the Administration was already being pulled on Cuba policy between the legacy of President Clinton and the political aspirations of Vice President Al Gore. Mr. Clinton is said by aides to see Washington's approach to Cuba as archaic. Mr. Gore is described as highly aware of the considerable influence that Cuban-American voters may have in two pivotal states, Florida and New Jersey.
Yet other officials say however modest the recent measures, the shift is particularly significant because it reflects a widespread view in the Administration that the domestic politics of Cuba policy are changing in fundamental ways.
A decade after the cold war's end, Administration officials say they see the strength of conservative Cuban-American groups waning, while opposition to the embargo continues to grow among business people, farmers, religious groups and younger Cuban-Americans.
After years of waiting for some political opening in Cuba, American officials say, they are now determined to go forward even if Mr. Castro responds by cracking down on dissent, as he did soon after Washington announced measures in January to increase contact between the two countries.
The Cuban response has even encouraged some American proponents of a hard-line policy who say the so-called people-to-people initiative might help destabilize the Communist Government by empowering the few dissidents on the island.
For its part, the Administration sees the approach as a means of undercutting Cuba's argument that it is under siege by the United States. The new direction is also widely seen as a way to present a kinder American face to ordinary Cubans and, perhaps, to build a modicum of trust with younger Cuban officials who will become more important after the 72-year-old Mr. Castro passes from power.
The Administration's latest actions on Cuba recall the largely secret White House effort in late 1995 and early 1996. Officials said that initiative, which focused more directly on the Government, was approved by Mr. Clinton and managed by Samuel R. Berger, deputy national security adviser at the time. It started with a relaxation of travel and other restrictions in October 1995. But according to current and former officials, the Administration also choreographed a series of possible steps to ease American sanctions if Cuba continued to open up its economy and to promote a more cooperative relationship with the Cuban Government.
"We were trying to open the door -- to push it open if necessary -- and make it clear to the Cuban Government that if they walked through that door, nothing bad would happen to them," one former official involved in the planning said.
Then as now, officials said, collaboration in antinarcotics efforts was high on the agenda. In meetings with Cuban officials, United States officials raised the possibility of American law-enforcement training for Cuban police and border-guard officials, as well as the stationing of a representative of the Drug Enforcement Administration in Havana, officials said.
"Narcotics was going to be a vehicle to get to other things," another former official involved in that initiative said. "The real question was what the next step would be."
Other proposals included encouraging American nongovernmental groups like environmental and human rights advocates to work in Cuba, some collaboration with the Cuban Government on environmental issues and an exploration of how to initiate contacts abroad between military officers of the two countries.
Such efforts slammed to an abrupt halt in February 1996, when the planes carrying the Cuban-Americans were shot down. The next month, Congress passed the Helms-Burton law, codifying the embargo and adding sanctions. Mr. Clinton signed the legislation over the advice of some senior aides and later came surprisingly close to winning a majority of the Cuban-American vote in Dade County, Fla.
In recent months, the Treasury Department has begun to simplify the cumbersome procedures for travel to Cuba by Americans like researchers and athletes, aid workers and freelance journalists. Similar consideration is most likely to be extended soon to others like students, artists and representatives of religious groups.
In March, the Administration moved to streamline the sale and donation of medicines to Cuba, and next month, a Florida pharmaceutical company is to start shipping medicines to Cubans from benefactors in the United States.
Under Federal rules that will take effect this month, Cuban emigres and others will be able to send money to Cubans by Western Union, reducing the cost of transfers that have been handled by travel agencies and other small businesses. Americans can now send up to $300 to the island every three months, as long as the money does not go to senior Government or Communist Party officials.
How much advantage Americans will take of the new rules remains to be seen. A spokeswoman for the Treasury Department, Maria Ibanez, said travel to Cuba had steadily increased since the new regulations were issued in May. The expected addition of direct charter flights from New York and Los Angeles is intended to accommodate that rise.
Since baseball games in the spring between the Baltimore Orioles and the Cuban national team, Washington has offered proposals for other sports events. Those plans have been set back, however, by differences over how to avoid generating revenue for the Cuban Government, a State Department official said.
But the Administration move last month to explore a more cooperative antidrug relationship with the Cuban Government has run into stronger opposition, mainly from a few members of Congress, who say the Cuban authorities are involved in the drug trade. Administration officials who have read a recent Central Intelligence Agency assessment of Cuba's role said it concluded, to the contrary, that although traffickers in the Caribbean might have bought the complicity of low-level Cuban officials, there was no evidence of high-level drug corruption.
Although some officials said the Administration's new approach was gaining momentum, others predicted that it would increasingly be filtered through Mr. Gore's Presidential campaign. Mr. Gore, the officials said, has taken a relatively hard line on Cuban policy in the past, playing a prominent role in the decision to suspend charter flights in 1994.
A spokesman for Mr. Gore, Tom Rosshirt, said the Vice President supported a policy of building contacts with the Cuban people while maintaining economic pressure on the Government. Mr. Rosshirt declined to comment on specific advice that Mr. Gore has given Mr. Clinton on Cuba.

HEADLINE: Worry Over Insurance Fraud Extends to Grave

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: JACKSON, Miss., July 2

 BODY:
Charles Holmes was sitting in his wheelchair in his double-wide mobile home when he heard the news that somebody up North had run off with the money from a half-dozen Southern insurance companies.
"At first it didn't register," Mr. Holmes said. "Then I said, 'Hey, I got a policy with those folks.' It was kind of a shock. I thought, 'This dude has gone and swindled off all the money and some of us are going to be left out in the cold.' " 
 Mr. Holmes, a former police officer in nearby Pearl, is one of the tens of thousands of policyholders in Mississippi and neighboring states wondering just how badly they are going to be hurt by a huge fraud that authorities say was pulled off by Martin R. Frankel, a reclusive money manager in Greenwich, Conn. Several hundred million dollars is missing from insurers controlled by Mr. Frankel, who Federal law enforcement officials say may have fled to Europe.
For years, Mr. Holmes and most of the others have made small monthly payments on policies worth a few thousand dollars to cover their burial costs. Regulators have assured them that their benefits will eventually be paid. But with the looted companies out of money, many are concerned.
"I prayed about it last night, and the church prayed for all the policyholders," said Kitty Ruth Lowry, a 62-year-old widow with two policies on herself and one on her son.
Even George Dale, the Insurance Commissioner in Mississippi, whose staff first discovered irregularities at Mr. Frankel's three companies in the state -- the Franklin Protective Life Insurance Company, the Family Guaranty Life Insurance Company and the First National Life Insurance Company of America -- betrays some reservations, saying he is "99 percent certain" that policyholders will be made whole.
Mr. Dale said he could think of nothing specific that might get in the way but that "nothing in life is certain."
Gordon Rusty Haydel, executive director of the Mississippi Life and Health Insurance Guaranty Association, an industry group responsible for guaranteeing payment of insurance benefits, is preparing to put a levy on the more than 640 life insurers doing business in the state to make up the losses of the Frankel companies, which have been seized by regulators.
As many as 300 policyholders may have died in Mississippi since the three companies were seized in early May and stopped paying claims, Mr. Haydel said. But he and Mr. Dale said they knew of no burials delayed for lack of insurance money.
Most policies in Mississippi used to pay burial costs are sold through funeral homes, which have been honoring the policies.
"I'm guaranteeing my people, they won't lose," said Steve Holland, owner of Lee Memorial Funeral Home in Tupelo. "I know the state guaranty fund is ultimately going to pay. I'm trying to keep pandemonium and bedlam from breaking out with my customers.
"In many cases, I placed their money with Franklin Protective. So I feel bad. My customers feel bad. But I'm reassuring them that I'm not going to let them lose."
Sheila Gates, a former agent for Franklin Protective Life, said the funeral homes were usually better known than the insurers. Burial insurance salespeople, she said, often begin a pitch by saying, "I'm representing so and so funeral home."
Small policies intended to pay burial costs are sold in most states, including New York. But advocates for consumers generally advise against them, noting they can be up to 10 times as expensive as term insurance. They are popular with low-income people, featuring monthly payments often less than $20 for up to $5,000 of coverage.
Insurance with better rates rarely comes in such small amounts, and the bigger, more economically efficient policies require larger premiums, often paid annually, which many people find beyond their reach.
Companies specializing in burial insurance charge higher rates, experts say, because their costs are higher. Even though agents in Mississippi work out of funeral homes, they often sell policies door to door and some still personally make monthly collections. With few exceptions, like people who acknowledge they are infected with the AIDS virus, coverage is available to all comers.
"If a man can fog a mirror -- if he's breathing -- he can usually buy this kind of insurance," said Harland Dyer, actuary for the Mississippi Insurance Department.
In Mississippi and much of the South, burial insurance is a matter of culture, tradition and rock-bottom economics. People of modest means say they take special comfort in knowing that no matter how bad things get, they can always pay their final expenses.
"I don't want my kids to have to put out anything to bury me," said Van Robinson Kersh, who is retired from a box factory and now works part time at a funeral home.
For many, this is the only insurance they have, their ties to the insurers among the few constants in life.
"I could call and ask them anything and they would give me an answer," said Frances Thornell, a 70-year-old widow with two policies on herself from a Frankel company and several on her children and grandchildren. "I'm just speechless."
Regulators have advised policyholders to keep making their monthly payments so their policies do not lapse. But many find that difficult to accept.
"Would you want to pay on something if you didn't know for sure it was going to be there for you?" Mrs. Lowry asked.
Mary Phillips, a retired furniture factory worker, said that every month when she helps her 85-year-old mother send off her insurance check, her mother tells her: "Well, I can be buried for another month. You won't have to put me in a ditch."
Ms. Philips said she has kept the news of trouble at Franklin Protective from her mother. "It would be very, very stressful for her," she said.
James Jack Robinson, who has made a small fortune in the funeral home business and four and a half years ago sold the company now known as Franklin Protective to a trust that investigators say was controlled by Mr. Frankel, said customers are often not aware that they can get much more insurance for their money.
"Agents for the better-priced insurance don't go out and knock on doors," he said.
Yet many around here say they would never think of buying anything but burial insurance.
Mr. Holmes and his wife, Faye, who drives a pickup for a courier service, both have $5,000 policies that cost them $23 a month. Even if they could save up to make one annual payment for more coverage, Mr. Holmes said, they probably would not.
"I was raised on this kind of insurance," he said. "My father bought it. His father bought it."
"In a way," he said, "you overpay. But these low premiums are enticing to a person who's only got a certain amount of money coming in."
To people here, Martin Frankel, the man who apparently made a fortune by looting their companies, is a hard-to-imagine faraway demon. If he is ever caught, they say, life in prison would be too kind.
"I didn't realize anyone could be so cruel," said Mrs. Thornell, who struggles with respiratory problems. "He must not have any feelings at all. I'm sure there are a lot of people like me living on Social Security and just able to pay for the insurance. Then some idiot like this comes and destroys us. It just drains you."
Mr. Holmes said he would like to see Mr. Frankel face to face.
"A lot of people," he said, "would love to get hold of the old boy and shake him a little bit to see what kind of change fell out. But I guess it's best for the law to handle that."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Media World to Conquer;
In Europe, Giants Are on the Rise

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
Europe's television industry is suddenly in the grip of an American-style consolidation.
Encouraged by the forces of the global economy and the power of the Internet, European media companies are forging cross-border links, and American giants like the Microsoft Corporation are buying into the action. The resulting corporate alliances are providing a gateway for advertisers to reach wider mass audiences and an opportunity for Europe to challenge America's supremacy in television programming. 
 The European television market was first opened up in the 1980's, as state broadcasting monopolies crumbled and commercial channels sprang up. Now the long-expected shakeout of an industry made up of dozens of struggling private and commercial channels has begun in earnest.
Europe, in fact, seems to be charging into a future very much like America's present, in which the TV industry is dominated by a handful of huge conglomerates. "It's a long road, and it will require a tremendous amount of money, but it will happen," said Marc Andre Feffer, deputy chairman and chief executive at Canal Plus in Paris.
The activity so far this year has been intense. A company in the Netherlands called United Pan-Europe Communications N.V. has been gobbling up cable companies across Europe and last month took a stake in SBS Broadcasting of Luxembourg, another innovator, to form a strategic alliance. In March, SBS acquired Central European Media Enterprises, a chain of TV and radio stations set up by Ronald S. Lauder in Central Europe after the fall of Communism. Last month, United Pan-Europe agreed to acquire Poland's leading provider of cable and satellite service and the fourth- and fifth-largest cable companies in France, lifting the number of its subscribers to 7.7 million in 10 European countries.
And Mediaset S.A., the Italian television company controlled by Silvio Berlusconi, an entrepreneur-turned-politician, and the Kirch Group of Germany announced a joint venture in March to market pay-per-view programming in four countries and handle Kirch's international film distribution and Mediaset's advertising sales.
Then, also in June, the French conglomerate Vivendi S.A. tightened its hold on Canal Plus, the French pay-per-view company, by taking over the French film production and distribution company, Pathe, that held a stake in Canal Plus. The gave rise to speculation that Canal Plus might revive discussions about cooperating with the News Corporation, owned by Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born media entrepreneur. Mr. Murdoch, who is pursuing the kind of television breakthrough in Europe that he has achieved in the United States with his Fox networks, acquired a stake in an Italian pay-for-view channel, Stream S.p.A., and a major chunk of German soccer rights through a small German affiliate, TeleMunchen, last month.
Mr. Murdoch, at a news conference in London last week, ruled out a merger between the News Corporation's B Sky B and Canal Plus but kept the door open for looser alliances in areas like film production and rights to sporting events.
What is causing this frenzy of reorganization? Mainly, the global economy, which is forcing Europe's relatively small players to join forces to cover the costs of switching to digital and pay-per-view TV and of marketing integrated bundles of television, telephone and Internet services.
"Several axes are evolving," said Nick Bertolotti, who follows the television business at J. P. Morgan in London. Describing the industry's state as "very unstable," he added, "Anything can happen."
American companies are a big part of the equation.
Pan-Europe Communications is controlled by the Denver-based investor group Unitedglobalcom. And, imitating the American drive into "bundled" telephone and Internet services, it has already provided 118,000 of its cable customers with phone service and more than 40,000 with Internet access.
Microsoft recently acquired a 7.8 percent stake in United Pan-Europe Communications as part of its effort to extend its reach into the European telecommunications revolution. "The rate of growth is moving very, very quickly," said Henrietta Hirst, a spokeswoman for United Pan-Europe in Amsterdam.
Microsoft has also taken stakes in leading cable companies in Britain and Portugal, while the longtime American television businessman Harry Evans Sloan has invested in SBS. American groups like Unitedglobalcom, which was known until recently as United International Holdings Inc., and Internet service providers like America Online Inc. are searching out European opportunities, as are providers of television programming, like the Walt Disney Company, that see the promise of larger markets for their products.
If much of this sounds like an echo of what is happening in the United States, it is also enhancing the local flavor of European television. European productions are hardly about to outstrip American programs as Europe's fare of choice, but the Europeans have reconquered prime time with home-grown quiz shows and soap operas. Last year, there were no American series and only 2 American feature films among the 10 most popular programs in Britain, France, Germany and Italy.
To be sure, off-prime time is still saturated with American products. Cable and pay per view now enable TV audiences to see hit films like "Titanic" within months of their release, and channels across Europe are showing reruns of "Little House on the Prairie," "Hogan's Heroes," "Cheers," "Golden Girls" and "Baywatch," dubbed into the local languages, as they have for years.
But the the sheer proliferation of new channels and technologies means more broadcast time for everybody. As a result, European production of both high-quality programs and knockoffs of American schlock, like a French version of "Baywatch" called "St.-Tropez," is making big inroads into American territory.
While Europe remains a checkerboard of small markets divided by culture and language, industry consolidation means that broadcasters have bigger, more efficient organizations to help them offer national programming. Thus, "the market is becoming more European," said Fedele Confalonieri, president of Mediaset. He said Mediaset's vision "is for many local broadcasters, as there are in the United States, united in large units, like CBS or ABC."
As an example of how this works, consider Mediaset's alliance with Kirch. Under it, the Germans focus on what they do best -- program production and trading of rights -- while Mediaset brings in expertise in advertising sales and program distribution. (Mediaset's parent company, Fininvest S.p.A., holds a stake in the European affiliate of the Blockbuster video chain.)
One of last year's most popular programs was "The Count of Monte Cristo," a $20 million, three-part miniseries produced jointly by Mediaset, Kirch and the leading commercial broadcaster in France, TF 1. And as Europe unifies, more and more companies are broadcasting the same commercial spots across the Continent, enabling Mediaset to sell air time in a multinational way. "The spots for McDonald's, Sony and Disney are the same in London, Paris and Milan," Mr. Confalonieri said.
European regulators are casting a wary eye on the deal-making, especially on agreements that concentrate a lot of power in a single entity. In April, for example, Britain blocked a plan by Mr. Murdoch to acquire the leading British soccer team, Manchester United, for $1 billion. And earlier, Italy limited the television soccer rights that any one broadcaster could control, thwarting a bid by Mr. Murdoch for most Italian professional soccer rights.
Although those attempts failed, they demonstrated Mr. Murdoch's faith in the power of sporting events to draw big television audiences. Indeed, the News Corporation has succeeded in acquiring broadcast rights to four of Italy's top soccer teams. And one of the attractions of Kirch as a partner for Mediaset was Kirch's $1.7 billion purchase earlier this year of the rights to broadcast the soccer World Cup in 2002 and 2006.
"At the end of the day, TV wants to drive ad revenues, which come from ratings," said Jose Violante, managing director of NBA Europe S.A., the marketing arm of the National Basketball Association in Paris. "And how do you get those ads? Sporting events."
As in the United States, pay-per-view TV companies, with cables that reach into millions of households, are drawing considerable investment in Europe, not least from American companies. Microsoft's decision to gather stakes in European cable television operators is based on the expectation they will require cash and technology to offer customers high-speed access to the Internet. In Italy, the Mediaset parent, Fininvest, has a deal with Excite Inc., America's second-largest Internet portal, while Bertelsmann in Germany is working similarly with America Online.
Georges Nahon, the head of Microsoft's Paris-based European Internet and telecommunications activities, said Microsoft focused on cable TV because of regulatory restrictions on the use of phone lines for Internet service. But the cable companies generally need both cash and technology, Mr. Nahon said, explaining Microsoft's policy of taking equity shares. Microsoft continues to search for cable partners, he said, and not necessarily as potential investment targets, but also as customers for software and services. "We are looking at companies that are very connected to high-speed data carriage," he said.
In the meantime, the television companies, while entrepreneurial, are not necessarily all moving at the speed of the Internet.
Mr. Confalonieri of Mediaset, while acknowledging that Internet access is part of the company's plans, said the immediate aims of the deal with Kirch were production, distribution and advertising sales. "The rest," he said, "is wishful thinking where tomorrow is a little blurred."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

British Telecom Ordered To Open Network to Rivals
Already under pressure from rival telephone and cable operators, British Telecommunications, which controls about 85 percent of the "local loop" copper network used by home subscribers and small businesses, was ordered by regulators to upgrade its network and open it to competitors by July 2001.
The directive reflects the rapidly intensifying competition in Europe to offer high-speed Internet access and other broadband services. But it also highlights the difficult situation facing the former state monopoly: competition is likely to accelerate the growth of the high-speed market, but it could also reduce British Telecommunications' slice of it. Page C5. 

Bill Could Create New Type of Bank
Depending on what a Congressional conference committee does, legislation that would overhaul the nation's financial system could include a provision for wholesale banks, which would take only large deposits and do everything else a commercial bank does. C2.
 
Oil Prices Approach $20 a Barrel
Crude oil rose to a 19-month high, near $20 a barrel, on signs that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would adhere to its promised production cuts in the months ahead. King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil-producing nation and OPEC's most influential member, said that his country would stick with its cuts. Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates also said the output reductions should be maintained. C7.
 
Late Selloff Pushes Stocks Lower
An afternoon selloff pulled stock prices down from early gains. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 4.12 points, to 11,135.12. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 3.10 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 1,388.12, and the Nasdaq composite index fell 4.24 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 2,736.78. C7.
 
Bond prices fell, sending yields to their highest level in a week. The yield on the 30-year issue rose to 6.03 percent from 6 percent. C7.
 
U.S. Sues Boeing Over Bias Inquiry
In an unusual legal tussle between the Government and its second-largest military contractor, the Department of Labor filed three lawsuits against Boeing, contending that the company was blocking its investigation of charges of racial discrimination. A17.
 
Death Casts Light on Frankel's Life
The death of a woman two years ago at the Greenwich, Conn., home of Martin R. Frankel provides an unusual insight into the life of Mr. Frankel, who is suspected of defrauding insurance companies in several states of hundreds of millions of dollars. B1.
 
Russian Businessmen Aid Charity
Although Russian businessmen are often vilified as exploiters and tax cheats, many are making significant contributions to nonprofit causes. The largest donation made by a Russian company or individual since 1917 came from Vladimir Potanin, who runs a financial-industrial group called Interros. He gave $1.4 million to support the reconstruction of the Rostral Columns, one of St. Petersburg's historic landmarks. C4.
 
Bathroom Humor Works for Film Ad
The advertising campaign for the film "Big Daddy," which shows two actors poised as if urinating, represents what may be the first time that a major Hollywood studio has sold a mainstream movie on the basis of a bodily function. But the ads have received almost universal acceptance by the media and few complaints. Advertising: Stuart Elliott. C6.
 
Russian Official to Head Company
Bowing to political pressure to reduce the role of foreign investors, the board of Russia's largest shipping company, Far Eastern Shipping, elected Aleksandr Lugovets, Russia's Deputy Transportation Minister, as chairman. C4.
 
Purchasing Index Shows Growth
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its index of nonmanufacturing business rose last month, suggesting the economy will continue to expand. C2.

SECTION: Section D; Page 4; Column 5; Sports Desk 

LENGTH: 842 words

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS;
Goodwill Games Headed for Bosnia?

BYLINE: By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
The war in Bosnia from 1992 to 1995 destroyed nearly all the athletic sites of the 1984 Winter Olympics in Sarajevo.
The wooden seats from the Zetra arena were used for coffins. The bobsled run turned into trenches. The mountain site for Nordic skiing was transformed into a Serbian artillery position. The Olympic stadium became a graveyard. 
 But Sarajevo, which plans to bid for the 2010 Winter Olympics, is trying to jump-start its resurrection by persuading Turner Sports to take the Winter Goodwill Games to the city.
"The process of reconciliation in Bosnia needs a spur, something to show the people that we are capable of pulling together," said Muhamed Sacirbey, the Ambassador to the United Nations from Bosnia and Herzegovina. "There have been three great world events in Sarajevo: the assassination of Archduke Ferdinand, the 1984 Olympics and the siege of Sarajevo. We prefer to be remembered for what the Olympics stand for: pluralism, tolerance and good will."
Sacirbey first discussed the Goodwill Games several months ago with Harvey Schiller, the president of Turner Sports. Mostly they discussed TNT's televising a figure skating event at the rebuilt Zetra, but the show was canceled because of NATO's bombing in Yugoslavia.
"We're excited," said Schiller, who visited with Bosnian Government and Olympic officials in Sarajevo last week. "But we've expressed our concerns with their ability to get it done. They've got rebuilding to do. The challenge lies with them."
Sacirbey admitted that his intense push for the 2001 Winter Goodwill Games will depend in part on the ability of Bosnia to attract public and private investors to build hotels and finance the continued reconstruction of the athletic sites. A deal with Turner, he said, may persuade private lenders and sponsors to make commitments.
"With private partners, they hear Bosnia, you think war, and why do you want to be there," he said. The athletic sites are in various states of repair, he said. The Zetra is ready. Some skiing has been restored. The speed-skating track is being rebuilt. Work is about to start on the ski-jumping facility. The bobsled and luge runs will not be resurrected.
Schiller is uncertain if Turner will commit to Sarajevo. Turner's first Winter Goodwill Games will take place in Lake Placid, N.Y., next year; to run two in consecutive years may not be plausible. Yet Schiller will consider it. A report on Sarajevo is due in September.
Sacirbey does not think a delay until 2002 is feasible because of the Winter Olympics that year in Salt Lake City. And 2003 seems too far away. "You want to maximize the benefits of this by doing it as soon as possible," he said.
Schiller said, "They'll need a lot of economic wherewithal to get it done."
Sacirbey would not rule out 2003. Bosnia is in no position to force anything. "We're looking to work as partners," he said. "We've had a good dialogue. No one wants to play hardball."
The allure of Sarajevo to Turner Sports, which staged the Goodwill Games in Moscow (1986) and St. Petersburg, Russia (1994), would be to reclaim the original peaceful intent behind the event. Ted Turner launched the games in 1986 after the United States boycotted the 1980 Summer Olympics in Moscow and the Soviet Union boycotted the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles.
Last year, when the games came to New York City, their purpose was redefined to raising money for the Boys and Girls Clubs of America and Unicef International.
 
Wimbledon Bidding
With Wimbledon over, so are NBC's and HBO's contracts to broadcast the tournament. NBC wants to continue, but HBO does not. ABC appears to be NBC's main rival, with ESPN, Fox Sports Net and the USA Network looking to replace HBO.
NBC is unlikely to bring in one of its cable units, MSNBC or CNBC, and would have to live with ESPN, Fox Sports Net or USA selling commercial time for the same event. (HBO carries no advertising.) NBC could team with Turner Sports, with which it is planning a football league, but it is not considered a strong possibility.
CBS is not likely to be in the fray because the All England Club would not be thrilled to have its Wimbledon jewel on the same network that carries the United States Open.
It's a good time for Wimbledon negotiations. The past weekend's ratings soared, because of the strong American showing and the placement of both singles finals on Sunday. The overnight Nielsen rating on Sunday leaped 40 percent to a 5.6. For the semifinals on Saturday, the rating jumped 48 percent.
 
A Woods-Duval Shortfall?
ABC might not show all 18 holes of the Aug. 2 Tiger Woods-David Duval prime-time (8 to 11 P.M., Eastern) match-play exhibition. The PGA Tour is insisting that the event begin at 7:30 P.M. Eastern (4:30 P.M. at the Sherwood Country Club in Los Angeles) to guarantee enough time to complete a round. ABC would join it in progress.
"The history of match play shows it takes between 3 hours and 20 minutes and 3:40," said Henry Hughes, the chief of operations for the PGA Tour.

HEADLINE: VOWING TO PURSUE PEACE WITH ARABS, BARAK TAKES OVER

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 6

 BODY:
Seven long weeks of political negotiations after he was elected, Ehud Barak took office as Prime Minister of Israel today and pledged that the pursuit of a "true, lasting peace" would be his foremost concern.
In a passionate inaugural speech, Mr. Barak, 57, addressed not only the Israelis glued to their radios and televisions but also the many Palestinians and Syrians who watched, waiting for messages. Despite a chorus of criticism against him for the composition of his Cabinet and some wariness about him in the region, Mr. Barak sounded a conciliatory note. 
 He reached out to all his domestic constituencies -- from high-tech workers to blue-collar unionists to soldiers' mothers "who don't sleep at night" -- as well as to each of Israel's neighbors.
Departing from the confrontational tone of Benjamin Netanyahu, his predecessor, Mr. Barak, the OneIsrael/Labor Party leader, told the Palestinians that he recognized their "suffering."
He spoke of the pain and death on both sides of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and suggested that each stop focusing on the "account settling of historical wrongs."
While Mr. Netanyahu always emphasized the dangers surrounding Israel, Mr. Barak described his country as "strong and confident." And he urged Israel's neighbors to meet him at the diplomatic table with an equal determination to ride the ups and downs of difficult negotiations.
"I call on all regional leaders to take our outstretched hands and build a peace of the brave," Mr. Barak said, embracing the phrase that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, often uses.
With a clear intent to allay the concerns of Palestinians that negotiations with Syria would take precedence, Mr. Barak said he would move forward on both peace tracks at once.
But, underscoring his keen interest in reopening talks with Syria, which controls much of Lebanon, Mr. Barak repeated his campaign promise to withdraw Israeli troops from southern Lebanon within a year.
In Gaza tonight, Mr. Barak's words were received by Palestinians as a welcome break from the perceived hostility of Mr. Netanyahu, who officially quit the Parliament today, shaking hands and walking out with his back to the television cameras still pursuing him.
Still, Palestinian leaders, who are wary of Mr. Barak, expressed cautious optimism. "Barak's speech is an important and positive signal," said Ahmed Qurei, known as Abu Ala, the Speaker of the Palestinian legislature. "We hope his words will soon be followed by deeds."
Mr. Barak is expected to meet next week with Mr. Arafat before traveling to Washington in mid-July for his first official meeting with President Clinton. Mr. Barak is also expected to see President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and King Abdullah of Jordan this month.
Using vivid language in his address, Mr. Barak, a highly decorated former general, described himself as a "warrior" who "for tens of years wore no other clothes but the olive uniform." Citing verses from the poet A. Hillel, he called himself one of the "gray soldiers whose hands are blackened from war and whose nostrils are filled with death."
"Our tongue is dry from the march," he quoted, "And we cry love into the insides of your souls."
After weeks of political negotiating behind closed doors, Mr. Barak re-emerged into the public eye this afternoon when he presented his Cabinet to the Parliament. Hours later, in a ceremony in the Israeli President's house, he was sworn in as the leader of a large majority coalition, controlling nearly two-thirds of the Parliament.
It was "no accident," he said in his inaugural speech, that he had taken almost all the 45 days allowed by law to form a Government now made up of seven very different political parties. "I was forced by the lessons of Jewish history and the deep divide within our people to form a Government that will be able to function during the most difficult times with the wide acceptance of the majority," he said.
From the lectern, as he spoke of inclusiveness, he faced down catcalls from Israeli Arab members of Parliament who feel unjustly excluded from his Cabinet. "How are you going to be the Prime Minister of everyone?" one shouted. "Where are the Arab ministers?"
Later, from another direction, Mr. Barak was rebuked by Ariel Sharon, the temporary leader of the opposition Likud Party, for not saying "one word" that would characterize the importance of the state as a "Zionist Jewish" enterprise.
Mr. Sharon, the former Foreign Minister, also criticized Mr. Barak for intransigence during the unsuccessful coalition negotiations with the Likud, and said that the "unique" personal relationship between them had been damaged.
Mr. Sharon said that he had requested and been denied the power to monitor the future peace negotiations, which, he said, in a reference to Mr. Barak, should not be controlled by only "one person no matter how talented he is."
Stinging news media criticism today labeled Mr. Barak as a leader with autocratic tendencies, calling him everything from "Caligulan" to a near "Ehud Bonaparte."
The criticism began after Mr. Barak unveiled his Cabinet. He was accused by many of making weak or inappropriate appointments. And many suggested that he was doing his best to consolidate his hold on power so that he could tackle his ambitious political agenda without interference.
In a country with a Parliament, it is unusual for the Prime Minister to act in a semi-presidential manner, but Mr. Barak, who was elected in a separate ballot from his party, says he has received a personal mandate.
"Barak promised fast economic growth, social justice, leaving Lebanon, completion of the peace accords, national reconciliation and security," Nahum Barnea, a senior political columnist, wrote in Yedioth Ahronoth. "Judging from the composition of the Government, it seems that he expects to carry out all of these tasks alone, with a commando knife between his teeth."
The new Prime Minister stared in the face his first political failure today when Avraham Burg, an ambitious Labor Party official and sometime critic of Mr. Barak, was sworn in as Speaker of the Parliament. Mr. Barak had backed a political novice for the post, only to have his own party choose Mr. Burg instead.
When Mr. Burg took his chair late this afternoon, he shook hands with the Prime Minister. "I have no hate in my heart toward the Prime Minister," he had said earlier in the day.
This afternoon, after presenting his Cabinet of 18 ministers, Mr. Barak said he would move immediately to alter the basic law of Israel. To accommodate the seven parties in his coalition and to take on tasks that are "humongous, maybe even historic," he said he would propose to expand the Cabinet to 24 ministers.
"And only one woman?" Tamar Gozansky, a member of Parliament from the Communist Party, called out.
Although he pledged to include at least three women in his Cabinet, he has appointed only one, Dalia Itzik of Labor, who will be Environment Minister, and no deputy ministers who are women. He has been roundly criticized for that.
Against the background noise of those charges, Mr. Barak nonetheless portrayed himself today as the leader of all sectors of Israeli society, a proponent of equal rights, and a healer.
He more or less apologized that Israel has "not always been wise enough to invest equally in all of its people." The remark was an echo of a legendary apology that Mr. Barak had earlier made to the Israeli Jews of Middle Eastern descent, on behalf of the Labor Party, whose original treatment of them is largely considered to have been discriminatory. He said he empathized with poor people who are "full of broken promises."
"We will change the national priorities," he said, promising to create 300,000 new jobs in the next four years and to invest heavily in education.
At one point, Mr. Barak addressed a personal remark to President Hafez Assad of Syria,
"We have been harsh and bitter enemies on the battlefield," he said. "Now it is time to form an open and brave peace that will insure the future and security of our peoples, our children and our grandchildren."
Mr. Barak also talked about working with Mr. Arafat to build a "true partnership in this land in which two peoples will live."
In a challenge to his intentions, bulldozers cleared land earlier in the day for a Jewish quarter in an Arab neighborhood of East Jerusalem. The Palestinians have urged Mr. Barak to stop expansion of settlements on land whose fate will be negotiated, and the guidelines of Mr. Barak's Government promise to do that.
Haim Ramon, who was sworn in as a minister today, will oversee Jerusalem. He said that the project, Ras al-Amud, should be canceled.

HEADLINE: Albany Tells Nassau: Price of a Bailout Is Oversight by the Comptroller

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., July 6

 BODY:
Democrats in Albany today made clear their asking price for a bailout of the Nassau County government, whose Republican leaders have run up a deficit of more than $200 million: the State Comptroller, who also happens to be a Democrat, would be given sweeping powers to supervise the county's financial practices.
Hoping to speed up talks with the Nassau County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, who is seeking legislative approval for a new 1 percent tax on real estate sales, Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli released a draft bill today that would drastically change the way Mr. Gulotta runs the county. He would be required to issue a great many long-term financial plans, projections and reports that are customary for businesses and many governments but for the most part are unheard-of in Nassau. 
 More important, Mr. DiNapoli's proposal would force the County Executive to obtain Comptroller H. Carl McCall's approval for all budgets and bond issues -- a requirement that Mr. Gulotta is unlikely to accept willingly, officials involved in the negotiations said.
Still, the draft bill falls well short of assigning total control over the county's finances to an independent agency, as happened in the New York City fiscal crisis of 1975.
Mr. DiNapoli, of Great Neck, who is also the Nassau Democratic leader, said the draft summarizes the Assembly leadership's current negotiating position. "I really felt we needed to spell out, in very clear terms, what we meant by 'oversight with teeth,' " he said, using a phrase he has repeated often in recent weeks. "If they want to have a few less teeth than we're proposing, we're open to talking about it. But it has to be something real."
Attempts to reach Mr. Gulotta and other Republican officials were unsuccessful today after power failures here emptied a number of county offices. A spokesman for Mr. Gulotta did not respond to telephone messages left at the spokesman's home.
Mr. DiNapoli said that in his talks with Mr. Gulotta's lobbyist, Brian R. Meara, the county's willingness to accept financial oversight seemed to be in flux. Most recently, he said, Nassau seemed to back away from any kind of strict supervision.
"Given Nassau's history," Mr. DiNapoli said, "they weren't really dealing with the reality of the situation."
After years in which the county spent more than it raised in taxes, Nassau's yawning budget deficit last week caused Standard & Poor's, the bond-rating agency, to cut the county's credit rating to one category above that reserved for junk bonds. The budget problems stick out even more because of the county's economic prosperity, which in other municipalities has translated into record surpluses.
Here are some major components of the Democratic proposal, which draws heavily on a plan by Mr. McCall and Gov. George E. Pataki, announced last month, for an "early warning system" to identify and assist local governments in the early stages of fiscal stress:
*The County Executive would have to prepare a four-year financial plan with each year's budget. The Comptroller would then review both the plan and its revenue estimates. If they appeared unsound, relying too heavily on one-shot revenues or otherwise contributing to deficits, the Comptroller could reject the plan and, if the county failed to submit an acceptable plan, substitute his own.
*Proposed budgets would have to fall within the revenue and spending projections of the four-year financial plan. The County Executive would have discretion over how money is spent, but he could not exceed the plan's limits. The Comptroller could take the county to court to force it to bring its budgets into compliance.
*The County Executive would have to issue quarterly reports explaining any departures from projected revenues and expenses. If a deficit opened up, he would have to provide more documentation and submit a remedial plan to the Comptroller for approval.
*Before the county issued any bonds or notes, the Comptroller would have to comment publicly on the county's ability to pay off those debts. An unfavorable comment by the Comptroller would increase the county's borrowing costs, according to a member of the Assembly's Ways and Means Committee staff.
*A 15-member panel would review the county's finances, compensation packages for nonunion county workers and all personal service agreements with the county. Five members would be appointed each by the County Executive and the majority and minority leaders of the County Legislature.

HEADLINE: A HEAT WAVE SIZZLES: THE POWER;
Utility Officials Sweat Out a Record Demand

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 6

 BODY:
Electric companies from here to Maine were stretched so thin today by demand from millions of air-conditioners that they breathed a sigh of relief when the weather broke, even though the break was in Michigan.
"It's good news; they'll have a little more to send us," said William J. Balet, executive director of the New York Power Pool, a consortium of the state's power generators and users that imports and exports power to and from utilities outside the state based on supply, demand and price. The pool also helps coordinate power production within the state. 
 Utilities in the eastern United States set records for demand today. Most of them were able to squeak through on supplies that they produced or imported, although electric companies in New York State and a broad area to the south cut voltage. In New York City tonight, all power was lost in Manhattan north of 155th Street, as well as on Long Island and in central New Jersey, mostly because the distribution lines and transformers overheated.
In all, hundreds of thousands of people lost power for at least part of the day.
The peaks in demand for electricity are getting ever higher, experts say, because all new commercial buildings and most new houses have air-conditioning, and owners of older houses are adding air-conditioning.
"People talk about how much better the economy is," said Ron Morano, a spokesman for General Public Utilities, in New Jersey. "People left their air-conditioners on for four consecutive days, day and night, and that contributed."
Many utilities called on customers to shut off nonessential appliances; the New England Power Pool avoided voltage cuts but asked the governors of the six New England states to appeal to the public for conservation.
In Washington, the Potomac Electric Power Company warned on its Web site that people should curtail consumption to prevent a "complete failure of the electric power grid." The notice warned, "This is a very serious situation," entirely in capital letters.
But Potomac Electric, like other utilities, made do with voltage reductions. Such cuts make electric motors run a bit slower and make the picture shrink slightly on computer and television screens, but generally do not hurt computers or other electric appliances. But when power is cut completely, computers can crash and data can be lost forever.
While people on the streets were breaking into a sweat, utility officials were doing the same indoors. About two dozen of them around eastern North America, including Mr. Balet in New York, held a conference call at 8 A.M., where they got the news of the weather break from their counterparts in Michigan. The officials also imported power from Ontario, Quebec and the Canadian Maritime Provinces, among other sources.
The conference call is a daily ritual on days like this when each power line, literally sagging as the heat makes it stretch, becomes a critical lifeline. The three major power pools in the Northeast all set records for demand today: the New York Power Pool, the New England Power Pool and the Pennsylvania-Jersey-Maryland Interconnection, which covers most of Pennsylvania and all of New Jersey, Maryland, Delaware and the District of Columbia.
All reported having much less generating capacity in reserve than they are accustomed to. That left them vulnerable to "load shedding" (their preferred term for blackouts) if they lost a single big generating station or transmission line. All said that in areas where power was deregulated -- such as in the Pennsylvania-Jersey-Maryland Interconnection area -- electricity was trading at a price 10 to 20 times higher than normal, near $1,000 a megawatt-hour.
So far, such extreme prices are a phenomenon of the wholesale market, but some energy economists think that they will make their way into pricing for factories and other big customers, to encourage them to close and send employees home on the hottest days, moderating the demand peaks and reducing the number of plants built to supply power only a few days a year. Already, many utilities offer big customers the option of getting lower prices for most of the year in exchange for allowing the power company to cut them off on days like today. And today, they were all shut down.
New York hit a peak load of 30,311 megawatts today, and it would have been higher but for a line of cooling thunderstorms upstate. The previous peak was 27,700 megawatts in July 1997.
New England set a record on June 28 of 21,810 megawatts, but broke it today, with 22,500 megawatts.
And the Pennsylvania-Jersey-Maryland Interconnection supplied about 52,000 megawatts, up from 49,406 megawatts two years ago.

HEADLINE: Common Ground Elusive as Technology Have-Nots Meet Haves

BYLINE: By KATIE HAFNER 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif.

 BODY:
FOR the average Internet user in the United States, life is a never-ending stream of dilemmas: Upgrade now or later. Order I.S.D.N. or wait for cable modem service to arrive. Buy the Palm V organizer or go with the one that connects to the Web. Check E-mail while on vacation or leave the laptop at home.
But a conference held here in June underscored a very different reality: in many corners of the world, there are dozens of developing countries where widespread access to the Internet -- of any kind -- remains a distant possibility. 
 While it is true that some of the earth's most remote places are now linked to the Net -- one recent addition is Bhutan, a small kingdom in the Himalayas, which inaugurated its first Internet link last month -- there are still no connections at all in Iraq, North Korea and a handful of African countries. In many countries that have Internet connections, Net access is concentrated in the largest cities and is prohibitively expensive when set against an individual's typical income. That expense largely restricts the use of the Internet to an elite, mostly made up of foreigners, government workers and business people. And in some cases, government censors put the Internet out of reach for most people in their countries.
The conference here, called INET 99, was the annual meeting of the Internet Society, a nonprofit group that coordinates Internet-related projects around the world and has the motto "Internet Is for Everyone." Each year, the group holds a three-day conference; previous locations have included Prague, Montreal, Geneva and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. This year, 1,600 network administrators, academics and business people gathered at the gleaming, cavernous San Jose Convention Center in the heart of Silicon Valley. That backdrop accentuated the fast-paced, high-risk, moneyed world of high technology, a world very far away from the everyday experiences of the people attending from developing nations.
Many people at the conference, from places like Japan, Germany, Finland and the Netherlands, were sophisticated Internet users, concerned with cutting-edge technical issues. But many others were from countries where Internet connections are available to only a privileged few.
"It created a sort of schizophrenia," said Will Foster, a research assistant at the University of Arizona in Tucson who attended the conference. "The presentations by Ebay and E*trade highlighted the tension between the go-go growth of Internet start-up companies in Silicon Valley and the realities of Internet connectivity in countries like Cameroon."
Each year, a workshop is held for a week preceding the conference; this year, 143 people from 66 developing nations attended. It is aimed at sending participants home with additional technical and administrative skills for running networks.
Those accepted for the workshop -- 570 people applied -- have basic technical skills. "They also have to have leverage within their organization, and the organization has to have leverage in the country -- for example, someone running networking for the major university in the country or within the P.T.T.," said George Sadowsky, the Internet Society's vice president for education, referring to the shorthand used for many countries' national telecommunications providers.
The demographics of the workshop shift each year, as telecommunications needs change across the world. The first workshop, in 1993, had a large contingent of Eastern Europeans. This year, more than half of the participants were from Africa, which accounted for about 13 percent of the world's population but just 1 percent of the world's Internet users as of the end of March, according to data from Mike Jensen, a consultant with the Association for Progressive Communications, a nonprofit group based in Johannesburg. Excluding South Africa (where 1 in every 177 people uses the Internet), for every 4,123 Africans, there is just 1 person who uses the Internet, according to Mr. Jensen's figures.
Wawa A. Ngenge, the national coordinator for the Sustainable Development Networking Program in Cameroon, said his country got its first Internet connection in 1997. Internet service providers there pay the national phone company $3,000 per month for a 64-kilobits-per-second line, which is not much faster than the fastest dial-up modem; such slow speeds are common in developing countries and mean that I.S.P. customers must put up with very slow speeds. Just 15,000 people out of 15 million have Internet access, all of it concentrated in the capital, Yaounde. Using the Internet costs about $3 per hour in Cameroon, a country where the average civil servant makes about $200 a month, Dr. Ngenge said.
One thing slowing the Internet's spread in developing countries is the fact that many governments there enjoy a telephone monopoly. Dr. Sadowsky said such governments feared that the Internet might reduce the revenue from international telephone calls and faxes. "Telecommunications rates are extraordinarily high," Dr. Sadowsky said. "In the worst case, the P.T.T. provides one-fifth of a country's G.N.P. Part of our work is in convincing countries that if you ignore the Internet, you'll keep your telephone revenues the same, but you'll pay in opportunity cost, in terms of economic and social development."
Once the main conference began, those who had attended the workshop found little use for the general sessions, many of which focused on state-of-the-art wireless communications, E-commerce, venture capital and the development of Internet II.
After a panelist at one session mentioned that 40 percent of all venture money was invested within a 40-mile radius of where he was sitting, a member of the audience asked about the prospects for venture capital investments in the developing world. "Remember, we're technology investors," the panelist answered politely.
"They're so far away from us," Dr. Ngenge said of conference participants from wealthier countries. "We're worrying about two different sets of problems."
One prominent set of problems is, of course, political. In Laos, for instance, the Communist government considers the Internet a destabilizing influence because of the free flow of information associated with the Web and keeps connections scarce, said Paula Uimonen, a Swedish researcher in Geneva who is studying the Internet in Laos and presented a paper at the conference. "It's obvious that it's a lack of political willingness," she said.
In some countries, users who can connect to the Internet sometimes find that access to certain sites is blocked, according to Human Rights Watch. The group said that some Mideast countries, for example, blocked access to political sites under the guise of protecting users from pornography.
Laos has had E-mail since late 1994, Ms. Uimonen said, and got its first I.S.P. last year. There are 1,000 Internet users, most of whom are foreigners. There are two cybercafes in the capital, Vientiane, but Laotians are not allowed in.
The connection of Myanmar, formerly Burma, to the Internet remains similarly tenuous. All modems must be registered with the government, which is run by the military, Dr. Sadowsky said. Neither Laos nor Myanmar had representatives at the conference.
Immigration policies can make it hard for people to get to the conference. Two Cubans were invited to participate in the workshop, but one was not given a visa and because of that, the other stayed home. A person from Sudan was registered for the conference and had a visa but was detained by the Immigration and Naturalization Service in New York, then sent back to Sudan.
A 24-year-old network administrator from Hanoi named Tuan Bui Anh arrived in California without incident. He said Vietnam got its first Internet connection in late 1997. Before that, computer users could send E-mail but could not go out on the Web. Net Nam, the main I.S.P., and four other service providers have connections concentrated in Hanoi and Ho Chi Minh City.
E-commerce has yet to make an impression in places like Vietnam, where few people have credit cards. Following a keynote speech given by Meg Whitman, chief executive of the Ebay auction site, Mr. Tuan seemed a bit bewildered. "I think this is for the Americans only," he said.

HEADLINE: Addition to Consumers' Arsenal: net Complaint Services for Hire

BYLINE: By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
GIVEN the service economy's hire-someone-else mentality, which leads some people to pay others to walk the dog and tutor the children in baseball, it is no wonder that you can now hire Internet businesses to complain on your behalf.
Sites like Complain.com and Fight Back promise to write letters, make phone calls and, if necessary, whine in exchange for a modest -- and sometimes not so modest -- fee. 
 "A lot of people have tried to handle problems themselves, but they're frustrated and angry," said Bill Tran, president of Caveat Emptor (www.cemptor.com), which went on line in March. "They want to forget about it," Mr. Tran said. "That's when I jump in."
One angry America Online customer, Elizabeth Huntington of Bradenton, Fla., failed to get an erroneous AOL charge canceled after three discussions with customer representatives over four weeks. "I don't think that business, especially AOL, takes me seriously," she said.
She turned up Caveat Emptor (www.cemptor.com) by searching for "complaint" on the Web. A week after Caveat Emptor sent a letter, AOL returned $48 to Ms. Huntington, along with a refund for a $50 bank overdraft fee. "When they got the letter from me through Caveat, then they took me seriously," Miss Huntington said. She wouldn't have got her money back without Caveat Emptor, she said.
Companies and clients say their specialized services are more effective than the efforts of a consumer working alone. "The reason the average person can't do this is that the average person does not have the kind of resources that we have," said David Horowitz, a consumer advocate who writes a "Fight Back" syndicated newspaper column and has a Web site at www.fightback.com.
With Americans buying and spending more than ever, the inevitable result is more services, products and goods to complain about. In addition, customer satisfaction with technology products may be declining in the face of rising product quality, creating a rich customer base for the professional complainers.
Some Web enterprises will complain for clients on a budget. The Consumer Complaint Resolution Company (www.complaintresolution .com) bills $29.95, or a 20 percent commission on the amount recovered. Fight Back will send out a letter personally signed by Mr. Horowitz for $25, a flat fee the company said covered administrative costs. Complain.com (www.complain.com) pleads a case for only $19.95. Caveat Emptor writes free complaint letters (but may start charging someday).
A number of these sites, like Fight Back and Caveat Emptor, also have complaint bulletin boards for posting complaints publicly. The goal is to give companies and agencies an incentive to shape up.
"This is a new way of handling it, where you can use the power of the Internet and the power of mass public exposure to resolve people's problems," Mr. Horowitz said.
Specialized expertise can carry a hefty price tag. Gary and Sandy Rattigan of Somerville, Mass., started Complain to Us in 1997 (www .complaintous.com). They charge $50 per hour (and a 30 percent commission when larger sums are recovered). They say they have an overall success rate of about 80 percent. Ellen Phillips of Alexandria, Va., gave up teaching English in middle school last year to turn all her attention to her business, Ellen's Poison Pen (www.ellenspoisonpen.com). She recently raised her rates to $30 per 100 words and $65 per hour. Clients spend an average of $400 for her services.
An Ellen's Poison Pen customer, Jamie Urick of Frankfort, Ill., explained, "If you have leg pain and you go to a physical therapist, you go to an expert -- it's the same thing." Mrs. Urick and her neighbors were frustrated that repeated pleas to state and county officials had resulted in no action against a noisy dirt bike track. Mrs. Phillips composed a biting letter whose recipients ranged from the county sheriff to the Governor of Illinois.
The sheriff replied immediately. Even though the case cost the complainers $240 and may still end up in court, the residents said the sharp, professional tone of the letter was worth it.

HEADLINE: Soul of the Eames Machine

BYLINE: By JOSEPH GIOVANNINI 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
NEARLY 50 years ago on a bluff in Pacific Palisades overlooking the Pacific, Charles and Ray Eames assembled their house and companion studio from prefabricated parts ordered off the shelf. The steel structure, prominently featured in an Eames exhibition currently at the Library of Congress, was hailed as the prototype for an industrially produced house that could yield a humane environment at minimal cost.
Today, the light-filled buildings still stand at the side of a meadow of rye, quintessential machines in the garden, built to show how industrialization could economically elevate living standards for everyone. The buildings embodied democracy. 
 The house was heroic in its idealism and global in its implications, but a big terra-cotta pot brimming with marguerites at the front door hints at another story. Flowers welcome visitors today, as they did when the Eameses lived there. Smaller pots with scented geraniums, lobelias, cyclamens, fuchsias and Mexican primroses line the front of the house, where the steel sash windows meet the gravel. The great house, built as a rigorous thesis with an ambitious social goal, has a soul.
The potted flowers surrounding the house were largely Ray's domain; she was "the esthetic conscience" of the office of Charles and Ray Eames, said their former associate Deborah Sussman, the Los Angeles graphic designer. "Ray sensed intuitively when art was present and when it wasn't, and that sense played a huge role in the Eames world," she added. "Everybody else, including Charles, knew she knew."
Though Charles got the lion's share of the credit for the creative work of the office, it was Ray, working with Charles out of a bathroom laboratory, who shaped the bewitching pretzels of plywood -- free-form sculpture molded in compound curves -- that would lend lilt to their Eames chair. (She died in 1988, 10 years to the day after her husband.)
In circuitous ways, Ray's flowers played a design role in the office. Trained as a painter with Hans Hofmann in New York, she had perfect pitch for color. Like nature, Ray abhorred a vacuum. Over the years, the clean-lined house on Chautauqua Boulevard acquired constellations of small things. A miniaturist, she gardened the interior with spoons, combs, vases and textiles. On her patios, she cultivated botanical humility, eschewing show-stoppers like orchids and lilies. She liked the intense orange-red-to-hot-red geranium flower's relationship to its green leaf. When she plucked dead leaves, she bowed straight from the waist, looking a little like a flower, herself. Her eye delighted in a detail like the square cut of a petal.
On a three-and-a-half-acre lot designed to look untamed, Ray planted the color. Her garden was pointillistic, composed of hundreds of dots that added up to the shifting color fields of a painter who preferred a small canvas. Over the years, with more and more pots, the patios filled in. What began as a spare carpet of space at the foot of the house and studio reached what Eames Demetrios, the Eameses' grandson, calls an ecological "climax community."
It was a collection that Tina Beebe, who worked beside Ray for years as a graphic artist, said "always harbored little surprises -- fraises de bois, Oxalis oregona." Ms. Beebe, a colorist associated with Moore Ruble Yudell, an architectural firm in Santa Monica, has cultivated a garden of Ray's favorites in Malibu, in remembrance of a woman who would appear at lunches with nosegays wrapped in moist swaddling.
"Ray taught me to love roses -- she gave me my first Belle of Portugal," Ms. Beebe said. "Ray liked flowers with little white faces, and singles rather than doubles. She didn't avoid a flower like tweedia because it was hard to grow. Her garden required a lot of work."
"She always traveled with scissors," Ms. Beebe continued. "Ray had an understanding with her neighbor Mrs. Bailey: any roses over the fence were fair game." She distributed them during the rest of her day.
She was a modernist with a subversive, almost Victorian, sensibility. "She'd give you these tiny, tiny little things carefully wrapped in wet cotton and wax paper," Ms. Sussman said. "Always this tiny little collage that was beautiful and exquisite, and meaningful to her and therefore to you. There would be forget-me-nots. Who has them now? The bouquets were never rigid: she worked them like a painter, pushing and pulling. Her understanding was in her cells."
She arranged the flowers on her tables at home and in the office in a perfect relationship. "She had as much depth and intensity of appreciation for that little petal, the ruffly petal of a rose, as she did for any designed object," said Elaine Sewell Jones, a fellow at the American Institute of Architecture and a close friend. "She loved scented flowers, and whenever we traveled, she almost always had a bouquet of gardenias or a clutch of lemon verbena. She often wore a Cecile Bruner rose, with that teeny, tiny bud."
Marilyn Neuhart, who contributed to "Eames Design: The Work of the Office of Charles and Ray Eames" (Harry N. Abrams, 1989) with her husband, John Neuhart, and Ray Eames, recalled her work habits. "The first thing Ray did after breakfast was to gather anything in bloom, and bring the flowers down to the office in a basket, along with lunch, and arrange them," she said.
Mr. Neuhart added: "The really wild thing was they used to go out to the west side of the office and picnic on a vacant lot. Charles and Ray would spread their blanket in all these weeds and debris, and she'd have a little thing of flowers, and she'd pull up her dress to sun her legs, and he'd take off his shirt."
Charles Eames recorded the world around him through his camera, including the world of flowers emanating from Ray's pots. In their film about the house, "House: After Five Years of Living" (1955), flowers fill the house like oxygen. The photographs -- there are 750,000 Eames stills at the Library of Congress -- constitute an implicit record of Ray's ecosystem of flowers approaching their climax state.
Flowers infiltrated the office's projects, too. Ms. Sussman opened a deck of the Eameses' building cards and discovered one of Ray's nosegays pictured -- daisies with a bit of a geranium, some violets and a little begonia -- "insignificant little things made art," Ms. Sussman said.
Ray's nosegays found their way onto the stock certificates of Herman Miller, the company that first produced Eames furniture. Flowers started appearing at Eames exhibitions. "She bought potted Easter lilies, and spread them at the base of the panels in the old I.B.M. galleries on Madison Avenue in New York," Mr. Neuhart said. "It took a certain curse off a temporary exhibition. It relieved the hard edges."
Bouquets even found their humanistic way into their multiscreen film "Glimpses of the U.S.A." (1959), shown in the Soviet Union at the exhibition made famous by the Nixon-Khrushchev kitchen debate. "In the 'U.S.A.' film, they didn't know how to end it," their grandson said. "Ray suggested an image of forget-me-nots, and they both knew it was right. And by one of those cosmic flukes, the flowers had the same name with the same meaning in Russian. So at the end of the film, the seven images merged into one picture of a bouquet of forget-me-nots, and everyone in Moscow choked up."
Ms. Sussman noted: "She made you see things differently by the way she put things together. Charles would sometimes conceptualize about whether a color should be bright or subdued, but he was conservative about color. It was one of her contributions to their work."
The Eames house is open on most weekdays, by appointment only; information: (310) 459-9663.

HEADLINE: MAKING WELFARE WORK;
Clinton's Cosmetic Poverty Tour

BYLINE: By Peter Edelman; Peter Edelman, a law professor at Georgetown, resigned as Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation at the Department of Health and Human Services to protest the 1996 welfare law.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
As President Clinton travels across the country this week visiting poor areas, he should stop referring to them as "pockets" of poverty. It is not just a matter of pockets. Persistent poverty is endemic in cities and rural areas and is increasingly present, if less visibly so, in suburbs.
The President cannot admit the extent of the problem because his Administration has a vested interest in the notion that welfare reform has been a success. But welfare reform does not live up to the hype. The welfare rolls are down 40 percent, but poverty has been reduced only a little. Even in our hot economy, those who have just left welfare are, on balance, worse off. More people are working, but the increased earnings add up to less than the benefits lost. 
 Why?
* People are being pushed off the rolls all over the country. Many states drop people from the rolls for such derelictions as failing to come to the office for an appointment. Depending on the state, 30 to 50 percent of those who leave welfare don't find jobs. With the rolls down by more than six million people, this adds up to a big number.
* Many people who lose jobs can't get welfare. They come to the welfare office for assistance and are told to look for a job. This is called "diversion." To make matters worse, they are often not told they can get Medicaid and food stamps right away. Indeed, the food stamp rolls are down by more than a third -- much more than what can be attributed to the booming economy.
* Getting a job doesn't always mean steady work. Unemployment records across a number of states show that since early 1997, two-thirds of those who left welfare were unemployed for at least three months in the first year after they left the rolls.
* Too many jobs pay poorly, often because they are only part time. Moreover, two million people work full time all year and can't get their families out of poverty. More than 70 percent of poor children live in families where somebody has income from work. Lousy pay from work is the biggest source of poverty for people who aren't elderly.
And all of these problems hit minorities the hardest. We should remember that race is an underlying issue in the debate on poverty.
Some states are better, some are worse. Vermont, Maine and Rhode Island are really trying to help people get and keep jobs and protect children at the same time. Minnesota gives income assistance to those with low-paying jobs.
Idaho, on the other hand, has a two-year lifetime limit, with few exceptions, and throws the whole family off welfare for life after the third violation of its rules. In Mississippi, which has very tough policies and a weak economy in much of the state, the welfare rolls went down by 68 percent, but only 35 percent of those people found jobs. New York City and a number of states force women out of community college and into welfare programs that lead nowhere.
The bottom line: the poor are not better off. The number of extreme poor -- people trying to survive on an income of less than half the poverty line, or less than about $6,750 a year for a family of three -- actually went up to 14.6 million people in 1997 from 13.9 million in 1995. Among families headed by single mothers, the poorest 10 percent actually lost 15.2 percent of their income over the same two years.
Boosters of the new welfare law tout the decreases in child poverty the past couple of years. Child poverty is down slightly, but it ought to be down much more in this hot economy. One child in five is still poor, and we are a long way from the early 1970's, when one child in seven was poor, itself not a statistic to write home about. And the number of children in extreme poverty has increased.
States are sitting on large surpluses of unspent Federal welfare money while welfare-to-work needs -- child care, transportation, literacy, mental health services and drug and alcohol treatment -- continue to go unmet. If we want real welfare reform, we have to offer more. The needs are going to become more pressing. Nearly eight million people are still on the rolls, three million of them adults, mostly women. The Federal five-year time limit, one of the welfare law's harshest features, will start hitting them two years from now.
In fact, the real issue isn't welfare. It's poverty. And it's not just poverty, it's the situation of millions of people who don't earn enough to support their families. When you add up what it really costs to pay the rent, buy food, buy clothes, pay to get to work and all the rest, it's a whole lot more than what we call the poverty line. The vast majority of those getting the short end of the stick are doing the best they can and are not making it.
If there is a constructive side to the new welfare law, it is that it has helped many people see anew the challenges in making work into a reality for so many who were marooned by the old system. Perhaps now we can have a debate that goes beyond bumper stickers and sound bites. For openers, we should insist that Mr. Clinton's poverty tour be based on the real facts about the state of the poor in America.
