SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 828 words

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
If doctors win theright to organize, patients could lose.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
A CLOSELY divided American Medical Association, which represents about a third of the nation's physicians, has voted to form a union to represent its members in collective bargaining with health plans, hospitals and universities. The rise of managed care has shaken the cozy world of these high-paid, elite professionals. Now they are seeking cover from two groups they used to shun: unions and the Democratic Party, which is leading the charge in Congress to clamp down on corporate managed care.
But would unionization, as advanced by the association, be good for patients? No, say antitrust officials in the Clinton Administration and many independent economists. 
 Under current labor law, only salaried doctors can unionize. About 40,000 of these salaried physicians are already unionized. For the association to begin an aggressive unionization drive among salaried doctors breaks no new ground.
But the association also has something novel in mind. It plans to put its well-financed lobbying power behind a bill, sponsored by Representative Tom Campbell, Republican of California, and about 130 other members of the House, to change the nation's labor laws so that even independent doctors could join forces to negotiate fees and working conditions with health plans.
Mr. Campbell, a former professor of antitrust law at Stanford University, says his legislation responds to two "alarming anticonsumer trends -- the increased level of concentration among health insurers and the exclusionary contracting practices some have followed."
Large health plans make local physicians a take-it-or-leave-it offer, dictating their pay and the way they are allowed to practice medicine. Mr. Campbell wants to offset the power of the plans by creating a countervailing power: a physicians union. A strong union, he says, would give doctors more power to protect patients from denials of care by managed-care officials.
But Martin Gaynor, an economics professor at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, says a union of independent physicians would be unwise. Under the Campbell bill, physicians would be allowed to fix prices and engage in other anticompetitive activities that would be illegal elsewhere in the economy. "A physicians' union will drive up health care costs, taking money from workers and putting it in the wallets of doctors," he says. Economists also worry that unionization of independent physicians will do something worse: severely limit the ability of managed-care plans to second-guess doctors who practice bad medicine.
Mr. Gaynor disputes Mr. Campbell's contention that creating a cartel of independent physicians would help patients even if, as Mr. Campbell assumes, managed-care plans wield monopoly power. But the fact is, he says, managed-care plans do not exert excessive market power. "For almost every major urban area in the United States, no H.M.O. accounts for more than 20 percent of the market" Mr. Gaynor says. "Many account for less than 10 percent."
He points out that there are no large profits that a physicians' union could strip from health plans without affecting patients. "Profit margins of typical managed-care plans were below 1 percent in 1995 and negative since then," he says.
"If a doctors' union jacks up fees," Mr. Gaynor adds, "it will force employers to pass along the added cost to workers as lower wages."
Robert Pitofsky, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, fears a union of independent physicians will harm patients by giving doctors power to refuse to deal with managed care. That, he says, will drive out competition and drive up costs.
Besides, he says, the antitrust exemption Mr. Campbell and the A.M.A. seek is unnecessary. Antitrust guidelines, which he administers, already allow independent physicians to collaborate to help patients. They can join forces to discuss raising standards of care or to form networks that improve care by coordinating treatment.
At the core of the debate is patient care. After an exhaustive review of the research, Robert H. Brook, a professor of medicine at the University of California at Los Angeles, concludes that about a third of acute care provided by physicians was wrong or unnecessary, posing not only needless expense but also needless risk.
Managed care is a possible cure because physicians hired by the managed-care companies to review treatment by practicing physicians can correct errors, including rejecting inappropriate tests, treatments and surgeries. Mr. Campbell's bill allows doctors in a region to band together to block treatment review.
Mr. Gaynor acknowledges that there are problems with managed-care plans. Their quality is uneven, and their decisions can be craven. But, he says, "injecting a cartel of otherwise independent doctors is not the answer."
So what is? He suggests vigorous enforcement of antitrust rules against excessive mergers of health plans and carefully drafted patient-protection laws.

HEADLINE: Japanese Premier Is Off to Mend Fences (He Hopes) With China

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, July 8

 BODY:
Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi leaves today for a major visit to China that aims to soothe relations between the great powers of East Asia and to improve the prospects of China's admission into the World Trade Organization by the end of the year.
No major breakthrough is expected. But officials are frantically negotiating market-opening arrangements in hopes of helping to work out a deal for China to enter the trade organization. That would be a major diplomatic triumph for Mr. Obuchi and lead to important opportunities and risks for China's economy. 
 Prime Minister Zhu Rongji of China offered far-reaching trade concessions on his trip to the United States in the spring. But the White House did not focus on the issue and no deal was agreed on.
Then Washington publicized Mr. Zhu's offer, embarrassing him at home and provoking a backlash from Chinese industries that would suffer from foreign competition. Since then, it has been unclear whether Beijing would be willing to sweeten its offer or even keep it on the table.
Japanese officials declined to go into details of the negotiations, but suggested that China was being relatively flexible.
"The negotiation is going on in Beijing," a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, Sadaaki Numata, said. "There has been some further progress in certain areas. But there are questions that remain."
In his two days in China, Mr. Obuchi will meet President Jiang Zemin and Prime Minister Zhu, as well as Li Peng, the hard-liner who is head of the National People's Congress. Attention is expected to focus on security issues.
In particular, Japan will raise its concerns about North Korea's missile program and the prospect that North Korea will test a missile soon. Japan would like China to put pressure on North Korea to hold off on the launching. But China is not expected to agree. In any case, it is not clear that China has much leverage over North Korea.
Japan will also ask China to stop sending ships that intrude into disputed waters near the Senkaku islands, which are also claimed by China and Taiwan and which they call the Diaoyu chain.
China, on the other hand, is most likely to voice irritation at new Japanese-American defense guidelines that would give Japan a greater military role -- supporting American forces -- in any conflict in the region. China is apprehensive that the guidelines could be applied to Taiwan and that they signal a step toward greater Japanese military assertiveness.
Ties between China and Japan have been increasingly strained in the last few years, and a visit to Tokyo in November by President Jiang seemed to add to the strains. At every turn, Mr. Jiang vigorously raised the issue of Japan's invasion of China early in the century, and by the end of the visit both sides seemed soured on the other.
"The Obuchi visit should be used to halt the worsening in Japan-China relations," Nihon Keizai Shinbun, one of Japan's leading newspapers, urged in an editorial on Wednesday.
Mr. Obuchi has been trying to soothe the ill will, but the underlying problem is a deep mutual suspicion, partly rooted in Japanese brutality in China during World War II. Chinese complain that Japan has never properly apologized for the war and tries to deny its culpability. Japanese insist that they have apologized many times and that it is time to move on.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Despite Upward Rate Pressure, Key Gauges Set Records

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
The three most popular stock market averages pushed to record closings yesterday despite upward pressure on interest rates and general disregard for shares of smaller companies, which fell.
The mixed performance was regarded optimistically by some analysts, while others contended that competition from the bond market would prove a drag on stocks in coming weeks. 
 "Given what we had," said Larry Wachtel, market analyst at Prudential Securities, referring to a 700-point rise in the Dow Jones industrial average from June 24 through Tuesday morning, "I think the action is very good." He added, "I think it's a sign of underlying strength."
But Steven Goldman, a strategist at Weeden & Company, fretted about the persistence of rate pressure as the Government auctioned $7 billion of inflation-indexed notes, and corporate issuers readied other big deals. "It's hard to be a pounding-the-table bull here," he said, predicting that rates were likely to offset the cheerful reading expected when the corporate earnings season reaches full stride next week.
"Everyone talks about how they are going to be terrific," Mr. Goldman added, "but that doesn't mean stock prices will do well."
A few companies, in fact, warned yesterday of lower profits, and their shares plunged. Waste Management dropped 19 5/8, to 33 15/16, after trading at a 52-week low of 31 1/16, barely half its May 4 peak of 60. New Era of Networks slid 24 5/8, to 19 7/16. On the other hand, after Yahoo, a technology bellwether, closed down 8 1/16, to 167 1/16, it announced second-quarter results that beat expectations.
On the strength of a late comeback, the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 52.24 points, or 0.47 of a percent, to a record 11,187.36, surpassing Friday's peak. General Electric, which won a huge jet engine order from Boeing, was the biggest factor, jumping 4, to 117 15/16. Caterpillar, up 2 13/16, to 62 1/8, and Allied Signal, up 2 1/8, to 63 7/8, placed second and third.
American Express, down 2 1/2, to 135 3/4, and Alcoa, down 2 3/8, to 61 3/8, were the Dow's biggest losers. They met profit forecasts -- Alcoa was even slightly above it -- but did not surpass them as some had hoped.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 7.74 points, to a record 1,395.86, paced by Microsoft, which climbed 2 3/4, to 92 5/16. A total of 268 index issues advanced, while 203 declined and 29 were unchanged.
The Nasdaq market, which is dominated by high-technology stocks, gained a modest 0.23 percent in rising 6.26 points, to its new high of 2,743.04.
But the record closings of the three main gauges masked softness elsewhere. For example, declines outnumbered advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange by 1,691 to 1,307, and the Russell 2000 and the Standard & Poor's 600, which include smaller companies, each fell by nearly 1 percent.
Drug, oil, retail and battered gold stocks turned in mixed performances yesterday, while airlines were mostly higher. Delta Air Lines gained 1 15/16, to 62 1/16, AMR 1 5/16, to 72 3/4, and U S Airways 7/8, to 46 5/16.
Volume on the Big Board expanded to a still-moderate 791 million shares; 93 issues reached new 52-week highs and 55 fell to new lows.
Major markets in the Asia and Europe eased by about half a percent, while prices climbed 0.6 percent in Brazil and 0.21 percent in Mexico.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Fall
 By Bloomberg News
 Bond prices fell for a second session yesterday as the Government met lackluster demand in a $7 billion note sale and companies including the Ford Motor Company prepared to sell about $12 billion of debt.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 4/32, to 89 4/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.04 percent from 6.03 percent. Holders of 30-year bonds have lost 10.5 percent so far this year, reflecting price declines and reinvested interest.
Bonds fell as the Treasury's auction of 9.5-year inflation-indexed notes drew only tepid interest. Bidders submitted orders for just 2.10 times the amount of notes available. In the previous five auctions, investors bid for 3.11 times the amount for sale, on average.
Corporations, meanwhile, are competing for investor dollars. Companies have been lining up bond sales since the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates by a quarter-point, to 5 percent, last week. The Household Finance Corporation issued $1 billion of seven-year notes, and Ford, the world's No. 2 auto maker, and its finance arm plan to sell as much as $7.5 billion of debt.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Clinton Restricts Imports of Brazilian Steel and Australian Lamb

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
Despite a booming American economy, President Clinton moved today to restrict imports of two politically sensitive products -- steel from Brazil and lamb from Australia and New Zealand -- in response to complaints from unions and farmers that their livelihoods were threatened by a surge of under-priced imports.
Mr. Clinton has justified each of the moves as examples of how his Administration is enforcing dumping laws, a critical step, Administration officials say, to build support for open trade. But abroad, Mr. Clinton's decisions are viewed quite differently, as more evidence that the United States, while talking up the merits of free trade, is increasingly closing its borders to imports. 
 Mr. Clinton's actions today underscored how trade has become an increasingly sensitive political issue, even as the American economy continues to lead the rest of the world. The White House -- and particularly Vice President Al Gore, as he tries to invigorate his troubled Presidential campaign -- are coming under increasing pressure to aid workers and industries hurt by a surging American trade deficit.
Moreover, import restrictions have become part of a delicate dance for the Administration. It is arguing that the only way to build public support for a free-trade system is to demonstrate that Washington is ready to halt imports of goods that the Administration determines are "dumped" at unfairly low prices to be purchased by American consumers. While that may bolster the Administration at home, it is undercutting efforts to press other nations to open their markets, particularly agricultural markets. That will be the subject of a major new round of international trade negotiations, starting in November.
The action on Brazilian steel is part of a series of steps to respond to industry and union complaints about low-cost steel from a number of countries, including Japan, South Korea and Russia. Under an arrangement negotiated with the Brazilian Government, Brazil's steel industry agreed to "voluntarily" reduce shipments to the United States, hours before a deadline that would have imposed tariffs of about 50 percent on its imports. Such "suspension agreements," so named because they suspend Commerce Department investigations into dumping, are also being sought with other nations accused of selling here at cut-rate prices.
Under the accord, Brazil will reduce shipments of hot-rolled steel by about 28 percent, and will export no more than 295,000 metric tons to the United States. The Brazilians also agreed to charge at least $327 a metric ton for their hot-rolled steel, a bit above the going rate in the United States. While the Administration defends such price-fixing as the only way to avoid dumping, it has previously responded with outrage when other countries, particularly Japan, have sought to set floors on the price of imported goods.
The agreement gives some protective cover to the Administration after the defeat two weeks ago in the Senate of a bill that would have set quotas on a wide range of steel products. The Administration had opposed that legislation, saying it was a violation of international trade accords. But tariffs to stop dumping and agreements like the one reached today are legal under most circumstances.
The lamb issue ranks low by economic measures -- but it is politically sensitive with both farmers and with New Zealand and Australia, not usual combatants in trade wars with America.
Mr. Clinton was acting on an International Trade Commission finding last April that a vast increase in the amount of lamb meat imported into the United States was harming the domestic industry. So today, in a proclamation, Mr. Clinton limited imports to 31,851 metric tons for the next year, starting on July 22. Any imports above that level will face a 40 percent tariff. Mr. Clinton said he would also offer roughly $100 million in aid to United States farmers over the next three years.
"The package of import relief and domestic assistance has been carefully crafted to help our lamb industry achieve sustained competitiveness," Joe Lockhart, the White House spokesman, said in a statement released during the President's trip today to South Dakota.
The subject is bound to be a central topic of a visit next week by Australia's Prime Minister, John Howard. The trip is meant to celebrate the American-Australian alliance, and Australia's actions to sidestep the worst effects of the Asian financial crisis that began two years ago. But the lamb issue is a major one for Mr. Howard, particularly at a time when Australia's major markets in Asia are still hurting.

HEADLINE: The Rural Poor Need Democracy and Jobs;
A Backup Plan

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While most politicians would be resting on their economic laurels, President Clinton is touring the country's impoverished areas (news article, July 7). His idea -- encouraging private investment by offering tax incentives -- deserves a chance to work.
It is, however, an indirect method of providing job opportunities to those left behind. If entrepreneurs do not find the bait (the tax credit) tempting enough to offset the perceived investment risk, the President's program will fail. Thus, we need a backup. 
 If after a few years the "new markets" project fails to lower local unemployment rates significantly, the Government should engage in direct job creation by providing public service employment in these high-poverty areas. This way, even if the private sector fails to respond, these communities will still have a chance to join the rest of the country.
 
JARED BERNSTEIN
Washington, July 7, 1999
 
The writer is an economist at the Economic Policy Institute.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. to Seek Cut in Capital Gains Tax

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
House Republicans said today that they would seek to cut the top tax rate on long-term capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent as part of the big tax-cutting bill they will take up next week in the face of opposition from President Clinton.
If enacted, the cut in the capital gains tax rate, which applies to profits on the sale of stock and other assets held for more than a year, would give a break to the growing legions of individual investors. And it could further fuel the long bull market on Wall Street, where stock prices hit another new high today. Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said the capital gains tax cut would help keep the economy growing by stimulating additional savings and investment. 
 Mr. Archer's capital gains proposal will be one element of an $864 billion, 10-year tax-cutting plan that his committee is scheduled to vote on next week as the Republican-controlled Congress begins a politically charged showdown with Mr. Clinton over how to allocate trillions of dollars in projected Federal budget surpluses. The capital gains tax reduction would account for about $50 billion of the tax cut over a decade, Congressional aides said.
The top capital gains rate was last cut, to 20 percent from 28 percent, as part of the 1997 bipartisan tax and budget deal. Last year, Mr. Clinton signed legislation that reduced to one year from 18 months the period that stocks or other assets had to be held to qualify for the long-term rate.
Prospects for the further cut in capital gains are uncertain. The Administration attacked the plan today, partly on the ground that it favors the wealthy, who own the vast majority of stocks and bonds.
Moreover, Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who heads the Senate Finance Committee, is leaning against including a capital gains cut in the tax bill that he is drafting for the Senate to consider later this month. Mr. Roth favors other proposals to encourage savings and investment, including expanding Individual Retirement Accounts and the 401(k) retirement savings program.
But both Mr. Archer and Mr. Roth intend to include in their bills the first substantial broad-based reduction in personal income taxes since 1981. Mr. Roth appears to be settling on a plan that would increase the amount of income that would be subject to the lowest income tax rate of 15 percent. Mr. Archer has not divulged his approach.
Mr. Clinton has made it clear he will veto any tax cut of the size and shape that Mr. Archer is developing. But he has signaled his willingness to negotiate, and many Democrats and Republicans believe there is a good chance that the White House and Congress will work out a deal on taxes and other budget issues this year, in large part because the projected surpluses are so great that they can accommodate both parties' priorities.
While the House is bitterly divided along partisan lines over taxes, there is considerable support among Democrats in the Senate for a sizable tax cut this year.
"There are very large numbers of Democrats and Republicans in the Senate who want a tax cut and are prepared to meet in the middle," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, who has co-sponsored a bipartisan plan to cut taxes on the middle class.
Mr. Clinton has invited Congressional leaders to meet with him next week to discuss his proposal for shoring up Medicare, the health insurance system for the elderly and disabled, and Administration officials said they expected the session to range across the panoply of budget issues dividing the parties.
After some wrangling among Republicans about how large a tax cut to pursue this year, Mr. Archer agreed at a meeting on Friday with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert to put a price tag of $864 billion on the House's tax-cutting package over the next decade. The tax cuts would be phased in as the projected surpluses grow, with $5 billion available for tax cuts next year and $200 billion over the first five years, Mr. Archer said.
The $864 billion figure is an increase from the $778 billion earmarked by Republicans earlier this year for a tax cut, reflecting new estimates showing that the budget surplus will be larger than anticipated.
In the Senate, Mr. Roth is likely to limit his tax cut bill to no more than the original $778 billion to insure that there is money available for adding prescription drug coverage to Medicare, a goal shared by Mr. Clinton.
The Congressional Budget Office reported last week that the surplus over the next decade would be just under $2.9 trillion. Of that amount, $1.9 trillion would come from the Social Security system, money that both parties have agreed should go to shoring up the retirement system and not to tax cuts or general spending.
Democrats and Republicans are battling primarily over what to do with the other $996 billion, which represents a cumulative excess of general tax revenues for the next 10 years if spending is kept at current levels (a separate estimate by the White House put the figure at just over $1 trillion).
While Republicans want to use nearly all of the surplus for tax cuts, the President has proposed using about $250 billion over 10 years for tax breaks to encourage low- and middle-income families to save more for retirement. He wants to use most of the rest of the $1 trillion to help extend Medicare's solvency and to increase spending on education, child care, health care and the military.
Mr. Archer said that if his capital gains tax plan was signed into law, it would apply retroactively to all sales starting July 1 of this year.
Under the Archer plan, the capital gains tax rate for taxpayers in the 15 percent income tax bracket -- generally those considered low to middle income -- would decline to 7.5 percent from 10 percent.

HEADLINE: A Classic Success Story Gets a Nod From Clinton

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, July 7

 BODY:
When Josie Ippolito was 7 years old, she loved to get up at 3 A.M. to help her father make tortillas in their small family shop in this struggling section of south-central Phoenix.
"There was just something about it that was very exciting," Mrs. Ippolito recalled. "And then at 7 o'clock I'd come home and be dead-beat tired and have to go to school." 
 More than 30 years later, Mrs. Ippolito is still getting up early to help make tortillas, but now she is co-owner of the family business, La Canasta Mexican Food Products, whose factory makes about 840,000 corn and flour tortillas and tortilla chips in each 18-hour day, for sale to the restaurant business nationwide. And as she rushed around this morning preparing for a visit by President Clinton, then ducking out to have her hair done, Mrs. Ippolito could scarcely contain her excitement -- or her pride.
"We're here," she said, gesturing at the 25,000-square-foot factory, which the company built in 1994 with a $1.2 million loan from the Small Business Administration, nearly doubling its previous space. "We're making it."
Indeed, Mrs. Ippolito's business is a classic success story, chosen by the White House to hammer home the President's message about the benefits of Government and private sector investment in the pockets of urban and rural poverty that the booming national economy has passed by. Mrs. Ippolito, who owns the business with her mother and two of her sisters, is also part of a potent emerging demographic group here: businesses owned by minorities and women.
Since 1992, the Phoenix metropolitan area has ranked third among the nation's top 50 cities in the growth of businesses owned by women, going to 94,500 this year from 42,000, according to the National Foundation for Women Business Owners, and it ranked 15th in the nation in the overall number of businesses owned by women.
In 1996, the last year for which figures are available, there were 9,000 businesses in Phoenix owned by Hispanic women alone, employing 18,400 people and generating $1.6 billion in sales, according to the foundation, a nonprofit research group based in Silver Spring, Md.
When La Canasta emerged as the White House choice for Mr. Clinton's main stop today in this fast-growing city, some local Hispanic business leaders complained, said a former high-ranking local official who spoke on condition of anonymity. They thought a tortilla factory was a cliche, the official said, and wondered why the President did not visit one of the region's several Hispanic-owned companies like QuePasa.com, a booming Internet portal intended for Hispanic users.
But Mrs. Ippolito made no apologies for La Canasta's low-tech industrial processes, in which women still stretch flour tortillas by hand. "I'm very proud of the accomplishments we've made," Mrs. Ippolito said, noting that 60 percent of the company's 140 workers come from within three miles of the plant in a neighborhood that is part of a designated 19-square-mile "enterprise community" eligible for special Federal tax breaks. While the company does not disclose its annual sales, it is clearly thriving, preparing to expand into tortilla products to be sold in supermarkets.
This morning the start of a groaning buffet was already spread out for Mr. Clinton, who has long had a hard time resisting second helpings when it is Mexican day at the White House mess, and tonight, he took note of how many customers La Canasta's daily output serves.
"Eight-hundred forty-thousand a day!" the President said. "That's a lot of people, you know. Of course, not everybody eats as many at one sitting as I do."
Mrs. Ippolito may have begun her tortilla-making career as a childhood lark, but she joined the business full time at the death of her father in 1974. Her mother was left with seven children, and Mrs. Ippolito went to work in the business, which had started as a neighborhood tamale stand.
"It was just a matter of survival at that point," she said. "We all had to lock arms and go on."
Now, as the White House talks up its proposals of tax incentives for new businesses in depressed areas, Mrs. Ippolito wants the President to know that even existing small businesses need special help.
"We've been here 39 years," she said. "It's nice to bring in new businesses. However, you don't forget those businesses that have a proven track record."

HEADLINE: Trouble in the Backyard

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, July 7

 BODY:
More quickly than the political opponents of Slobodan Milosevic had dared hope, grass-roots dissatisfaction with the Yugoslav President is surfacing across much of Serbia.
Hostility toward Mr. Milosevic, bubbling up this week on the streets of the most unlikely of towns, has raised expectations among opposition politicians that Mr. Milosevic's survival in power might now be measured not in years, but in months. 
 What has particularly raised eyebrows among political analysts -- who are beginning to doubt that opposition parties are capable of harnessing the anger -- is the surprise eruption of large and violent protests in the southern Serbian city of Leskovac, a long-time stronghold of the Milosevic regime.
There, without the help of any political party, but with the participation of army reservists who fought in the lost war in Kosovo, more than 20,000 people marched on Monday night calling for Mr. Milosevic to resign. On Tuesday, about 2,000 people charged the local police station, demanding the release of the local television technician who had organized Monday's rally.
The police responded with tear gas and by beating demonstrators with nightsticks. The crowd retreated and later attacked the home of a local political boss who belongs to the Yugoslav Left, a hard-line Communist party headed by Mr. Milosevic's wife. They smashed windows in the house and destroyed its front gate, a police official there said by phone.
"If Milosevic is in trouble in Leskovac, then he is really in trouble," said Aleksa Djilas, a historian and political analyst in Belgrade who is not affiliated with the opposition groups trying to force the Yugoslav leader from office. "It is like a Kennedy being in trouble in Boston. This is the beginning of the end. I don't know when the end will happen, but it will be months, not years."
The presence of Yugoslav Army reservists in demonstrations in Leskovac is a wild-card element which, if repeated in towns and cities across Serbia, could tip the scales against Mr. Milosevic more quickly than opposition leaders had expected.
Since the end of the Kosovo war in early June, hundreds of reservists have intermittently blocked roads and bridges in central and southern Serbia, demanding their overdue pay for service during the 11-week war in Kosovo.
The survival skills of Mr. Milosevic, who has been indicted on war crimes charges, should not be underestimated. Although he has lost four wars this decade while presiding over the implosion of the economy, he remains a shrewd politician. He has weathered eruptions of mass unhappiness in Serbia before, most recently in the winter of 1996-97, when three months of daily demonstrations all but paralyzed Belgrade.
The two major tools in his survival kit are an enormous state police apparatus, which is still believed to be loyal, and state television, which is the primary source of information for most of the country.
There is a consensus among opposition leaders that Mr. Milosevic cannot afford politically to use his police to arrest, injure or kill large numbers of Serbs. As Zoran Djindjic, a key opposition leader, said at a rally on Tuesday night in the western Serbian town of Uzice, "If there are a lot of us, they will not use force."
Instead, they expect Mr. Milosevic to do what he has done in the past: deploy his police and his large party apparatus to harass, intimidate and try to buy off the opposition. For instance, to disrupt an opposition rally planned for Thursday night in Prokuplje, Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party has called its own rally at the same place and time. He tried the same tactic two years ago in Belgrade, without much success in igniting street violence.
That leaves television, which is doing what it has done so effectively throughout Mr. Milosevic's 12 years in power. It ignores or distorts all the news that is bad for Mr. Milosevic and his family, while vilifying their rivals and critics as corrupt anti-Serbian traitors.
There has been almost no television coverage, for instance, of this week's trouble in Leskovac or of three large opposition rallies in Serbia in the past week. But there has been plenty of television footage of Mr. Milosevic handing out medals to war heroes and promoting the image of a country on the mend. These moments have been private ones engineered for television rather than public appearances that might draw protesters.
As they have been for years, opposition leaders in Serbia are divided about how to best plug into popular discontent, which is rooted both in anger about the lost war in Kosovo and fear stirred by the collapsing economy.
The Serbian Renewal Movement, led by the charismatic Vuk Draskovic, had insisted since the war in Kosovo ended that the time was not right for street demonstrations. As recently as Monday, Mr. Draskovic told a news conference that he is a "legalist" who wants to press for reform from within the system.
The stunning news from Leskovac, which is controlled by Mr. Milosevic's Socialists but where the Serbian Renewal Movement is the main opposition group, appears to have forced the hand of Mr. Draskovic. His party announced today that it would take charge of a rally in Leskovac on Thursday night.
A senior adviser in the party, Ognjen Privbicevic, offered this explanation for Mr. Draskovic's sudden and seemingly opportunistic change of strategies.
"Vuk has such a good nose for these things," Mr. Privbicevic said. "Things are changing so quickly here. Nothing is predictable. This is the first rule."
Milan Bozic, the Deputy Mayor of Belgrade and a top leader in the Serbian Renewal Movement, said that all political parties in Serbia have underestimated both the depth of popular anti-Milosevic feeling and its power to bring people to the streets.
"All of sudden, it looks as though frustration over Milosevic is much more deeply embedded into the national consciousness than we expected," Mr. Bozic said.
Mr. Djindjic, a key leader of the Alliance for Change, a coalition of opposition groups, and a rival of Mr. Draskovic, delivered a rousing -- if vague -- speech on Tuesday that envisioned simultaneous daily rallies in towns across the country as well as a general strike.
Mr. Djindjic said he expected the Serbian Orthodox Church, which last month demanded that Mr. Milosevic resign and which has since been bitterly condemned on state television, will soon join the opposition and ring church bells across the country to call Serbs out on the nationwide general strike.
The timing and the planning for that strike are not yet clear, said Milan Protic, also a leader of the Alliance for Change. He said the opposition movement has not yet sat down with church leaders to ask for their help.
The Milosevic regime appears to fear the involvement of the church in politics. Politika, its main newspaper, today condemned church leaders for making peace in Kosovo with "terrorist" Albanian leaders and warned the church to avoid the "murky waters" of politics.

HEADLINE: 6 Are Killed in Ethnic Strife in Solomon Islands

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 7

 BODY:
The Solomon Islands, the group of tropical Pacific islands that witnessed some of World War II's most intensive battles, is once again the scene of strife, this time of its own making.
United Nations officials said today that at least six people had been killed and 15,000 to 20,000 people had been forced to flee their homes by ethnic conflict on Guadalcanal, the main island and scene of a major World War II battle. 
 Kevin M. Kennedy, chief of the Emergency Liaison Branch of the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, said the United Nations would support a mediation effort by the Commonwealth and would help the Red Cross provide food and housing to those displaced by the fighting.
Mr. Kennedy said that according to refugees, small bands of lightly armed militants belonging to the Gwale majority on Guadalcanal had already driven out most of the minority population of Malaitan villagers from the countryside. The Malaitas went to Gaudalcanal, often a generation or two ago, from the island of Malaita, 60 miles away.
Hundreds more Malaitas have been harassed or frightened into fleeing to the capital, Honiara, whose population is mostly Malaitan. Many are now sleeping on the streets, Mr. Kennedy said. Others have sought refuge with friends or relatives on Malaita, placing additional burdens on a population of mostly subsistence farmers and fishermen.
"These terrified people are unlikely to return to their homes any time soon," Mr. Kennedy said in an interview, "and certainly not until their safety can be assured."
The United Nations sent its mission in response to an appeal from Bartholomew Ulufa'alu, a Malaitan who is Prime Minister and who invited the Commonwealth to mediate the dispute. Sitiveni Rabuka, Fiji's former Prime Minister, has been trying to negotiate an end to the violence.
Occupying an area that is slightly smaller than Maryland with a population of about 440,000, the Solomon Islands, which gained independence from Britain in 1978, is a democracy known for its fractious Parliament.
Diplomats said that while the ethnic tensions among Guadalcanal residents goes back decades, fighting erupted last April when small gangs of jobless men began purging the Malaitans from their villages around Honiara Province. They were protesting what they saw as preferential employment treatment given Malaitans on the island, where about 115,000 people live.
After speaking to correspondents about the situation in the Solomon Islands, from which he has just returned, Mr. Kennedy was taken aback by a reporter who asked why the United Nations should spend time and money on a place where the death toll was "small potatoes" compared with the suffering in other parts of the world, like Africa and Kosovo.
"Well, it's not small potatoes to the people who've been driven out of their homes," Mr. Kennedy replied. "In the context of the country, which has not seen very much violence in recent decades, it's a major crisis."

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Grand Designs Warrant Wary Looks

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
SOME of the world's most illustrious architects have grand designs for the 12 blocks between Pennsylvania Station and the Hudson River. Their schemes, unveiled last week at a competition sponsored by the Canadian Center for Architecture, call for parks and hotels, a riverfront stadium, a new Madison Square Garden and a glass-covered commons big enough to hold 90,000 people.
Those plans might sound like an improvement over the railyards now occupying that land. But before embarking on a new megaproject, it's worth recalling how some of the past ones turned out. Consider, for instance, an entry from the American Institute of Architects Guide to New York City for a project completed in 1970: 
 "Out in the middle of nowhere, on marshy land that was once the site of an ill-fated amusement park named Freedomland, a group of government officials, union representatives, and housing developers dreamed the impossible dream. Today the dream may better be described as a coma." That entry on Co-op City pronounced it bereft of "a scintilla of wit," a judgment that fits just about any megaproject in New York in the last half-century.
If they all suddenly disappeared, not many of them would be rebuilt. The sterile towers of the World Trade Center and the United Nations are not beloved by the public or architects. Few tears will be shed if the proposed demolition of Shea Stadium takes place. The Javits Center, billed as an urban renewal project, has had little impact on the surrounding neighborhood.
The comeback of Times Square might be considered a victory for urban planners, but it occurred only after the master plan was discarded to allow more haphazard development. Other renewal plans were just as bad. No one today would tear down hundreds of buildings on the West Side, as was so casually done by Robert Moses and the other planners who replaced them with mostly ugly high-rises and empty plazas.
Lincoln Center is in some ways a success, but the buildings have long been criticized for their acoustical flaws and architectural mediocrity. The Metropolitan Opera House and Avery Fisher Hall will never be as revered as Carnegie Hall is; the New York State Theater's rhinestones and intricate balcony railings give it the feel of the Ramada Inn of Seville.
"There's been lots of shoddy architecture in these big projects," said Norval White, a co-author of the American Institute of Architects' guide to the city. "You can point to some college campuses and parks like Jones Beach that are reasonably successful, but most of the big projects would never be done again. If you're looking for a great master plan done recently that works, I think Battery Park City would be about the only one."
Battery Park City, though, was a modest endeavor. Although it began as a megaproject -- the original designers were responsible for the elephantine Albany Mall -- it was scaled back into a re-creation of old neighborhoods like Tudor City.
Those old neighborhoods were not built by master planners. The street-front buildings were put up by many developers who followed simple zoning rules. It was only later that avant-garde architects and planners rewrote the regulations to promote the tower-in-the-park and other visions of urbanity that turned out so badly.
SO why trust today's avant-garde architects to make grand plans for the West Side? It's good of them to share their ideas, and maybe some of them will be built. But a new Robert Moses is not going to be warmly welcomed.
"The city will look at these new ideas for the West Side, but we're not necessarily going to settle for a unified megaproject," said Joseph B. Rose, director of the Department of City Planning. Mr. Rose, who was a juror for the competition, recently vowed to "drive a stake through the heart of tower-in-the-park zoning."
"The projects that have worked in New York," Mr. Rose said, "operate within the context of the market instead of trying to overcome it with some totalitarian vision. The old rules worked. The Zoning Resolution of 1916 produced some of the city's best neighborhoods."
It's hard to imagine going back to those times, but perhaps the railyards could be a special kind of historic district. Instead of drawing a master plan, sell off parcels to developers and exempt them from all housing and environmental regulations adopted since 1916. Granted, it would be risky. But could it turn out much worse than the projects we're already stuck with? 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Massachusetts Chief Joins Effort on Drug Insurance for Elderly

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 7

 BODY:
It may be the hot political issue of the moment in Washington, but from here, the Federal Government's rising debate over coverage of prescription drugs for the elderly looks a bit late, a bit leisurely.
The Massachusetts Legislature, dominated by Democrats, has been grappling with the issue for months, and this week Gov. Paul Cellucci, a Republican, jumped in with his own plan for a state-run insurance program that would offer a form of drug coverage to all the state's elderly citizens. 
 "We don't feel that we can wait for Federal action," said State Representative Harriette L. Chandler, the House chairwoman of the Legislature's Joint Committee on Health Care. "We have seniors who are in all forms of real crisis at this point. We have people who are cutting their prescriptions in half, we have people skipping days and people who haven't been filling prescriptions. They really do exist."
The urgency has grown out of unusual circumstance: Massachusetts had been the only state to require health maintenance organizations to offer elderly members the option of full prescription drug coverage. But that law was overturned in Federal court, and though the state's H.M.O.'s have been slowly phasing out the drug coverage, thousands of members already face problems paying for their medications.
But Massachusetts is not the only state that has long been pursuing a solutions to such drug costs. In recent years, 13 other states have passed various programs to help the elderly pay for prescription drugs, mainly focused on low-income people who do not qualify for Medicaid.
And in recent months, more than half the state legislatures have examined bills on the issue, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Proposals have ranged from drug discounts to adding people to state-subsidized programs.
All the talking crystallized here into two main proposals, one by the House of Representatives and one by the Senate. The two plans differed in dollar amounts and various provisions, though both would expand the pool of elderly eligible for state aid in buying their prescriptions as well as the amount of aid they could receive.
When Governor Cellucci announced his own plan on Tuesday, he called it a compromise between the House and Senate versions. But analysts say it entails not merely state subsidies but also a state-run insurance program that any elderly person could join.
For a premium of about $54 a month -- less or nothing for the poor -- enrollees would get unlimited coverage for prescription drugs, though with co-payments, and after paying a deductible of $750 a year for the elderly whose income is 150 percent of the Federal poverty level to $1,500 for those better off. The proposed co-payments would range from $8 to $35, depending on the type of drugs. There would also be an estimated 22 percent discount on all drugs.
The plan would begin in January and last either two years or until the Federal Government enacted its own drug coverage plan, whichever came first.
Governor Cellucci's plan appears to be generally drawing high marks, but not everywhere. Alan Sager, a Boston University health care economist, said today that making such a drug-coverage plan voluntary, as both Governor Cellucci's and President Clinton's proposals would, amounted to a financial "death sentence."
"You get into adverse selection," Mr. Sager said, "because prescription drugs are the single most predictable expense in health care." Thus, the sickest people are likely to enroll, he said, and the healthier people needed to make the plan financially viable are not.
Lawmakers also raised objections, including that it did not provide enough help for the disabled and moderately poor elderly. Questions also remain about whether the incentives it provides younger, healthier elderly people to sign up, like a planned 10 percent discount on their monthly premium, will be enough.
But over all, said Geoff Wilkinson, executive director of the Massachusetts Senior Action Council, which has staged two drug-coverage rallies at the Statehouse here in recent months, "There's a lot to like about the Governor's plan."
"Congress would do well to take a look at what's going on here," Mr. Wilkinson said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Officials Say Aid for Terrorists Came Through Two Persian Gulf Nations

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN with BENJAMIN WEISER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7

 BODY:
United States officials say they believe that two suspected terrorists wanted by the F.B.I. have received help through two Persian Gulf countries with close ties to Washington, complicating the Administration's counterterrorism efforts.
Although the Clinton Administration has made no public protests, it quietly sent senior officials last week to one of the countries, the United Arab Emirates, to lobby for a halt to a suspected financial relationship between a Government-controlled bank and Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile charged in the bombings of United States embassies in Africa last year. 
 A Federal indictment charges that Mr. bin Laden's extensive businesses have provided him a cover to acquire explosives and weapons, and Washington has begun a worldwide effort to curb his access to international financial systems.
The Central Intelligence Agency has obtained evidence that Mr. bin Laden has been allowed to funnel money through the Dubai Islamic Bank in Dubai, which the United Arab Emirates Government effectively controls.
The Administration is also confronting allegations by some American officials that the Foreign Minister of Qatar told a suspected lieutenant of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, a convicted terrorist, that an F.B.I. counterterrorism team was on its way to Qatar to arrest him.
Some Administration officials said they did not believe that the Foreign Minister was involved in the 1996 incident, but that the United States believed that at least some Qatar officials had warned the fugitive, Khaled Shaikh Mohammad. The United States wanted him in connection with a plot to blow up 12 American airliners over the Pacific.
Both cases highlight the difficulties of managing relations with moderate Arab states long courted by Washington, showered with aid and allowed to buy high-technology military weapons.
The American generosity is meant to encourage the moderate states to stand as a bulwark against radical Islam, with public policies and with quiet support for American intelligence operations.
But analysts say some members of the elite even in moderate Arab states apparently feel a need to hedge their bets against critics of their pro-Western policies and to insure against becoming targets of terrorist attacks themselves.
The allegations that the Dubai Islamic Bank is dealing with Mr. bin Laden seem to underscore that this scion of one of Saudi Arabia's wealthiest families retains some support among the elite of the Arab world.
Although Mr. bin Laden was exiled and supposedly cut off by his family, which controls construction companies in Saudi Arabia, American officials believe wealthy Sunni Arabs in the Persian Gulf quietly share his anti-Western fundamentalist beliefs, even though they run counter to other moderate Arab interests.
United States intelligence officials said they had evidence that Mr. bin Laden had a relationship with the bank, which they believed had been arranged with the approval of the officials who control the bank.
The Minister of State for Finance and Industry for the Emirates, Mohammed Khalfan bin Kharbash, was elected chairman of the bank in February, after the Government stepped in to prop it up in the wake of severe financial losses last year that followed charges of embezzlement.
A senior United States official who went to the Emirates last week said that officials were "responsive" to American concerns about the Dubai bank's involvement with Mr. bin Laden. But the official refused to provide details about the meetings, which included Treasury Department and National Security Council officials. The American officials also declined to say how much money they believed that Mr. bin Laden had funneled through the bank.
Mr. bin Laden is believed to be living in Afghanistan under the protection of the Taliban. Estimates of his wealth vary widely. Some analysts say they are convinced that he has just a few million dollars left from his vast inheritance. The Central Intelligence Agency estimates that he has up to $250 million, including assets in legitimate businesses.
A press adviser in the Emirates Embassy here, Edmund Ghareeb, said he could not comment on the suspected bank dealings. The Qatar Ambassador to the United States, Saad Mohammed al-Kobasi, declined to comment on the allegations against officials in his country.
The Clinton Administration has refrained from public comment on either case, apparently fearing damage to relations with two oil-rich Arab states that have generally supported American policies in the region and that also help American military operations in the gulf.
For years, the main port of call for United States warships in the gulf was in the Emirates. Last year, the country agreed to pay $8 billion for F-16's fighters, a major boost for Lockheed Martin.
In Qatar, construction is under way on what United States officials say will be the Pentagon's largest prepositioning supply base outside the United States. When the $178 million complex is completed in about a year, it will support up to 10,000 troops and 5,000 vehicles, aiding operations against Iraq.
Since the gulf war, Qatar has also deepened its economic ties, cutting deals with American oil companies like Occidental Petroleum and Mobil. Breaking with its larger neighbor, Saudi Arabia, Qatar also became the first gulf state to establish open trade relations with Israel.
Its Foreign Minister, Sheik Hamed bin Jasim al Thani, plays a significant role in the relationship with Washington. He has met Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright two times recently, in November and February, officials said.
The Qatar case centers on efforts to arrest Mr. Mohammad in connection with Mr. Yousef's plot to destroy the airliners. Mr. Yousef was convicted in the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center in Manhattan. In January 1996, the United States secretly indicted Mr. Mohammad as an accomplice in the airliner plot.
The indictment charged that in late 1994 and early 1995, Mr. Mohammad lived in Mr. Yousef's apartment in Manila, where they kept explosive devices and chemicals. Federal prosecutors have also said they believe Mr. Mohammad helped Mr. Yousef devise and finance the airliner plot.
In early 1996, American authorities learned that Mr. Mohammad was living in the capital of Qatar, Doha, and working at the Public Works Ministry, said one official.
The American Ambassador to Qatar, Patrick N. Theros, a former counterterrorism official in the State Department, met Qatar officials and reported that he was optimistic that Qatar would be willing to arrest Mr. Mohammad and turn him over to the United States, officials recounted.
There was a recent precedent such an action. About a year earlier, the United States sent a plane to Pakistan after the authorities there arrested Mr. Yousef and agreed to turn him over to the F.B.I.
The F.B.I., however, found itself thwarted in its attempt to catch Mr. Mohammad. Its agents, sent to Doha in early 1996, were told that the suspect, who had been under surveillance, was now nowhere to be found. A Qatar police search of a beachfront estate where the officers had been told that Mr. Mohammad was staying, proved fruitless.
The F.B.I. spent about a week awaiting word of Mr. Mohammad's whereabouts, they returned to the United States empty-handed.
American officials now say they believe that Mr. Mohammad was warned by someone in the Qatar Government and that he was staying at the estate of Abdallah bin Khalid, a fundamentalist who has provided support for other Islamic radicals. A former American intelligence official said Mr. bin Laden also visited Mr. bin Khalid in Qatar twice in the mid-1990's.
Although American officials said they had no conclusive proof, current and former officials said they believed that the Foreign Minister was involved, directly or indirectly.
The Foreign Minister declined to comment for this article.
American officials also noted that the raid occurred at a time of confusion in Qatar, which might have contributed to its failure. In the summer of 1995, the ruler of Qatar was overthrown by his son. In early 1996, about the time of the F.B.I. action, the father was staging an unsuccessful countercoup.
Two years after the fruitless F.B.I. action, Federal prosecutors in Manhattan unsealed the indictment against Mr. Mohammad. A $5 million reward for information leading to his arrest or conviction is being offered.

HEADLINE: The Rural Poor Need Democracy and Jobs

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "A Pledge of Federal Help for the Economic Byways" (news article, July 6): Many local governments in Appalachia's poorest counties are corrupt, from the county commissions to boards of education. In central Appalachia, so the saying goes, "there are gavel judges and gravel judges." A vote often buys a load of gravel and political protection. A hundred years of external ownership and concentrated power have left the region's residents without the institutions they need. 
 Yes, the region still needs water and sewer systems. Health care centers are sparse. Schools are antiquated, and teachers' skills are outdated. The lack of jobs persists. But these issues pale in comparison with the need for truly democratic institutions. Programs that strengthen citizenship and participation are fundamental to real development.
 
AMY GLASMEIER
University Park, Pa., July 6, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of geography and regional planning at Pennsylvania State University.

LENGTH: 974 words

HEADLINE: 200 Hear First Lady. Townspeople Were There, Too.

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: PINDARS CORNERS, N.Y., July 7

 BODY:
The likely candidate put it wryly.
"I'm really excited about being able to take these long, beautiful summer days," she said, looking out toward the gentle upstate farmland and probably the largest press corps ever to assemble for a United States Senate race, "and, you know, kind of at a leisurely pace with, you know, a few hundred of you." 
 The Schumer campaign was never like this. The Pataki, Cuomo and Koch campaigns were never like this. Even Hillary Rodham Clinton's husband, the President, didn't have as large a press entourage with him today as he traveled to a South Dakota Indian reservation in one of the poorest parts of the United States.
But then, the trip of a second-term President with 18 months left in office was no match for the historic and sometimes surreal spectacle of the first campaign-like day of the first First Lady to seek political office on her own, with her husband still in the White House.
By 9 A.M., four huge press buses had disgorged more than 200 reporters and television technicians from around the world on the farm of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who after 2000 will vacate the seat Mrs. Clinton is considering. Two days ago, bales of hay were cleared from one of Mr. Moynihan's fields to make way for an enormous press platform, more than 30 television cameras and 8 satellite dishes.
"When I woke up this morning and went out on the front step and saw the satellite trucks at the top of the hill," said Elizabeth Moynihan, the Senator's wife, "I felt like a character in 'The Invasion of . . . ' -- you know, one of those space alien movies."
Although this is Mrs. Clinton's 13th visit to New York since announcing her interest in the Senate seat earlier this year, the trip was the first to be paid for by her Senate exploratory committee and not the White House. Still, it seemed a strange hybrid of an official White House trip and a traditionally bumpy Senate campaign.
There was a White House-like press pool and a press center in Oneonta. And there were the typical trappings of a Senate campaign, with Clinton aides -- many of them former members of the Presidential staff -- volunteering their time, and complaining that the rented cell phones and beepers were not up to White House standards.
Howard Wolfson, the press secretary for Mrs. Clinton's exploratory committee, would not say what the trip was costing and how much money the committee, formed on Tuesday, had raised in the 24 hours of its existence. But he did offer that "you don't pay for these trips in cash." In past weeks, he said, Mrs. Clinton has made fund-raising calls from her residence in the White House, using either a cell phone or a line paid for by her exploratory committee.
The sight of the day was of Mr. Moynihan slowly walking Mrs. Clinton down the road from the one-room schoolhouse where he has written his 18 books toward the gantlet of press in his field.
The Clintons and Moynihans have had a sometimes difficult relationship in Washington -- particularly when the Senator criticized portions of the Clinton health care plan during the President's first term. But this time it seemed as if the Senator could be giving away a bride, or at least sending Mrs. Clinton off on her journey across New York, a state she has never lived in.
When the two reached the press, under brilliant sunshine and cooled by the first breezes in days, Mr. Moynihan introduced the First Lady, and said simply: "I'm here to say that I hope she will go all the way. I mean to go all the way with her."
Then New York's senior Senator took on the job of refereeing questions from the press directed at the First Lady. When Gabe Pressman of WNBC-TV asked about Mrs. Clinton's "chutzpah" in running for Senate, Mr. Moynihan said: "Now, Gabe, we're in Delaware County. What was this word?"
For many foreign reporters, the word chutzpah was as new as covering a local American political race. Yoichi Kato, a Washington correspondent for The Asahi Shimbun, one of the largest daily newspapers in Japan, said that as far as he knew, it was the first time his newspaper had covered a United States Senate campaign, although he could not vouch for what had happened in 1964, when Robert F. Kennedy ran for the Senate in New York.
Japanese women, he said, are fascinated by Mrs. Clinton, because they believe that a typical American woman would have divorced her husband if he had had a relationship like the one Bill Clinton had with Monica S. Lewinsky. "She decided to put up with it without making too much fuss about it," Mr. Kato said. "That made Japanese people very curious about what she is up to."
Martin J. Kettle, a correspondent for The Guardian, said that the interest of the British public in Mrs. Clinton is "completely nonpolitical" and based on celebrity and scandal. "If Barbara Bush had decided to run, we wouldn't be here," he said.
Mrs. Clinton is "a sort of Lady Diana figure, the victim in a troubled marriage looking to live life on her own terms," Mr. Kettle said. "That appeals to a lot of people."
And also, apparently, to the American press. At the first "listening" event of what Mrs. Clinton is calling her summer listening tour of New York, most of the television cameras slowly slipped out of a conference room at the SUNY college campus at Oneonta as Mrs. Clinton listened to more than an hour and a half of local citizens complaining about the education system, lack of high-speed Internet access and, at one point, the manners of young people.
But the Oneonta citizens were also impressed by the media intensity. "We should be historically recording these cameras for our purposes," said Margaret Maguire, an associate professor of economics and business at Oneonta, staring at the television crews crowding two sides of the room. "I've never seen anything like it."

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1260 words

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton Begins Pre-Campaign in a New Role for Her

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: PINDARS CORNERS, N.Y., July 7

 BODY:
The First Lady of the United States flew into New York on an Air Force jet today and presented herself as a potential candidate to replace Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan upon his retirement. Standing at Mr. Moynihan's side at his farm here, Hillary Rodham Clinton described questions about her residency as legitimate and said she would attempt to address them in the months ahead.
"It's a very fair question and I fully understand people raising it," Mrs. Clinton said at an appearance here that was part news conference and part political spectacle. "I think I have some real work to do to get out and listen and learn from the people of New York and demonstrate that what I'm for is maybe as important -- if not more important -- than where I'm from." 
 Mrs. Clinton then plunged into her first day on the campaign trail for herself, as opposed to being the candidate's spouse. She visited the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, ate lunch at a barbecue restaurant in Oneonta, and savored the generally large and enthusiastic crowds who turned out to catch sight of the First Lady and her entourage at every stop. She also held the first of the orchestrated "Listening to New Yorkers" forums that are to anchor her schedule this summer, listening intently and taking notes during a long discussion about education.
It was, by any measure, a remarkable day in the politics of both New York and the nation. It began at 11 A.M., when Mr. Moynihan, who is 72, slowly escorted Mrs. Clinton up the road from the old schoolhouse on his property that serves as his office, to a huge assemblage of reporters.
As the center of the kind of attention that is unheard of in a race for the United States Senate -- or even in the early days of a race for President -- Mrs. Clinton began molding a new public image for herself. With each of her eight answers at the 10-minute press conference, and then in stops throughout the day, she stepped away from the role of political wife that she had filled since Bill Clinton was elected Attorney General of Arkansas in 1976, and began filling in the contours of her own potential candidacy.
Mrs. Clinton rarely mentioned her husband, whose term ends in January 2001, and the President was not at her side, choosing to visit an Indian reservation in South Dakota. The First Lady presented herself as someone ready to learn about a state she has never lived in. She also for the first time offered some hint of dealing with the more difficult questions her aides expect ahead, from unresolved questions from Whitewater, to why she may, after seven tumultuous years in the White House, seek to become the first First Lady in the nation's history to run for public office. The leading Republican candidate likely to run against her is Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"I intend to be spending my time in the next days and weeks and months listening to New Yorkers," Mrs. Clinton said. "Now I suppose the question on everybody's mind is, 'Why the Senate and why New York and why me?' All I can say is I care deeply about the issues that are important in this state, that I've already been learning about and hearing about."
She added: "I would be, if I run and am honored to be elected, a strong and effective advocate on the part of the people of New York. I'm very excited about this."
The place where Mrs. Clinton headed first -- Mr. Moynihan's 900-acre farm, in this one-traffic-light hamlet 70 miles west of Albany -- was a curious choice. Of all the Democratic Senators in Washington, Mr. Moynihan often had the most unsettled relations with the Clintons. He was particularly critical of portions of the health care plan that was promoted by Mrs. Clinton during her husband's first term, and Mr. Clinton's aides frequently complained then that Mr. Moynihan was not helping Mr. Clinton accomplish his agenda.
But Mr. Moynihan and Mrs. Clinton share a senior political adviser, Mandy Grunwald, and Ms. Grunwald sat in with them in their private 25-minute meeting before their news conference. Mrs. Clinton has, over the last few months, repeatedly visited Mr. Moynihan's home in Washington to discuss the potential race, effectively recruiting him as her most prominent supporter.
As a jaunty Mr. Moynihan walked her to the microphone -- a moment suffused with generational symbolism -- he left no doubt about who he wanted to succeed him. But he almost neglected to say that as he turned over the platform to his guest.
"My God, I almost forgot," Mr. Moynihan exclaimed, then added: "Yesterday, Hillary Clinton established an exploratory committee with regards to a candidacy for the Senate, the United States Senate from New York, a seat which I will vacate in a year and a half. I'm here to say that I hope she will go all the way. I mean to go all the way with her. I think she's going to win."
Mrs. Clinton was assured if self-effacing throughout the day, taking the guidance of her advisers, who have been concerned that she may have projected something of an air of entitlement in past discussions about the seat. She seemed also undisturbed as she encountered a steady if small stream of protesters challenging the credentials of this Chicago native to seek office in New York State.
When Mrs. Clinton arrived for lunch, she was greeted by a small group of people shouting, "Go Home Hillary." That chant was drowned out by a rival chant of supporters, "We want Hillary."
At her news conference, Mrs. Clinton said she did not believe some of the issues that had shadowed her years in the White House -- such as the disappearance of her law firm records in the Whitewater case -- would be a problem in the campaign.
"New Yorkers will make their own judgments about that," she said. "I think we've moved beyond all of it. I'm going to be talking about the future of education and health care and making sure that upstate New York gets the same kind of economic opportunities that the rest of the state has enjoyed."
The First Lady's staff sought to present today's forum with voters as a spontaneous exchange of views, though there was some evidence of stage management at hand. For one thing, the First Lady is well known for her command of policy, and her aides acknowledged there was a limit to how much she might actually learn at these forums. And the people who attended the forum were all selected by the State University of New York at Oneonta, which had invited Mrs. Clinton to appear.
Mrs. Clinton seemed eager to come across as student rather than teacher. When someone at the forum said the upstate economy and schools were hobbled by the absence of high-speed Internet connections, the First Lady's eyes lit up. She asked him to give her a memo. At the Soccer Hall of Fame, she stopped to talk to Frank Bachelor after learning that he was a dairy farmer who owned 30 head of cattle at a farm in Monroe. "Dairy farmers need your support," said Mr. Bachelor. Mrs. Clinton responded with her own request. "I need your help. I know there is no harder job than being a farmer."
Mrs. Clinton got another lesson -- this one in New York media -- from Mr. Moynihan. At the start of her news conference, reporters -- including Gabe Pressman of WNBC in New York and Andrea Mitchell, the Washington correspondent for NBC -- gestured for her attention. Mrs. Clinton moved instinctively to call on Ms. Mitchell, a familiar face.
But then Mr. Moynihan gave her a little nudge of advice, and Mrs. Clinton did what most New York politicians would do in the situation. She called on Mr. Pressman.

HEADLINE: Clinton, Amid the Despair on a Reservation, Again Pledges Help

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: PINE RIDGE, S.D., July 7

 BODY:
Offering tax credits, loan guarantees and other incentives to encourage private businesses to create jobs and housing, President Clinton swept into the destitute Oglala Lakota Sioux reservation today, by many measures the sickest, most hopeless, most squalid corner of America.
To revive Pine Ridge and other impoverished communities of the kind that the President is visiting on his four-day tour of the nation, White House aides said that over five years the President wants to allow $980 million in tax credits to stimulate $6 billion in private investment for businesses. He is also seeking Federal appropriations of $81 million a year to subsidize and guarantee loans. 
 Like other Federal subsidies Mr. Clinton has proposed on his trip to underwrite programs, these would require Congressional action, though Mr. Clinton has not sent all the specific legislation to Capitol Hill.
The President is on a four-day tour of the nation's poorest communities, first in Kentucky and Mississippi, then here on the Great Plains and the nation's second-largest Indian reservation. This evening he visited a family-owned tortilla factory in Phoenix that was started with a loan from the Small Business Administration, and on Thursday he will travel to Los Angeles. Each time, he was sounding alarms about how the prosperity of nearly seven years in office has passed these areas by and the potential for help from what he called his "new markets initiatives."
"Our nation will never have a better chance" to help these communities, he said.
The Pine Ridge reservation with a population of about 25,000 spread over more than 3,100 square miles, is the United States' own third world country. It has been left far behind by the current economic boom and all of those that came before it. The second-largest reservation after that of the Navajo in Arizona and New Mexico, Pine Ridge has institutionalized squalor, with rampant alcoholism, diabetes, suicide and a male life expectancy rate of 56.5 years. Only 62 miles of road are paved.
Unemployment is rampant and unmeasurable. Mr. Clinton used a figure of "nearly 75 percent." Tribe leaders say it is 85 percent. Most of the few jobs are with the tribal bureaucracy, the Federal Government or the modest new casino, which has 150 Oglala Sioux workers.
Mr. Clinton toured hovels that people live in here, including that of a teary Geraldine Blue Bird, whose shack and trailer house 28 people in five bedrooms.
"See those houses on the street?" Ms. Blue Bird said to him. "You notice they don't have windows. That's because it has to come from the pocket, and we don't have that pocket."
Afterward, the President spoke in the sweltering heat outside the kindergarten-to-12th-grade Pine Ridge School, where many students board because their own homes on the two-million-acre reservation are too far away or too decrepit.
Mr. Clinton and other members of his party, including the Rev. Jesse Jackson, Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, and bankers and businessmen were warmly received.
But a sign in back of the crowd, painted on a sheet, said, "Stop Lakota ethnic cleansing," a reference to the tribe's loss of the Black Hills northwest of the reservation and the gold those hills held.
The Oglalas are the band of Crazy Horse, the victor over George Armstrong Custer at the battle of Little Big Horn in 1876, though that triumph soon gave way to the tribe's being relegated to this rolling grassland with no marketable resources.
The Oglalas continue to complain of a Government in Washington with misguided policies. They see themselves as a sovereign nation, and Mr. Clinton today, nodded to that idea, calling his a "nation to nation" visit.
It was the first time a President visited an Indian reservation since Franklin D. Roosevelt stopped at a Cherokee reservation in North Carolina in 1936 while on vacation.
"We hope the President can open a new chapter of Indian-Federal policy," said Dave Archambault, a councilman of the Standing Rock Reservation, which straddles North and South Dakota, "so we can sit down as equals and enhance the government-to-government relationship."
The tribes need a Marshall Plan, like the one that rebuilt Europe, Mr. Archambault said.
Mr. Clinton made no gestures of that magnitude. But his economic message also represents a big change in Federal policy. Departing from the largely discredited conventions of welfare and charity, formed a generation ago by President Lyndon B. Johnson's War on Poverty, Mr. Clinton told the Oglalas and leaders of more than 100 other tribes attending his speech, "We will do our part."
By enlisting the private sector, the President is trying alternative approaches to aiding the poor.
"We're coming from Washington to ask you what you want to do and tell you we will give you the tools and support to get done what you want to do for your children and their future," he said.
Mr. Clinton has been given credit for holding a tribal summit several years back at the White House. Indian leaders also praise the President for protecting tribal sovereignty in siding with Indians and helping to block efforts in Congress to curb the power of Indian nations to govern themselves.
But the tribes also say he has deserted them on other issues. In 1995, Congress took aim at the Bureau of Indian Affairs, passing a spending bill that cut all Bureau operations by 25 percent. The cuts were later rescinded by about half, and that measure was signed by Mr. Clinton -- much to the chagrin of Indians who depend on the annual budget, of just over $1.2 billion, for many of their operations and jobs.
Also, Indians fault him for not doing a better job of cleaning up the mess over trust funds, owned by perhaps as many 500,000 individual Indians and held in trust by the Government. The documents showing how much money is managed in these funds are missing, lost or stolen, and the Indians have filed the biggest class-action suit ever by tribes to try and clean it up. A trial is now under way. In the course of the trial, two Clinton Cabinet members have been held in civil contempt for not producing records in a timely way for the court case.
"The Administration has been very good on sovereignty and gaming issues for the tribes," said John Dossett, general counsel for the National Congress of American Indians, the largest group representing Indians in Washington. "If you step back and look at the record from afar, I would think you have to give them a good grade."
But others are sharply critical, noting that thousands of Pine Ridge Sioux are part of the lawsuit to sort out their trust funds.
"Thousands of members of that tribe are being actively defrauded by the Clinton Administration," said Jim McCarthy, a consultant to tribes in the trust fund case. "For him to go out there and throw some crumbs off the Federal plate is really appalling, because here you have some of the poorest people in the country being denied what is theirs."
