SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 36; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4669 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.
* denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
"COLLECTING IN DEPTH: DRAWINGS BY GROSZ, SCHWITTERS, ERNST AND KLEE," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9400 (through July 20). While a little on the dry side, this exhibition effectively encapsulates the careers of four major German modernists, layering their sensibilities like a sandwich and demonstrating the singular uses that each artist found for Cubism. In the outer layers, George Grosz and Paul Klee reformed the tensile lines and transparencies of Analytic Cubism for the purposes, respectively, of scathing social satire and psychologically charged fusions of fantasy and form. In between, Kurt Schwitters and Max Ernst took innovations of Synthetic Cubist collage into new territory. Schwitters used the detritus of everyday life to create a streetwise formalism that indexed different kinds of social interaction and human contact. Ernst extracted found images from their natural habitat in the public press to create a universe as fully imaged as Klee's, only scarier. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 8:15 P.M. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Roberta Smith). 

* "SIGMUND FREUD: CONFLICT AND CULTURE," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Sept. 9). Having caused a fracas even before the plans for it were completed, this show is bound to attract big crowds. So be warned: this library exhibition, full of documents, requests that we stand and read much of the time. There are also text panels interspersed with family photographs, odd works of art and other objects (including the couch) that Freud owned. This is supplemented by video clips from films, television programs and home movies showing Freud, his sisters and associates. It's a basic intro to Freud, cleverly designed and geared to the public; it aims to be neutral, though it's a fair guess that no exhibition, no matter how judicious, could possibly satisfy his admirers and detractors. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 11 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Tuesdays, to 8 P.M. Admission: $8; $5.50, students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
"GLOBAL CONCEPTUALISM: POINTS OF ORIGIN, 1950's-80's," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700 (through Aug. 29). This ambitious and groundbreaking exhibition of more than 240 works by 135 Conceptualists attempts to track a worldwide explosion in Conceptual Art production, a development whose significance has been likened to the development of Cubism. Divided among 10 geographical regions, from China to Europe to Australia, the show presents a huge but hard-to-digest mass of information and very few visually compelling works. Don't miss it if you like to read while standing up. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.. Admission: $4; $2, students and the elderly (Ken Johnson).
 
* "HANS HOFMANN IN THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART," Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Oct. 17). A charismatic teacher of painting who translated his theories into vigorous practice, Hofmann (1880-1966) became a leader of the Abstract Expressionist movement. Most of the paintings in this show, the Renate Series, were made as a homage to his second wife, Renate Schmitz (1931-1992), whom he married a year before his death; the 10 paintings in the series went to the museum as her gifts or bequests. Both acclaimed and disparaged for their stylistic inconsistency, they form an anthology of the modes he worked in during the last phase of his career. Abstract but based on nature, they range from exuberant, fluent "landscapes" made by vibrant juxtapositions of color masses to a work or two of chaotic organization that misses the mark. But their energy and vitality are contagious. Hours: Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 8:45 P.M. Admission: $10; $5, students and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
"IMPRESSIONISTS IN WINTER: EFFETS DE NEIGE," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Aug. 29). Think of the Impressionists and chances are you think green: lawns, hedges and fertile fields of a deciduous nature caught at full leaf. But these artists were year-round workers, and winter landscapes, rendered in the frosty open air or through the glass of a studio window, figured in their repertory. Here are some 60 such paintings. And if ever a show were tailor-made for summer viewing, this one is. Its size is untaxing, and its deep-freeze images of snow-covered fields and ice-caked trees are the visual equivalent of air-conditioning. Of course, much of the work by Monet, Pissarro, Sisley and their colleagues is extremely beautiful in that immediate, you-have-to-be-there Impressionist way. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, to 8 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. (to 11 P.M. on the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $9.50; $7.50, students over 10 and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
* "THE MEDIEVAL HOUSEBOOK: A VIEW OF 15TH-CENTURY LIFE," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through July 25). Mystery still surrounds the vivacious 15th-century German manuscript known as the Medieval Housebook -- who the artists were, for example. Part idyll, part real-life manual for the landed gentry, the housebook touches on such miscellaneous matters as astronomy, astrology, courtly love, chivalry, mining, metallurgy, jousting, warfare, recipes, medications, castle defense, animal husbandry and the trapping of men by female predators. In its exquisitely detailed drawings, a mischievous mix of the elegant and the bawdy, men and women conduct lofty amours and earthy functions, the raffish mingle with the raffine, and sybarites are far more evident than saints. A secular sanctuary in a religious era, the manuscript captures, for an enchanted moment, the spirit of a world that's bygone yet very much a prologue to our own. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 6 P.M. Admission: $7; $5, students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
"MEN WITHOUT WOMEN: PAUL CADMUS AS CURATOR," National Academy Museum and School of Fine Arts, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Aug. 29). This is the fifth in a series of exhibitions organized by distinguished National Academicians, and Mr. Cadmus's choice of theme is a natural. The male figure, often nude, has been at the center of his art pretty much from the start, and the show's opening gallery delivers a bracing hit of preening masculine pulchritude, from George Henry Hall's 1858 "Study of an Irishman" to a convocation of 20th-century Apollos. The interest level cools after this, but heats up again with a small selection of Mr. Cadmus's own work, including "The Fleet's In" (1934), a painting that mightily displeased the United States Navy when first exhibited and is on loan here from the Naval Historical Center in Washington. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. o 5 P.M.; Fridays, to 6 P.M. Admission: $8; $5, students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
* "NEW YORK COLLECTS DRAWINGS AND WATERCOLORS, 1900-1950," Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0008 (through Aug. 29). This superb gathering of 140 drawings from 73 private New York collections is the Morgan's first foray into exhibitions of 20th-century art. Starting with Cezanne and ending with Pollock, it skims across modernism like a train whizzing past wondrous cities, and yet nearly every drawing can prompt you to pull the emergency cord and shred your itinerary. Picasso, Matisse, Beckmann, Klee, Miro -- the greats look great here. But the exhibition never loses steam; in the back hallway gallery hang some of the best drawings you'll ever see by Matta, Henry Moore, Wols, Dubuffet and Freud. A complete feast. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Fridays, to 8 P.M.; Saturdays, to 6 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $7; $5, students and the elderly; children 12 and under, free (Smith).
 
* "EL NUEVO MUNDO: THE LANDSCAPE OF LATINO LOS ANGELES," Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, Smithsonian Institution, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 (through Sept. 5). For more than two decades, the photographer Camilo Jose Vergara has documented the process of physical change in the poorest neighborhoods in American cities. The story is often one of disintegration, but in the color pictures here he turns his eye on the largely Mexican community in Los Angeles, where transplanted cultural roots are in photogenic flower. Life is hard, but houses, stores and city walls are painted with vivid images of religious icons, consumer goods and yearned-for south-of-the-border vistas. Mr. Vergara's career-long project is an important one; this show is a vivid installment in his expansive field work. And it takes on an extra resonance at the Cooper-Hewitt, a former Andrew Carnegie mansion. Hours: Tuesdays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Admission: $5; children under 12 and the elderly, $3 (Cotter).
 
* "SURREALISM: TWO PRIVATE EYES," the Nesuhi Ertegun and Daniel Filipacchi Collections, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 12). The Surrealist collections formed by two friends fill the museum from lobby to ceiling. Although it has more than 700 objects, this powerful show is by no means a comprehensive survey but an intense, close-up experience of Surrealism that might be imparted by two obsessed acquisitors taking you on a personal tour of their treasures. Highlights include clusters of paintings by Dali, Victor Brauner, Magritte, Andre Masson and Yves Tanguy; a splendid group of boxes by Joseph Cornell; a brilliant selection of photographs rife with portraits by Man Ray; dozens of beautifully bound books, and remarkable drawings by Hans Bellmer and Masson. The show has notable omissions and a few surprising inclusions, but by and large the menu is gourmet. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. Admission: $12; $7 for students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
* "URBAN MYTHOLOGIES: THE BRONX REPRESENTED SINCE THE 1960's," Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, Morrisania, (718) 681-6000 (through Sept. 5). The recent cultural history of an embattled, resilient, often joyous section of New York comes across here. The art, like the Bronx, is multifaceted, ranging from videos to sculptures to aerosol-spray murals. Photography makes a real impact in the work of Carlos Ortiz, Ricky Flores, Walter Rosenblum and Camilo Jose Vergara and the incandescent portraits by Sophie Rivera. Indigenous art, like graffiti, joins work made by Manhattan artists who visited or settled in. And the myths of fear and hope long spun around the borough are distilled in a fantastic domestic installation by Pepon Osorio, a version of which appeared in the 1993 Whitney Biennial. Hours: Wednesdays, 3 to 9 P.M.; Thursdays and Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $3; $2, students and the elderly (Cotter).
 
"0044: CONTEMPORARY IRISH ART IN BRITAIN," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Aug. 29). The work of 20 Irish artists living and working in London whose work sometimes addresses Irish themes and sometimes doesn't. Although the level of professionalism is uniformly high, most of the artists are pursuing familiar strategies of painting, sculpture, installation or video art. Look for Frances Hegarty's video self-portrait, Liadin Cooke's aluminum casts of small rough balls of Irish clay, Kathy Prendergast's drawings of the world's rivers and lakes, Tina O'Connell's installation pieces (which riff on Post-Minimalists like Robert Smithson, Carl Andre and Lynda Benglis without losing their identity) and Daphne Wright's walk-in environment of tall craggy outcroppings of aluminum foil, each accompanied by its own tiny foil seagull. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $5 (Smith).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
"CHARLES HENRI FORD: PRINTED MATTER, 1929-1969," Ubu Gallery, 16 East 78th Street, (212) 794-4444 (through July 16). This revelatory exhibition covers four decades of the busy career of Charles Henri Ford, poet, novelist, editor and publisher. It includes copies of Blues: A Magazine of New Rhythms, which Mr. Ford founded in 1929, at the age of 19, and of View, notable for its artist-designed covers, which he created and oversaw in the 1940's. But it is dominated by the less well-known "Poem Posters" that Mr. Ford made in 1964-65. These, in turn, are dominated by acid colors, chains of verse spliced together like a kidnapper's ransom note and pop culture images, Jayne Mansfield among them. They may be high Pop Art, but they are also the culmination of Mr. Ford's long involvement with Surrealism, whose strategies find new expression here (Smith).
 
JAN MATULKA, Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through July 30). This exhibition of harbor scenes presents Matulka (1890-1972), one of the lesser known but more engaging of American Early Modernists, at his most appealing. The paintings offer views of seaside houses, sheds and wharves, rocky shores, cozy, blue bays and chunky, toylike boats robustly painted in a brightly colored, chunky style that looks like a marriage of folk art and Cubism (Johnson).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
JOSE BEDIA, Ramis Barquet, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-9090 (through July 16) and Annina Nosei, 530 West 22d Street, Chelsea, (212) 741-8695 (through July 16). The best works in this two-gallery show are visionary white line pictures made on shaped and unstretched black canvases. A pointy-eared figure at the top of a crystalline mountain grasps a great flying bird by the tail; a man warms his hands at a fire while a woman with flowing breast milk nurses a phoenix. Mr. Bedia, a Cuban-born artist living in Florida, condenses such fabulous narratives into luminous compositions of Art Deco-like elegance (Johnson).
 
ELLIOTT GREEN, JANE HAMMOND, DAVID TRUE, TREVOR WINKFIELD, Tibor de Nagy, 724 Fifth Avenue, (212) 262-5050 (through July 26). Each of the painters in this well-selected show has developed his or her own idiosyncratic mix of Pop, Surrealism and figurative narrative. They harmonize well together, but Mr. True's big, zany cartoon version of the biblical Expulsion, with its eerie population of rubbery, incandescently hued characters, steals the show (Johnson).
 
JASPER JOHNS, Susan Sheehan, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 489-3331 (through July 31). Familiar Johnsian motifs are here embodied in prints from the 60's, 70's and 80's: the numbers 0 through 9 stenciled one over another; three versions of brushes in a Savarin coffee can; five expansive, hatchwork abstractions; a blotchy, black-and-white double flag; and the autobiographical suite "Four Seasons." Johns's distinctively deft, matter-of-fact touch animates them all (Johnson).
 
"LINEAR IMPULSE," Michael Rosenfeld, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 247-0082 (through Aug. 13). This crowded presentation of variously linear paintings and sculptures includes famous artists like David Smith, Mark Tobey and Lee Krasner. There are works in outmoded Modernist styles, like the Surrealistic Cubist paintings of Jimmy Ernst, but there are things that still look fresh, including richly layered paintings by Alfonso Ossorio and a dense ball of wire and glass by Claire Falkenstein (Johnson).
 
ALICE TRUMBULL MASON, Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through July 23). Descended from a prominent Colonial New England family, Mason (1904-1971) studied with Arshile Gorky in the late 1920's. As this selection of works from four decades proves, she remained devoted to abstraction throughout her long, under-recognized career. Her modestly scaled paintings, always rigorously structured, sensuously painted and richly colored, were influenced by Miro early on and later by Mondrian, but they always have their own engaging personality (Johnson).
 
JOHN McLAUGHLIN, Ameringer Howard, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 935-1110 (through July 30). McLaughlin (1898-1976) dealt in Asian antiquities and served as a high-ranking translator during World War II before moving to California and, at age 50, beginning his distinguished career as a painter of austere, Zen-inspired abstractions. This show presents five dry, near-Minimalist rectilinear canvases and a series of lithographs from which Peter Halley might have got the barred windows of his cell paintings (Johnson).
 
JUDITH JOY ROSS, Pace Wildenstein MacGill, 32 East 57th Street, (212) 759-7999 (through Aug. 27). Ms. Ross makes understated, uncommonly sensitive photographic portraits, especially of children. Among her lovely gold-toned 8-by-10-inch works are pictures of a blond, messy-haired urchin slouched at his elementary school desk, gazing at the camera with a look of heartbreaking ennui, and of a 10- or 11-year-old girl standing by a hazy lake with a Band-Aid on her knee and an ethereal aura (Johnson).
 
"WALKING," Danese, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 223-2227 (through Aug. 27). An unexpected variety of approaches to the theme of walking makes this an intriguing show. Among the 21 works included are pictures of Marina Abramovic walking the Great Wall of China, a gouache painting of a maze pattern by Richard Fleischner, a photograph of an attractive woman in a phone booth shot by the pedestrian voyeur Garry Winogrand, and Ann Truitt's striped minimalist column painted colors observed while walking outdoors (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
BARTON LIDICE BENES, Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Spring Street, (212) 941-0012 (through July 30). Mr. Benes produces modern reliquaries: broad, shallow boxes divided into little cubbyholes, each containing a labeled, more or less sacred relic. Among the items displayed in "Celebrity" you'll find a police badge worn by Sean Penn in the movie "Colors" and a wad of Dustin Hoffman's chewing gum. These devotional works are for a Warholian world where the gods have devolved into celebrities (Johnson).
 
ROSS BLECKNER, Betsy Senior, 375 West Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 941-0960 (through Aug. 27). The 10 new etchings in this show correspond to the large cellular abstract paintings Mr. Bleckner exhibited last fall. Patterns of luminous, blurry lines and glowing dots are Bleckneresque but the prints don't have the magical illusionism of the paintings (Johnson).
 
ANTOINE PEVSNER, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through July 30). This remarkable exhibition presents 120 drawings done from 1912 to 1956 by one of the original Russian Constructivists. Made in graphite in an elasticized Cubist style, they realize Pevsner's fantasy of Machine Age dynamism more persuasively than do his sculptures, which today look clunky and dated. Artists who continue to explore the possibilities of abstraction might find this collection a rich source of ideas (Johnson).
 
"SIGNS OF THE TIMES," American Primitive, 594 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212) 966-1530 (through Sept. 3). Quirkiness prevails in this fascinating exhibition of more than 125 signs ranging in date from the late 19th century to the present. There are pieces of elegant folk art, vintage professionalism and poetic vernacular, like a bent and torn sheet of cardboard with the scrawled words "I smile only from the truth. I don't wash car windows" (Johnson).
 
JOAQUIN TORRES-GARCIA, Cecilia de Torres, 140 Greene Street, (212) 431-5869 (through July 31). This show of small paintings and drawings on paper commemorates the 50th anniversary of the Uruguayan-born modernist's death. Torres-Garcia's gridded, pictographic works, by which he articulated a comprehensive cosmic philosophy with an unassuming, comic touch, are especially engaging (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
SAINT CLAIR CEMIN, Cheim & Read, 521 West 23d Street, (212) 242-7727 (through July 31). Mr. Cemin, one of his generation's most inventive sculptors (he was born in 1951) presents five marmoreal mock monuments, including a sphinx with a smoothly finished woman's face and a roughly carved body; an archaic, cartoonish horse pierced by a stainless steel spear, and a square wind-filled sail carved from a single block of stone (Johnson).
 
"CHANGING FACES," Jim Kempner, 501 West 23d Street, (212) 206-6872 (through July 24). A crowded, wildly diverse and rewarding selection of 74 contemporary portraits, including Robert Mapplethorpe's luminous photograph of a beatific Alice Neel; John Currin's ink drawing of a winsomely sensual girl; a skittery lithograph by Kiki Smith depicting birds, a cat and someone's sideways head; and tiny, finely made portraits of artists by Jim Torok. Look also for works by Elizabeth Peyton, Chuck Close, David Hockney and William Kentridge (Johnson).
 
"EUROPE ON A SHOESTRING," Weber, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 691-5711 (through July 31). This roundup of European avant-gardists ranges from the amusing to the oblique. Highlights include a Roman Olpalka number painting; Alghiero E. Boetti's enormous steel-framed window with the delightful title, "Nothing to see, nothing to hide," and Hans Haacke's "Photo Opportunity," which pairs a portrait of George and Barbara Bush at a storm disaster site with a portrait of a poor Alabama farm family by Walker Evans (Johnson).
 
RITA McBRIDE AND SYLVIA PLIMACK MANGOLD, Alexander and Bonin, 132 10th Avenue, at 18th Street, (212) 367-7474 (through July 30). Ms. McBride's installation focuses obliquely on the concept of the art exhibition. Three sets of curvy wooden bleachers invite viewers to sit and look at a picture on the wall, which will periodically change (first up was a Cindy Sherman self-portrait as a secretary from 1978). Ms. Mangold's Precisionist painting of a ruler on a wooden floor reflected in a wood-framed mirror and a more recent Cezannesque portrait of a tree echo the woodiness of the bleachers (Johnson).
 
B. G. MUHN, Stux, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 352-1600 (through July 31). Mr. Muhn, who was born in Korea and teaches at Georgetown University, produces crafty, surrealistic paintings combining abstract elements, luminous color fields and images that may be highly finished or loosely sketched. Mood ranges from portentous to absurd, as in the picture of a rabbit with a big pink tongue on a tormented-looking bald man's head (Johnson).
 
"SUMMER GROUP EXHIBITION," DCA, 525 West 22d Street, (212) 255-5511 (through July 17). This presentation of 11 Danish artists is remarkable mainly for how derivative the works are. Kehnet Nielsen's abstract paintings look like Clyfford Still's; Bjarne Werner Sorensen's layered networks are like Terry Winters's; Erik A. Frandsen's snapshot-based enamel picture is like a Gary Hume. But Michael Kvium's strange painting of paunchy men in underwear brandishing sock puppets and doing something weirdly erotic has an eccentric personality of its own (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
ROMUALD HAZOUME, The Project, 421 West 126th Street, Harlem, (212) 662-8610 (through July 25). The first United States show of this West African artist includes two dozen small, masklike sculptures made from industrial and commercial materials: detergent jugs, video cassette casings, electric fan blades. Mr. Hazoume is a deft and witty assemblagist of objects and ideas: references to traditional art, consumer culture and an economy of recycling are all touched on here. In the back gallery are seven airy paintings of oracular pictographic forms painted on layers of earth. A welcome debut (Cotter).
 
"WHEN TIME BEGAN TO RANT AND RAVE: FIGURATIVE PAINTING FROM 20TH-CENTURY IRELAND," Grey Art Gallery and Study Center, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through July 24). This begins with works influenced by Impressionism and Post-Impressionism and ends with routine versions of 80's Neo-Expressionism. Rife with derivative, overearnest work, it is most valuable as a reflection of Ireland's painful history and its effect on its art. It makes palpable the tensions between artists who wanted to keep abreast of international (mostly French) developments in art and those who disdained modernism and celebrated Irish rural life or the struggle for independence. Its high points are few, but include the work of Jack B. Yeats, whose thickly painted Expressionist works succeed in fusing distinctly Irish predicaments and states of mind with an original, contemporary style (Smith).
 
Last Chance
 
* "CROSSCURRENTS: MASTERPIECES OF EAST ASIAN ART FROM NEW YORK PRIVATE COLLECTIONS," Japan Society Gallery, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through Sunday). The strength of New York private collecting in Asian art is confirmed in this beautiful show. It begins with a heart-lifting 13th-century Japanese wood carving of the bodhisattva Jizo, protector of travelers and children, and ends with an installation of tea ceremony utensils from China, Korea and Japan. In between come paintings, porcelains and lacquer, all exemplary. A big, expansive accomplishment for the Japan Society. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $5 (Cotter).
 
"INVITATIONAL EXHIBITION," Curt Marcus, 578 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 226-3200 (through today). The five painters in this exhibition work in various styles but are united by a predilection for painterly richness and conscientious craft. Included are Matthew Abbot's dazzlingly complicated Pop mandalas; Elizabeth Saveri's small, charmingly unassuming realist pictures; lovely, subtly patterned and layered abstractions by Dean Smith; luminous, crusty abstractions by Richard Tsao and lush grids by David Collins (Johnson).
 
BYRON KIM, Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, 120 Park Avenue, at 42d Street, (917) 663-2453 (through next Friday). Mr. Kim likes to imbue modernist modes like monochromatic painting with oblique political overtones. Here he has created subtle, mural-scale wall drawings using gray washes pigmented by dust vacuumed up around the Philip Morris building, orchestrating a marriage of high formalism and low materialism. One wall bears the ghost image of a brick wall with blocked-up windows. The others are entirely abstract (Johnson).
 
* "TO CONSERVE A LEGACY: AMERICAN ART FROM HISTORICALLY BLACK COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES," Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212) 864-4500 (through Sunday). The 200 works on view, drawn from the collections of six educational institutions and spanning more than a century, form a lively and eclectic gathering in which Georgia O'Keeffe and Romare Bearden, Edmonia Lewis and Arthur Dove, the ultra-urbane Charles Demuth and the ecstatic self-taught Minnie Evans keep kindred-spirit, all-American company. The exhibition serves as a lesson in the intricacies of art conservation, an introduction to the endlessly absorbing subject of American education and a richly deserved 30th-birthday celebration for the Studio Museum itself. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 6 P.M. Admission: $5; $3, students and the elderly. Admission is free the first Saturday of each month (Cotter).

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
SMITHKLINE TO CUT 800JOBS AT FIVE ANTIBIOTICS PLANTS

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

 BODY:
SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., Europe's fifth-biggest drug maker, said yesterday that it planned to cut 800 jobs, or about 1.4 percent of its work force, as it consolidates its antibiotics manufacturing operations. SmithKline, which makes antibiotics like Augmentin and Amoxil, plans to end production at five plants in Spain, France, Mexico, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Five others -- in Scotland, England, Belgium, France and Singapore -- will become the company's main antibiotic centers. The plan is part of a larger effort announced Feb. 9 to streamline operations and save more than $300 million a year by 2002 to compete better in the $300 billion drug industry.

LENGTH: 891 words

HEADLINE: Treasury Chief Urges Inner-City Investment

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN

 BODY:
The new Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, went to Harlem yesterday to encourage more private investment in poor neighborhoods and announced the formation of a new mentoring program to allow inner-city entrepreneurs in New York to draw upon the expertise of large corporations.
Under the new program, a task force will be set up by the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, the city's leading business group, to match big companies with start-ups or other small businesses. Ten entrepreneurs will be selected in each of the next two years. "This is about much much more than money," Mr. Summers told a group of business leaders who gathered at Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday to share some of their previous mentoring experiences with him. "It's about advice, it's about networks, it's about the provision of opportunity, and it's about providing and sharing the types of knowledge that are necessary. In many ways, the money and financing are the least of it." 
 In his visit to New York, Mr. Summers underscored the same themes that President Clinton sounded this week during a four-day trip to Hazard, Ky., and other economically distressed areas across the country. Like the President, Mr. Summers said that investing in poor neighborhoods was not a matter of charity but made good economic sense. The Administration has proposed a new tax credit to encourage investments in what it calls "new markets."
The new Treasury Secretary drew praise from David Rockefeller, who participated in the meeting of business leaders, for coming to New York less than week after he was sworn in. Mr. Rockefeller said that the economic development initiatives taking place while the city's economy is robust represent a fundamental change that would continue in harsher times.
During a tour of the construction site of Harlem U.S.A., a long-delayed shopping center on 125th Street that is scheduled to open by Christmas, Mr. Summers seemed genuinely impressed by the numbers he was fed. Drew Greenwald, one of the developers, and Mark Willis, a senior vice president at Chase, told him that the complex was expected to generate $200 million a year in sales and $17 million in sales taxes, yet had required only $11 million in government loans. They said that nearby property values had soared to $75 a square foot from $30. About 500 new jobs are expected to be created.
"A lot of people are going to make a lot of money here," Mr. Summers said at the shopping center, whose tenants will include Disney, HMV and Old Navy. Later, he said that the financial leaders he met with had stressed that such investments are no longer relegated to special bank subsidiaries dealing with community development but are viewed as mainstream investments.
Some Harlem business owners have complained that they have been driven out by rising rents on 125th Street, but Mr. Summers said some displacement was inevitable with economic development. But, he said, "you'll see more vibrancy spread off 125th Street to the next streets."
Mr. Summers, who has spent much of the last six years assisting emerging countries, first as Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs and then as Deputy Treasury Secretary, added: "We always say of countries that it's much better to be a country that capital is trying to get into than a country that capital is trying to get out of."
The Secretary did not allude to it, but the Harlem U.S.A. project is one of the few successful projects to emerge from the stalled Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, a $300 million Federal, state and city program designed to spur economic development. Halfway through the five-year program, only $35 million has been spent on projects and administrative costs.
Other success stories were recounted at the meeting at Chase as examples of the kind of mentoring the new program aims to bring about. The task force is part of a national effort called BusinessLINC (Learning, Information, Network Collaboration). There are similar efforts in six other cities.
Fernando Espuelas, a former marketing executive at A.T.&T., said that the help he received from Chase and the New York City Investment Fund, which was created by Henry R. Kravis to stimulate job growth, had proved invaluable for getting his Internet business off the ground. "We are able to tap into networks of people that for a young company, a start-up, are just not available," he said after the meeting. His company, Star Media, which serves Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking Internet users around the world, created 200 jobs in New York.
Another speaker, Desmond Emanuel, who is black, described the difficulties he had in the 1980's getting financing for his construction company. What gave his business momentum, he said, was the help he got from the New York City Housing Partnership, an offshoot of the New York City Partnership that promotes the development of affordable housing. His company, Santa Fe Construction Inc., now employs 48 people, making it the largest minority-owned construction company in the city, he said.
Even now, he said, a relationship with a larger company would be useful. "If my business is going to grow to the next level, where I'm going to be able to take on more substantial private work," he said, "I think linkages with larger companies may be helpful."

HEADLINE: Reservists a Crucial Factor In Effort Against Milosevic

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN

DATELINE: LESKOVAC, Serbia, July 8

 BODY:
Beneath a sign for the Swing Jeans Shop, a dozen or so Serbian policemen in powder blue uniforms stood around tonight, glaring at locals who dared gather here for the fourth night running to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic.
All around the police in the town square, there were hundreds of Yugoslav Army reservists, some in soiled camouflage uniforms and many drinking beer. 
 They were home from the lost war in Kosovo, unpaid, jobless and angry enough to tangle this week with Mr. Milosevic's men, who call the shots in Leskovac, a city in a part of Serbia known as the "Red South."
On Monday about 20,000 people, most of them reservists and their families, filled this square and astonished much of Serbia by staging the largest demonstration since the end of the Kosovo war.
On Tuesday about 2,000 of them rushed the police station and vandalized the house of a local boss from Mr. Milosevic's Socialist Party.
On Wednesday a drunken military policeman shot a cafe owner in the town square.
And tonight a thousand or so people, many of them reservists, milled around, shooting dirty looks at the police.
"The fear has disappeared," said Vlada Djordjevic, 31, a conscript who served for 65 days in Kosovo, while listening every night with his friends from Leskovac to American, British and German short-wave radio broadcasts about the war. "We were in the field and we could see that Serbian radio was telling us lies about the war. We believed BBC. And now we are not afraid."
In what appears to be a growing popular movement to force the Yugoslav leader from power, the wild card may well prove to be the Yugoslav Army and its reservists. In previous bouts of demonstrations against Mr. Milosevic, the army has either come out in favor of Mr. Milosevic or sat on the sidelines.
But the sudden anti-Government activism of reservists in this most unlikely of cities suggests that the army could prove to be a muscular ally, if fractious opposition movement can figure out how to use it.
The reservists' anger is not confined to this city. Demanding unpaid wages from the war, they have sporadically tied up roads and blocked bridges in central and southern Serbia in the last two weeks.
The principal object of the reservists' frustration here in Leskovac is Zivojin Stefanovic, the local chairman of the Socialist Party, who runs this down-at-the-heels textile town of 170,000. Mr. Stefanovic declined today to return repeated phone calls.
It was his house that reservists smashed up on Tuesday night, and it was his resignation that remains a non-negotiable demand of their demonstrations, which are scheduled to go on until he quits or is fired.
The reservists are also demanding the release from jail of Ivan Novkovic, a TV Leskovac technician turned local hero. Stunning local TV viewers, he sneaked his own videotape on the air last week. It called for the people of Leskovac to gather in the square on Monday and demand the ouster of Mr. Stefanovic. After a huge crowd did exactly that, throwing in the demand that Mr. Milosevic resign, the TV technician was arrested and sentenced to 30 days in jail.
What infuriated reservists about the local party boss was his mobilizing zeal for the war in Kosovo. Apparently trying to curry favor in Belgrade, Mr. Stefanovic organized the call-up of about 40,000 local men, according to opposition party leaders and human rights activists.
The bitter joke here is that as a result of Mr. Stefanovic's mobilizing passion, there were just two combatants in the Kosovo war: NATO versus Leskovac.
When reservists came home from the 11-week conflict in early June, they learned that the Government had not provided their families with food and household supplies, as the army had promised.
Nor have they been paid the $50 a month they were promised when they went off to war. So far they have received about a third of that.
"I am not the kind of guy who makes trouble, but we need those wages for electricity bills, for school books for our kids, for firewood," said Bratislav Stamenkovic, 37, a reservist who laid mines along the Kosovo-Macedonian border.
The reservists said they had also learned that there were going to be no jobs for veterans and that the local economy was in even deeper trouble than before the war.
The one thing they have not been told by local officials is how many soldiers from Leskovac were killed. The local Serbian Orthodox Church has an unofficial list of 70 names. Reservists say they will demonstrate here until they get an official number from the Government.
"In 10 years, all we have is war," said Pasan Cosic, 55, who was slightly drunk and very bitter in the town square tonight.
Mr. Milosevic has started and lost wars in the former Yugoslav republics of Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia, as well as in Kosovo, a province in southern Serbia.
Mr. Cosic said he had been drafted by the Milosevic Government to fight in Croatia, where he lost a son and was wounded in the knee. Equipped with a plastic knee, he said he was later drafted to fight in Bosnia and then in Kosovo.
"We just have war, and I am getting poorer," repeated Mr. Cosic, a taxi driver who spoke to the crowd tonight from an open microphone that was made available to anybody who had a complaint against the Government.
"We don't have bread, cigarettes, sugar or cooking oil." he said. "I am asking Mr. Milosevic, 'How long can you keep this up?' "
Many of the reservists here tonight said they were well aware of the atrocities and theft committed by some Serbian fighters in Kosovo.
They said they personally had not committed crimes against civilians, a claim that, in general, has been supported by Kosovo Albanians, who in hundreds of interviews have said that nearly all the killings of civilians were committed by Serbian paramilitary forces and not by regular army troops.
But the reservists said that everywhere in Kosovo they were surrounded by Serbs in uniform carrying stolen televisions, satellite dishes and other electronic equipment. The scene was so familiar that it generated one of the best jokes of the war, said Mr. Djordjevic, the reservist who spent much of his war listening to the radio.
"So Rambo volunteers to fight for the Serbs," Mr. Djordjevic said. "In a few days Rambo is back in the States and drunk. Asked why he quit the war, Rambo answered, 'I couldn't carry a gun and a television set at the same time." '
There was nothing very funny, though, about the Kosovo war, Mr. Djordjevic said.
"At this point, what I care about is finding out who died from Leskovac," he said. "I don't give a damn about Kosovo."

HEADLINE: Slash And Burn Urban Renewal

BYLINE: By Robert Wilson; Robert Wilson is the editor of Preservation magazine.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
You live in a battered neighborhood in an ag ing city Buffalo or Baltimore, Hartford or Detroit. Next door or down the street is an abandoned house where crack is being sold or squatters congregate or fires are set. If you complain, the chances are pretty good that your local government will respond by tearing down the house, using Federal grants from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, special state demolition money or even city revenue.
Obviously an empty lot is a better next-door neighbor than a crack house. But what happens when the crack house moves across the street, then three houses down, then over on the corner, and local officials, eager to spend those demolition dollars on eager local demolition companies, obligingly follow? Soon your street begins to look like a Halloween pumpkin's smile. The lots become trash-strewn, and another ailing city neighborhood goes into cardiac arrest. 
 At a time when some of the news from American cities gives cause for hope, when many governments at all levels are solvent enough to spend their money to clean up even their worst neighborhoods, we have to ask ourselves whether these distressed neighborhoods are so bad that we have to destroy them in order to save them. I worry that we are moving too quickly and going too far in taking down abandoned housing. A decade from now, we could sorely regret the loss of sturdy buildings that we might have stabilized now at a fraction of the cost of restoring or replacing them later.
Although there's evidence that demolition is increasing, especially in Rust Belt cities that are losing population, New York is one city that doesn't have a policy of demolishing abandoned housing because rebuilding from scratch is more costly than renovating. Besides, much of the city's housing stock, from brownstones in Brooklyn to Art Deco apartment houses on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx, is irreplaceable. "The cost of trying to replicate such buildings is impossible," says Bill Traylor, a senior program director of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a national nonprofit group that helps rebuild neighborhoods.
The city has committed $5 billion since 1986 to restoring its housing stock, affecting 120,000 units. Much of the money has gone to the moderate rehabilitation of existing buildings, but some of it has gone to reconstruction where multifamily buildings had been torched or become so decrepit that rehab was impossible.
As a result of this investment in existing housing, Mr. Traylor says, parts of the city, like the South Bronx and Central Harlem, which lost more than half their populations in the 1960's and 70's, are growing again. He points to a study done for the Local Initiatives Support Corporation that found that three distressed New York City neighborhoods have seen employment go up by 11 percent and the number of businesses increase by 13 percent since 1989.
Many other aging cities, however, have a plan of attack that seems to be the opposite of New York's. For example, Detroit got a Federal loan last year of up to $60 million for "an accelerated demolition initiative." Buffalo spent $1.9 million in 1998 to demolish more than 200 houses. Hartford has received $4.8 million in state demolition money in the past two years. New York State has earmarked $5 million this year and in 1997 New Jersey appropriated $20 million to help local governments tear down vacant buildings, including housing.
Many people defend urban demolition in places like Buffalo and Baltimore by saying that some cities are simply smaller than they once were, that they have more housing than they need. But when you look at the peripheries of such cities, you see that new housing is being built. The question is how to draw people to housing where infrastructure already exists, where density makes the delivery of services easier and where new construction doesn't promote sprawl.
As we know, the answers to these questions are complicated, involving at a minimum people's attitudes toward race, crime and education. But what can be said with certainty is that if there's too little housing in cities, people will live elsewhere.
New York City's success at beginning to revive its most distressed neighborhoods has many sources, both public and private, all of them related in some way to good economic times. But even in cities where times haven't been so good, where population continues to decrease, it cannot be smart to tear away at fragile residential neighborhoods. We may in fact be undergoing stealth urban renewal, a leveling of city neighborhoods that will appall us as much in the future as the urban renewal projects of the 50's and 60's appall us today.
Whether many shrinking cities will ever really come back is an open question -- unless we demolish the housing that people might have come back for. Then the future is clear, and grim.

HEADLINE: Working Hard, More or Less;
Studies of Leisure Time Point Both Up and Down

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
In a society in which the long lunch has gone the way of the screened-in porch and free time often seems as rare as a telephone without call waiting, it is surprisingly difficult to get a definitive answer to the deceptively simple question of whether Americans have more or less time on their hands than they used to.
The research on time-use yields evidence for three seemingly contradictory answers: Americans work longer and have less leisure time than they did 30 years ago; Americans work less and have more leisure time; Americans work roughly as much as they used to, at least on average. 
 "I could talk statistics to you from here to midnight," said Randy E. Ilg, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which has generated its own share of befuddling results. "But one set of statistics will give you one point of view and another set of statistics will tell you something else."
A big part of the problem is that time-use researchers use different methods and different data. They depend on the indulgence and memories of ordinary folks (who, like everyone else, may be feeling they could use a day off). They study different time periods. They even have different definitions of basic concepts, like leisure and work.
But another part of the problem, some researchers say, may be that they have been asking the wrong question. The question may not be whether Americans are working or playing more but which ones are. As it turns out, there may be more people underemployed and, at the same time, more people overworked.
"What sense does it make to talk about averages if we have two very divergent realities?" asked Jiri Zuzanek, a sociologist at the University of Waterloo in Ontario. Mr. Zuzanek recently edited a special issue of the scholarly journal Society and Leisure devoted to what some scholars call the "time famine."
"If there is a group of people who are overworked, and others are benefiting from a greater amount of leisure, and the trends are diverging, the average is not particularly meaningful," he said. "That's where I am a little concerned that reporting averages does not always reflect the dynamics of social change."
In fact, Americans may be working longer and have more leisure time. That is, some Americans are clearly working longer hours while others may have more leisure than past generations did. While hard-driving baby boomers may infatuate the media, many men have retired early and many people in their 20's and 30's have postponed marriage and child rearing or are having fewer children.
A 1997 study by the Bureau of Labor Statistics on which Mr. Ilg was a co-author found that the segment of employees working at least 49 hours a week rose from 13 percent in 1976 to 18.5 percent in 1993. Among those most likely to work very long hours were professionals and managers, who were also among the highest paid. People in transportation and sales are also working more, although the reasons are unclear.
"When I first got into this, I said both sides can't be right," said Jerry A. Jacobs, a professor of sociology at the University of Pennsylvania who set himself the task of trying to reconcile the contradictory views about work and leisure. "It turns out that it is logically possible for them both to have a kernel of truth because they are talking about different people."
Aside from people's personal fascination with the way they use their time, economists use the information to help assess the economy's long-term health and growth. Sociologists use it to trace, among other things, the changing social roles of men and women, tracking the time they spend working outside and inside the home.
It's quite possible that many people have an exaggerated sense of how long they work. The rise of couples in which each one works has created intense time pressures in families. Many Americans also have more opportunities than before and more knowledge of opportunities missed. Leisure activities are increasingly complex and organized. Meanwhile, E-mail, fax machines and beepers have muddied the boundary between work and home.
"Some people say the only way to make it work off the job is to treat life off the job like work," said James T. Bond, vice president of the Families and Work Institute, a policy research institute in New York City that has found that the average workweek is rising. "You have to apply good management skills and scheduling if you want to lead a normal life."
But when one tries to measure the time Americans spend at work and leisure, all sorts of perplexing questions crop up. If a person skips out of the office to run an errand, is that work or something else? Is commuting work? Should the work of 16- and 17-year-olds be counted? Are night courses work? When is shopping housework and when is it recreation?
The largest source of public data on work hours is the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which regularly surveys 400,000 nonfarm businesses for the number of hours worked by production and nonsupervisory employees. It also surveys 50,000 randomly selected households, conducting telephone interviews about hours worked in the previous week.
The survey of businesses suggests the average workweek in the companies studied "trended down," as Mr. Ilg put it, from 38.8 in the mid-1960's to 36.1 in the mid-1970's, 34.9 in the mid-1980's and 34.6 in 1998. The household survey suggests the workweek went from 40 hours in the mid-1960's to approximately 38 in the mid-1970's to 39 in the mid-1980's to 39.3 in 1998.
Over the years, other studies have suggested divergent conclusions. F. Thomas Juster, an economist at the University of Michigan who surveyed Americans about their use of time in the mid-1970's and early 1980's, said he found that total work declined for both men and women and leisure increased between the mid-1960's and the early 1980's. He looked at not only paid work but housework, too.
In 1991 Juliet B. Schor, an economist at Harvard, reported in "The Overworked American: The Unexpected Decline of Leisure" (Basic) that time on the job had risen steadily over the previous 20 years. Leisure was dwindling, she said; manufacturing employees, for example, were working the equivalent of two months longer each year than their counterparts in West Germany and France.
Then John P. Robinson, a professor of sociology at the University of Maryland, and Geoffrey Godbey, a professor of leisure studies at Penn State University, reported the opposite in "Time for Life: The Surprising Ways Americans Use Their Time" (Penn State Press, 1997). They said men and women were working less than they did in 1965 and had gained nearly an hour of free time a day.
In a revised edition of the book, due out in September, they write that further studies they conducted in the 1990's did not show a continuing decline in people's hours of paid work. Nevertheless, they said, free time continued to increase, in large part because the amount of time spent on eating and grooming declined.
Unlike Ms. Schor, Mr. Robinson and Mr. Godbey based their findings primarily on "time diaries" in which people were asked to record in detail how they spent their time over the course of a day, in contrast to the Bureau of Labor Statistics' method of asking employers about hours worked or asking participants to recall their work hours from the previous week.
Mr. Robinson and others say that people exaggerate their hours when asked to recall them from memory. The more hours they work, Mr. Robinson says, the more they inflate. Meanwhile, critics of the time diary method say it is biased in the other direction: busy people are too busy to keep diaries, so the method favors the unbusy, a charge Mr. Robinson denies.
Mr. Robinson, Ms. Schor and their critics and defenders have all sorts of other reservations about each side's (and everyone else's) data -- about the points in the business cycle when the data were collected, about the representativeness of their samples, about whether they were measuring time working or simply time at work.
"There are problems in measurement on both sides," said Andrew S. Harvey, an economist who directs the time-use research program at St. Mary's University in Halifax, Nova Scotia. "A lot has to do with the timing of the observations. Then there's a question of who you're looking at. If two of you were looking at slightly different populations, you might get different answers."
But many researchers also say the data are probably telling multiple stories at once, not only those of the undeniably time-pressed couples juggling multiple jobs and young children but also the stories of unhappily underemployed people perpetually searching for more work and of men in their early 60's who until recently were retiring at a younger and younger age.
"The one thing everybody agrees on is there is a time divide," said Robert Drago, an economist at the University of Wisconsin in Milwaukee. "There is a large group of people who are overworked and there is an arguably smaller group of people who are underworked and searching for anything to get by. The question of whether, on average, people are working more or less is maybe not as important as this time divide."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Indexes End on High Note for a 2d Consecutive Friday

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
For the second consecutive Friday, the stock market finished the week with a hat trick, as all the three major indexes reached new highs. Bond prices ended slightly lower as the Ford Motor Company completed the biggest corporate bond issue ever.
Ford, and its finance company, Ford Motor Credit, sold $8.6 billion in bonds, including $1.8 billion of 32-year bonds that were priced to yield 7.529 percent, or 1.4 percentage points over the yield on the Government's 30-year bond. In a reflection of the recent strong demand for these and other corporate bonds, which offer higher yields than the Treasury market, Government bond prices managed to remain relatively stable ahead of and during the record sale. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average finished the day at 11,193.70, up 66.81 points, or six-tenths of one percent. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 8.86 points, or six-tenths of a percent, to 1,403.28. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 21.21 points, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 2,771.86.
For the week, the Dow was up half a percent, hitting two new highs. The S.& P. 500 rose nine-tenths of one percent, hitting two new highs, while the Nasdaq index was up 1.9 percent, setting three new highs.
In the bond market, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond was down 5/32 , to 89 22/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6 percent from 5.99 percent Thursday.
The yield on the 30-year bond bounced around all day. It popped over 6 percent as some dealers apparently were selling as a way to hedge against losses if the Ford bond sale prompted a selloff in the Treasury market. It dropped below 6 percent as traders decided that the Ford deal was going well. But then it inched back to 6 percent as the afternoon wore on.
Both stock and bond investors will be keeping a close eye on the barometers of economic growth and inflation that the Government will release next week. Any hint of rising inflation -- which is not expected -- or acceleration in the pace of economic growth could send stocks lower and interest rates higher.
Wednesday will bring the report on producer prices, which could give some signal if the recent rise in industrial commodity prices is affecting prices. The Government's overall retail sales report for June will also be released Wednesday. Sales in retail stores rose sharply last month. On Thursday, comes the Consumer Price Index for June and industrial production figures follows on Friday. The University of Michigan survey on consumer sentiment will also be released Friday.
Speaking about the lackluster day in the bond market, Thomas Connor, the head government trader at J. P. Morgan Securities, said, "The bond market wasn't going to get up and go because we want to see the C.P.I. number next week."
Equity investors will also begin concentrating on corporate earnings reports as the second-quarter reporting season gears up. It is the optimism about the outlook for earnings growth the rest of the year that is helping bolster stocks in the face of the quarter-point interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve at the end of last month and the possibility of another later in the year.
The two main compilers of corporate earnings forecasts are predicting a double-digit increase in the profits for the 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's stock index. The First Call Corporation's forecast is an increase of 11.2 percent, compared with the second quarter of 1998. I.B.E.S. International's prediction is 10 percent.
Since Fed policy makers raised their short-term interest rate target to 5 percent on June 30, investors have been debating whether another rate increase will be necessary to curb economic growth and keep inflation in check.
The yield on the two-year Treasury note, which is sensitive to Fed rate moves, finished yesterday at 5.58 percent.

HEADLINE: The High Cost of Long Island Politics

 BODY:
Creating a fiscal crisis in a prosperous suburban county during one of the biggest economic booms in American history takes some doing, but the Nassau County Executive, Thomas Gulotta, has pulled it off. The county ended 1998 with a deficit of nearly $200 million, and is wrestling with another big projected gap this year. Its ridiculous property tax assessment system, which has turned challenging assessments into a local industry, is costing the county more than $100 million a year in refunds. In the latest blow, Standard & Poor's has announced that it is reducing the rating of the county's bonds to BBB -- near junk status.
Mr. Gulotta has relied on costly short-term borrowing to pay the bills, while inventing increasingly outlandish ploys to paper over a budget that is structurally out of balance. Earlier this year the county got a $70 million infusion of cash from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in return for accepting $240 million in long-term M.T.A. debt. Next, Mr. Gulotta hopes to borrow against anticipated future gains from the county's share of a national tobacco settlement. 
 Out-of-control labor costs, particularly in the police department, are one of the main causes of the county's problems. More than half of last year's deficit was due to cost overruns in police salaries and benefits. The county must also reform its assessment system, under which homes are assessed on the basis of 1938 construction costs and 1964 land costs.
The system is impossible to administer, one of the reasons the county winds up owing so much to homeowners for refunds from assessment appeals. Astonishingly, the county sells bonds to pay for those refunds, and its long-term debt has now ballooned to almost $2.7 billion. The assessment system has been decried by everyone from the county business community to the Justice Department, which says it discriminates against minority neighborhoods.
Like New York City in the 1970's, Nassau County is being run by a one-party political system that has become brain-dead from lack of new blood. In this case, it is the Republican Party that has run the government into the ground by spending money it did not have to keep political allies happy. The Republicans do not seem capable of reforming themselves and the Democrats do not appear to have the capacity to challenge them. The only answer may be an outside arbiter to put a spine in its fiscal policies.
The county could get some breathing time if the State Legislature approves a plan to raise the tax on property transfers. But the Democratic-dominated State Assembly is demanding a price -- giving the State Comptroller, Carl McCall, authority to oversee the county's fiscal practices. Republicans are unhappy with the idea of giving this power to a Democrat. But Mr. McCall's office has the expertise to do the job, and his duties would only entail forcing officials to do what they should be doing already -- engaging in long-term financial planning and keeping spending within the bounds of county income.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
They Sought Change and Found Death

BYLINE: By WILBORN HAMPTON 

 BODY:
It has been almost 30 years now since a night of deadly rioting in Belfast prompted Britain to send in army troops to try to restore order in Northern Ireland. Since then at least 3,200 people, many of whom were simply caught in the crossfire, have been killed. In "The Freedom of the City," whose evocative revival is being presented as part of Lincoln Center Festival '99, the Irish playwright Brian Friel tells the fictional story of three of them.
The conflict known as "the Troubles" has provided at least a subtext for much of Irish literature, especially that written for the stage, over the last three decades. In Mr. Friel's "Aristocrats," which is also being staged by the Gate Theater during the festival, and in "Translations," the plight of a people at the mercy of powers beyond their control runs between the lines. But in "The Freedom of the City," which concerns three ordinary protest marchers who accidentally occupy Derry's Guildhall and end up being gunned down as "terrorists," Mr. Friel openly addresses the strife that at the time of its writing had just come to full boil. 
 The play was written following Bloody Sunday in 1972 when British Army troops opened fire on protesters in Derry (or Londonderry, as British loyalists persist in calling it), killing 13. A British Government inquiry ended up exonerating the army, and the inquiry itself became a source of contention. But Mr. Friel, in an apparent attempt to deflect any suggestion that the play is merely an oversimplified dramatization of the Derry massacre, sets "The Freedom of the City" in 1970. The play was produced on Broadway in 1974 but closed after a week; not only were American audiences at the time so preoccupied with their own conflicted emotions over Vietnam and the resignation of a President, but also some felt Mr. Friel's play was little more than a political pamphlet for the Irish Republican Army.
That was nonsense, of course. But any playwright who tackles overtly political themes runs the risk of writing a sermon instead of a drama. It is a danger that Mr. Friel does not completely avoid in "The Freedom of the City."
But Mr. Friel is a master playwright, not a politician, and such departures into polemics are few and brief. The play's success rests with the characters of the three marchers -- two young men and a middle-aged woman who is the mother of 11 -- who find themselves thrown together in the unlikely refuge of the mayor's private office in the Guildhall and who slowly come to realize they are candidates for martyrdom.
This is no surprise for the audience. In a stunning and gripping opening scene, the lights come up on all three lying dead while a helicopter hovers above them. Suddenly a photographer rushes up and begins to snap their pictures. Then a priest scurries in and begins to recite the last rites of the Roman Catholic church. As this surreal tableau unfolds, the photos of the victims are flashed on a giant screen and a magistrate monotonously begins questioning a police constable about the circumstances surrounding the deaths.
The action abruptly returns to the police breaking up the march and the stage erupts in a riot, complete with clouds of tear gas, baton charges and fusillades of rubber bullets. Through the rest of the play Mr. Friel cuts back and forth between the live action of that day and the often grimly comic inquiry that follows. For the most part, there is little editorial commentary. Mr. Friel leaves it to the audience to ponder how the British military, the Ulster police and the news media could mistake three frightened protest marchers for a band of 40 armed terrorists or how a pathologist and forensic expert could so misconstrue the evidence at hand.
In one humorous touch the playwright brings on from time to time an American sociologist who attempts to explain the tragedy in a lecture, delivered in academic double-speak, on the nature of poverty and its ramifications in a society's culture. Mr. Friel even pokes fun at Irish sentimentality by having a balladeer compose an instant folk song about the three martyrs suitable for singing in pubs from Dublin to Long Island.
This is all made credible by very smooth ensemble work from the dozen or so actors in the Abbey's cast as Conall Morrison, the director, deftly moves the story along with the tautness of a well-edited television documentary.
As always with Mr. Friel, however, it is through the specificity of his characters' lives that the drama takes on poignancy. As we learn of the thwarted efforts of Michael Hegarty -- in a fine, understated performance from Gerard Crossan -- to keep a job, we begin to care more about the plight of the Catholic minority at the hands of the Protestant majority than we could from any recitation of unemployment figures. As we discover the circumstances that fostered the rebellion of Skinner, given an able if somewhat manic portrayal by Michael Colgan, we tend to be more forgiving. And as we discover the details of Lily Doherty's life with her unemployed husband and her 11 children, one with Down syndrome, all of them living in two shabby rooms without running water, we are ready to go out and march with her.
It is Lily, in an effective performance by Sorcha Cusack despite a somewhat nervous beginning, who emerges as Mr. Friel's true hero.
If the two young men represent the extremes of nonviolent protest and anarchy, it is Lily who speaks for the innocents caught in the middle. Lily may not be able to tell you why she marches, but she knows that something is not right and that she should be out there marching to change it. It is Lily, the veteran marcher, who knows how to get the tear gas out of your lungs; it is Lily who dies "overwhelmed by regret" but who also leaves a legacy of optimism for the future.
As she advises Skinner at one point about the nature of injuries from a police baton or rubber bullet, "As long as you can see blood, there's always hope."
 
THE FREEDOM OF THE CITY
 
By Brian Friel; directed by Conall Morrison; sets by Francis O'Connor; costumes by Joan O'Clery; lighting by Ben Ormerod; sound by Dave Nolan; stage director, Colette Morris; assistant stage managers, Catriona Behan and Stephen Dempsey; voice coach, Andrea Ainsworth; sets by Abbey Theater Workshop; costumes by Abbey Theater Wardrobe Department. The Abbey Theater presented by Lincoln Center Festival '99, Nigel Redden, director. At John Jay College Theater, 10th Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets, Manhattan.

HEADLINE: On-Line Grocer Is Setting Up Delivery System For $1 Billion

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9

 BODY:
Only a month ago, Webvan Group Inc., a Silicon Valley start-up that sells groceries on line, was taking its first orders from customers. Today it placed a sizable order of its own, asking Bechtel, the engineering and construction giant, to build distribution and delivery centers in 26 markets.
And even as Internet deals go, the price tag was impressive: $1 billion. 
 Webvan, a privately held company based in Foster City, Calif., is the brainchild of Louis Borders, co-founder of the Borders bookstore chain. Though it trails on-line grocers like Peapod Inc. of Skokie, Ill., and Homegrocer.com Inc. of Bellevue, Wash., in coming to market, it has aggressive expansion plans.
It operates a 330,000-square-foot distribution center in Oakland, Calif., serving the Bay Area, and says it will begin operations in Atlanta early next year.
"Infrastructure is everything," said David Cooperstein, an analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "To do on-line sales the right way rather than the rush-to-market way they need to develop a very complex distribution system."
In groceries, profit margins "are so tight you need to figure out where the leverage is," Mr. Cooperstein said, adding that Webvan had determined that the leverage was in distribution.
Analysts say on-line grocery shopping is a tough market to crack because customers expect high quality and are unwilling to pay extra for the convenience. Grocery stores already operate on razor-thin profit margins without the added expense of delivery, and the perishable nature of many foods does not make operating from a central location feasible. By some estimates, an on-line grocer must do 10 times the volume of a typical store to be successful.
Yet William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman and chief executive, has said on-line grocery shopping could account for a third of United States food sales by 2005. But Jupiter Communications estimates that the on-line grocery market will grow from $350 million in 1999, to $3.5 billion in 2002. That would make groceries one of the largest on-line commerce categories but still less than 1 percent of the total grocery market in the United States.
Today just one-tenth of a percent of groceries and health-and-beauty items are bought on line in the United States, compared with 4 percent of airline tickets and books and 9 percent of software, according to Jupiter.
Since its founding last year, Webvan has raised $100 million of venture capital from Knight Ridder, CBS, the Softbank Corporation of Japan and two of Silicon Valley's leading venture-capital firms, Benchmark Capital and Sequoia Capital. The company is expected to raise capital through the sale of as much as $1 billion in junk bonds this year, as well as a possible initial public offering.
Most established grocers have only dabbled in the on-line market, like Albertson's Inc., which is testing an Internet store in Dallas for nonperishables only, or Wholefoods, which ships nonperishable natural foods from its headquarters in Austin, Tex., and a few perishables from a site in Southern California.
"We think this is all good for the space," said John Fischer, interactive marketing director for Wholefoods.com, of the Webvan expansion plans. "We have a niche that can only benefit from the expansion of the market."
Unlike earlier Internet grocers, who relied on human shoppers racing down aisles to fill on-line orders, Webvan's operation is highly automated. Webvan opened its Bay Area service on June 2. Customers can place orders on line all day, seven days a week and select a convenient delivery time within 30 minutes. Orders are delivered the same day or up to five days later.
Chris Mannella, Webvan's vice president for marketing, said the two-year Bechtel deal would enable the company "to accelerate the national rollout we had planned." Bechtel, based in San Francisco, said most of the 26 centers would involve retrofitting existing warehouses.
"Our partnership with Bechtel is a major step forward for our company," Mr. Borders, Webvan's chief executive, said in a statement. "It accelerates our distribution capabilities, and it enables us to focus fully on our core competency, delivering a superior product directly to a customer's home or office."
Mr. Borders co-founded Borders Books in 1971, before selling it to the Kmart Corporation in the early 1990's. Since that time he has been chairman of Mercury Capital Management, a small investment firm, and a consultant to other companies. http://www.nytimes.com
