HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Heady Aromaof Recovery;
An Ancient Trade Propels Indonesia's Economy Ahead

BYLINE: By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, July 9

 BODY:
On a clear day, Singaporeans can see recession-wracked Indonesia from their southern shore. From their living room, Seah Soo Lin and his son Jeng Jye can smell the archipelago's budding recovery.
Cinnamon, pepper, nutmeg and cloves: an aromatic bounty sits packed in a jumble of cardboard boxes on the floor. Outside on the patio, sandalwood chips are piled into a mound on a table. For the last 30 years, Mr. Seah's small family-run company, Chop Wee Kiat, has traded Indonesian spices and fragrant woods, buying in places like Timor and Sumatra and selling to customers from Bahrain to Tokyo. 
 Mr. Seah, seated in short trousers under a Chinese landscape painting, might seem unsuited to a discussion of financial market dynamics. Chop Wee Kiat, after all, is a tiny $5-million-a-year business in a local market estimated to amount to $1.5 billion a year. But for small players like Chop Wee Kiat, sticking with this ancient trade amid the latest financial storms has meant staying in touch with modern-day economics. Growing competition from distant suppliers and larger players, meanwhile, means relying on strengths developed through tradition.
"Nowadays if you want to survive, you must have a good reputation, be very active and offer good service," Mr. Seah, 65, said from behind yellow-tinted bifocals. "Experience also counts."
He has plenty of that. Distant relatives from Indonesia introduced Mr. Seah to the trade back in 1969 when they needed someone to broker the sale of cinnamon sticks from Sumatra. His depth of experience in Indonesia makes him sanguine today about what will emerge from the country's economic and political upheaval. "It won't be so different," he shrugs.
Economic crisis has in fact been kind to the Seahs and their Indonesian suppliers. When the rupiah plummeted last year, prices for Indonesian products dropped, too. That put a squeeze on manufacturers who were borrowing in foreign currency and had to import supplies, but it was a windfall to those whose livelihoods sprang from the ground.
And now the spice trade is pointing toward stability and hope for the future in Indonesia. Agriculture has proved an unexpected bulwark of the nation's economy, sheltering rural communities from recession. "The one sector that hasn't been hit is agriculture," said David Fernandez, a J. P. Morgan economist.
Agriculture alone -- representing less than 20 percent of the economy -- will not be enough to pull Indonesia out of recession. Further growth in crops will require money from banks, says Stephen Mink at the World Bank, and Indonesia's banks are being rescued by the Government under a plan the World Bank estimates will cost the country $60 billion.
Still, agriculture accounts for 40 percent of Indonesian jobs, and the sector's health has been crucial in containing the spread of poverty. Farmers outside the densely populated main island of Java have done so well that last year the World Bank declared the economic crisis a largely middle-class phenomenon. Jobless urbanites began filtering back to the countryside in search of work.
Now, economists say, natural resources, from palm oil and coffee to pepper and cinnamon, are helping Indonesia claw its way slowly back to health. Interest rates, once above 70 percent, have been halved. Inflation has all but disappeared. And in the first three months of this year, the economy grew from the quarter before -- not a real recovery yet, but a hint that growth may be around the corner.
To know the spice trade is to know a good deal about Indonesia. Traders have been carrying spices from these islands to the rest of the world for thousands of years, and spices have played a huge role in the nation's political and economic history.
Spices lured traders from Arabia, Persia and India, who brought with them Hinduism and later Islam. Spices supported a seventh-century commercial empire centered on Sumatra that extended as far as modern-day Thailand and Cambodia.
Arab traders long ago introduced pepper, cloves and cardamom from Southeast Asia to Europe, where they were treasured as preservatives and analgesics. Visigoths once ransomed Rome for pepper. The Arabs kept the source of their spices a secret, however, until Marco Polo divulged the truth after returning in 1292 from his travels, which included several months on Sumatra.
Once the word was out, Europeans started a race for the Indies, with spices inspiring the voyages of Columbus, da Gama and Magellan. Spices financed the expansion of shipping and sowed the seeds of empire for Spain, Portugal and England. But it was ultimately the Dutch who captured the true spice islands, trading Manhattan to the English in return for a tiny island covered with nutmeg trees.
Singapore's warehouses brimmed with Indonesian spices as the British port became a transshipment point and home to myriad companies like Tai Eng Ltd., which opened for business in 1948 on land now occupied by the Singapore Stock Exchange, according to the founder's grandson, Raymond Lee.
Farther inland, Mr. Seah's home office still has jalousie windows, and the only air-conditioning comes from a couple of fans. But the business brings in nearly $5 million a year, enough for him to raise six children, including Seah Jeng Jye, 32, who earned an accounting degree at Singapore's top university and then came to work for the family business.
Indonesia's troubles threatened to uproot Chop Wee Kiat's network of sellers, many of whom were among those Chinese-Indonesians who fled the country when mobs turned their rage against them. But after a week or so, Mr. Seah said, most of them returned home. "They go back because they can make money," he said, slipping back into his native Hokkien dialect.
With agriculture rebounding, markets for spices and other extracts are bulging. Consider Indonesia's patchouli. Cultivated predominantly by small farmers, the leaves of the patchouli bush yield a pungent yellow oil that lends a soothing fragrance to soaps, detergents and fancy perfumes. Aromatherapists say patchouli is good for treating everything from cellulite and athlete's foot to anxiety and snake bites.
Before the crisis, patchouli prices were at rock bottom and farmers had begun to dig the bushes up to plant crops they could eat or sell. But a sharp decline in supplies led to a rebound in prices just as the economic crisis reached its worst point. After patchouli prices jumped, farmers responded by digging up food crops to plant patchouli, and prices have fallen back to normal.
Adequate cultivation is no guarantee of supply, either. Early this year, so few goods were being shipped to Indonesia that exporters were unable to find containers to pack their products in. Banks were in such dire straits that they were declining to issue exporters letters of credit advanced to guarantee payments. When Chop Wee Kiat was buying nutmeg last year, Mr. Seah said, its partner in Indonesia had no choice but to ship the spice off and trust that payment would come.
Cloves are another story altogether. They are used in Indonesia's most popular consumer item, flavored cigarettes called kreteks. Encouraged by their success in cornering the nutmeg market, a group of ethnic Chinese traders decided in 1990 to do the same with cloves. When the plan failed, they enlisted President Suharto's son, who persuaded the Government to give him a monopoly on the clove trade. Companies like Chop Wee Kiat had to settle for cloves from Madagascar and Zanzibar.
One demand imposed by the International Monetary Fund for its $43 billion aid package was that the clove monopoly be dismantled. That reopened Indonesia's clove trade to Mr. Seah, but confusion has ensued. While the monopoly could not buy cloves, traders could not get the bank loans they needed to step in. Huge shipments of cloves were smuggled out (to the detriment of world clove prices), but most Indonesian farmers simply stopped bothering to harvest and dry their clove buds, said Suhas Chougule, general manager of Surice Trading Ltd., a Singapore spice company.
Lower prices for farmers usually mean fatter margins for traders, because the end market for spices is largely impervious to the boom-and-bust crop cycle, Mr. Chougule said. "People who use white pepper must have white pepper," he said.
Still, the role of small middlemen is under assault by concerns like McCormick & Company, a $1.9 billion enterprise in the United States that bills itself as the world's largest spice company. McCormick's buyers were once content to deal through local trading companies like Chop Wee Kiat. But the quest for greater consistency in quality and price has encouraged big processors to increase direct purchases from growers.
And the tumult in Indonesia has made the spice trade more volatile than ever, Tai Eng's Mr. Lee said. During the height of Indonesia's crisis, he said, prices gyrated by as much as 30 percent in two weeks.
Market prices are still determined largely by word of mouth. "There's no securities exchange offering nutmeg futures," Seah Jeng Jye said. It is not uncommon now for spice traders to enter into their own forward contracts, buying a shipment of cinnamon in June for delivery later or to simply stockpile a spice in the hope that prices will improve. Communications are evolving, too, the younger Mr. Seah said. Gone are the telex and cable; Chop Wee Kiat now takes inquiries by E-mail.
Modern ways may be coming, but spice traders hope the business is specialized enough to require their continued existence. Experienced spice traders can tell a bad clove bud by sight and can price sandalwood by how it smolders. "You need to have people who know about the trade," Mr. Lee said.
